____________________________________________________________

The complex relationship with health: Rural and urban &apos;poor&apos; women

Author: Singh, Shweta; Zhou, Ru; Li, Xiong; Tong, Liping

Publication info: International Social Work ; London  Vol. 59, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 32.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1764079156?accountid=14667

Abstract: Health and wealth are important to international social work discussions. This article examines the relationship between wealth indexes and the outcome of diseases such as diabetes, asthma, and BMI irregularities. It examines a construct of virtual neighborhoods in urban and rural populations of women. The data are drawn from the NFHS-3 (2007) and applies a hierarchical logistic regression analysis. It is found that women in mid-level neighborhoods in rural areas and poor neighborhoods in urban areas are most at-risk for negative health outcomes. Thus, women&apos;s health outcomes and processes appear to be complicated due to poverty and neighborhood interaction. [web URL: http://isw.sagepub.com/content/59/1/32.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+complex+relationship+with+health%3A+Rural+and+urban+%26amp%3Bapos%3Bpoor%26amp%3Bapos%3B+women&amp;rft.au=Singh%2C+Shweta%3BZhou%2C+Ru%3BLi%2C+Xiong%3BTong%2C+Liping&amp;rft.aulast=Singh&amp;rft.aufirst=Shweta&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=32&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+complex+relationship+with+health%3A+Rural+and+urban+%26amp%3Bapos%3Bpoor%26amp%3Bapos%3B+women&amp;rft.au=Singh%2C+Shweta%3BZhou%2C+Ru%3BLi%2C+Xiong%3BTong%2C+Liping&amp;rft.aulast=Singh&amp;rft.aufirst=Shweta&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=32&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Enhancing Recovery from Trauma: Facilitating a Mindfulness Skills Group on a Department of Veterans Affairs Inpatient PTSD Unit

Author: Landrum, Sam Schwartz

Publication info: Social Work with Groups ; New York  Vol. 39, Iss. 1,  (Jan/Mar 2016): 35-47.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1765527432?accountid=14667

Abstract: Mindfulness and acceptance based treatments are being increasingly implemented for a variety of emotional and psychological related problems, including the impact of military and combat related trauma exposure. This article describes a mindfulness skills group as it was implemented on a sub-acute inpatient PTSD Unit at a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center, to demonstrate and explore the role of the mindfulness skills development in a group setting, for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder and other trauma related problems.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Enhancing+Recovery+from+Trauma%3A+Facilitating+a+Mindfulness+Skills+Group+on+a+Department+of+Veterans+Affairs+Inpatient+PTSD+Unit&amp;rft.au=Landrum%2C+Sam+Schwartz&amp;rft.aulast=Landrum&amp;rft.aufirst=Sam&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=35&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2014.999203

The Space of Family Care-Giving in Australian Aged Care Facilities: Implications for Social Work

Author: Petersen, Maree; Wilson, Jill; Wright, Olivia; Ward, Elizabeth; Capra, Sandra

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 81.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1766991664?accountid=14667

Abstract: While the importance of involving families in care provision in residential care facilities is recognised, how to achieve an inclusive care space that balances the needs of families, residents, staff and the sector&apos;s regulatory requirements remains problematic for social work and the aged care sector. In this paper, a spatial perspective is used to examine the role of family carers in residential care facilities. Information obtained from focus groups with families, naturalistic interviews with staff and families, and observations of mealtimes in one case study site is analysed thematically to demonstrate how the physical, social and symbolic meanings of space interact to produce or impede family care-giving. The findings provide important guidelines for social work in this setting suggesting practice at micro, mezzo and macro levels. These include the acknowledgement of families in care-giving, genuine partnerships between staff and families, and family-inclusive policies within facilities. In addition, this paper highlights how the social work profession and the residential care sector more generally can strengthen their person-centred focus, engage with families and lessen the marginalisation of families in care-giving. [web URL: https://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/1/81.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Space+of+Family+Care-Giving+in+Australian+Aged+Care+Facilities%3A+Implications+for+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Petersen%2C+Maree%3BWilson%2C+Jill%3BWright%2C+Olivia%3BWard%2C+Elizabeth%3BCapra%2C+Sandra&amp;rft.aulast=Petersen&amp;rft.aufirst=Maree&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=81&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Decision by Approved Mental Health Professionals to Use Compulsory Powers under the Mental Health Act 1983: A Foucauldian Discourse Analysis

Author: Buckland, Rosie

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 46.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1766991929?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study uses a Foucauldian discourse analysis approach to explore the use of compulsory powers under the Mental Health Act 1983 as amended in 2007 (MHA) amongst a group of Approved Mental Health Professionals (AMHPs). Semi-structured interviews were conducted with ten AMHPs currently practising in one local authority in the south of England and then analysed. Findings indicate significant variation within and across AMHPs&apos; accounts. A range of discursive shifts commonly occur in relation to the use of compulsory powers, however, including the move from social worker to AMHP and a service user&apos;s first detention. Categories of mental disorder and risk were explicitly problematised by participants but normative discourses relating to mental illness and its treatment in hospital were then reproduced within the accounts. Together with the apparent importance of factors such as ethnicity and gender, this complicates the recurrent evocation of universal human values by AMHPs within the interviews. The implications of these findings for policy and practice, when contradiction and uncertainty are integral to the work undertaken by AMHPs, are then discussed. Lastly, it is suggested that developing the use of Foucauldian understandings of power and explorations of discourse within AMHP practice and research may provide a means of further considering the application of the MHA. [web URL: https://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/1/46.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Decision+by+Approved+Mental+Health+Professionals+to+Use+Compulsory+Powers+under+the+Mental+Health+Act+1983%3A+A+Foucauldian+Discourse+Analysis&amp;rft.au=Buckland%2C+Rosie&amp;rft.aulast=Buckland&amp;rft.aufirst=Rosie&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=46&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Decision+by+Approved+Mental+Health+Professionals+to+Use+Compulsory+Powers+under+the+Mental+Health+Act+1983%3A+A+Foucauldian+Discourse+Analysis&amp;rft.au=Buckland%2C+Rosie&amp;rft.aulast=Buckland&amp;rft.aufirst=Rosie&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=46&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

An Exploratory Factor Analysis of the Resource Generator-United States: A Social Capital Measure

Author: Foster, Kirk A; Maas, Carl D

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 8.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1766992252?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social capital is gaining prominence in social work discourse given its role in social and economic mobility. Yet measuring social capital pragmatically in terms of policy, practice and research is challenging because it suffers from lack of definitional clarity, leading to measurement disputes. We define social capital as access to knowledge and opportunities through networks to enhance social and/or economic mobility. To facilitate the integration of social capital into social work practice, we present the Resource Generator (RG) adapted for an urban US context to measure specific network-embedded resources. This paper reports the results from exploratory factor analyses measuring the reliability of this tool. Analyses suggested that a three-factor model was robust (x2(29) = 30.93, p = 0.37; CFI = 0.994; TLI = 0.996; RMSEA = 0.024; AIC = 1917.26; BIC = 1863.71), which is dissimilar to the RG results reported in the UK. These factors-Expert Access, Problem Solving and Personal Support-provide insight as to how social capital resources converge in the USA. These findings also present a potential list of social capital items salient for the US context and highlight the utility of a measure for mezzo and macro social work practice in urban US settings. [web URL: https://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/1/8.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=An+Exploratory+Factor+Analysis+of+the+Resource+Generator-United+States%3A+A+Social+Capital+Measure&amp;rft.au=Foster%2C+Kirk+A%3BMaas%2C+Carl+D&amp;rft.aulast=Foster&amp;rft.aufirst=Kirk&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=8&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Work and Social Media: Online Help-Seeking and the Mental Well-Being of Adolescent Males

Author: Best, Paul; Manktelow, Roger; Taylor, Brian J

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 257.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1766992390?accountid=14667

Abstract: Current global concerns regarding the mental well-being (MWB) of young males have called for fresh approaches to social work service delivery. This study investigates the efficacy of adopting more &apos;online&apos; approaches within social work practice by examining the current impact of online help-seeking behaviours on the MWB of adolescent males. A survey questionnaire comprised of validated scales measuring mental well-being and self-efficacy, combined with questions examining online help-seeking attitudes and behaviours was completed by 527 respondents aged 14-16 years within a school environment. The internet was used by 42 per cent of respondents to retrieve health information. In general, respondents appeared knowledgeable regarding the importance of trusted and quality online health information, yet were more likely to use search engines (57 per cent) or social networking sites (48 per cent) to find information rather than a government-sponsored website (23 per cent). Young males who reported speaking to online friends regarding personal problems recorded statistically significantly higher levels of mental well-being (p < 0.02). This may suggest that being able to communicate online how you are feeling is a positive for male mental health. Social work practitioners need to recognise this generational shift in help-seeking, in terms of providing and commissioning interpersonal helping via social media. [web URL: https://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/1/257.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+and+Social+Media%3A+Online+Help-Seeking+and+the+Mental+Well-Being+of+Adolescent+Males&amp;rft.au=Best%2C+Paul%3BManktelow%2C+Roger%3BTaylor%2C+Brian+J&amp;rft.aulast=Best&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=257&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+and+Social+Media%3A+Online+Help-Seeking+and+the+Mental+Well-Being+of+Adolescent+Males&amp;rft.au=Best%2C+Paul%3BManktelow%2C+Roger%3BTaylor%2C+Brian+J&amp;rft.aulast=Best&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=257&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Reversing the Perspective: When the Supervisors Learn from Their Trainees

Author: Fazzi, Luca; Rosignoli, Angela

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 204.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1766992437?accountid=14667

Abstract: There is widespread interest among social work scholars in the processes of learning in practice. By contrast, little attention has been paid to the learning that the relationship with trainees can produce for professional experts. The article reports the results of field research conducted on a group of forty social worker supervisors in order to determine the conditions that foster a &apos;dual learning&apos; process between supervisor and trainee. The research was conducted in collaboration with a sample of supervisors of trainee social work students at the University of Trento in Italy through in-depth interviews and questionnaires. The results of the inquiry highlight the importance of dual learning for both the professional growth of social workers and their job satisfaction. The conclusions indicate the main obstacles to overcome in promoting models and practices of supervision centred on the learning needs of both students and their supervisors. [web URL: https://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/1/204.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Reversing+the+Perspective%3A+When+the+Supervisors+Learn+from+Their+Trainees&amp;rft.au=Fazzi%2C+Luca%3BRosignoli%2C+Angela&amp;rft.aulast=Fazzi&amp;rft.aufirst=Luca&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=204&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Reversing+the+Perspective%3A+When+the+Supervisors+Learn+from+Their+Trainees&amp;rft.au=Fazzi%2C+Luca%3BRosignoli%2C+Angela&amp;rft.aulast=Fazzi&amp;rft.aufirst=Luca&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=204&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Decision Making in Dutch Child Welfare: Child&apos;s Wishes about Reunification after Out-of-Home Placement

Author: Minkhorst, Floor AM; Witteman, Cilia LM; Koopmans, A Carien; Lohman, Nickie; Knorth, Erik J

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 169.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1766992629?accountid=14667

Abstract: The child is a major stakeholder in the decision whether to continue placement in foster-care or to reunify her or him with the biological family. This study investigated whether Dutch social workers are influenced by the child&apos;s wish in their recommendations about reunification. Data were gathered from 120 child welfare professionals and 120 students who read a vignette about a child in foster-care and completed a questionnaire about their reunification recommendation. Results showed a weak, but significant relationship between the child&apos;s wish and the recommendation (Cramer&apos;s V = 0.295 and 0.188, respectively). Also, a moderating effect was found: participants who explicitly mentioned the child&apos;s wish in their justifications gave a recommendation that was significantly associated with the child&apos;s wish (p < 0.05) while, with those who did not mention the child&apos;s wish, there was no association. The results might seem obvious, but they are not consistent with prior research. The findings show that children might influence the decision-making process by stating their wishes. Raising children&apos;s awareness about this could be useful; believing that they are active agents regarding their own care might enhance motivation, co-operation and faith in their future. Explanations and implications of the results are discussed. [web URL: https://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/1/169.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Decision+Making+in+Dutch+Child+Welfare%3A+Child%26amp%3Bapos%3Bs+Wishes+about+Reunification+after+Out-of-Home+Placement&amp;rft.au=Minkhorst%2C+Floor+AM%3BWitteman%2C+Cilia+LM%3BKoopmans%2C+A+Carien%3BLohman%2C+Nickie%3BKnorth%2C+Erik+J&amp;rft.aulast=Minkhorst&amp;rft.aufirst=Floor&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=169&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Decision+Making+in+Dutch+Child+Welfare%3A+Child%26amp%3Bapos%3Bs+Wishes+about+Reunification+after+Out-of-Home+Placement&amp;rft.au=Minkhorst%2C+Floor+AM%3BWitteman%2C+Cilia+LM%3BKoopmans%2C+A+Carien%3BLohman%2C+Nickie%3BKnorth%2C+Erik+J&amp;rft.aulast=Minkhorst&amp;rft.aufirst=Floor&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=169&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Work-Family Conflict among Social Workers, Managers and Policy Makers in Times of Disaster

Author: Baum, Nehami

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 222.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1766992662?accountid=14667

Abstract: Fifty Israeli social workers at three hierarchical levels (direct service providers, agency or regional managers, policy makers) were interviewed about their experience of work-family conflict during wartime when the communities where they lived and most of them worked came under attack. The findings provide evidence of intensified work-family conflict throughout, but also show that the experience of the conflict varied with the workers&apos; hierarchical level and gender. The direct service workers of both genders were torn between their family and job responsibilities. Male and female managers differed in their attitudes and conduct towards workers who absented themselves the first few days of the war so as to make child-care arrangements. Male and female policy makers differed in their assessments of the ability to resolve the conflict at a systemic level. Suggestions are made for planning the delivery of social work services in disasters with the work-family conflict in mind. [web URL: https://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/1/222.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Work-Family+Conflict+among+Social+Workers%2C+Managers+and+Policy+Makers+in+Times+of+Disaster&amp;rft.au=Baum%2C+Nehami&amp;rft.aulast=Baum&amp;rft.aufirst=Nehami&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=222&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Work-Family+Conflict+among+Social+Workers%2C+Managers+and+Policy+Makers+in+Times+of+Disaster&amp;rft.au=Baum%2C+Nehami&amp;rft.aulast=Baum&amp;rft.aufirst=Nehami&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=222&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Workers as Members of Community Mental Health Teams for Older People: What Is the Added Value?

Author: Abendstern, Michele; Tucker, Susan; Wilberforce, Mark; Jasper, Rowan; Brand, Christian; Challis, David

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 63.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1766992695?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social workers have worked with older people with mental ill health in multidisciplinary teams for many years. Research regarding their contribution is nevertheless sparse. This article addresses this gap. Qualitative data from semi-structured staff interviews were drawn from a multiple case study of community mental health teams (CMHTs) for older people, some with and others without social worker members. Interviews included questions about team roles and the impact of the presence or absence of social workers on team functioning. A grounded theory approach was adopted to analyse the data, enabling issues of importance to interviewees to emerge. Non-social work CMHT staff were found to place a high value on social worker team membership due to their specific skills, knowledge and values, and with regard to communication pathways. Social workers and other team members&apos; views were found to differ regarding whether social workers within CMHTs should operate as generalists or specialists. The findings suggest the need for formal structures extending beyond the co-location of multidisciplinary staff; appropriate and sufficient supervision for social work team members; and the development of more workable and direct referral systems between CMHTs and social services adult social work teams. [web URL: https://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/1/63.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Workers+as+Members+of+Community+Mental+Health+Teams+for+Older+People%3A+What+Is+the+Added+Value%3F&amp;rft.au=Abendstern%2C+Michele%3BTucker%2C+Susan%3BWilberforce%2C+Mark%3BJasper%2C+Rowan%3BBrand%2C+Christian%3BChallis%2C+David&amp;rft.aulast=Abendstern&amp;rft.aufirst=Michele&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=63&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Workers+as+Members+of+Community+Mental+Health+Teams+for+Older+People%3A+What+Is+the+Added+Value%3F&amp;rft.au=Abendstern%2C+Michele%3BTucker%2C+Susan%3BWilberforce%2C+Mark%3BJasper%2C+Rowan%3BBrand%2C+Christian%3BChallis%2C+David&amp;rft.aulast=Abendstern&amp;rft.aufirst=Michele&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=63&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Child Welfare Attitudes, Risk Assessments and Intervention Recommendations: The Role of Professional Expertise

Author: Davidson-Arad, Bilha; Benbenishty, Rami

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 186.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1766992813?accountid=14667

Abstract: The study, carried out in Israel, explores the question of whether professionals&apos; status and experience moderate the relationships between their attitudes and their assessments and decisions on removal. It compares the associations between attitudes towards issues in child welfare, maltreatment, risk assessments and decisions of three groups of respondents: social work students and less and more experienced child protection social workers. The sample of 210 workers and 263 social work students filled out an attitudes questionnaire and responded to a written vignette showing a case of alleged child maltreatment. Compared with students, practitioners were more against removal, more in favour of reunification and optimal duration, and had a less favourable view of residential care. No significant group differences, however, were found in the risk assessments or removal recommendations. Four attitudes were associated with the recommendation not to remove: negative attitudes towards removal, positive attitudes towards parental participation in the decision, positive attitudes towards children&apos;s participation in the decision, and positive attitudes towards speedy reunification. Professional status and experience did not moderate these associations. The authors urge examination of professionals&apos; post-graduation training and supervision in order to determine whether the role of attitudes in professionals&apos; risk assessment might be further reduced. [web URL: https://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/1/186.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Child+Welfare+Attitudes%2C+Risk+Assessments+and+Intervention+Recommendations%3A+The+Role+of+Professional+Expertise&amp;rft.au=Davidson-Arad%2C+Bilha%3BBenbenishty%2C+Rami&amp;rft.aulast=Davidson-Arad&amp;rft.aufirst=Bilha&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=186&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Child+Welfare+Attitudes%2C+Risk+Assessments+and+Intervention+Recommendations%3A+The+Role+of+Professional+Expertise&amp;rft.au=Davidson-Arad%2C+Bilha%3BBenbenishty%2C+Rami&amp;rft.aulast=Davidson-Arad&amp;rft.aufirst=Bilha&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=186&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Work, Animal-Assisted Therapies and Ethical Considerations: A Programme Example from Central Queensland, Australia

Author: Taylor, Nik; Fraser, Heather; Signal, Tania; Prentice, Kathy

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 135.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1766992824?accountid=14667

Abstract: Animals are increasingly being used in a range of social work settings and extant research demonstrates they can offer a wide range of benefits to humans. With other professions, social work is oriented towards caring for people but does not officially recognise (non-human) animals. Given the rise in animal-related interventions and emergence of veterinary social work, we argue that this needs to change. We recognise that obstacles to change include social work&apos;s history of dichotomising (or falsely dividing) humans from animals, and focusing exclusively on human experiences of social problems (such as poverty). Using a programme example of a canine-assisted therapy project for child sexual abuse victims/survivors in Bundaberg (Central Queensland, Australia), we consider some of the ethical and practical issues associated with animal-assisted therapies (AATs). We examine whether AATs can benefit both humans and animals by positively changing people&apos;s attitudes and behaviours towards animals. We argue that the ethical legitimacy of AATs rests on their willingness to understand animals as sentient beings with needs of their own, not just possessions or tools for humans to use. [web URL: https://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/1/135.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work%2C+Animal-Assisted+Therapies+and+Ethical+Considerations%3A+A+Programme+Example+from+Central+Queensland%2C+Australia&amp;rft.au=Taylor%2C+Nik%3BFraser%2C+Heather%3BSignal%2C+Tania%3BPrentice%2C+Kathy&amp;rft.aulast=Taylor&amp;rft.aufirst=Nik&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=135&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work%2C+Animal-Assisted+Therapies+and+Ethical+Considerations%3A+A+Programme+Example+from+Central+Queensland%2C+Australia&amp;rft.au=Taylor%2C+Nik%3BFraser%2C+Heather%3BSignal%2C+Tania%3BPrentice%2C+Kathy&amp;rft.aulast=Taylor&amp;rft.aufirst=Nik&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=135&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Work Values, Perceived Job Rewards and Life Outcomes of the New Generation of Chinese Migrant Labourers&apos; in Guangzhou, China: Implications for Social Work Practice

Author: To, Siu-ming; Tam, Hau-lin

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 27.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1766993079?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study aimed to explore the direction of social work practices by examining how work values and job rewards were associated with job and life satisfaction among the new generation of Chinese migrant labourers who work in Guangzhou, China. Based on a survey design of 775 migrant labourers of two generational cohorts randomly selected from two toy factories, the results indicate that the younger participants&apos; instrumental work values were negatively associated with job satisfaction. Moreover, of the younger participants, all aspects of perceived job rewards were positively associated with both job and life satisfaction. The results challenge the public perception that the acquisition of monetary reward is a prime source of positive life outcomes among the new cohort of migrant labourers. On the contrary, the young migrants who work in a metropolis in South China are conscious of the significance of all the extrinsic, intrinsic and social job rewards for their well-being. There is thus a need for social workers to generate multidimensional service strategies in response to their concerns. Besides providing training programmes and continuing education, practitioners can engage in social support interventions, cultivate a collaborative relationship with corporations and put pressure on the government to initiate policy changes. [web URL: https://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/1/27.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Work+Values%2C+Perceived+Job+Rewards+and+Life+Outcomes+of+the+New+Generation+of+Chinese+Migrant+Labourers%26amp%3Bapos%3B+in+Guangzhou%2C+China%3A+Implications+for+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=To%2C+Siu-ming%3BTam%2C+Hau-lin&amp;rft.aulast=To&amp;rft.aufirst=Siu-ming&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=27&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Work+Values%2C+Perceived+Job+Rewards+and+Life+Outcomes+of+the+New+Generation+of+Chinese+Migrant+Labourers%26amp%3Bapos%3B+in+Guangzhou%2C+China%3A+Implications+for+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=To%2C+Siu-ming%3BTam%2C+Hau-lin&amp;rft.aulast=To&amp;rft.aufirst=Siu-ming&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=27&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Researching Social Work Practice Close Up: Using Ethnographic and Mobile Methods to Understand Encounters between Social Workers, Children and Families

Author: Ferguson, Harry

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 153.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1766993096?accountid=14667

Abstract: Research into child and family social work has largely stopped short of getting close enough to practice to produce understandings of what goes on between social workers and service users. This is despite the known problems in social worker engagement with children in cases where they have died. This paper outlines and analyses the methods used in a study of social work encounters with children and families on home visits where there were child protection concerns. It illustrates how mobile methods of walking and driving interviews were conducted with social workers on the way to and from home visits, and how the ethnography involved participant observation and audio-recordings of the interactions between social workers, children and parents in the home, revealing the talk, actions and experiences that occurred. Social workers often moved around the home, especially to interview children on their own in their bedrooms, and the paper shows how ways were found to stay close enough to observe these sensitive encounters within families&apos; most intimate spaces, while ensuring the research remained ethical. Ethnographic and mobile methods produce vital data that advance new understandings of everyday social work practices and service users&apos; experiences and of dynamics that are similar to breakdowns in practice that have occurred in child death cases. [web URL: https://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/1/153.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Researching+Social+Work+Practice+Close+Up%3A+Using+Ethnographic+and+Mobile+Methods+to+Understand+Encounters+between+Social+Workers%2C+Children+and+Families&amp;rft.au=Ferguson%2C+Harry&amp;rft.aulast=Ferguson&amp;rft.aufirst=Harry&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=153&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Researching+Social+Work+Practice+Close+Up%3A+Using+Ethnographic+and+Mobile+Methods+to+Understand+Encounters+between+Social+Workers%2C+Children+and+Families&amp;rft.au=Ferguson%2C+Harry&amp;rft.aulast=Ferguson&amp;rft.aufirst=Harry&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=153&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Work and Interprofessional Education in Health Care: A Call for Continued Leadership

Author: Jones, Barbara; Phillips, Farya

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. 1,  (Jan/Mar 2016): 18-29.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1767298400?accountid=14667

Abstract: A report from the Interprofessional Education Collaborative and another from the Institute of Medicine cite working as part of interdisciplinary teams as a core proficiency area for improving health care. This article discusses the core competencies of interprofessional education and the essential role for social workers as leaders and facilitators of this practice. Educators will learn how to help students discover the knowledge, skills, and attitudes for successful interprofessional work. Specifically, this article has the following objectives: Discuss essential elements of effective interprofessional practice; Present exemplars of interprofessional education involving social work; Identify the roles for social work in leadership, education, and practice in interprofessional education.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+and+Interprofessional+Education+in+Health+Care%3A+A+Call+for+Continued+Leadership&amp;rft.au=Jones%2C+Barbara%3BPhillips%2C+Farya&amp;rft.aulast=Jones&amp;rft.aufirst=Barbara&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=18&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1112629

____________________________________________________________

Experiences of opioid-dependent women in their prenatal and postpartum care: Implications for social workers in health care

Author: Howard, Heather, PhD, MSW, LICSW11 Department of Social Work, Wheelock College, Boston, Massachusetts, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 61-85.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1768231414?accountid=14667

Abstract: The prevalence of prescription opioid abuse has increased nationally in the last decade with increased incidence rates reported among pregnant women. This was a qualitative study designed to understand the role of pregnant women with an opioid use disorder participating in medical decision making regarding their prenatal care while addressing their addiction. Group interviews were conducted with postpartum women who self-identified as opioid dependent during their pregnancy, and the data were analyzed using Interpretative Phenomenological Analysis. Social workers in the health care setting are an integral part of the interdisciplinary team in caring for pregnant and postpartum opioid-dependent women. Social workers are ideal in creating stigma reduction strategies, peer and professional supports, and comprehensive coordinated care. A social justice-based practice may be a framework to utilize when caring for this unique population.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Experiences+of+opioid-dependent+women+in+their+prenatal+and+postpartum+care%3A+Implications+for+social+workers+in+health+care&amp;rft.au=Howard%2C+Heather%2C+PhD%2C+MSW%2C+LICSW&amp;rft.aulast=Howard&amp;rft.aufirst=Heather&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=61&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2015.1078427

Addressing access barriers to services for mothers at risk for perinatal mood disorders: A social work perspective

Author: Keefe, Robert H, PhD, LMSW, ACSW1; Brownstein-Evans, Carol, PhD, ACSW2; Rouland Polmanteer, Rebecca S, LMSW11 School of Social Work, University at Buffalo, SUNY, Buffalo, New York, USA2 Nazareth College and The Greater Rochester Collaborative MSW Program, Rochester, New York, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 1-11.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1768231705?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article identifies variables at the micro/individual, mezzo/partner/spouse and family, and macro/health care-system levels that inhibit mothers at risk for perinatal mood disorders from accessing health and mental health care services. Specific recommendations are made for conducting thorough biopsychosocial assessments that address the mothers&apos; micro-, mezzo-, and macro-level contexts. Finally, the authors provide suggestions for how to intervene at the various levels to remove access barriers for mothers living with perinatal mood disorders as well as their families.

Associations between comorbid health conditions and the use of mental health services among adults with bipolar disorder

Author: Lee, Sungkyu, PhD1; Matejkowski, Jason, PhD21 School of Social Welfare, Soongsil University, Seoul, South Korea2 School of Social Welfare and Center for Mental Health Research and Innovation, University of Kansas, Lawrence, Kansas, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 28-40.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1768231784?accountid=14667

Abstract: Using a nationally representative sample, this study examined to what extent the number of comorbid health conditions was associated with various mental health service utilization among people with bipolar disorder. The results of logistic regression models indicate that a greater number of comorbid medical conditions were associated with higher odds of using specialty mental health service, while they were not associated with utilization of services provided by general health care providers. The type of bipolar disorder, functional impairment, and marital status were found to be associated with the use of a specialty service, while ethnicity was the only covariate significantly related to general health care use.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Associations+between+comorbid+health+conditions+and+the+use+of+mental+health+services+among+adults+with+bipolar+disorder&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Sungkyu%2C+PhD%3BMatejkowski%2C+Jason%2C+PhD&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Sungkyu&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=28&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2015.1107016

____________________________________________________________

Promoting Individual and Social Changes: A Hybrid Model of Social Work with Groups

Author: Roy, Valérie; Pullen-Sansfaçon, Annie

Publication info: Social Work with Groups ; New York  Vol. 39, Iss. 1,  (Jan/Mar 2016): 4-20.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1768232520?accountid=14667

Abstract: Taking as a starting point two influential, yet different approaches in group work, that is, the self-directed group work and mutual aid models, this article examines a possible alternative for conducting social work with groups. Drawing from structuration theory, which makes a strong dialectical relation between agency and structure possible, this article highlights how our alternative model could lead to a greater integration of the micro- and macrodimensions in group-work practice. The Discussion section proposes three key principles for group work, namely, a belief in people&apos;s strengths and capacities, a focus on critical thinking, and a concern for the development of a democratic culture in groups. These principles are conveyed through the group worker&apos;s roles as consciousness raiser and process facilitator and provide a flexible and participatory process that can be used with a broad range of service-user groups. The article concludes with a discussion on the strengths and limitations of the model.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Promoting+Individual+and+Social+Changes%3A+A+Hybrid+Model+of+Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.au=Roy%2C+Val%C3%A9rie%3BPullen-Sansfa%C3%A7on%2C+Annie&amp;rft.aulast=Roy&amp;rft.aufirst=Val%C3%A9rie&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=4&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2015.1033585

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Promoting+Individual+and+Social+Changes%3A+A+Hybrid+Model+of+Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.au=Roy%2C+Val%C3%A9rie%3BPullen-Sansfa%C3%A7on%2C+Annie&amp;rft.aulast=Roy&amp;rft.aufirst=Val%C3%A9rie&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=4&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2015.1033585

____________________________________________________________

&quot;Improving Long-Term Psychiatric Care: Bring Back the Asylum&quot;: Implications for Ethnic Minority Individuals

Author: Mfoafo-M'Carthy, Magnus

Publication info: Journal of Ethnic & Cultural Diversity in Social Work ; Abingdon  Vol. 25, Iss. 1,  (Jan/Mar 2016): 68-74.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1773419361?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article is a response to a previous article published in The Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA) advocating for the reintroduction of the asylum system. Despite the arguments made by the authors, this author believes that reverting to the asylum system would not be beneficial for individuals with mental illness. This is due to the impact of the asylum system on a large number of this client population. Also, the reintroduction of the asylum system would worsen the plight of persons from ethnic minority backgrounds, based on the discriminatory practices of the health care system in the Western world.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=%26amp%3Bquot%3BImproving+Long-Term+Psychiatric+Care%3A+Bring+Back+the+Asylum%26amp%3Bquot%3B%3A+Implications+for+Ethnic+Minority+Individuals&amp;rft.au=Mfoafo-M%27Carthy%2C+Magnus&amp;rft.aulast=Mfoafo-M%27Carthy&amp;rft.aufirst=Magnus&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=68&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2015.1121419

The Cultural Adaptation of the DISC-IV: Appropriateness for Sotho-Speaking South Africans

Author: Skinner, Donald; Sharp, Carla; Serekoane, Motsaathebe; Ross, Michael

Publication info: Journal of Ethnic & Cultural Diversity in Social Work ; Abingdon  Vol. 25, Iss. 1,  (Jan/Mar 2016): 1-19.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1773419766?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Diagnostic Interview Schedule for Children (DISC-IV) has been designed for use by trained laypersons so it can be used in developing countries including South Africa. We examine the sociocultural appropriateness of the DISC-IV for Sesotho families. In-depth individual interviews and focus groups were conducted with Sesotho clinicians who used the DISC-IV. The clinicians found it to be a rigorous assessment tool offering new insights into their patients&apos; mental capacities. Concerns were raised about its length and structure, norms, and gaps in diagnostic criteria specific to the Sesotho community. With adaptation the DISC-IV could make a valuable contribution to their assessment tools.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Cultural+Adaptation+of+the+DISC-IV%3A+Appropriateness+for+Sotho-Speaking+South+Africans&amp;rft.au=Skinner%2C+Donald%3BSharp%2C+Carla%3BSerekoane%2C+Motsaathebe%3BRoss%2C+Michael&amp;rft.aulast=Skinner&amp;rft.aufirst=Donald&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2015.1129521

Maternal Warmth: A Re-Examination of the Role Race and Socioeconomic Status Play

Author: Henninger, William R, IV; Gross, Patricia E

Publication info: Journal of Ethnic & Cultural Diversity in Social Work ; Abingdon  Vol. 25, Iss. 1,  (Jan/Mar 2016): 36-49.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1773420150?accountid=14667

Abstract: Of particular importance to the development of young children is the extent to which parents provide a warm, responsive, and helpful environment. Child well-being is generally maximized when parents support their children and avoid harsh punishments. The purpose of this research is to investigate the role ethnicity plays in the warmth of the relationship between mothers and their children independent of socioeconomic status (SES), social emotional risk of the child, and child-reported relationship with the mother. Using data collected as part of the Early Head Start Research and Evaluation Project (EHSRE), 647 caregiver/child dyads were studied. Mother&apos;s education, child&apos;s report of mother&apos;s warmth, and child risk of social emotional issues were entered into the regression model as predictors of mother&apos;s reported warmth. Except for mother&apos;s education, all the variables were significantly related to parental warmth at p &1t; 0.5. However, in this sample parents who identified their child as White were less warm (on average) than the other parents in the sample. Implications of this finding are discussed, as well as implications for future research.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Maternal+Warmth%3A+A+Re-Examination+of+the+Role+Race+and+Socioeconomic+Status+Play&amp;rft.au=Henninger%2C+William+R%2C+IV%3BGross%2C+Patricia+E&amp;rft.aulast=Henninger&amp;rft.aufirst=William&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=36&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2016.1145089

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Maternal+Warmth%3A+A+Re-Examination+of+the+Role+Race+and+Socioeconomic+Status+Play&amp;rft.au=Henninger%2C+William+R%2C+IV%3BGross%2C+Patricia+E&amp;rft.aulast=Henninger&amp;rft.aufirst=William&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=36&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2016.1145089

Social Work, Human Rights, and the Migration of Central American Children

Author: Chappell Deckert, Jennifer

Publication info: Journal of Ethnic & Cultural Diversity in Social Work ; Abingdon  Vol. 25, Iss. 1,  (Jan/Mar 2016): 20-35.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1773420328?accountid=14667

Abstract: A humanitarian crisis related to an influx of unaccompanied children from Central America arriving in the United States demands a comprehensive approach ensuring appropriate intervention to protect basic human rights. Advocates and policymakers are scrambling to find ways to address the complex needs of these vulnerable children, most of whom are fleeing violence, criminal coercion, and/or extreme deprivation in their home countries. Legislative attempts to guarantee access to due process are threatened by a restrictive ideological stance instead of employing a needs-based strategy for reform. Social workers can play a key role by responding to the crisis in ways that draw from core social work values and contribute to a collaborative, comprehensive solution that addresses the needs of these children.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work%2C+Human+Rights%2C+and+the+Migration+of+Central+American+Children&amp;rft.au=Chappell+Deckert%2C+Jennifer&amp;rft.aulast=Chappell+Deckert&amp;rft.aufirst=Jennifer&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=20&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2015.1121420

Home Visitors&apos; Perceptions of Structural Constraints, Family Resilience, and Adverse Childhood Experiences

Author: Davis, Sarah M; Kane, Emily W

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 97, Iss. 1,  (2016): 23.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1779888150?accountid=14667

Abstract: Scholars and practitioners interested in children, families, and health have documented that adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) predict a range of adult outcomes. While ACEs research and practice emphasize community- and social-level factors, we explore whether daily practice using the ACEs framework within the home visitation model directs attention away from those broader social factors. Through community-based research partnered with a local agency, we document that home visitors using the ACEs framework combine daily practice at the individual and household level with strong attention to the broader social context the literature emphasizes. But we also document room for further reflective practice to reinforce that broader context, and the role that research partnerships between higher education and local organizations can play in that practice.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Home+Visitors%26amp%3Bapos%3B+Perceptions+of+Structural+Constraints%2C+Family+Resilience%2C+and+Adverse+Childhood+Experiences&amp;rft.au=Davis%2C+Sarah+M%3BKane%2C+Emily+W&amp;rft.aulast=Davis&amp;rft.aufirst=Sarah&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=23&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Teenage Pregnancy in Latino Communities: Young Adult Experiences and Perspectives of Sociocultural Factors

Author: Aparicio, Elizabeth M; Vanidestine, Todd; Zhou, Kelly; Pecukonis, Edward V

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 97, Iss. 1,  (2016): 50.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1779888341?accountid=14667

Abstract: Racial and ethnic inequities persist in teenage pregnancy rates, prompting examinations of how to provide better attuned teen pregnancy prevention in key affected communities. The current study focused on sociocultural factors of teen pregnancy in Latino communities, using in-depth, semi-structured qualitative interviews to elicit the experiences and perspectives of young adult Latino/as (some who prevented and others who directly experienced teen pregnancy in their own lives). Using a grounded theory approach to data analysis, avoiding teen pregnancy emerged as related to 7 facets of youth experience. Findings offer a critical window into the complex interplay of these experiences in Latino teens&apos; lives, particularly when using a gender-sensitive lens. Implications and future research directions are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Teenage+Pregnancy+in+Latino+Communities%3A+Young+Adult+Experiences+and+Perspectives+of+Sociocultural+Factors&amp;rft.au=Aparicio%2C+Elizabeth+M%3BVanidestine%2C+Todd%3BZhou%2C+Kelly%3BPecukonis%2C+Edward+V&amp;rft.aulast=Aparicio&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=50&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Impact of Crime Tolerance in Low-Income Housing on Neighbor Cohesion and Collective Efficacy

Author: Walker, Laurie A; Aguayo, Anabel

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 97, Iss. 1,  (2016): 41.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1779888648?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article focuses on determining the impact that resident crime tolerance in public housing has on other factors that predict perceptions of residents&apos; ability to work together to address crime and call the police. Survey participants (n = 387) were recruited through door-to-door knocking in 2 redeveloping public housing neighborhoods. Study measures were validated with factor analysis before developing a structural equation model. Perceptions of neighborhood problems, neighbor cohesion, and organizational collective efficacy predict collective efficacy: working together against crime and/or calling the police. Two crime tolerance variables covary, but do not have a direct impact on their perception of their ability to address crime or call the police.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Impact+of+Crime+Tolerance+in+Low-Income+Housing+on+Neighbor+Cohesion+and+Collective+Efficacy&amp;rft.au=Walker%2C+Laurie+A%3BAguayo%2C+Anabel&amp;rft.aulast=Walker&amp;rft.aufirst=Laurie&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=41&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Impact+of+Crime+Tolerance+in+Low-Income+Housing+on+Neighbor+Cohesion+and+Collective+Efficacy&amp;rft.au=Walker%2C+Laurie+A%3BAguayo%2C+Anabel&amp;rft.aulast=Walker&amp;rft.aufirst=Laurie&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=41&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Role of Research in the Family Service Agency: Reflections Some 30 Years Later

Author: Caputo, Richard K

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 97, Iss. 1,  (2016): 67.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1779888855?accountid=14667

Abstract: "The role of research in the Family Service Agency" is a topic that encompasses a variety of seemingly paradoxical, if not contraindicative, issues: social science research versus social work research, the researcher versus the practitioner, practice versus policy, academic research versus agency-based research, the generation of knowledge versus the application of research findings, and empirical research versus theoretical research. The issues exist in part because of the historical influences that shaped the development of the social sciences and the profession of social work and in part because of the differences in the size, structure, function, and resources of an agency. They are also due to differences in the nature, purpose, methodology, and design of research as well as to differences in the affinity of administrators and practitioners for the findings of research activities.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=The+Role+of+Research+in+the+Family+Service+Agency%3A+Reflections+Some+30+Years+Later&amp;rft.au=Caputo%2C+Richard+K&amp;rft.aulast=Caputo&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=67&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=The+Role+of+Research+in+the+Family+Service+Agency%3A+Reflections+Some+30+Years+Later&amp;rft.au=Caputo%2C+Richard+K&amp;rft.aulast=Caputo&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=67&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Recruiting and Retaining African American Custodial Grandparents in University-Sponsored Research: An Opening Dialogue

Author: Whitley, Deborah M

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 97, Iss. 1,  (2016): 58.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1779888896?accountid=14667

Abstract: Studies on recruitment and retention of grandparents raising grandchildren into community-based research have received scant attention by scholars. The lack of attention is especially troubling considering the continuing growth of this family group, as well as the large proportion of custodial grandparents who are ethnically diverse and vulnerable to various health and psychological risks. Limited attention to recruitment and retention methods leads to reduced understanding of the full value of service interventions for custodial grandparents and the grandchildren they are raising. This article describes the recruitment and retention methods used in one longstanding research study involving African American custodial grandparents. The merits of establishing a research agenda on this topic are reviewed, along with specific suggestions for extending this line of inquiry.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Recruiting+and+Retaining+African+American+Custodial+Grandparents+in+University-Sponsored+Research%3A+An+Opening+Dialogue&amp;rft.au=Whitley%2C+Deborah+M&amp;rft.aulast=Whitley&amp;rft.aufirst=Deborah&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=58&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Recruiting+and+Retaining+African+American+Custodial+Grandparents+in+University-Sponsored+Research%3A+An+Opening+Dialogue&amp;rft.au=Whitley%2C+Deborah+M&amp;rft.aulast=Whitley&amp;rft.aufirst=Deborah&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=58&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Re-Envisioning Macro Social Work Practice

Author: McBeath, Bowen

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 97, Iss. 1,  (2016): 5.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1779888928?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents 10 recommendations supporting a re-envisioning of macro practice for the 21st century. These strategies are needed to counter a generational trend of disinvestment in macro social work practice and to support the historic vision of the social work profession as equally responsive to the needs of at-risk, disadvantaged populations and the organizational, community, and policy roots of social injustice. Before describing these recommendations and discussing their implications for the social work profession, I first briefly review the challenges facing macro practice and current initiatives promoting its renewal. The goal of this analysis is to define the essential contributions of macro practice while identifying strategies for responding to current dilemmas facing the social work profession.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Re-Envisioning+Macro+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=McBeath%2C+Bowen&amp;rft.aulast=McBeath&amp;rft.aufirst=Bowen&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=5&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

An Integrated Approach to Relationship Education: Supporting Human Services Providers to Strengthen Individuals and Families

Author: Arnold, Amy Laura; Carlson, Matthew; Grimsley, Rebecca N; Cenizal, Robyn

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 97, Iss. 1,  (2016): 32.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1779888948?accountid=14667

Abstract: Healthy relationship education helps ameliorate the cycle of family fragmentation. Although provided in a variety of forms, scholars support that the most efficient way of promoting healthy relationship education is through integration within human services. The National Resource Center for Healthy Marriage and Families uses a workshop approach to assist human services providers to integrate healthy relationship skills into their preexisting service delivery methods. In this study, a "for whom does it work" approach was used to identify workshop participant (N = 40) characteristics that influenced learning impact and transfer of learning. Supervisors reported greater transfer of learning. Personal and agency readiness were predictive of learning impact. Barriers to integration, as well as implications for practice and research, are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=An+Integrated+Approach+to+Relationship+Education%3A+Supporting+Human+Services+Providers+to+Strengthen+Individuals+and+Families&amp;rft.au=Arnold%2C+Amy+Laura%3BCarlson%2C+Matthew%3BGrimsley%2C+Rebecca+N%3BCenizal%2C+Robyn&amp;rft.aulast=Arnold&amp;rft.aufirst=Amy&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=32&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=An+Integrated+Approach+to+Relationship+Education%3A+Supporting+Human+Services+Providers+to+Strengthen+Individuals+and+Families&amp;rft.au=Arnold%2C+Amy+Laura%3BCarlson%2C+Matthew%3BGrimsley%2C+Rebecca+N%3BCenizal%2C+Robyn&amp;rft.aulast=Arnold&amp;rft.aufirst=Amy&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=32&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The impact of the crisis on homelessness in Spain: social intervention in a context of greater need and fewer resources

Author: Márquez, Gorka Moreno1; Urraza, Xabier Aierdi21 Department of Sociology and Social Work, University College for Social Work, University of the Basque Country, Partehartuz Research Group, Vitoria-Gasteiz, Spain2 Department of Sociology and Social Work, Faculty of Social Science and Communication, University of the Basque Country, Civersity Research Group, Bilbao, Spain

Publication info: European Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 19, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 31-45.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784138893?accountid=14667

Abstract: English: The purpose of this article is to deepen the understanding of the impact of the social and economic crisis on homeless people in Spain. To this end we present the results of research carried out prior to the crisis and later updated in the midst of the economic recession, underscoring the main results obtained in both periods and tracing their evolution. The number of homeless people in Spain has risen as a result of the crisis. Moreover, while some characteristics of this group remain the same, others have changed. Hence, difficulties in access to the labour market and cuts in certain economic benefits are resulting in an increase in the duration of social inclusion processes. This results in a worsening of the personal situation of the homeless, especially in relation to mental illness and substance abuse. The immigrant population is the group most affected by these impacts. The situation clearly demonstrates the need to reflect on how to deal with the problem of homelessness in Spain, and to rethink the way professionals intervene, especially during periods of economic recession. Spanish: En este artículo se pretende profundizar en el impacto que está teniendo la crisis económica y social sobre las personas sin hogar en España. Para ello, se presentan los resultados de una investigación realizada en el momento previo a la crisis y su actualización en pleno periodo de recesión económica, destacando los principales resultados en ambas en clave evolutiva. Como consecuencia de la crisis se detecta un aumento del número de personas sin hogar. Igualmente, y aunque se mantienen algunas características del colectivo, otras se han modificado. Así, las dificultades de acceso al mercado laboral y el recorte en ciertas prestaciones económicas están haciendo que la duración de los procesos de incorporación social aumente. Este contexto está haciendo que la situación personal de las personas sin hogar también empeore, sobre todo en aspectos como las patologías mentales o los consumos. El colectivo inmigrante es el que más intensamente está sufriendo este impacto. Este escenario muestra la necesidad de reflexionar en torno a la atención a las personas sin hogar, así como un cierto replanteamiento en el modo de intervenir de los profesionales, sobre todo en un momento de crisis como el actual.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+impact+of+the+crisis+on+homelessness+in+Spain%3A+social+intervention+in+a+context+of+greater+need+and+fewer+resources&amp;rft.au=M%C3%A1rquez%2C+Gorka+Moreno%3BUrraza%2C+Xabier+Aierdi&amp;rft.aulast=M%C3%A1rquez&amp;rft.aufirst=Gorka&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=31&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13691457&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F13691457.2015.1022712

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+impact+of+the+crisis+on+homelessness+in+Spain%3A+social+intervention+in+a+context+of+greater+need+and+fewer+resources&amp;rft.au=M%C3%A1rquez%2C+Gorka+Moreno%3BUrraza%2C+Xabier+Aierdi&amp;rft.aulast=M%C3%A1rquez&amp;rft.aufirst=Gorka&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=31&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13691457&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F13691457.2015.1022712
