____________________________________________________________

&quot;Parenting Is Not a Job ... It&apos;s a Relationship&quot;: Recognition and Relational Knowledge Among Parents of Gender Non-conforming Children

Author: Pyne, Jake11 School of Social Work and Gender Studies and Feminist Research Program, McMaster University, Toronto, Ontario, Canada

Publication info: Journal of Progressive Human Services ; Binghamton  Vol. 27, Iss. 1,  (Jan/Apr 2016): 21-48.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784138994?accountid=14667

Abstract: Parents of gender non-conforming children encounter substantial conflict as they negotiate their children&apos;s "Otherness." For decades, a pathologizing service model has advocated clinical correction. In opposition, some parents adopt affirming stances toward their children. This study explored the knowledge underneath this stance, asking parents of gender non-conforming children how they know what they know. Analysis revealed a process of recognition and knowledge of the children&apos;s needs acquired through relationship. Drawing on political philosophy and psychoanalytic theory, I argue that the affirming approach to gender non-conforming children is a non-aggressive response to the "Other" and a justice-based parenting practice.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Progressive+Human+Services&amp;rft.atitle=%26amp%3Bquot%3BParenting+Is+Not+a+Job+...+It%26amp%3Bapos%3Bs+a+Relationship%26amp%3Bquot%3B%3A+Recognition+and+Relational+Knowledge+Among+Parents+of+Gender+Non-conforming+Children&amp;rft.au=Pyne%2C+Jake&amp;rft.aulast=Pyne&amp;rft.aufirst=Jake&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=27&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=21&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Progressive+Human+Services&amp;rft.issn=10428232&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10428232.2016.1108139

Socially Engaged Art and Social Work: Reflecting on an Interdisciplinary Course Development Journey

Author: Wehbi, Samantha1; McCormick, Katy2; Angelucci, Sara21 School of Social Work, Ryerson University, Toronto, Ontario, Canada2 School of Image Arts, Ryerson University, Toronto, Ontario, Canada

Publication info: Journal of Progressive Human Services ; Binghamton  Vol. 27, Iss. 1,  (Jan/Apr 2016): 49-64.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784139109?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article shares key questions guiding our process of building interdisciplinary bridges between social work and art to contribute to social justice-oriented education. Through a focus on socially engaged art, we discuss the purpose and forms that these practices take and the role of the audience/participants when working for social change with communities. We then present a proposed course outline that brings social work and socially engaged art together. Our hope is that this discussion will guide others interested in working through interdisciplinary collaborations, as can be seen by the growing interest in the mix of art and social work in practice and education.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Progressive+Human+Services&amp;rft.atitle=Socially+Engaged+Art+and+Social+Work%3A+Reflecting+on+an+Interdisciplinary+Course+Development+Journey&amp;rft.au=Wehbi%2C+Samantha%3BMcCormick%2C+Katy%3BAngelucci%2C+Sara&amp;rft.aulast=Wehbi&amp;rft.aufirst=Samantha&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=27&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=49&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Progressive+Human+Services&amp;rft.issn=10428232&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10428232.2016.1108167

Working with social complexity in a neoliberal society: challenges for social work in Estonia

Author: Mitendorf, Airi1; van Ewijk, Hans21 Institute of Social Work, Tallinn University, Tallinn, Estonia2 Department of Social Work Theory, University of Humanistic Studies, Utrecht, the Netherlands

Publication info: European Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 19, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 78-91.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784139247?accountid=14667

Abstract: English: This article deals with Estonian social workers' perspectives on the fundamentals of the social work profession in a society where radical social, political, and economic changes have occurred within a very short period of time. Estonia typically figures as a model country, sometimes as a positive model, sometimes as a negative one, but according to most commentators, Estonia has pursued social and economic transformations in a particularly dramatic way. Social workers have recognized that radical changes have created new types of problems and social work should deal with vulnerable people and families under uncertain and unforeseeable conditions. Estonia is a challenging example to understand social work in the context of a neoliberal market society. It is therefore necessary to find out what the new challenges for the development of social work as a profession are. This article explores a 'direction' toward which social work in Estonia is developing, focusing mainly on the influence of the Estonian political context. The results of the research are relevant to the entire social work profession, insomuch as they address questions about the essence of social work and the ethical principles of the social work profession in society and how they can be strongly influenced by neoliberal thinking and increasing complexity. Estonian: See artikkel käsitleb sotsiaaltöötajate vaatenurki sotsiaaltöö professionaalsest praktikast ühiskonnas, kus radikaalsed sotsiaalsed, poliitilised ja majanduslikud muutused on asetleidnud lühikesel ajaperioodil. Eesti taasiseseisvumisest alates 1991.a on ulatuslikud reformid (turumajanduslike ja demokraatlike institutsioonide ülesehitamine, omandisuhte muutumine, ümberkorraldused sotsiaal- ja tervishoiupoliitikas ning hariduses) avaldanud olulist mõju Eesti inimeste eluteedele ning seeläbi ka sotsiaaltöö praktikale. Mitmed autorid on üsna üksmeelel selles osas, et uute Euroopa Liidu riikide seas on Eesti kõige puhtakujulisem liberaalse turumajanduse näide: väiksemad maksud (kuid vähem avalikke hüvesid), madalam töötuse tase (kuid rohkem vange), suurem ebavõrdus, kõrgemad võõrdumis- ja madalamad solidaarsusnäitajad, rohkem vabadust (rikaste jaoks), suurem sotsiaalne ebakindlus ja vaesus. Sotsiaaltöötajate sõnul on kiired muutused loonud uut tüüpi sotsiaalprobleeme, millel puuduvad konkreetsed ja lihtsad lahendused. Liberaalse turumajanduse korral pakub sotsiaalkaitsesüsteem minimaalseid sotsiaalseid hüvesid jättes suurema vastutuse indiviididele ja perekondadele rõhutades inimese enda vastutust oma ühiskonnas osalemise, heaolu ja sissetuleku eest. Uuringu tulemusena selgus, et sotsiaaltöötajad puutuvad enda igapäevatöös kokku inimestega, kes on sattunud mitmekesiste probleemide keskele ning kes ei suuda või kellel puuduvad võimed võtta vastutust enda elu puudutavates küsimustes. Sotsiaaltöötajad tegutsevad sageli komplekssete sotsiaalprobleemide, ühiskondlike nõuete ja ootuste ning keerukate eetliste valikute kolmnurgas. Uuringu tulemused on olulised, et mõtestada sotsiaaltöö tähendust ja eetilisi põhimõtteid ühiskonnas, mis on tugevalt mõjutatud neoliberaalsest maailmavaatest.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Working+with+social+complexity+in+a+neoliberal+society%3A+challenges+for+social+work+in+Estonia&amp;rft.au=Mitendorf%2C+Airi%3Bvan+Ewijk%2C+Hans&amp;rft.aulast=Mitendorf&amp;rft.aufirst=Airi&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=78&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13691457&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F13691457.2015.1025711

Critical Reflexivity and Moral Regulation

Author: Badwall, Harjeet11 School of Social Work, York University, Toronto, Ontario, Canada

Publication info: Journal of Progressive Human Services ; Binghamton  Vol. 27, Iss. 1,  (Jan/Apr 2016): 1-20.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784139453?accountid=14667

Abstract: Critical reflexivity is a dominant practice framework in social work. It is designed to address the operation of power relations between social workers and their clients. However, I intend to shed light on a different set of concerns related to this practice. I examine the ways in which critical reflexivity can operate to re-inscribe colonial notions of moral superiority, and re-center whiteness within social work education and practice settings. Drawing on research I conducted with racialized social workers in Toronto, Canada, this article examines the ways in which critical reflexivity can operate as a governing technology to silence the operation of racism.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Progressive+Human+Services&amp;rft.atitle=Critical+Reflexivity+and+Moral+Regulation&amp;rft.au=Badwall%2C+Harjeet&amp;rft.aulast=Badwall&amp;rft.aufirst=Harjeet&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=27&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Progressive+Human+Services&amp;rft.issn=10428232&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10428232.2016.1108169

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Progressive+Human+Services&amp;rft.atitle=Critical+Reflexivity+and+Moral+Regulation&amp;rft.au=Badwall%2C+Harjeet&amp;rft.aulast=Badwall&amp;rft.aufirst=Harjeet&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=27&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Progressive+Human+Services&amp;rft.issn=10428232&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10428232.2016.1108169

Qualitative examination of rural service provision to persons with concurrent developmental and mental health challenges

Author: Kreitzer, Linda1; McLaughlin, Anne Marie1; Elliott, Grace1; Nicholas, David11 Department of Social Work, University of Calgary, Edmonton, AB, Canada

Publication info: European Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 19, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 46-61.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784139551?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although there has been an international trend away from institutionalization to community-based care, this has not always been successful, particularly for the unique and vulnerable population diagnosed with both mental health and developmental disabilities. The challenge of meeting the needs of this population is increased in rural and remote areas. As a part of a larger study, this paper reports on the voices of service providers for people dually diagnosed as they maneuver through the considerable challenges of meeting complex needs while located in remote northern communities. The complexities of rural service provision for those with a dual diagnosis of mental illness and developmental disability is also highlighted and includes challenges of northern living, difficulties in diagnosis, and system level issues. This paper confronts the inequities in provision of effective community-based services to this population and draws attention to the need to support and develop local, integrated services in order to build inclusive communities for all.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Qualitative+examination+of+rural+service+provision+to+persons+with+concurrent+developmental+and+mental+health+challenges&amp;rft.au=Kreitzer%2C+Linda%3BMcLaughlin%2C+Anne+Marie%3BElliott%2C+Grace%3BNicholas%2C+David&amp;rft.aulast=Kreitzer&amp;rft.aufirst=Linda&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=46&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13691457&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F13691457.2015.1022859

____________________________________________________________

Social work and social control in the penitentiary system: an empirical study in northern Italy

Author: Cellini, Giovanni11 Department of Culture, Politics and Society, University of Turin, Turin, Italy

Publication info: European Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 19, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 92-105.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784139741?accountid=14667

Abstract: English: In Italy there is a prison and probation system based on a rehabilitative model, which is connected with social policies and entrusts relevant tasks to the helping professions. Among these, social work is affected by changes in social policies, marked by the influence of neoliberal thought. Contemporary sociological studies highlight the transition from a model mainly focused on ensuring social welfare, to a model in which the dominant interest is to increase effective social control. In this transition there has been an impoverishment of social protection for the most vulnerable segments of the population. This article presents the results of a qualitative research study carried out in northern Italy, among professionals working in the penitentiary sector (mainly social workers). Research has focused on the representations of the respondents on specific issues, including: the relationship between the crisis of the welfare state and the penal-welfare system; the culture of control and the changes in the role of social workers. Results show, inter alia, that social workers reject punitive responses, especially those towards the most disadvantaged social groups. Moreover, in this crisis of the welfare state and the rehabilitative model, political ideals, felt by the entire professional community, seem to be lacking. Italian: In Italia il sistema penitenziario è basato su un modello riabilitativo, connesso con le politiche sociali, che affida compiti rilevanti alle professioni di aiuto. Tra queste, il servizio sociale è interessato dai cambiamenti nelle politiche sociali, segnate dall’influenza del pensiero neoliberista. Studi sociologici contemporanei hanno messo in luce il passaggio da un modello basato principalmente sulla garanzia del benessere sociale ad un modello in cui l’interesse dominante è l’incremento di un efficace controllo sociale. In questa transizione si è avuto un impoverimento della protezione sociale per le fasce più deboli della popolazione. L’articolo presenta i risultati di una ricerca qualitativa, realizzata nel nord Italia tra professionisti che operano nel sistema penitenziario (in maggioranza assistenti sociali). La ricerca si è concentrata sulle rappresentazioni degli intervistati relative ad alcuni temi, tra cui: la relazione tra la crisi del welfare state e il penal-welfare system; la cultura del controllo e i cambiamenti nel ruolo degli assistenti sociali. I risultati mostrano, fra l’altro, che gli assistenti sociali rigettano risposte punitive, specialmente quelle dirette ai gruppi sociali più svantaggiati. Peraltro, nella crisi del welfare state e del modello riabilitativo, sembrano venire meno valori ed ideali politici condivisi dall’intera comunità professionale.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+work+and+social+control+in+the+penitentiary+system%3A+an+empirical+study+in+northern+Italy&amp;rft.au=Cellini%2C+Giovanni&amp;rft.aulast=Cellini&amp;rft.aufirst=Giovanni&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=92&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13691457&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F13691457.2015.1022713

Rediscovering the social question

Author: Lorenz, Walter11 Faculty of Educational Sciences, Free University of Bolzano, Franz-Innerhofer-Platz 8, Bozen-Bolzano, Italy

Publication info: European Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 19, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 4-17.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784139762?accountid=14667

Abstract: English: Neoliberal policies not only privatise formerly public services but also focus one-sidedly on discourses of individual autonomy and responsibility. This makes it difficult to raise 'the social question' (the question what constitutes social bonds) publicly since market principles are presented as allowing no alternatives. Social work owes its professional origins however to a shift from early capitalist individualism to policies recognising the need for social reconstruction and cohesion. It was mandated to reconcile the key principles of modernity, personal freedom and equality, although its methodology, often corresponding with social policy regimes, interpreted this mandate variably. Attempts in current social work to adjust to the cancellation of the social question through techniques of 'activation' and individualised care further the crisis of the project of modernity which manifests itself in a split between heightened public control measures and privatised concerns for 'care', thereby altering its core identity. Reflections on social work's historical position within varying political contexts help to promote a renewed critical examination of the profession's political role and highlight the need to turn interventions at the personal level into occasions that affirm social citizenship, ensure rights and promote social equality. German: Neoliberalismus bewirkt zunehmend nicht nur die Privatisierung öffentlicher Dienste, sondern auch eine einseitige Betonung individueller Autonomie und Verantwortung. Damit wird „die soziale Frage“ aus der öffentlichen Diskussion eliminiert und Marktprinzipien gelten zunehmend als alternativlos. Historisch gesehen kam aber professionelle Soziale Arbeit gerade dadurch zustande, dass angesichts der soziale Bindungen zersetzenden Wirkungen des Frühkapitalismus die soziale Frage gestellt werden musste um nicht anomische soziale Zustände zu riskieren. Damit erhielt die Profession das Mandat, die Kernprinzipien des Projekts der Moderne, persönliche Freiheit und ausgleichende Gerechtigkeit zu einander in Beziehung zu setzen, wobei ihre Methodik sich immer mit den unterschiedlichen sozialpolitischen Modellen auseinandersetzte. Anpassungsversuche der Sozialen Arbeit an die fortschreitende Eliminierung der sozialen Frage in der Form von Aktivierungsmethoden und personenzentrierten Veränderungsstrategien verschärfen die Krise des Projekts der Moderne, die sich hauptsächlich in der progressiven Spaltung zwischen verstärkten Kontrollmaßnahmen in öffentlicher Hand und privatisierter Verantwortung für „Helfen“ zeigt. Die Besinnung auf die Rolle der Sozialen Arbeit in unterschiedlichen politischen Kontexten während ihrer Geschichte ermöglicht eine kritische Stellungnahme zu ihrer gegenwärtigen politischen Vereinnahmung. Dies wiederum verändert das Herangehen an personenbezogene Interventionen in die Richtung, dass es dabei um das Praktizieren von bedingungsloser, rechtsverbindlicher und sozial gerechter Inklusion in die Gesellschaft geht. Dutch: Een neoliberaal beleid privatiseert niet enkel publieke voorzieningen maar focust ook eenzijdig op een discours van individuele autonomie en verantwoordelijkheid. Dit maakt het moeilijk om de sociale kwestie (de vraag naar sociale verbanden tussen mensen) publiek onder de aandacht te brengen gezien marktprincipes worden voorgesteld alsof er geen alternatieven zijn. Het sociaal werk is echter als professie ontstaan in de beweging van een vroeg kapitalistisch individualisme naar een beleid gericht op het erkennen van de nood aan sociale cohesie. Het mandaat van het sociaal werk was om de kernprincipes van de moderniteit—vrijheid en gelijkheid—te verzoenen, hoewel dit mandaat in relatie tot tot verschillende sociaal beleidsregimes methodologisch vaak variabel werd geïnterpreteerd. Actueel onderneemt het sociaal werk pogingen om zich aan te passen aan het verdwijnen van de vraag naar de sociale kwestie door het benadrukken van technieken van activering en individuele zorg. Deze technieken versterken echter de crisis van het project van de moderniteit die zich manifesteert in de split tussen maatregelen voor verhoogde publieke controle and geprivatiseerde bekommernissen voor zorg en veranderen alsdusdanig de identiteit van het sociaal werk. Nadenken over het sociaal werk haar historische positie binnen varierende politieke contexten kan bijdragen tot een kritisch onderzoek van de professie haar politieke rol. Dit belicht de noodzaak om interventies op het persoonlijke niveau om te turnen tot interventies die sociaal burgerschap versterken, rechten waarborgen en sociale gelijkheid promoten.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Rediscovering+the+social+question&amp;rft.au=Lorenz%2C+Walter&amp;rft.aulast=Lorenz&amp;rft.aufirst=Walter&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=4&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13691457&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F13691457.2015.1082984

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Rediscovering+the+social+question&amp;rft.au=Lorenz%2C+Walter&amp;rft.aulast=Lorenz&amp;rft.aufirst=Walter&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=4&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13691457&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F13691457.2015.1082984

Subject: Freedom; Responsibility; Autonomy; Citizenship; Identity; Equality; Rights; Individualism; Modernity; Neoliberalism; Social cohesion; Civil rights; Social policy; Social work; Public services; Social identity

Identifier / keyword: crisis of modernity neoliberalism social question social work history activation Krise der Moderne Neoliberalismus Soziale Frage Geschichte der Sozialarbeit Aktivierung crisis van de moderniteit neo-liberalisme sociale kwestie geschiedenis van het sociaal werk

Title: Rediscovering the social question

Alternate title: Die Soziale Frage erneut stellen - eine Herausforderung für die Soziale Arbeit De herontdekking van de sociale kwestie

Social work as a bureaucratic professional labour: an empirical analysis in non-profit organizations in northern Portugal

Author: Caria, Telmo H1; Pereira, Fernando A21 Faculdade de Psicologia e de Ciências da Educação, CIIE - Centro de Investigação e Intervenção Educativas, Universidade do Porto, Porto, Portugal2 Faculdade de Psicologia e de Ciências da Educação, CIIE - Centro de Investigação e Intervenção Educativas, Universidade do Porto, Porto, Portugal; Instituto Politécnico de Bragança, Nucleus for the Elderly Research and Intervention, Bragança, Portugal

Publication info: European Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 19, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 120-139.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784139950?accountid=14667

Abstract: English: In the last decade and a half, a new perspective on sociological analysis of professional groups has gradually emerged: professionalism and professionalization are no longer analysed as opposed to bureaucracies. In a previous article, we developed an analytical model in which we theorized a hybrid concept of Bureaucratic Professional Work (BPW), based on a theoretical hypothesis of association between various organizational forms (divisional bureaucracies, professional bureaucracies, neo-bureaucracies and post-bureaucracies) and different types of professional work in social work. Structured interviews were conducted with 63 social work professionals who work in 35 non-profit organizations of social services in northern Portugal. We questioned how these professionals perceive their own work in relation to the level of control and centralization of decisions, the routine of procedures and the predictability of results. We also study how social constraints, the tasks performed and work in multidisciplinary teams vary according to the type of BPW. This allows us to detail the modalities of the BPW and set out exploratory hypotheses for other more extensive quantitative studies as well as complementary studies of a qualitative nature. Portuguese: Na última década e meia uma nova perspetiva de análise sociológica sobre os grupos profissionais tem progressivamente emergido: o profissionalismo e a profissionalização deixaram de ser analisados em oposição com as burocracias. Num artigo prévio desenvolvemos um modelo de análise em que teorizámos o conceito híbrido de trabalho profissional burocrático (TPB) com base numa hipótese teórica de associação entre formas organizacionais variadas (burocracias divisionárias, burocracias profissionais, neoburocracias e pós-burocracias) e diferentes tipos de serviço social profissionalizado. Os dados resultam de entrevistas estruturadas com 63 profissionais de trabalho social que trabalham em 35 organizações não lucrativas (ONL) de serviços sociais do norte de Portugal. Questionamos a forma como estes profissionais percecionam o seu próprio trabalho em relação ao nível de controlo e centralização de decisões, de rotinização de procedimentos e de previsibilidade de resultados. Também estudamos a forma como os constrangimentos sociais, as tarefas realizadas e a trabalho profissional em equipas multidisciplinares varia segundo o tipo de TPB. Isto permitiu entrar no detalhe e no pormenor das modalidades de existência do TPB e colocar hipóteses exploratórias para outros estudos quantitativos mais extensivos e para estudos complementares de natureza qualitativa.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+work+as+a+bureaucratic+professional+labour%3A+an+empirical+analysis+in+non-profit+organizations+in+northern+Portugal&amp;rft.au=Caria%2C+Telmo+H%3BPereira%2C+Fernando+A&amp;rft.aulast=Caria&amp;rft.aufirst=Telmo&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=120&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13691457&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F13691457.2014.996533

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+work+as+a+bureaucratic+professional+labour%3A+an+empirical+analysis+in+non-profit+organizations+in+northern+Portugal&amp;rft.au=Caria%2C+Telmo+H%3BPereira%2C+Fernando+A&amp;rft.aulast=Caria&amp;rft.aufirst=Telmo&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=120&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13691457&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F13691457.2014.996533

Subject: Groups; Centralization; Decisions; Professionalization; Professionalism; Tasks; Teamwork; Social services; Social work; Work organization

Title: Social work as a bureaucratic professional labour: an empirical analysis in non-profit organizations in northern Portugal

Are we ready for them? Overseas-qualified social workers&apos; professional cultural transition

Author: Fouché, Christa1; Beddoe, Liz1; Bartley, Allen1; Parkes, Eleanor11 School of Counselling, Human Services and Social Work, University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand

Publication info: European Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 19, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 106-119.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784139965?accountid=14667

Abstract: Developing sociocultural competence in a new country is essential for migrants practising social work within new and distinct cultures. An argument for interventions needed to support the cultural transitioning of a migrant social work workforce is made, informed by findings from a mixed methods study of the experiences of overseas-qualified social workers in New Zealand. One of the main findings relates to migrant social workers&apos; professional adaptation to the new environment. We focus the discussion here on how the perceptions and practices regarding the cultural dimensions of the transition informed their adaptation. Although this is a highly contextual example of social work practice in a foreign setting, the dynamics have equivalents in many international contexts as migration of labour is common globally. We argue that a greater focus on the migrant workforce is required in debates on globalisation. The discussion of the findings will highlight the need for culturally informed interventions to enable an increasingly global workforce to successfully make a professional cultural transition.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Are+we+ready+for+them%3F+Overseas-qualified+social+workers%26amp%3Bapos%3B+professional+cultural+transition&amp;rft.au=Fouch%C3%A9%2C+Christa%3BBeddoe%2C+Liz%3BBartley%2C+Allen%3BParkes%2C+Eleanor&amp;rft.aulast=Fouch%C3%A9&amp;rft.aufirst=Christa&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=106&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13691457&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F13691457.2015.1022858

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Are+we+ready+for+them%3F+Overseas-qualified+social+workers%26amp%3Bapos%3B+professional+cultural+transition&amp;rft.au=Fouch%C3%A9%2C+Christa%3BBeddoe%2C+Liz%3BBartley%2C+Allen%3BParkes%2C+Eleanor&amp;rft.aulast=Fouch%C3%A9&amp;rft.aufirst=Christa&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=106&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=European+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13691457&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F13691457.2015.1022858

Strain, Psychological Conflicts, Aspirations-Attainment Gap, and Depressive Tendencies among Youth of Mexican Immigrants

Author: Paat, Yok-Fong11 University of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, Texas, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 1,  (Jan/Feb 2016): 19-29.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784146254?accountid=14667

Abstract: Using Children of Immigrants Longitudinal Study (CILS), this study examined the links between strain, psychological conflicts, aspiration-attainment gap, and depressive tendencies of 755 youth of Mexican origin. Two research questions were raised: (a) What types of strain and psychological conflict induced depressive tendencies? (b) What types of aspirations were relevant to these depressive symptoms? Overall, this study showed that factors implicated by collision of values, perceived discrepancies between aspiration and attainment, and negative appraisal of self could induce depressive mood, feelings, and behaviors, an important finding revealing that this underserved population can benefit from better public health services.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Strain%2C+Psychological+Conflicts%2C+Aspirations-Attainment+Gap%2C+and+Depressive+Tendencies+among+Youth+of+Mexican+Immigrants&amp;rft.au=Paat%2C+Yok-Fong&amp;rft.aulast=Paat&amp;rft.aufirst=Yok-Fong&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=19&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1087910

Connecting Refugees to Substance Use Treatment: A Qualitative Study

Author: McCleary, Jennifer S1; Shannon, Patricia J2; Cook, Tonya L21 Tulane University School of Social Work, New Orleans, Louisiana, USA2 University of Minnesota School of Social Work, Minneapolis, Minnesota, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 1,  (Jan/Feb 2016): 1-8.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784146372?accountid=14667

Abstract: An emerging body of literature identifies substance use as a growing concern among refugees resettling in the United States. Like immigrants, refugees may face cultural, linguistic, or systems barriers to connecting with mainstream substance use treatment programs, which may be compounded by refugees&apos; unique experiences with exposure to trauma, displacement in refugee camps, and resettlement. This qualitative study explores factors that support and prevent refugees from connecting with chemical health treatment. Fifteen participants who identified as social service or public health professionals who work with refugees responded to an online, semistructured survey about their experiences referring refugees to substance use treatment. Resulting data was analyzed using thematic analysis. Themes emerged identifying a lack of culturally informed treatment models, policy issues, and client characteristics such as motivation and past trauma as barriers to engaging with treatment. Ongoing case management and coordination were identified as important to successful linkage. Findings from this study contribute to a better understanding of how to support refugees seeking substance use treatment and suggest that developing trauma informed, culturally relevant models of treatment that are integrated with primary health care and geographically accessible may enhance treatment linkage.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Connecting+Refugees+to+Substance+Use+Treatment%3A+A+Qualitative+Study&amp;rft.au=McCleary%2C+Jennifer+S%3BShannon%2C+Patricia+J%3BCook%2C+Tonya+L&amp;rft.aulast=McCleary&amp;rft.aufirst=Jennifer&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1087906

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Connecting+Refugees+to+Substance+Use+Treatment%3A+A+Qualitative+Study&amp;rft.au=McCleary%2C+Jennifer+S%3BShannon%2C+Patricia+J%3BCook%2C+Tonya+L&amp;rft.aulast=McCleary&amp;rft.aufirst=Jennifer&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1087906

An Integrative Approach to Conceptualizing and Treating Complex Trauma

Author: Mahoney, Donna1; Markel, Brandon21 Illinois School of Professional Psychology/Schaumburg, Schaumburg, Illinois, USA2 Wheaton Franciscan Healthcare, Northbrook, Illinois, USA

Publication info: Psychoanalytic Social Work ; Abingdon  Vol. 23, Iss. 1,  (Jan/Jun 2016): 1-22.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794673623?accountid=14667

Abstract: Complex trauma (CT) often presents with polymorphous symptoms (i.e., emotional dysregulation, dissociation, somatic distress) resulting from repeated and chronic exposure to traumatic stressors. While the public is increasingly aware of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and its accompanying symptoms, the phenomena of complex trauma is less recognized and understood. Since the trauma reactions with CT typically occur during childhood, and the symptoms go well beyond PTSD, the authors of this article assert that an integrative approach is needed that synthesizes the most effective elements of cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) while blending a self-psychological approach. A review of the literature addresses the definition of complex trauma, cognitive-behavioral conceptualizations and treatment approaches, self-psychological models, current theories of attachment, and advances in neuropsychoanalysis. An integrative model is then proposed, supported by clinicians in the trauma field, identifying three intertwined phases of treatment.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=An+Integrative+Approach+to+Conceptualizing+and+Treating+Complex+Trauma&amp;rft.au=Mahoney%2C+Donna%3BMarkel%2C+Brandon&amp;rft.aulast=Mahoney&amp;rft.aufirst=Donna&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15228878&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228878.2015.1104640

Transference-Love and Institutional Involvement in a Case of Psychotherapy Supervision

Author: Alfandary, Rony11 Postgraduate Program of Psychoanalytic Psychotherapy, Bar Ilan University, Ramat Gan, Israel

Publication info: Psychoanalytic Social Work ; Abingdon  Vol. 23, Iss. 1,  (Jan/Jun 2016): 60-71.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794673759?accountid=14667

Abstract: Transference-love in supervision remains a relatively unexplored subject in psychotherapy. This article describes and analyzes an incident of the supervision of a student whose dress code raised a question regarding the existence of transference-love. The role of the institution in maintaining a protective envelope is shown to be significant in the satisfactory resolution of what appeared to have been an impasse. In addition, multicultural and gender issues are examined to illustrate the complexity of the subject.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Transference-Love+and+Institutional+Involvement+in+a+Case+of+Psychotherapy+Supervision&amp;rft.au=Alfandary%2C+Rony&amp;rft.aulast=Alfandary&amp;rft.aufirst=Rony&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=60&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15228878&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228878.2015.1104513

Womanhood as Experienced in Childbirth: Psychoanalytic Explorations of the Body

Author: Hall, Caroline11 Department of Psychiatry, Georgetown University Hospital, Washington, District of Columbia, USA; Private Practice, Arlington, Virginia, USA

Publication info: Psychoanalytic Social Work ; Abingdon  Vol. 23, Iss. 1,  (Jan/Jun 2016): 42-59.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794674590?accountid=14667

Abstract: Evaluating data from interviews with 30 first-time mothers predelivery and postdelivery reveals three pertinent themes: fear of bodily damage, immense pride and awe about producing a baby, and circumscribed terms of true womanhood. Data demonstrate an evolving pressure on some women to deliver vaginally without medical intervention or pain medication and to nurse a baby exclusively without formula as a marker of womanhood. Psychoanalytic theorists have explored the unique trajectory of growth from girlhood to womanhood wrestling with the unconscious meanings of pregnancy and motherhood. Not enough focus has been placed on the unconscious meanings of actual childbirth itself. Qualitative data illustrate the current social pressure on women to adhere to an unspoken norm regarding womanhood. This article examines contemporary issues of awe, fear, and performance anxiety reported by childbearing women and evidences a need to augment our understanding of female psychosexual development around unconscious tasks unique to giving birth.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Womanhood+as+Experienced+in+Childbirth%3A+Psychoanalytic+Explorations+of+the+Body&amp;rft.au=Hall%2C+Caroline&amp;rft.aulast=Hall&amp;rft.aufirst=Caroline&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=42&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15228878&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228878.2015.1073161

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Womanhood+as+Experienced+in+Childbirth%3A+Psychoanalytic+Explorations+of+the+Body&amp;rft.au=Hall%2C+Caroline&amp;rft.aulast=Hall&amp;rft.aufirst=Caroline&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=42&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15228878&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228878.2015.1073161

Case to Cause: Back to the Future

Author: Abramovitz, Mimi; Sherraden, Margaret S

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. sup1,  (2016): 89-.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1804219791?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reopens the historic debate about the roles of micro and macro practice in social work and encourages the profession to find ways to achieve a better balance between case and cause in education, practice, and research. To this end, it traces the history of the case versus cause debate including conceptual frameworks for rebalancing social work education: Bertha Capen Reynolds, C. Wright Mills, and William Schwartz, highlights three alternative approaches for resolving the dualism put forward over the years; separation, merger and interconnection; and identifies four model that help to bridge the gap by taking both the individual and the social structures into account: ecological, financial capabilities, trauma theory and oppression. This historical analysis offers promising directions for the social work profession as it tackles 21st-century social challenges, including growing inequality and austerity-driven public policies.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Case+to+Cause%3A+Back+to+the+Future&amp;rft.au=Abramovitz%2C+Mimi%3BSherraden%2C+Margaret+S&amp;rft.aulast=Abramovitz&amp;rft.aufirst=Mimi&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=sup1&amp;rft.spage=89&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1174638

Reconsidering Social Work 100 Years Post-Flexner: Where Are We Now, Where Are We Headed, What Has Been Gained, What Has Been Lost?

Author: Gelman, Caroline Rosenthal; González, Manny J

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. sup1,  (2016): 1-.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1804219798?accountid=14667

Abstract: A century has passed since Abraham Flexner deemed social work not to be a profession, and the field finds itself once again in a moment of questioning and redefining its nature, objectives, methods, and standing among the professions and in the academy. In this introduction we revisit Flexner&apos;s influential speech, review some of the critical issues facing social work today, and highlight the contributions of the 15 social work educators from schools all across the country, experts in social work research, practice, policy, and education, as they consider what social work has been, where it stands today, and what it should be as we look to the future.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Reconsidering+Social+Work+100+Years+Post-Flexner%3A+Where+Are+We+Now%2C+Where+Are+We+Headed%2C+What+Has+Been+Gained%2C+What+Has+Been+Lost%3F&amp;rft.au=Gelman%2C+Caroline+Rosenthal%3BGonz%C3%A1lez%2C+Manny+J&amp;rft.aulast=Gelman&amp;rft.aufirst=Caroline&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=sup1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1192932

Implementation Science: Why It Matters for the Future of Social Work

Author: Cabassa, Leopoldo J

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. sup1,  (2016): 38-.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1804219808?accountid=14667

Abstract: Bridging the gap between research and practice is a critical frontier for the future of social work. Integrating implementation science into social work can advance our profession&apos;s effort to bring research and practice closer together. Implementation science examines the factors, processes, and strategies that influence the uptake, use, and sustainability of empirically supported interventions, practice innovations, and social policies in routine practice settings. The aims of this article are to describe the key characteristics of implementation science, illustrate how implementation science matters to social work by describing several contributions this field can make to reducing racial and ethnic disparities in mental health care, and outline a training agenda to help integrate implementation science in graduate-level social work programs.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Implementation+Science%3A+Why+It+Matters+for+the+Future+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Cabassa%2C+Leopoldo+J&amp;rft.aulast=Cabassa&amp;rft.aufirst=Leopoldo&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=sup1&amp;rft.spage=38&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1174648

Plurality and Fragmentation in Social Work: Analyzing the Implications of Flexner Using a Philosophy of Science Perspective

Author: Brady, Shane R; Moxley, David

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. sup1,  (2016): 74-.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1804219818?accountid=14667

Abstract: The authors examine how the profession&apos;s adaptation to Flexner&apos;s criteria influences the emergence of the neomedical model as the majoritarian paradigm within social work even in the face of a pluralism manifest by the existence of other competing paradigms. One endorses empowerment in social work, and the other embraces societal transformation in radical terms. Given this pluralism, we consider how fragmentation exists within the profession, such that two scenarios are useful in considering how social work will evolve as a profession: (a) seeking unity with a majoritarian paradigm in ascendancy as it attempts to co-opt the other two paradigms; or (b) fragmenting into multiple entities each with its own stance on society, theory of social issues, and models of practice.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Plurality+and+Fragmentation+in+Social+Work%3A+Analyzing+the+Implications+of+Flexner+Using+a+Philosophy+of+Science+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Brady%2C+Shane+R%3BMoxley%2C+David&amp;rft.aulast=Brady&amp;rft.aufirst=Shane&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=sup1&amp;rft.spage=74&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1174639

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Plurality+and+Fragmentation+in+Social+Work%3A+Analyzing+the+Implications+of+Flexner+Using+a+Philosophy+of+Science+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Brady%2C+Shane+R%3BMoxley%2C+David&amp;rft.aulast=Brady&amp;rft.aufirst=Shane&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=sup1&amp;rft.spage=74&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1174639

Applying Research to Enhance Capacity: A Unifying Purpose for an Integrated Profession

Author: Keenan, Elizabeth King

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. sup1,  (2016): 62-.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1804219830?accountid=14667

Abstract: For more than a century the social work profession has had a dual purpose: to promote individual well-being and social justice, but the micro-macro divide is fragmenting the profession. This article suggests that the profession&apos;s aim might best be realized by adopting a unifying purpose, a just sense of well-being. Research on complex adaptive systems conceptualizes a unifying purpose as vertical integration carried out in differentiated ways in discrete moments of practice in various settings. Interpersonal neurobiology and Aristotle&apos;s interdependence of character virtues and practical judgment inform a corresponding shift from the dualities of personal and professional to the social worker as a person with differentiated professional capacities and activities. Integration with differentiation enhances capacity to promote the profession&apos;s purpose.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Applying+Research+to+Enhance+Capacity%3A+A+Unifying+Purpose+for+an+Integrated+Profession&amp;rft.au=Keenan%2C+Elizabeth+King&amp;rft.aulast=Keenan&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=sup1&amp;rft.spage=62&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1174640

Teaching to Transform? Addressing Race and Racism in the Teaching of Clinical Social Work Practice

Author: Varghese, Rani

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. sup1,  (2016): 134-.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1804219832?accountid=14667

Abstract: Faculty members are key stakeholders to support social work students&apos; learning about race and racism in practice and to promote the professional standards established by the field. This qualitative study examines how 15 clinical social work faculty members teaching advanced practice in the Northeast conceptualize and incorporate their understanding of race and racism in their teaching. An analysis of participants&apos; responses to a case vignette suggests clinical social work faculty members view race primarily as an individual ethnic or cultural identity and lack conceptual, historical, and sociological knowledge about racism and its links to other forms of oppression. This study suggests that additional faculty development opportunities and institutional support are needed to encourage faculty efforts to address race and racism.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Teaching+to+Transform%3F+Addressing+Race+and+Racism+in+the+Teaching+of+Clinical+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=Varghese%2C+Rani&amp;rft.aulast=Varghese&amp;rft.aufirst=Rani&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=sup1&amp;rft.spage=134&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1174646

PhD Versus DSW: A Critique of Trends in Social Work Doctoral Education

Author: Howard, Tyriesa

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. sup1,  (2016): 148-.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1804219836?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work educators are in a phase of reintroducing the doctor of social work (DSW) degree and refining distinctions between PhD and DSW doctoral programs. This article examines how the two options have been prey to a noticeable seesaw of precedence, resulting in a debatable history of social work&apos;s approach to doctoral education that is yet to be discussed in a manner leading to the profession&apos;s acknowledgment of the quandary. It is essential for those in social work education to be progressive and abreast of emergent needs; however, it is also critical to be cognizant of the far-reaching implications associated with major educational shifts to avoid an identity crisis stemming from outside criticism potentially similar to Abraham Flexner&apos;s report on social work&apos;s ambiguity as a profession.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=PhD+Versus+DSW%3A+A+Critique+of+Trends+in+Social+Work+Doctoral+Education&amp;rft.au=Howard%2C+Tyriesa&amp;rft.aulast=Howard&amp;rft.aufirst=Tyriesa&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=sup1&amp;rft.spage=148&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1174647

Recasting Licensing in Social Work: Something More for Professionalism

Author: Grise-Owens, Erlene; Owens, Larry W; Miller, Justin Jay

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. sup1,  (2016): 126-.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1804219840?accountid=14667

Abstract: Abraham Flexner contended that "something more than a degree or claim" is needed to make a profession. He further asserted that the definitions of a profession require recasting over time. This article critically considers recasting licensing as something more for social work. Analysis of past and present discourse on licensing in social work revealed three overarching themes: (a) advocacy and rationale for licensing, (b) scrutiny and critique of licensing, and (c) the disconnect and dissonance between professional licensing and social work education. Moving forward, we suggest recasting social work&apos;s professional paradigm in the common framework of competency, with licensing part of the continuum of professionalization. This recasting can promote critical congruence between social work education and ongoing professional competency.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Recasting+Licensing+in+Social+Work%3A+Something+More+for+Professionalism&amp;rft.au=Grise-Owens%2C+Erlene%3BOwens%2C+Larry+W%3BMiller%2C+Justin+Jay&amp;rft.aulast=Grise-Owens&amp;rft.aufirst=Erlene&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=sup1&amp;rft.spage=126&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1174641

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Recasting+Licensing+in+Social+Work%3A+Something+More+for+Professionalism&amp;rft.au=Grise-Owens%2C+Erlene%3BOwens%2C+Larry+W%3BMiller%2C+Justin+Jay&amp;rft.aulast=Grise-Owens&amp;rft.aufirst=Erlene&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=sup1&amp;rft.spage=126&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1174641

____________________________________________________________

Salir adelante (perseverance): Lessons from the Mexican immigrant experience

Author: Hanna, Ashley-Marie Vollmer1; Ortega, Debora Marie11 University of Denver, USA; University of Denver, USA

Publication info: Journal of Social Work ; London  Vol. 16, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 47-65.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1808601267?accountid=14667

Abstract: Summary Although migration and immigrant issues have been well studied in sociology, economics, and demography there is significantly less information specific to Latino immigrants within the field of social work. This is of particular concern as the population of Latino immigrants and their children continues to grow and access areas of social work practice and policy development. This research study focuses on understanding the experience of first-generation immigrants of Mexican origin living in Denver, Colorado, through the use of qualitative research methods. Seven Mexican immigrants living in Denver described their experience through an in-depth interview process. Grounded theory was the chosen method for analysis. Findings Four themes emerged during the data analysis process: (1) 'We are working people'; (2) 'I am not an animal' (experiencing racism, prejudice and discrimination); (3) fear; and (4) internal strength. Together these themes create a conceptual framework that is useful as a starting place to understand the lives and culture of Mexican immigrants. This conceptual framework highlights how immigrants negotiate racism, prejudice, discrimination, and fear through their strong work ethic and the belief in their ability to ' salir adelante ' (to persevere or better oneself or one's family situation). Applications Results indicate that Mexican immigrants are faced with numerous challenges, particularly due to racist laws, discriminatory procedures, and acts of prejudice. However, results also suggest that Mexican immigrants and their cultural resources provide a source of hope, allowing them to persevere even as they face challenges. The findings have several implications for direct service, advocacy and social justice, and social work education.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Salir+adelante+%28perseverance%29%3A+Lessons+from+the+Mexican+immigrant+experience&amp;rft.au=Hanna%2C+Ashley-Marie+Vollmer%3BOrtega%2C+Debora+Marie&amp;rft.aulast=Hanna&amp;rft.aufirst=Ashley-Marie&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=47&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017314560301

____________________________________________________________

Models of adult safeguarding in England: A review of the literature

Author: Graham, Katherine1; Norrie, Caroline1; Stevens, Martin1; Moriarty, Jo1; Manthorpe, Jill1; Hussein, Shereen11 Social Care Workforce Research Unit (SCWRU), King's College London, UK; Social Care Workforce Research Unit (SCWRU), King's College London, England; Social Care Workforce Research Unit (SCWRU), King's College London, England; Social Care Workforce Research Unit (SCWRU), King's College London, England; Social Care Workforce Research Unit (SCWRU), King's College London, England; Social Care Workforce Research Unit (SCWRU), King's College London, England

Publication info: Journal of Social Work ; London  Vol. 16, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 22-46.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1808601304?accountid=14667

Abstract: Summary This article presents the findings of a narrative synthesis of literature published between January 2000 and September 2013 exploring the organisation of adult safeguarding services in England. The review sought to identify the characteristics of safeguarding practice, which may be important for local authorities to consider when choosing between models of organisation. Findings The findings suggest that the development of adult safeguarding policy and practice has prompted local authorities to develop specialist safeguarding roles. The implications of specialism have not been extensively explored. However, several important characteristics of safeguarding practice are identifiable from the literature including specialism within the organisation of adult safeguarding; decision-making and thresholds for safeguarding response; and multi-agency working. Applications The review found limited evidence relating to the organisation of adult safeguarding, which suggests that further empirical research is needed. The critical features of safeguarding practice identified here comprise a useful starting point from which to explore the implications of different 'models' of safeguarding organisation.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Models+of+adult+safeguarding+in+England%3A+A+review+of+the+literature&amp;rft.au=Graham%2C+Katherine%3BNorrie%2C+Caroline%3BStevens%2C+Martin%3BMoriarty%2C+Jo%3BManthorpe%2C+Jill%3BHussein%2C+Shereen&amp;rft.aulast=Graham&amp;rft.aufirst=Katherine&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=22&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017314556205

____________________________________________________________

Empowering the 'shamed' self: Recognition and critical social work

Author: Houston, Stan11 Queen's University Belfast, UK

Publication info: Journal of Social Work ; London  Vol. 16, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 3-21.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1808601338?accountid=14667

Abstract: Summary This article provides a review of the contribution of Axel Honneth's model of recognition for critical social work. While Honneth's tripartite conceptualisation of optimal identity-formation is positively appraised, his analysis of the link between misrecognition, the experience of shame and eventual sense of moral outrage, is contested. Drawing on a range of sources, including the sociology of shame, Honneth's ideas about the emotional antecedents of emancipatory action are revised to guide critical social work with misrecognised service users. Findings The intellectual background to Honneth's recognition model, emanating from leading German philosophers, is described and its application to social work set out. Even so, Honneth's model is found to be deficient in one primary regard: its assumption about the emotional antecedents to quests for withheld recognition is misapprehended. In particular, the argument in this article is that the ubiquitous emotion of shame, which Honneth argues flows from misrecognition, must be carefully addressed through the medium of relationship, otherwise it might lead to repressed shame and frustrated attempts at social struggle. To this end, a social work process is delineated for dealing with shame, following episodes of misrecognition. Applications Honneth's model of recognition, along with revised ideas about how to recognise and manage shame, is incorporated into a conceptual framework for critical social work practice. With this renewed understanding of the impact of shame, following misrecognition, social workers should be better equipped conceptually to enable service users to take action for empowerment.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Empowering+the+%27shamed%27+self%3A+Recognition+and+critical+social+work&amp;rft.au=Houston%2C+Stan&amp;rft.aulast=Houston&amp;rft.aufirst=Stan&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=3&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017314566789

____________________________________________________________

Negotiation of user identity and responsibility at a prerelease conference

Author: Berger, Nichlas Permin1; Eskelinen, Leena11 KORA (Danish Institute for Local and Regional Government Research), Copenhagen, Denmark; Department of Sociology and Social Work, Aalborg University, Aalborg, Denmark; KORA (Danish Institute for Local and Regional Government Research), Copenhagen, Denmark

Publication info: Qualitative Social Work ; London  Vol. 15, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 86-102.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1808704282?accountid=14667

Abstract: Recent political changes in the field of social work have sought to incorporate values of independence and client participation into social work practice. Such an ideological shift stresses user roles, agency, and clients' responsibility to play an active role in their rehabilitation and participate in decision-making processes. This reflects a move away from traditional paternalism, dependency, and professional control. Based on a single case of a prerelease conference in prison, this article investigates the complexity of social work practice in relation to user engagement in the social interaction between the inmate, his parents, and frontline professionals from prison and various welfare institutions. We explore how the participants negotiate the inmate's identity and find that the professionals' intention of engaging the inmate as a user and accentuating his responsibility creates a process in which different identity positions are at stake. The aim of engaging the inmate as a user conflicts with the two other identity categories, namely "client in need of support" and "victim of ADHD," demonstrating how different discourses are drawn upon by professionals and parents in talk. Despite the professionals' attempts to set the stage as client empowering, the analysis shows that the inmate is frequently presented as a dependent individual. This creates an ambivalent situation for the inmate, who responds with resistance against the situation. The findings discussed in this article highlight the complexity of engaging clients as users.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Qualitative+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Negotiation+of+user+identity+and+responsibility+at+a+prerelease+conference&amp;rft.au=Berger%2C+Nichlas+Permin%3BEskelinen%2C+Leena&amp;rft.aulast=Berger&amp;rft.aufirst=Nichlas&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=86&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Qualitative+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14733250&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1473325015585161

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Qualitative+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Negotiation+of+user+identity+and+responsibility+at+a+prerelease+conference&amp;rft.au=Berger%2C+Nichlas+Permin%3BEskelinen%2C+Leena&amp;rft.aulast=Berger&amp;rft.aufirst=Nichlas&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=86&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Qualitative+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14733250&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1473325015585161

Communicating parent community at prevention meetings in Norwegian schools

Author: Henriksen, Øystein1; Hydén, Lars Christer11 University of Nordland, Bodø, Norway; Linköping University, Linköping, Sweden

Publication info: Qualitative Social Work ; London  Vol. 15, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 55-69.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1808704651?accountid=14667

Abstract: Parental cooperation has increasingly become a key component in alcohol prevention efforts in schools. Many prevention programs actively utilize parent participation in order to strengthen the sense of community between parents, develop shared attitudes toward alcohol use, delay the beginning of alcohol use for adolescents, and limit alcohol usage by young people. Strengthening community is thus a core goal in prevention activities. This article analyses how community is developed and expressed in discussions during formal school meetings involving parents. The data used in the analysis consists of audio recordings of parent meetings in alcohol prevention programs for eighth-grade students at four separate schools in different regions of Norway. The analysis focuses on how personal pronouns are used in the conversations to signal inclusion or exclusion from the community. The article also discusses how different discursive expressions of community are used by meeting participants to position themselves as responsible parents, and the relevance of these meetings for social work.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Qualitative+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Communicating+parent+community+at+prevention+meetings+in+Norwegian+schools&amp;rft.au=Henriksen%2C+%C3%98ystein%3BHyd%C3%A9n%2C+Lars+Christer&amp;rft.aulast=Henriksen&amp;rft.aufirst=%C3%98ystein&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=55&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Qualitative+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14733250&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1473325015577155

____________________________________________________________

To plan or not to plan: The internal conversations of young people leaving care

Author: Hung, Isabelle1; Appleton, Peter11 University of Essex, UK; Persistent Pain Service, Mile End Hospital, London, UK; University of Essex, UK

Publication info: Qualitative Social Work ; London  Vol. 15, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 35-54.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1808707615?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this research is to characterise the internal conversations of individual young people in transition from state care, with a goal of supporting practitioners' approaches to 'pathway planning', and contributing to theories of agency in emerging adulthood under conditions of long-term adversity. We used Margaret Archer's theory of agency, in which internal conversations are regarded as playing a central role in mediating between structure and agency. Archer describes three different modes of (actively agential) internal conversation: communicative reflexivity, autonomous reflexivity and meta-reflexivity; and one mode of passive agency: fractured reflexivity - associated with adverse contextual constraints. In a qualitative design, using Archer's open-ended interview framework we met nine participants, aged 19-24, varying considerably in outcome, recruited at a specialised service for care leavers in London UK. Analysis of the interview data included an extended phase of individual case analysis. Two participants experienced emerging active agency (however, both experienced elements of fractured reflexivity). Three participants experienced fractured reflexivity, with limited internal conversation, and low planning agency (however, each experienced green shoots of focused internal dialogue). Four participants experienced a survival-oriented mode of internal conversations, a category not found in Archer's previous work. All four of these participants showed some elements of fractured reflexivity, but narrated rich internal conversations, including accounts of adverse experiences in which self-reliance was seen as having been essential. The majority of participants (across modes) found the idea of planning (beyond day-to-day) anathema.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Qualitative+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=To+plan+or+not+to+plan%3A+The+internal+conversations+of+young+people+leaving+care&amp;rft.au=Hung%2C+Isabelle%3BAppleton%2C+Peter&amp;rft.aulast=Hung&amp;rft.aufirst=Isabelle&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=35&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Qualitative+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14733250&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1473325015577408

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Qualitative+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=To+plan+or+not+to+plan%3A+The+internal+conversations+of+young+people+leaving+care&amp;rft.au=Hung%2C+Isabelle%3BAppleton%2C+Peter&amp;rft.aulast=Hung&amp;rft.aufirst=Isabelle&amp;rft.date=2016-01-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=35&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Qualitative+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14733250&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1473325015577408

____________________________________________________________

One-eyed mules and social work: An essay on serendipity

Author: Shaw, Ian

Publication info: Qualitative Social Work ; London  Vol. 15, Iss. 1,  (Jan 2016): 136-149.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1808707762?accountid=14667

Abstract: A review essay on a book by R. K. Merton and E. Barber, The Travels and Adventures of Serendipity (2004).
