____________________________________________________________

&quot;We have to help each other heal&quot;: The path to recovery and becoming a professional peer support

Author: Mendoza, Natasha S; Resko, Stella; Wohlert, Beverly; Baldwin, Adrienne

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment ; Abingdon  Vol. 26, Iss. 2,  (2016): 137.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753379414?accountid=14667

Abstract: Over the past decade, the peer support role in the treatment of substance use disorders has become increasingly formalized. With the growing popularity of peer support interventions, it is imperative to understand the unique role of peer support specialists (PSSs). The current study is focused on women&apos;s roles as PSSs. Understanding women&apos;s paths toward their peer support work through their experiences is essential for the continued formalization of peer support interventions designed for women working in gender-specific community-based treatment settings. The major aim of this study was to explore and describe how female PSSs working in a gender-specific treatment setting evolved from being in recovery to coaching recovery. We conducted in-depth qualitative interviews to examine PSS&apos;s experiences and attitudes toward their work. Results reinforced prominent feminist psychological developmental theory, an important implication for practice.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=%26amp%3Bquot%3BWe+have+to+help+each+other+heal%26amp%3Bquot%3B%3A+The+path+to+recovery+and+becoming+a+professional+peer+support&amp;rft.au=Mendoza%2C+Natasha+S%3BResko%2C+Stella%3BWohlert%2C+Beverly%3BBaldwin%2C+Adrienne&amp;rft.aulast=Mendoza&amp;rft.aufirst=Natasha&amp;rft.date=2016-02-15&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=137&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

A new approach to motivation: Four-drive model

Author: Shafi, Ayaz Ahmed; Khemka, Meenakshi; Choudhury, Sayantani Roy

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment ; Abingdon  Vol. 26, Iss. 2,  (2016): 217.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753379427?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents a new approach to the field of motivation. To start, it reviews the previously available literature in the field and analyzes some of the more popular theories and finds the gaps. A new model is put forward, which aims to cover the relevant parameters -- as well as to plug the identified gaps. The model proposes four types of drives -- sensual, material, emotional, and spiritual. A quantitative study was done to validate the proposed theory and to have a better understanding in identifying the socioeconomic parameters that are significant in predicting which drive is likely to dominate in a person. Using the proposed theory and the results from the quantitative analysis, a model for motivation is proposed. This research is part of an ongoing research effort to test, validate, and generalize the proposed model.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=A+new+approach+to+motivation%3A+Four-drive+model&amp;rft.au=Shafi%2C+Ayaz+Ahmed%3BKhemka%2C+Meenakshi%3BChoudhury%2C+Sayantani+Roy&amp;rft.aulast=Shafi&amp;rft.aufirst=Ayaz&amp;rft.date=2016-02-15&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=217&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The utility of the DSM-5 Z-codes for clinical social work diagnosis

Author: Walsh, Joseph

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment ; Abingdon  Vol. 26, Iss. 2,  (2016): 149.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753379446?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM) is the standard reference text used by social workers for diagnosing mental disorders. The social work profession has always had an uneasy relationship with the DSM, but for 33 years there was an opportunity to note a client&apos;s psychosocial stressors on Axis IV. With the publication of the DSM-5, however, the multiaxial diagnostic system was abandoned, and many social workers are concerned that this change limits their ability to provide comprehensive diagnoses. The purpose of this article is to consider an expanded use of Z-codes as one way to continue including social work&apos;s psychosocial perspective on human functioning in the diagnostic process.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=The+utility+of+the+DSM-5+Z-codes+for+clinical+social+work+diagnosis&amp;rft.au=Walsh%2C+Joseph&amp;rft.aulast=Walsh&amp;rft.aufirst=Joseph&amp;rft.date=2016-02-15&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=149&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Supportive exits: A best practices report for a sex worker intervention

Author: Preble, Kathleen M; Praetorius, Regina T; Cimino, Andrea

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment ; Abingdon  Vol. 26, Iss. 2,  (2016): 162.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753379508?accountid=14667

Abstract: Despite the prevalence of agencies serving sex workers in the United States, there are few program evaluations of supportive services. Phenomenological methods were used to explore the lived experiences of 13 sex workers receiving supportive services in a major city in the American Southwest. Results from this study suggest that clients find the trusted and supportive community within the agency especially helpful. Length of time with the agency influenced respondents&apos; perceptions of supportive services. Respondents, however, suggested improvements to services such as mentorship programs, opportunities for outreach participation, and services for male sex workers.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Supportive+exits%3A+A+best+practices+report+for+a+sex+worker+intervention&amp;rft.au=Preble%2C+Kathleen+M%3BPraetorius%2C+Regina+T%3BCimino%2C+Andrea&amp;rft.aulast=Preble&amp;rft.aufirst=Kathleen&amp;rft.date=2016-02-15&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=162&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

An exploratory study examining needs, access, and competent social services for the transgender community in Phoenix, Arizona

Author: Salisbury, Megan E; Dentato, Michael P

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment ; Abingdon  Vol. 26, Iss. 2,  (2016): 119.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753379592?accountid=14667

Abstract: Phoenix is the sixth largest city in the United States, with a vibrant yet underserved lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer (LGBTQ) population. Despite an extensive community presence, social service delivery bias persists among members of the LGBTQ community, but more often among transgender individuals. Existing research has examined social services from the perspective of either the client or the practitioner. This exploratory study specifically examines social services in the Phoenix metropolitan area for the transgender community. Data collected from interviews with participants and providers contributed to an assessment of the current level of social services for the transgender community, with a specific emphasis on identifying service gaps and recommendations for culturally competent and comprehensive services.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=An+exploratory+study+examining+needs%2C+access%2C+and+competent+social+services+for+the+transgender+community+in+Phoenix%2C+Arizona&amp;rft.au=Salisbury%2C+Megan+E%3BDentato%2C+Michael+P&amp;rft.aulast=Salisbury&amp;rft.aufirst=Megan&amp;rft.date=2016-02-15&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=119&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The language of money

Author: Smith, Thomas E; Richards, Kristin V; Shelton, Victoria M

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment ; Abingdon  Vol. 26, Iss. 2,  (2016): 202.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753379656?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article examines the relationship of personal finance in a narrative-based treatment strategy as applied to couples. It builds on behavioral economics as the undergirding of an approach to financial literacy. By matching the treatment strategy with the stages of readiness for change, couples are able to gradually adopt a financially prudent lifestyle. The authors argue that the couples&apos; conflicts about personal financial behaviors are a proxy of underlying problems in intimacy. The use of a narrative-based theory addresses how personal finances are used to control relationships.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=The+language+of+money&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Thomas+E%3BRichards%2C+Kristin+V%3BShelton%2C+Victoria+M&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Thomas&amp;rft.date=2016-02-15&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=202&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Lessons on social and health disparities from older lesbians with alcoholism and the role of interventions to promote culturally competent services

Author: Rowan, Noell L; Giunta, Nancy

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment ; Abingdon  Vol. 26, Iss. 2,  (2016): 210.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753379683?accountid=14667

Abstract: Older adults who are lesbian, gay, bisexual, or transgender (LGBT) face greater health risks and possibly more costly care because of their reluctance to seek out health and long-term care services because of limited cultural sensitivity of service providers. This is particularly evident in older lesbians who face substantial risk of health problems associated with alcoholism and are less likely to be open with health care providers because of stigma combined with feelings of alienation, stress, and depression. An estimated 4.4 million older adults are predicted to have problems with alcohol by 2020, and the rates of alcohol-related hospitalizations are similar to those for heart attacks, creating exorbitant medical costs. More culturally competent health and long-term care may reduce health care costs by effectively addressing the dynamics of alcoholism, aging, and lesbian culture. Training initiatives such as those developed by the National Resource Center on LGBT Aging have begun to address the need of a more culturally competent aging services network. This article provides exemplars from empirical data on older lesbians with alcoholism to highlight some of the health, economic, and social disparities experienced in the aging LGBT community. Current interventions in the form of cultural competence training for service providers are presented as a potential step toward addressing health disparities among LGBT older adults.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Lessons+on+social+and+health+disparities+from+older+lesbians+with+alcoholism+and+the+role+of+interventions+to+promote+culturally+competent+services&amp;rft.au=Rowan%2C+Noell+L%3BGiunta%2C+Nancy&amp;rft.aulast=Rowan&amp;rft.aufirst=Noell&amp;rft.date=2016-02-15&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=210&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Lessons+on+social+and+health+disparities+from+older+lesbians+with+alcoholism+and+the+role+of+interventions+to+promote+culturally+competent+services&amp;rft.au=Rowan%2C+Noell+L%3BGiunta%2C+Nancy&amp;rft.aulast=Rowan&amp;rft.aufirst=Noell&amp;rft.date=2016-02-15&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=210&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Mindfulness in financial literacy

Author: Smith, Thomas E; Richards, Kristin V; Shelton, Victoria M

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment ; Abingdon  Vol. 26, Iss. 2,  (2016): 154.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753379720?accountid=14667

Abstract: Financial education is becoming imperative in a society that has pitfalls for unwary consumers. To ensure effectiveness, educational strategies must take into consideration the readiness of consumers to learn the curriculum. Behavioral economics highlights the obstacles that educators face in promoting financial efficacy. Such obstacles include envy, fear, greed, and other all too familiar human failings. One innovative model, mindfulness, provides insight into the human dynamics of personal financial behaviors. This article ties together financial education, mindfulness techniques, and transtheoretical stages of readiness. The impact of gradually introduced educational tasks is presented with an eye toward clients&apos; stages of readiness, and mindfulness addresses the emotional burdens of altering a financially profligate lifestyle.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Mindfulness+in+financial+literacy&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Thomas+E%3BRichards%2C+Kristin+V%3BShelton%2C+Victoria+M&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Thomas&amp;rft.date=2016-02-15&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=154&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Listening to Words, Hearing Feelings: Links Between Eating Disorders and Alexithymia

Author: Barth, F Diane

Publication info: Clinical Social Work Journal ; New York  Vol. 44, Iss. 1,  (Mar 2016): 38-46.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1771404119?accountid=14667

Abstract: Issue Title: Special Issue: Body Meets Mind: Eating Disorders and Body Image - a 21st Century Perspective Research suggests that eating disorders often involve difficulty with affect regulation and processing of emotions. Studies also show that many individuals with these difficulties suffer from alexithymia, or an impaired ability to use language to tolerate or process emotions. Many clients with eating disorders are highly verbal, able to talk about feelings and even have good insight into the causes of their behaviors. Yet their verbal and cognitive strengths may disguise their inability to use thoughts to manage their emotions. Such clients often have a lifelong experience of appearing more capable and competent than they feel. Self-criticism and negative self-image concretized in a negative body image are part of their eating disorder. Therapeutic exploration can increase anxiety and self-criticism, aggravating feelings of inadequacy and the concomitant need for self-soothing. Techniques that focus on affect regulation have been shown to be effective, yet a psychodynamic approach can be an important tool in such an integrative practice. In this article, clinical material and theory will illustrate some of the ways that incorporating an understanding of alexithymia into the work can enhance the use of both psychodynamic exploration of meaning and also tools to manage affect and change behavior.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=Listening+to+Words%2C+Hearing+Feelings%3A+Links+Between+Eating+Disorders+and+Alexithymia&amp;rft.au=Barth%2C+F+Diane&amp;rft.aulast=Barth&amp;rft.aufirst=F&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=38&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=00911674&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10615-015-0541-6

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=Listening+to+Words%2C+Hearing+Feelings%3A+Links+Between+Eating+Disorders+and+Alexithymia&amp;rft.au=Barth%2C+F+Diane&amp;rft.aulast=Barth&amp;rft.aufirst=F&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=38&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=00911674&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10615-015-0541-6

Experiences, Burdens, and Support Needs in Siblings of Girls and Women with Anorexia Nervosa: Results from a Qualitative Interview Study

Author: Jungbauer, Johannes; Heibach, Jessica; Urban, Karl

Publication info: Clinical Social Work Journal ; New York  Vol. 44, Iss. 1,  (Mar 2016): 78-86.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1771404517?accountid=14667

Abstract: Issue Title: Special Issue: Body Meets Mind: Eating Disorders and Body Image - a 21st Century Perspective For many years, siblings of women and girls suffering from anorexia have been regarded as "the forgotten kin," as they have been overlooked by both researchers and clinicians. Therefore, the goal of this explorative study was to investigate siblings&apos; experiences, burdens, and support needs in a differentiated manner. Siblings (n = 16) of patients with an ICD-10 diagnosis "anorexia nervosa" (F 50.0) took part in a qualitative, in-depth interview study; the data were assessed using content analysis. The results of this study should be especially interesting for clinical social work. Using the findings, a variety of concrete recommendations for psycho-social practice can be made, for example regarding the inclusion of siblings in treatment settings, as well as specific support concepts for siblings of anorexic women and girls in different age groups.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=Experiences%2C+Burdens%2C+and+Support+Needs+in+Siblings+of+Girls+and+Women+with+Anorexia+Nervosa%3A+Results+from+a+Qualitative+Interview+Study&amp;rft.au=Jungbauer%2C+Johannes%3BHeibach%2C+Jessica%3BUrban%2C+Karl&amp;rft.aulast=Jungbauer&amp;rft.aufirst=Johannes&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=78&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=00911674&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10615-015-0569-7

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=Experiences%2C+Burdens%2C+and+Support+Needs+in+Siblings+of+Girls+and+Women+with+Anorexia+Nervosa%3A+Results+from+a+Qualitative+Interview+Study&amp;rft.au=Jungbauer%2C+Johannes%3BHeibach%2C+Jessica%3BUrban%2C+Karl&amp;rft.aulast=Jungbauer&amp;rft.aufirst=Johannes&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=78&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=00911674&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10615-015-0569-7

____________________________________________________________

Eating Disorder Treatment as a Process of Mind-Body Integration: Special Challenges for Women

Author: Sands, Susan H

Publication info: Clinical Social Work Journal ; New York  Vol. 44, Iss. 1,  (Mar 2016): 27-37.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1771404541?accountid=14667

Abstract: Issue Title: Special Issue: Body Meets Mind: Eating Disorders and Body Image - a 21st Century Perspective The concept of body image remains too focused on internal representation and not enough on internal experiencing. Body image is but one expression of the more foundational body self. When an eating disorder is conceptualized as an attempt to manage an impaired sense of body self (and associated disregulation), the ultimate goal of treatment becomes embodiment. The eating disordered body must be worked with as an actual as well as symbolic body and understood within its own developmental trajectory. The gender-specificity of eating disorders is explored by focusing on three particular bodily challenges for females in our society: (1) Women are more likely than men to unconsciously use their bodies as repositories for their dissociated need and desire, (2) girls&apos; bodies are mirrored in a more distorted and overstimulating manner than boys&apos; and (3) because girls are the same biological sex as their usual primary caretakers, they are more likely to be used as narcissistic extensions. A clinical example is presented, illustrating the influence of these female bodily challenges on the development of body self and eating disorders and how these issues play out in treatment. An intensive clinical focus on the patient&apos;s and therapist&apos;s body states allows for the desomatization and integration of dissociated affect, resulting in a more integrated body-mind self and a decreased need for an eating disorder.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=Eating+Disorder+Treatment+as+a+Process+of+Mind-Body+Integration%3A+Special+Challenges+for+Women&amp;rft.au=Sands%2C+Susan+H&amp;rft.aulast=Sands&amp;rft.aufirst=Susan&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=27&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=00911674&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10615-015-0540-7

Body Dissatisfaction and the Relevance of Religiosity: A Focus on Ultra-Orthodox Jews in a Community Study of Adult Women

Author: Feinson, Marjorie C; Hornik-lurie, Tzipi

Publication info: Clinical Social Work Journal ; New York  Vol. 44, Iss. 1,  (Mar 2016): 87-97.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1771404556?accountid=14667

Abstract: Issue Title: Special Issue: Body Meets Mind: Eating Disorders and Body Image - a 21st Century Perspective Body image dissatisfaction (BID) is one of the most robust risk factors associated with eating disturbances. However, much remains unknown about it especially regarding a potentially protective factor, namely religiosity. As shown in hundreds of studies, religiosity has consistently been associated with better health and mental health outcomes. Utilizing a large, community-based study of adult Jewish women, we compare ultra-Orthodox and Secular Jewish women, two groups at opposite ends of the religious observance spectrum. Detailed telephone interviews were conducted with a broadly representative sample of adult women (mean age 44) in Israel from distinct religious observance groups. Frequency of 13 BID symptoms was assessed in addition to two clinical correlates, weight and self-criticism. Separate hierarchical regressions use bootstrapping to explore predictors of BID severity within each group. Contrary to expectations, no significant differences in body dissatisfaction emerge between rigorously religious and non-religious Jewish respondents. In addition, the findings reveal surprisingly similar patterns of predictors of BID severity with self-criticism making a noteworthy contribution for both groups. However, despite strong similarities, it is premature to dismiss potentially protective aspects of religiosity vis-à-vis BID without additional studies. In the interim, clinical prevention and treatment interventions that focus on reducing self-criticism may be extremely important for addressing BID issues among adult women--regardless of degree of religious observance.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=Body+Dissatisfaction+and+the+Relevance+of+Religiosity%3A+A+Focus+on+Ultra-Orthodox+Jews+in+a+Community+Study+of+Adult+Women&amp;rft.au=Feinson%2C+Marjorie+C%3BHornik-lurie%2C+Tzipi&amp;rft.aulast=Feinson&amp;rft.aufirst=Marjorie&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=87&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=00911674&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10615-016-0574-5

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=Body+Dissatisfaction+and+the+Relevance+of+Religiosity%3A+A+Focus+on+Ultra-Orthodox+Jews+in+a+Community+Study+of+Adult+Women&amp;rft.au=Feinson%2C+Marjorie+C%3BHornik-lurie%2C+Tzipi&amp;rft.aulast=Feinson&amp;rft.aufirst=Marjorie&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=87&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=00911674&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10615-016-0574-5

Psychodynamic Issues in the Treatment of Binge Eating: Working with Shame, Secrets, No-Entry, and False Body Defenses

Author: Zerbe, Kathryn

Publication info: Clinical Social Work Journal ; New York  Vol. 44, Iss. 1,  (Mar 2016): 8-17.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1771404942?accountid=14667

Abstract: Issue Title: Special Issue: Body Meets Mind: Eating Disorders and Body Image - a 21st Century Perspective Two clinical moments from patients in treatment for Binge Eating Disorder (DSM 5) are described where a manifest problem with body image difficulty was initially denied. Each patient entered treatment with the desire to lose weight as well as gain a fuller understanding of self and mastery over addictive eating patterns that caused considerable psychological anguish. An integrated treatment matrix of practical, contemporary psychodynamic interventions and more behavioral, experiential and supportive tools allowed each patient to uncover and work through heretofore split off aspects of their bodily selves. Defense mechanisms such as &apos;no entry&apos; fantasies and &apos;the false body&apos; that have recently been described in the analytic literature are applied in formulating each case example. The author underscores how therapists must probe for secrets in the personal and family history that are &apos;hidden, but in plain view&apos; and pursue them in order for the patient to embrace a more coherent, true sense of her/his bodily self. These secrets often contain a less conscious rationale for treating the body poorly and perpetuating hated, shameful and derogatory aspects of body image that may become externalized onto the therapist. These externalizations can further complicate countertransference reactions that must be acknowledged and worked through by the therapist in personal or self-analysis.

The Intersubjective Experience of the Physical Body in the Clinical Setting of Eating Disorders

Author: Daly, Suzanne B

Publication info: Clinical Social Work Journal ; New York  Vol. 44, Iss. 1,  (Mar 2016): 47-56.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1771404990?accountid=14667

Abstract: Issue Title: Special Issue: Body Meets Mind: Eating Disorders and Body Image - a 21st Century Perspective This paper will illuminate one dimension of self-disclosure as it relates to the inescapable presence of the body in treatment, and the female clinician&apos;s ability to bring her physical body into clinical discussions during an encounter with a female client with an eating disorder. Although the clinical literature on eating disorders validates that transference and countertransference issues are particularly powerful, it generally neglects the exploration of these issues specific to the body&apos;s physical presentation. Since body dissatisfaction is increasingly normative for women today, female clinicians need to have a theoretical road map on which to rely when they encounter a shared body experience. Thus, in order to encourage discussions of the therapist&apos;s body in clinical social work practice, the body needs to be situated in a larger theoretical framework within which it can be explained and located; this framework is object relations theory viewed through an intersubjective lens. Concepts from object relations theory will demonstrate the importance of the body in the clinical exchange by highlighting the parallel between Winnicott&apos;s &apos;good enough&apos; mother and the &apos;good enough&apos; therapist&apos;s body. When the therapist is able to judiciously invite discussions of her body into the clinical arena, the client is given the opportunity to move from object relating to object usage. A case presentation exemplifies how this conceptual framework can be applied to clinical social work practice, strengthening the relationship between knowing and doing.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=The+Intersubjective+Experience+of+the+Physical+Body+in+the+Clinical+Setting+of+Eating+Disorders&amp;rft.au=Daly%2C+Suzanne+B&amp;rft.aulast=Daly&amp;rft.aufirst=Suzanne&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=47&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=00911674&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10615-014-0475-4

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=The+Intersubjective+Experience+of+the+Physical+Body+in+the+Clinical+Setting+of+Eating+Disorders&amp;rft.au=Daly%2C+Suzanne+B&amp;rft.aulast=Daly&amp;rft.aufirst=Suzanne&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=47&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=00911674&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10615-014-0475-4

Body-States, Body Image and Dissociation: When Not-Me is 'Not Body'

Author: Petrucelli, Jean

Publication info: Clinical Social Work Journal ; New York  Vol. 44, Iss. 1,  (Mar 2016): 18-26.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1771405005?accountid=14667

Abstract: Issue Title: Special Issue: Body Meets Mind: Eating Disorders and Body Image - a 21st Century Perspective The relationship between dissociation, eating disorders and disordered eating is key as it relates to dissociative disruptions to body image. It undermines normal integration of appearance-relevant information and cuts off access to subjective experience and feeling states necessary to form an internal representation of one&apos;s self and body. This vulnerability contributes to body image distortions and the uncritical internalization of society&apos;s notion of the thin ideal--which is an unrealistic standard, that leads, in turn, to body dissatisfaction. Patients with eating disorders live under the assumption that if they feel their sensations and feelings these will overwhelm them &apos;forever&apos;. The fear of being consumed by these terrible feelings, leads them to believe that &apos;not feeling&apos;-or even not existing-is the only answer. Being able to tolerate one&apos;s subjective, affective experience is part of being able to internally represent one&apos;s states, including body-states and to develop a stable experience of body image.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=Body-States%2C+Body+Image+and+Dissociation%3A+When+Not-Me+is+%27Not+Body%27&amp;rft.au=Petrucelli%2C+Jean&amp;rft.aulast=Petrucelli&amp;rft.aufirst=Jean&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=18&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=00911674&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10615-015-0539-0

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=Body-States%2C+Body+Image+and+Dissociation%3A+When+Not-Me+is+%27Not+Body%27&amp;rft.au=Petrucelli%2C+Jean&amp;rft.aulast=Petrucelli&amp;rft.aufirst=Jean&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=18&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=00911674&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10615-015-0539-0

Interview with Susie Orbach, Ph.D., C.S.W.

Author: Starkman, Holly

Publication info: Clinical Social Work Journal ; New York  Vol. 44, Iss. 1,  (Mar 2016): 4-7.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1771405725?accountid=14667

Abstract: Issue Title: Special Issue: Body Meets Mind: Eating Disorders and Body Image - a 21st Century Perspective An interview with Susie Orbach highlights the trajectory of her career and current thinking on body image issues and eating disorders. Dr. Orbach&apos;s work in this area as a clinical social worker, psychoanalyst, best-selling author and social activist has spanned three decades. In this interview she reflects on her earlier books, Fat is a Feminist Issue and Hunger Strike: An Anorectic&apos;s Struggle as a Metaphor for Our Age, and discusses her current work and perspectives within the context of contemporary culture.

An Integrative Group Treatment Model for Women with Binge Eating Disorder: Mind, Body and Self in Connection

Author: Starkman, Holly

Publication info: Clinical Social Work Journal ; New York  Vol. 44, Iss. 1,  (Mar 2016): 57-68.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1771405758?accountid=14667

Abstract: Issue Title: Special Issue: Body Meets Mind: Eating Disorders and Body Image - a 21st Century Perspective Binge eating disorder (BED) is the most prevalent eating disorder reported among women, and its recent diagnostic recognition in the DSM-5 (APA 2013 ) calls for further discussion on effective treatment. Women with BED commonly report a diet/binge cycle that can exacerbate a disconnection between mind and body and reinforce feelings of shame and isolation. This article presents an integrative group treatment model for women with BED that has shown positive outcomes in clinical practice. The group model addresses key biopsychosocial factors associated with BED and incorporates mindfulness principles tailored to problems of the disorder. A core foundation of the group model is the relational context that fosters connections between women members and promotes self-efficacy. The discussion includes etiology of BED and current empirical support for integrating mindfulness skills in treatment for binge eating problems, as well as the author&apos;s clinical experience in formulating a short-term group model. The eight-session semi-structured group format integrates evidence-based treatments in resonance with treatment-based evidence that reflects the distinct clinical needs of women with BED. Clinical vignettes illustrate how the group model can provide an anchoring therapeutic support to women with BED for linking experiences of mind, body, and self.

____________________________________________________________

The interaction of local and international child welfare agendas: A South African case

Author: Schmid, Jeanette; Patel, Leila

Publication info: International Social Work ; London  Vol. 59, Iss. 2,  (Mar 2016): 246.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1775309907?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article assesses the interaction between international and local influences in South African child welfare practice and education between 2001 and 2010. Based on a mixed methods study, it finds that the primary mechanism for international exchange occurred through funding. Professional imperialism continued to be evidenced in the domination of Northern agendas in local curricula and the lack of critical interrogation of external practices. A disjuncture between research and practice priorities was found with some areas of intersection. The article provides insight into the local/global nexus in child welfare and recommends further investigation into more authentic and egalitarian international relationships of exchange.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+interaction+of+local+and+international+child+welfare+agendas%3A+A+South+African+case&amp;rft.au=Schmid%2C+Jeanette%3BPatel%2C+Leila&amp;rft.aulast=Schmid&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeanette&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=246&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Coping strategies of HIV-positive individuals and its correlation with quality of life in Pune, India

Author: Kohli, Rewa; Sane, Suvarna; Ghate, Manisha; Paranjape, Ramesh

Publication info: International Social Work ; London  Vol. 59, Iss. 2,  (Mar 2016): 256.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1775310023?accountid=14667

Abstract: Quality of life including the domains of physical health and mental health are influenced by HIV infection. Coping strategies and their relationships with various domains of quality of life (QOL) were assessed among 97 HIV-infected individuals in Pune, India. Most of the infected individuals adopted emotion-focused strategies through cognitive reframing and acceptance of their HIV status. One-third adopted problem-focused coping and sought health care, scientific information and social support. Significant associations of coping strategies were observed with marital status and work and earning domains of the QOL questionnaire. Findings can help decide appropriate care and support strategies and psycho-social interventions for HIV-infected individuals. [web URL: http://isw.sagepub.com/content/59/2/256.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Coping+strategies+of+HIV-positive+individuals+and+its+correlation+with+quality+of+life+in+Pune%2C+India&amp;rft.au=Kohli%2C+Rewa%3BSane%2C+Suvarna%3BGhate%2C+Manisha%3BParanjape%2C+Ramesh&amp;rft.aulast=Kohli&amp;rft.aufirst=Rewa&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=256&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Melanesian visions? Some preliminary thoughts about social work education and practice in Papua New Guinea

Author: Brydon, Kerry; Lawihin, Dunstan

Publication info: International Social Work ; London  Vol. 59, Iss. 2,  (Mar 2016): 192.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1775310038?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work is a discipline that has its origins in the Western context but has spread to a wide range of contexts. We undertook a small research project as a quest to enhance the delivery of fieldwork programs but the findings clearly held implications for the development of new social work models and practices that are unique to the Papua New Guinea context. While further research is needed, it is our contention that the integration of Melanesian values holds promise, albeit accompanied by challenges, to contribute to the indigenization of social work as a model of practice that reflects local needs and local context in Papua New Guinea.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Melanesian+visions%3F+Some+preliminary+thoughts+about+social+work+education+and+practice+in+Papua+New+Guinea&amp;rft.au=Brydon%2C+Kerry%3BLawihin%2C+Dunstan&amp;rft.aulast=Brydon&amp;rft.aufirst=Kerry&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=192&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Children and disability: Constructions, implications and change

Author: Fawcett, Barbara

Publication info: International Social Work ; London  Vol. 59, Iss. 2,  (Mar 2016): 224.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1775310048?accountid=14667

Abstract: In the arena of disability, disabled children and young people continue to be positioned in a variety of ways with some of these affording opportunities and others continuing to focus on deficit and constraint. Social workers occupy a pivotal position at the interface between policy and practice, and can effectively counter circular processes of disablement. In this article, a frame of reference is employed which, by incorporating key areas such as targeting and rights and social exclusion and social investment, enables the potential for further development in relation to the personalization agenda in both Australia and the United Kingdom, to be critically appraised.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Children+and+disability%3A+Constructions%2C+implications+and+change&amp;rft.au=Fawcett%2C+Barbara&amp;rft.aulast=Fawcett&amp;rft.aufirst=Barbara&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=224&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

&apos;We didn&apos;t bring the treasure of Pharaoh&apos;: Skilled migrants&apos; experiences of employment seeking and settling in Australia

Author: Rynderman, John; Flynn, Catherine

Publication info: International Social Work ; London  Vol. 59, Iss. 2,  (Mar 2016): 268.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1775310242?accountid=14667

Abstract: Australia has an established history of migration from the Middle East. In recent years, however, the emergence of international terrorism has defined those from that area as the new enemy; yet we do not fully understand the impact of this on the settlement experiences of migrants from that region. Given Australia&apos;s migration pattern is dominated by skilled migration, this exploratory study sought to investigate how a small sample of self-selected skilled migrants from the Middle East experienced job seeking and settlement in Melbourne, Australia. Seven individuals participated in semi-structured interviews during July-August 2009. Thematic analysis revealed that participants had high, but ultimately unfulfilled, expectations for life and employment in Australia. Those immigrating with families experienced initial difficulties securing stable and suitable housing. The majority of participants struggled to find equivalent employment. This was seen to be influenced by their lack of both local qualifications and experience; differing cultural expectations about behaviour in job interviews was also an issue raised as influential. These challenges, combined with lack of government support, led to social isolation, psychological vulnerability and financial hardship. [web URL: http://isw.sagepub.com/content/59/2/268.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=%26amp%3Bapos%3BWe+didn%26amp%3Bapos%3Bt+bring+the+treasure+of+Pharaoh%26amp%3Bapos%3B%3A+Skilled+migrants%26amp%3Bapos%3B+experiences+of+employment+seeking+and+settling+in+Australia&amp;rft.au=Rynderman%2C+John%3BFlynn%2C+Catherine&amp;rft.aulast=Rynderman&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=268&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=%26amp%3Bapos%3BWe+didn%26amp%3Bapos%3Bt+bring+the+treasure+of+Pharaoh%26amp%3Bapos%3B%3A+Skilled+migrants%26amp%3Bapos%3B+experiences+of+employment+seeking+and+settling+in+Australia&amp;rft.au=Rynderman%2C+John%3BFlynn%2C+Catherine&amp;rft.aulast=Rynderman&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=268&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Counterbalancing the integration policy for migrants through social work

Author: DeRoo, Paul; Braeye, Sarah; DeMoor, Alexandra

Publication info: International Social Work ; London  Vol. 59, Iss. 2,  (Mar 2016): 210.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1775310243?accountid=14667

Abstract: Migration problems are mainly reduced unilaterally to problems that migrants cause in the guest society regarding housing, employment, education and health care. At the same time migration research often focuses on the same reduction: the living conditions of migrants in our society and ghettoization, unemployment, the concentration of migrant children in so called &apos;sink&apos; schools, unsuccessful integration and the sense of insecurity within the native community due to the presence of foreigners. Social workers proceed according to this evidence-based practice. Social workers are committed to the realization of a social policy that needs to accomplish an effective integration of migrants. In this article we question the evidence of the integration policy that is pursued. The reasons for this are multiple, but not least because the integration practices are often very counterproductive. I argue that migrant problems are not confined to the borders of our own community. A social policy of integration, addressed to migrants and other newcomers, which only depends on the conditions of our own society, must fail. Social work has increasingly been drawn into a role of punishment in its work with newcomers. This article looks to enlarge evidence-based practice to a reflexive collaboration with professionals in order to counterbalance the current rejection and submission of &apos;unsuccessful&apos; migrants and newcomers.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Counterbalancing+the+integration+policy+for+migrants+through+social+work&amp;rft.au=DeRoo%2C+Paul%3BBraeye%2C+Sarah%3BDeMoor%2C+Alexandra&amp;rft.aulast=DeRoo&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=210&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Counterbalancing+the+integration+policy+for+migrants+through+social+work&amp;rft.au=DeRoo%2C+Paul%3BBraeye%2C+Sarah%3BDeMoor%2C+Alexandra&amp;rft.aulast=DeRoo&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=210&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Subject: Children; Needs; Foreigners; Housing; Borders; Punishment; Schools; Cooperation; Migration; Employment; Health; Migrants; School desegregation; Migrant workers; Health problems; Social policy; Health care services policy; Social workers; Health education; Social work; Evidence based practice; Immigration policy; Health care services; Social integration

Classification: 6148: problems of minority groups

Title: Counterbalancing the integration policy for migrants through social work

____________________________________________________________

Doing fieldwork with transnational families in an unstructured environment: Issues and challenges for beneficent research

Author: Chereni, Admire

Publication info: International Social Work ; London  Vol. 59, Iss. 2,  (Mar 2016): 205.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1775310319?accountid=14667

Abstract: My intentions in this article are two-fold: 1) to highlight some of the complexities related to beneficent research which social workers might encounter when doing fieldwork with transnational families in an unstructured environment; 2) to argue that efforts to bring about good for vulnerable respondents outside remedial social work settings may have to confront structures that maintain people in circumstances of injustice. Structural change, however, can hardly be achieved within the scope of fieldwork research relationships. Throughout I draw on my fieldwork experiences for illustrations.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Doing+fieldwork+with+transnational+families+in+an+unstructured+environment%3A+Issues+and+challenges+for+beneficent+research&amp;rft.au=Chereni%2C+Admire&amp;rft.aulast=Chereni&amp;rft.aufirst=Admire&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=205&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Doing+fieldwork+with+transnational+families+in+an+unstructured+environment%3A+Issues+and+challenges+for+beneficent+research&amp;rft.au=Chereni%2C+Admire&amp;rft.aulast=Chereni&amp;rft.aufirst=Admire&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=205&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Factors related to help-seeking attitudes about professional mental health services among Jamaican immigrants

Author: Yorke, Cordelle B; Voisin, Dexter R; Baptiste, Donna

Publication info: International Social Work ; London  Vol. 59, Iss. 2,  (Mar 2016): 293.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1775310338?accountid=14667

Abstract: Using survey data collected from 115 first-generation Jamaican immigrants residing in New York City, this study identified factors that were associated with their attitudes toward seeking professional mental health services. Results indicated that persons reporting psychological distress, negative stigma and attributions about mental illness, and positive social support from friends were less likely than their counterparts to report positive attitudes towards professional mental health services. Implications of the study are discussed in relation to these findings. [web URL: http://isw.sagepub.com/content/59/2/293.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Factors+related+to+help-seeking+attitudes+about+professional+mental+health+services+among+Jamaican+immigrants&amp;rft.au=Yorke%2C+Cordelle+B%3BVoisin%2C+Dexter+R%3BBaptiste%2C+Donna&amp;rft.aulast=Yorke&amp;rft.aufirst=Cordelle&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=293&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Factors+related+to+help-seeking+attitudes+about+professional+mental+health+services+among+Jamaican+immigrants&amp;rft.au=Yorke%2C+Cordelle+B%3BVoisin%2C+Dexter+R%3BBaptiste%2C+Donna&amp;rft.aulast=Yorke&amp;rft.aufirst=Cordelle&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=293&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Understanding motivations to participate in an observational research study: Why do patients enroll?

Author: Soule, Michael C1; Beale, Eleanor E1; Suarez, Laura1; Beach, Scott R2; Mastromauro, Carol A1; Celano, Christopher M2; Moore, Shannon V1; Huffman, Jeff C21 Department of Psychiatry, Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, Massachusetts, USA2 Department of Psychiatry, Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, Massachusetts, USA; Department of Psychiatry, Harvard Medical School, Boston, Massachusetts, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 3,  (Mar 2016): 231-246.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1781103406?accountid=14667

Abstract: By understanding common motivations for participating in observational research studies, clinicians may better understand the perceived benefits of research participation from their clients&apos; perspective. We enrolled 164 cardiac patients in a study about the effects of gratitude and optimism. Two weeks post-enrollment, participants completed a four-item questionnaire regarding motivations for study enrollment. Altruistic motivation ranked highest, while intellectual, health-related, and financial motivations rated lower. Four subgroups of participants emerged, each with distinct characteristics and different priorities for participating. These findings may help front-line clinicians to understand which motivations for participation apply to their clients who enroll in non-treatment-based research projects.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Understanding+motivations+to+participate+in+an+observational+research+study%3A+Why+do+patients+enroll%3F&amp;rft.au=Soule%2C+Michael+C%3BBeale%2C+Eleanor+E%3BSuarez%2C+Laura%3BBeach%2C+Scott+R%3BMastromauro%2C+Carol+A%3BCelano%2C+Christopher+M%3BMoore%2C+Shannon+V%3BHuffman%2C+Jeff+C&amp;rft.aulast=Soule&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=231&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2015.1114064

Social workers as care coordinators: Leaders in ensuring effective, compassionate care

Author: Monterio, Christine, MSW, MAPM1; Arnold, Janis, MA1; Locke, Susanna, MSW1; Steinhorn, Lena, MSW1; Shanske, Susan, MSW11 Department of Social Work, Boston Children's Hospital, Boston, Massachusetts, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 3,  (Mar 2016): 195-213.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1781103433?accountid=14667

Abstract: The concept of care coordination is at the forefront of national conversations in the context of health care reform. As pediatric social workers, we are interested in how care coordination benefits our patients, and which disciplines are providing coordination services. We have determined that significant overlap exists between the work social workers are already doing in inpatient and outpatient medical settings and the literature&apos;s definition of care coordination activities. This article outlines our process of literature review and creation of a working definition of care coordination, and frames the concepts we believe remain central to the process of care coordination.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Social+workers+as+care+coordinators%3A+Leaders+in+ensuring+effective%2C+compassionate+care&amp;rft.au=Monterio%2C+Christine%2C+MSW%2C+MAPM%3BArnold%2C+Janis%2C+MA%3BLocke%2C+Susanna%2C+MSW%3BSteinhorn%2C+Lena%2C+MSW%3BShanske%2C+Susan%2C+MSW&amp;rft.aulast=Monterio&amp;rft.aufirst=Christine&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=195&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2015.1093579

____________________________________________________________

Place matters: Mitigating obesity with the person-in-environment approach

Author: O'Dare Wilson, Kellie, PhD11 Department of Social Work, University of West Florida, Pensacola, Florida, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 3,  (Mar 2016): 214-230.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1781103445?accountid=14667

Abstract: Research demonstrates that environmental and community-level variables contribute to obesity. Many of these variables are outside of personal volitional control, such as the characteristics of the places in which people live. Social work&apos;s unique person-in-environment (PIE) approach is an ideal perspective from which to address obesity. This study employs the PIE perspective to examine sprawl, one environmental-level factor. We employed secondary data analysis to examine the effect of sprawl on obesity while controlling for covariates. Region of residence and sprawl significantly predicted obesity, net of covariates. Given that obesity varies among communities, social workers can respond with PIE-oriented solutions.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Place+matters%3A+Mitigating+obesity+with+the+person-in-environment+approach&amp;rft.au=O%27Dare+Wilson%2C+Kellie%2C+PhD&amp;rft.aulast=O%27Dare+Wilson&amp;rft.aufirst=Kellie&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=214&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2015.1107017

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Place+matters%3A+Mitigating+obesity+with+the+person-in-environment+approach&amp;rft.au=O%27Dare+Wilson%2C+Kellie%2C+PhD&amp;rft.aulast=O%27Dare+Wilson&amp;rft.aufirst=Kellie&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=214&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2015.1107017

____________________________________________________________

Cancer survivorship care-planning: Practice, research, and policy implications for social work

Author: Wagner, Richard W, EdM1; Pritzker, Suzanne, PhD11 Graduate College of Social Work, University of Houston, Houston, Texas, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 3,  (Mar 2016): 181-194.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1781103506?accountid=14667

Abstract: Increasing numbers of cancer survivors are living longer than 5 years from their diagnosis date. This has resulted in a growing population of cancer survivors, expected to reach 19 million by 2024. Survivors frequently experience late effects caused by cancer and its treatment, reducing survivors&apos; quality of life in multiple domains. Survivorship care-plans may aid the many physical, psychosocial, and financial needs that emerge posttreatment. However, the lack of reimbursement mechanisms, the limited amount of effectiveness research, and minimal guidelines for content and delivery are barriers to the widespread provision of survivorship care-plans. Challenges and opportunities for social work practice, research, and policy are identified and discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Cancer+survivorship+care-planning%3A+Practice%2C+research%2C+and+policy+implications+for+social+work&amp;rft.au=Wagner%2C+Richard+W%2C+EdM%3BPritzker%2C+Suzanne%2C+PhD&amp;rft.aulast=Wagner&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=181&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2015.1115800

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Cancer+survivorship+care-planning%3A+Practice%2C+research%2C+and+policy+implications+for+social+work&amp;rft.au=Wagner%2C+Richard+W%2C+EdM%3BPritzker%2C+Suzanne%2C+PhD&amp;rft.aulast=Wagner&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=181&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2015.1115800

____________________________________________________________

Beyond Individualism: Social Work and Social Identity

Author: Houston, Stan

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 2,  (Mar 2016): 532.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1781528514?accountid=14667

Abstract: Individualism continues to have a notable impact on social work. The personalisation of services and the individualisation of care are just two examples of this societal trend. While helping service users to articulate their aspirations for a better future, individualism, if taken too far, undermines the social aspects of life. In response to this concern, this paper argues that social work must appreciate the interplay between the individual and the collective spheres, and its impact on identity formation, in order to enhance human well-being. To give substance to this argument, Jenkins&apos;s model of social identity is appropriated and augmented to take account of four interlinked, yet distinct, orders of experience, namely the individual, interactional, institutional and societal orders. This reworked conceptualisation is then considered in terms of its implications for social work practice. [web URL: http://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/2/532.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Beyond+Individualism%3A+Social+Work+and+Social+Identity&amp;rft.au=Houston%2C+Stan&amp;rft.aulast=Houston&amp;rft.aufirst=Stan&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=532&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Reconstructing the Foundations of Joined-Up Working: From Organisational Reform towards a Joint Engagement of Child and Family Services

Author: Roets, Griet; Roose, Rudi; Schiettecat, Tineke; Vandenbroeck, Michel

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 2,  (Mar 2016): 306.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1781528530?accountid=14667

Abstract: In a diversity of European countries, an ambitious pursuit of organisational reform is stressed in the field of social work policy and practice, which is rhetorically rooted in &apos;joined-up thinking&apos;. Emerging criticism about joined-up working has been identified in the body of available research, particularly in terms of the construction and pursuit of joint goals. In this article, we discuss the empirical findings that were acquired during a recent qualitative research project in Belgium. The underlying assumptions of joined-up working in child and family services were examined in two disadvantaged quarters, bearing in mind the complexity of social work practices in dealing with families in poverty. The perspectives of parents in poverty situations and front line social workers were explored by means of qualitative, in-depth interviews in combination with the vignette technique. In the research findings, functional and responsive approaches to joined-up working are discussed. We assert that functional approaches to joined-up working undermine responsive and particularly reflexive social work. In that vein, we argue that social workers should discuss the values and dilemmas at play in their responses to complexity at organisational and inter-organisational levels. Such collective engagement can lead to reconstructing the foundations of joined-up working. [web URL: http://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/2/306.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Reconstructing+the+Foundations+of+Joined-Up+Working%3A+From+Organisational+Reform+towards+a+Joint+Engagement+of+Child+and+Family+Services&amp;rft.au=Roets%2C+Griet%3BRoose%2C+Rudi%3BSchiettecat%2C+Tineke%3BVandenbroeck%2C+Michel&amp;rft.aulast=Roets&amp;rft.aufirst=Griet&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=306&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Reconstructing+the+Foundations+of+Joined-Up+Working%3A+From+Organisational+Reform+towards+a+Joint+Engagement+of+Child+and+Family+Services&amp;rft.au=Roets%2C+Griet%3BRoose%2C+Rudi%3BSchiettecat%2C+Tineke%3BVandenbroeck%2C+Michel&amp;rft.aulast=Roets&amp;rft.aufirst=Griet&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=306&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Technology Configuring the User: Implications for the Redesign of Electronic Information Systems in Social Work

Author: Gillingham, Philip

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 2,  (Mar 2016): 323.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1781528565?accountid=14667

Abstract: The introduction of technology to any workplace can not only change the nature of the task, but re-orient priorities and change the way that workers conduct and think about their work. In this article, based on the findings of a programme of ethnographic research, examples of changes brought to both the context for and the practice of social work by the heavily critiqued current designs of electronic information systems (IS) are analysed. It is argued that understanding these changes is crucial to research-based approaches to redesigning IS that support rather than hinder social work practice. The implications for initiatives to improve social work practice are also explored. [web URL: http://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/2/323.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Technology+Configuring+the+User%3A+Implications+for+the+Redesign+of+Electronic+Information+Systems+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Gillingham%2C+Philip&amp;rft.aulast=Gillingham&amp;rft.aufirst=Philip&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=323&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Getting to Know the Context: The Complexities of Providing Off-Site Supervision in Social Work Practice Learning

Author: Zuchowski, Ines

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 2,  (Mar 2016): 409.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1781528617?accountid=14667

Abstract: Field education is central to social work education, facilitating the development of practice skills, professional identity and a professional practice framework. External supervision in social work field education is becoming more prevalent due to economic, social and political changes at a global level and is likely to continue to be a feature of field education. This article provides findings from current Australian qualitative research exploring &apos;social work student placements with external supervision&apos;, focusing on the experiences and views of external field educators. It explores the research findings in light of international social work education research, particularly with reference to experiences and contexts in England, UK. A range of themes emerge from this study, including a focus on supervision, relationships, roles, placement preparation and assessment. Findings suggest that knowledge and understanding of the placement context is a dominant consideration in social workers&apos; reflections on their experience of providing external supervision to social work students. External supervisors apply a range of strategies to build the understanding of the context of the students&apos; experience and the nature of host agency policies, practices and culture. This can lead to an active engagement of students in their learning, but has implications for resourcing. [web URL: http://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/2/409.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Getting+to+Know+the+Context%3A+The+Complexities+of+Providing+Off-Site+Supervision+in+Social+Work+Practice+Learning&amp;rft.au=Zuchowski%2C+Ines&amp;rft.aulast=Zuchowski&amp;rft.aufirst=Ines&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=409&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Getting+to+Know+the+Context%3A+The+Complexities+of+Providing+Off-Site+Supervision+in+Social+Work+Practice+Learning&amp;rft.au=Zuchowski%2C+Ines&amp;rft.aulast=Zuchowski&amp;rft.aufirst=Ines&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=409&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Perceptions of the &apos;Occupational Other&apos;: Interpreters, Social Workers and Intercultures

Author: Tipton, Rebecca

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 2,  (Mar 2016): 463.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1781528659?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article investigates occupational intercultures generated between interpreters and social workers, and is informed by research in Translation and Interpreting Studies. The Bourdieusian concepts of field, habitus and zones of uncertainty are used to illuminate the particular status of interpreter mediation within the interculture as a backdrop to theorising about the impact of interpreter mediation on the nature of social workers&apos; change agency and reflexive approaches to practice. The article reports on an exploratory and mixed-methods qualitative study in which interpreters and social workers in statutory and non-statutory services were interviewed about their perceptions of the &apos;occupational Other&apos;, and in which a discourse-analytical approach to the data helped take account of the researcher&apos;s position as an insider of the interpreting community in the final analytic write-up. The findings suggest that the interculture can often be weakened due to poor understandings of the structural weaknesses in the constitution of public service interpreting and the &apos;recontextualising&apos; practices that occur in interaction; furthermore, interpreter mediation appears to challenge communicative practices in social work in ways that practitioners do not always have the resources to address effectively. The article ends with a call for more research at the micro level of interaction. [web URL: http://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/2/463.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Perceptions+of+the+%26amp%3Bapos%3BOccupational+Other%26amp%3Bapos%3B%3A+Interpreters%2C+Social+Workers+and+Intercultures&amp;rft.au=Tipton%2C+Rebecca&amp;rft.aulast=Tipton&amp;rft.aufirst=Rebecca&amp;rft.date=2016-03-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=463&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/
