Exploring Minority Youths' Police Encounters: A Qualitative Interpretive Meta-synthesis

Author: Nordberg, Anne; Crawford, Marcus R; Praetorius, Regina T; Hatcher, Schnavia Smith

Publication info: Child & Adolescent Social Work Journal : C & A ; New York  Vol. 33, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2016): 137-149.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1773418879?accountid=14667

Abstract: Recent deaths by police of unarmed minority youth have raised important questions about the nature and outcomes of involuntary minority youth-police encounters. Youth are the most surveilled group of Americans and minority youth frequently live in neighborhoods disproportionately targeted for proactive policing (i.e., using broad police discretion to "target" those most likely to be engaged in criminal activity before criminal acts become apparent). Understanding the experiences of minority youth who encounter police officers is of critical concern for social workers in many practice and research areas. Social workers must examine how a minority person's perceptions are formed through repeated, frequent, involuntary encounters with the police. The purpose of this qualitative interpretive meta-synthesis was to capture these experiences through the voices of minority youth in recounting their contacts with the police. Four themes were identified: dangerous, controlling, prejudiced, and ineffective. Further reduction of these themes resulted in an overarching theme that captures the essences of these youth's experiences: dehumanization. These results enhance understanding of minority youth experience with police officers and, thus, inform social work advocacy efforts around this issue in both practice and research arenas.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+Minority+Youths%27+Police+Encounters%3A+A+Qualitative+Interpretive+Meta-synthesis&amp;rft.au=Nordberg%2C+Anne%3BCrawford%2C+Marcus+R%3BPraetorius%2C+Regina+T%3BHatcher%2C+Schnavia+Smith&amp;rft.aulast=Nordberg&amp;rft.aufirst=Anne&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=137&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.issn=07380151&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10560-015-0415-3

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+Minority+Youths%27+Police+Encounters%3A+A+Qualitative+Interpretive+Meta-synthesis&amp;rft.au=Nordberg%2C+Anne%3BCrawford%2C+Marcus+R%3BPraetorius%2C+Regina+T%3BHatcher%2C+Schnavia+Smith&amp;rft.aulast=Nordberg&amp;rft.aufirst=Anne&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=137&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.issn=07380151&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10560-015-0415-3

Supporting Adolescent Daughters as They Come of Age: Latina Mothers' Reflections and Recommendations

Author: Okwumabua, Theresa M; Hyers, Lauri L; Watson, Andrea N; Walker, Kristin M; Quiroz, Cynthia

Publication info: Child & Adolescent Social Work Journal : C & A ; New York  Vol. 33, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2016): 175-184.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1773418887?accountid=14667

Abstract: The current project describes themes emerging from a set of focus groups with 20 Latina mothers (aged 25 to over 45) who reflected on the transition to adulthood for their daughters. As community stakeholders residing in a large city in the Southern USA, these mothers shared their perspectives and advice on supporting adolescent girls during the transition to adulthood. Qualitative coding revealed four key aspects of the transition that were important to these mothers: ethnic identity, involvement of others, communication with daughters, and individual personality characteristics. We discuss their reflections with regard to the development of more culturally relevant programs for Latina girls coming of age within the USA context.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.atitle=Supporting+Adolescent+Daughters+as+They+Come+of+Age%3A+Latina+Mothers%27+Reflections+and+Recommendations&amp;rft.au=Okwumabua%2C+Theresa+M%3BHyers%2C+Lauri+L%3BWatson%2C+Andrea+N%3BWalker%2C+Kristin+M%3BQuiroz%2C+Cynthia&amp;rft.aulast=Okwumabua&amp;rft.aufirst=Theresa&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=175&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.issn=07380151&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10560-015-0407-3

Perspectives of Youth in Care in Serbia

Author: Burgund, Anita; Zegarac, Nevenka

Publication info: Child & Adolescent Social Work Journal : C & A ; New York  Vol. 33, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2016): 151-161.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1773419918?accountid=14667

Abstract: In the context of evaluating child protection reform in Serbia, we explored the concept of positive youth development as well as how they experienced and understood the experience of placement. We sought to understand how youth perceive their strengths, the role of the care system, their views on how life experiences affect their strengths and how they see their future. Our position is that the way in which children see their situation is equally valuable as any other point of view, and that their doubts, questions and views should be learned in the research process. We used the methodology of semi-structured in-depth interviews conducted with 16 young people in care aged 13-18 years. Results indicate their limited involvement in the process of making decisions related to their life and future. There is a strong need for meaningful involvement of children and young people in order to ensure their positive development.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.atitle=Perspectives+of+Youth+in+Care+in+Serbia&amp;rft.au=Burgund%2C+Anita%3BZegarac%2C+Nevenka&amp;rft.aulast=Burgund&amp;rft.aufirst=Anita&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=151&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.issn=07380151&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10560-015-0413-5

Childhood origins and adult destinations: The impact of childhood living conditions on coexisting disadvantages in adulthood

Author: Almquist, Ylva B

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 25, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2016): 176-186.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1776710122?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aim of this study was to analyse linkages between childhood living conditions and coexisting disadvantages in adulthood. Analyses were based on the Stockholm Birth Cohort, consisting of more than 14,000 individuals born in 1953, followed up until 2007. Based on education, labour market outcomes, economic poverty and health, four outcome profiles with varying levels of disadvantage were identified by means of latent class analysis. Coexisting disadvantages were present in approximately one-fifth of the individuals. Low educational attainment, social welfare recipiency and mental health problems simultaneously occurred in two of the profiles, suggesting that these dimensions are highly interconnected. Results from multinomial regression analysis showed that individuals who had experienced disadvantaged childhood conditions had particularly high risks of ending up in these two outcome profiles, with or without the presence of unemployment. Key Practitioner Message: -- Four outcome profiles with varying combinations of adult disadvantage are identified; -- Coexisting disadvantages are present in approximately one-fifth of the individuals; -- Those experiencing adverse childhood conditions have higher risks of coexisting disadvantages, with or without the presence of unemployment.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Childhood+origins+and+adult+destinations%3A+The+impact+of+childhood+living+conditions+on+coexisting+disadvantages+in+adulthood&amp;rft.au=Almquist%2C+Ylva+B&amp;rft.aulast=Almquist&amp;rft.aufirst=Ylva&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=176&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12178

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Childhood+origins+and+adult+destinations%3A+The+impact+of+childhood+living+conditions+on+coexisting+disadvantages+in+adulthood&amp;rft.au=Almquist%2C+Ylva+B&amp;rft.aulast=Almquist&amp;rft.aufirst=Ylva&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=176&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12178

____________________________________________________________

Differentiation of welfare regimes: The case of Italy

Author: Bertin, Giovanni; Carradore, Marco

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 25, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2016): 149-160.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1776710154?accountid=14667

Abstract: The different welfare system classifications mainly address systems on the national level, while the local levels have not been considered in any great detail. The welfare reform measures adopted in some countries have led to more autonomy on the local level. Consequently, local authorities have adopted different social policies and developed diverse welfare services. This article addresses the case of Italy and shows that classifying a welfare regime by considering only the national level can lead to important local features being missed that are indeed relevant for its classification. The units of analysis are the 20 administrative regions of Italy. The results demonstrate that the Italian welfare system is far from being a homogeneous system and that the resources available on the local level have a considerable effect on the level of the welfare services provided. These results show that more attention needs to be directed at the local level.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Differentiation+of+welfare+regimes%3A+The+case+of+Italy&amp;rft.au=Bertin%2C+Giovanni%3BCarradore%2C+Marco&amp;rft.aulast=Bertin&amp;rft.aufirst=Giovanni&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=149&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12183

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Differentiation+of+welfare+regimes%3A+The+case+of+Italy&amp;rft.au=Bertin%2C+Giovanni%3BCarradore%2C+Marco&amp;rft.aulast=Bertin&amp;rft.aufirst=Giovanni&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=149&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12183

Exploring a blind spot in comparative pension reform research: Long-term trends in non-contributory pensions in Europe

Author: Goedeme, Tim; Marchal, Sarah

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 25, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2016): 161-175.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1776710193?accountid=14667

Abstract: Over the past two decades, pension reforms have been high on the agenda of social policy makers in Europe. In many countries, these reforms have resulted in less generous public pensions. At the same time, minimum income protection for older adults has received attention from policy makers, but much less so from social policy researchers. Therefore, this study explored how benefit levels of non-contributory minimum income schemes for older adults evolved from 1992 to 2012 in 13 'old' EU member states. Building on two cross-national longitudinal datasets with comparative data on minimum income protection in Europe, the study shows that over the past 20 years, the erosion of the principal safety net of last resort for older persons has been limited. Moreover, a substantial number of European countries have pursued a deliberate policy of considerably increasing minimum income benefits.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+a+blind+spot+in+comparative+pension+reform+research%3A+Long-term+trends+in+non-contributory+pensions+in+Europe&amp;rft.au=Goedeme%2C+Tim%3BMarchal%2C+Sarah&amp;rft.aulast=Goedeme&amp;rft.aufirst=Tim&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=161&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12189

Material hardship and depression among low-income households in South Korea: Differences by household type

Author: Kim, Jaeseung; Shim, Joyce; Lee, RaeHyuck

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 25, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2016): 187-198.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1776710203?accountid=14667

Abstract: With the recent trend of growing poverty in South Korea, low-income households, particularly elderly- and single-headed households, are at high risk of experiencing material hardship and depression. However, less is known about the association between material hardship and depression by household type in Korea. Using data (N = 2,913) from the Korean Welfare Panel Study and employing several methodological approaches to address the omitted variables bias, this study examined: (i) the association between material hardship and depression among low-income households, and (ii) whether the association differed by household type. We found that experiencing material hardship was associated with a higher likelihood of being depressed. In addition, we also found that the association between material hardship and depression differed by household type. The magnitude of the association was most pronounced in single- and elderly-headed households. Policy implications to improve well-being among low-income households were discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Material+hardship+and+depression+among+low-income+households+in+South+Korea%3A+Differences+by+household+type&amp;rft.au=Kim%2C+Jaeseung%3BShim%2C+Joyce%3BLee%2C+RaeHyuck&amp;rft.aulast=Kim&amp;rft.aufirst=Jaeseung&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=187&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12181

You can go your own way! The long-term effectiveness of a self-employment programme for welfare recipients in Germany

Author: Wolff, Joachim1; Nivorozhkin, Anton1; Bernhard, Stefan11 Institute for Employment Research, Nuremberg, Germany

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 25, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2016): 136-148.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1776784217?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this study, we examined the long-term effects of supporting welfare recipients by means of a subsidy to start their own business. We used administrative data and propensity score matching to estimate the impact of the subsidy on the probability of receiving welfare benefits and on unemployment status up to 72 months after programme start. We supplemented our estimation results with the results of a qualitative survey which provided insights into the diversity of entrepreneurial activities and the recipients&apos; motivation for starting a business. Our results are encouraging. We found a stable positive effect on the outcomes of interest. We further found that foreign nationals and the long-term unemployed benefit the most. We conclude that the subsidy allows some people to successfully start a business who would not have otherwise done so and who would have been less successful by choosing the alternative of continued job search.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=You+can+go+your+own+way%21+The+long-term+effectiveness+of+a+self-employment+programme+for+welfare+recipients+in+Germany&amp;rft.au=Wolff%2C+Joachim%3BNivorozhkin%2C+Anton%3BBernhard%2C+Stefan&amp;rft.aulast=Wolff&amp;rft.aufirst=Joachim&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=136&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12176

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=You+can+go+your+own+way%21+The+long-term+effectiveness+of+a+self-employment+programme+for+welfare+recipients+in+Germany&amp;rft.au=Wolff%2C+Joachim%3BNivorozhkin%2C+Anton%3BBernhard%2C+Stefan&amp;rft.aulast=Wolff&amp;rft.aufirst=Joachim&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=136&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12176

Transferring from the poor to the rich: Examining regressive redistribution in Chinese social insurance programmes

Author: Liu, Junqiang1; Liu, Kai2; Huang, Yunong31 Center for Chinese Public Administration Research, School of Government, Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou, China2 Department of Social Security, School of Labor and Human Resources, Renmin University of China, Beijing, China3 School of Social and Policy Studies, Faculty of Social and Behavioral Sciences, Flinders University, Adelaide, Australia

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 25, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2016): 199-210.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1776784227?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social insurance promotes progressive redistribution through risk pooling and cross-subsidy. However, in China, risks and protection are mismatched, with benefits and protection accruing to the privileged while high-risk groups are inadequately protected. This article reports on a study of the sources of regressive redistribution in Chinese pension, health and unemployment insurance programmes, and discusses the possible cause of this redistribution paradox. It argues that the government has adopted different strategies for welfare reform towards different socioeconomic groups. For the core groups, such as public employees, reform has been characterised by replacing old programmes with new (i.e., a replacement strategy). For marginal groups, the government has handed off its responsibilities to individuals and the market (a retrenchment strategy). This political pecking order of welfare reform is the cause of distorted distributional outcomes. As social policy programmes continue to spread in developing countries, China&apos;s case illustrates that they may reinforce existing disparities rather than realise progressive redistribution, risk management and social inclusion.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Transferring+from+the+poor+to+the+rich%3A+Examining+regressive+redistribution+in+Chinese+social+insurance+programmes&amp;rft.au=Liu%2C+Junqiang%3BLiu%2C+Kai%3BHuang%2C+Yunong&amp;rft.aulast=Liu&amp;rft.aufirst=Junqiang&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=199&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12172

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Transferring+from+the+poor+to+the+rich%3A+Examining+regressive+redistribution+in+Chinese+social+insurance+programmes&amp;rft.au=Liu%2C+Junqiang%3BLiu%2C+Kai%3BHuang%2C+Yunong&amp;rft.aulast=Liu&amp;rft.aufirst=Junqiang&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=199&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12172

____________________________________________________________

Is there still such a thing as the &apos;European social model&apos;?

Author: Bilbao-Ubillos, Javier11 Department of Applied Economics I, University of the Basque Country (UPV/EHU), Bilbao, Spain

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 25, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2016): 110-125.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1776784589?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents a definition and characterisation of the &apos;European social model&apos; (ESM), admitting the existence of variants and increasing heterogeneity in institutional and social contexts within the EU in the wake of successive enlargements. The constituent parts of the ESM are compared with data observed in the different countries, in search of empirical evidence of the ESM&apos;s position as a distinctive model of development, characteristic of Western Europe as opposed to the paths taken by other non-European developed OECD countries.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Is+there+still+such+a+thing+as+the+%26amp%3Bapos%3BEuropean+social+model%26amp%3Bapos%3B%3F&amp;rft.au=Bilbao-Ubillos%2C+Javier&amp;rft.aulast=Bilbao-Ubillos&amp;rft.aufirst=Javier&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=110&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12177

Giving Our Students Professional Voice: Development and Implementation of a BSW Course on Writing for Agency Practice

Author: Thomas, Jeanne L; Schuster, Elizabeth O; Fuller, Alison R

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 234-241.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1780746582?accountid=14667

Abstract: In social work practice, writing is a tool for advocacy, communication with clients, and other professionals, and accountability. In virtually all practice settings, workers at every organizational level invest significant time and effort in writing. However, the social work education literature reveals little attention to teaching BSW students to write for practice settings. This article summarizes the development of a BSW course on writing human service agency documents, decisions made and lessons learned in the process, and suggestions for creating similar courses elsewhere.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Giving+Our+Students+Professional+Voice%3A+Development+and+Implementation+of+a+BSW+Course+on+Writing+for+Agency+Practice&amp;rft.au=Thomas%2C+Jeanne+L%3BSchuster%2C+Elizabeth+O%3BFuller%2C+Alison+R&amp;rft.aulast=Thomas&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeanne&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=234&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1151277

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Giving+Our+Students+Professional+Voice%3A+Development+and+Implementation+of+a+BSW+Course+on+Writing+for+Agency+Practice&amp;rft.au=Thomas%2C+Jeanne+L%3BSchuster%2C+Elizabeth+O%3BFuller%2C+Alison+R&amp;rft.aulast=Thomas&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeanne&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=234&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1151277

Macro-Focused Social Work Dissertations: A Preliminary Look at the Numbers

Author: Fogel, Sondra J; Ersing, Robin

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 170-177.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1780746613?accountid=14667

Abstract: Dissertation research is an important indicator of practice trends and emerging issues. The social work profession relies on this scholarship to build its knowledge base thus reducing reliance on cognate fields. It is worthwhile to note how many dissertations are being completed and to review the categories being pursued in dissertation products to see if there are trends or questions that are dominating or masking larger issues in the field. Social work dissertations focused on macro scholarship efforts are of particular interest for the purpose of this article. This research investigates two simple, yet important, questions: How many macro-focused social work dissertations have been awarded in the past 10 years? and What was the content area of these works?

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Macro-Focused+Social+Work+Dissertations%3A+A+Preliminary+Look+at+the+Numbers&amp;rft.au=Fogel%2C+Sondra+J%3BErsing%2C+Robin&amp;rft.aulast=Fogel&amp;rft.aufirst=Sondra&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=170&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1151272

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Macro-Focused+Social+Work+Dissertations%3A+A+Preliminary+Look+at+the+Numbers&amp;rft.au=Fogel%2C+Sondra+J%3BErsing%2C+Robin&amp;rft.aulast=Fogel&amp;rft.aufirst=Sondra&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=170&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1151272

The Role of Field Education in a University-Community Partnership Aimed at Curriculum Transformation

Author: Lewis, Laura A; Kusmaul, Nancy; Elze, Diane; Butler, Lisa

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 186-197.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1780746633?accountid=14667

Abstract: University-community partnerships can play an important role in curriculum development, but little has been written about the role of community agencies in designing curricula. This article describes the role of field education in an innovative university-community partnership aimed at transforming an MSW curriculum to integrate a trauma-informed and human rights perspective throughout foundation- and advanced-year courses. This university-community partnership positioned field educators and social service agencies in a collaborative relationship with faculty in curriculum development. The benefits and potential challenges associated with employing a university-community partnership for curriculum change are discussed, and recommendations are provided for schools that are interested in using this approach.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=The+Role+of+Field+Education+in+a+University-Community+Partnership+Aimed+at+Curriculum+Transformation&amp;rft.au=Lewis%2C+Laura+A%3BKusmaul%2C+Nancy%3BElze%2C+Diane%3BButler%2C+Lisa&amp;rft.aulast=Lewis&amp;rft.aufirst=Laura&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=186&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1151274

Assessing the Development of Cultural Proficiency Among Upper-Level Social Work Students

Author: Rahill, Guitele J; Joshi, Manisha; Lucio, Robert; Bristol, Brittany; Dionne, Ariele; Hamilton, Alexis

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 198-213.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1780746669?accountid=14667

Abstract: Graduate social work pedagogy is challenging to diverse faculty and students who work with diverse clients, often in international practice. We discuss the development, outcomes, and assessment of an assignment designed to stimulate students&apos; research on proverbs as cultural resources for practice and to promote attainment of six competencies related to diversity and social justice of the Council on Social Work Education&apos;s Educational Policy and Accreditation Standards. We used procedures from grounded theory and Atlas.ti to analyze 40 student papers. More than 70% of papers reflected students&apos; mastery of three competencies, suggesting the assignment was insufficient to ensure attainment of all six competencies and signaling errors in the structure of the assignment and in the rubric. Ensuring students&apos; achievement of the competencies requires careful design and assessment of assignments and deliberate, structured assessment of the assignment outcomes.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Assessing+the+Development+of+Cultural+Proficiency+Among+Upper-Level+Social+Work+Students&amp;rft.au=Rahill%2C+Guitele+J%3BJoshi%2C+Manisha%3BLucio%2C+Robert%3BBristol%2C+Brittany%3BDionne%2C+Ariele%3BHamilton%2C+Alexis&amp;rft.aulast=Rahill&amp;rft.aufirst=Guitele&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=198&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1152134

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Assessing+the+Development+of+Cultural+Proficiency+Among+Upper-Level+Social+Work+Students&amp;rft.au=Rahill%2C+Guitele+J%3BJoshi%2C+Manisha%3BLucio%2C+Robert%3BBristol%2C+Brittany%3BDionne%2C+Ariele%3BHamilton%2C+Alexis&amp;rft.aulast=Rahill&amp;rft.aufirst=Guitele&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=198&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1152134

Making Social Work Education App'ier : The Process of Developing Information-based Apps for Social Work Education and Practice

Author: Campbell, Anne1; McColgan, Mary21 Social work department, Queens University Belfast, Belfast, Northern Ireland2 Social work department, Ulster University, Magee campus, Derry, Northern Ireland

Publication info: Social Work Education ; Abingdon  Vol. 35, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2016): 297-309.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784417622?accountid=14667

Abstract: Mobile App technology in social work education remains in the embryonic stages of development with a few notable exceptions. The use of Apps in College and University settings has been reported in other sectors of higher education, although there is a paucity of research in relation to its relevance to social work education and practice. The following article describes the creation of four social work education and practice Apps by a team of social work educators. The primary focus is on the design process and the partnership approach to the creation of the tools. It also outlines the rationale for the App development, the working process and the theoretical framework underpinning mobile learning. Furthermore, it provides information on the level of usage of the Apps according to geographical location, download information and time spent on each section of the App. The article also incorporates a pragmatic summary of developmental guidelines which may aid social work educators in the development and implementation of specialist information-based Apps for education and practice.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Making+Social+Work+Education+App%27ier+%3A+The+Process+of+Developing+Information-based+Apps+for+Social+Work+Education+and+Practice&amp;rft.au=Campbell%2C+Anne%3BMcColgan%2C+Mary&amp;rft.aulast=Campbell&amp;rft.aufirst=Anne&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=35&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=297&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=02615479&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02615479.2015.1130805

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Making+Social+Work+Education+App%27ier+%3A+The+Process+of+Developing+Information-based+Apps+for+Social+Work+Education+and+Practice&amp;rft.au=Campbell%2C+Anne%3BMcColgan%2C+Mary&amp;rft.aulast=Campbell&amp;rft.aufirst=Anne&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=35&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=297&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=02615479&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02615479.2015.1130805

____________________________________________________________

The application of social media in social work community practice

Author: Sitter, Kathleen C1; Curnew, Ashley H11 School of Social Work, Memorial University, St. John's, Canada

Publication info: Social Work Education ; Abingdon  Vol. 35, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2016): 271-283.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784417703?accountid=14667

Abstract: Advocacy is a core part of social work practice. While social media platforms have grown in popularity in online campaigns, there is little evidence of how social workers can use social media when working with community groups. In this article, we provide an exemplar of an innovative advocacy practice with social media involving community members who created participatory videos as part of a research study, and subsequently integrated the videos into a larger human rights advocacy campaign. The case highlights three forms of social media engagement: platform integration, call-to-action, and blending offline and online advocacy efforts in real time. Included in this article is also a YouTube link to one of the participatory videos. We begin by considering the benefits and concerns of social media in social work education, followed by the implications in the field, with particular attention paid to advocacy. In the second section, we present the case study to demonstrate the application of social media platforms and conclude with practical considerations for social workers adopting social media when working alongside communities in social justice initiatives.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=The+application+of+social+media+in+social+work+community+practice&amp;rft.au=Sitter%2C+Kathleen+C%3BCurnew%2C+Ashley+H&amp;rft.aulast=Sitter&amp;rft.aufirst=Kathleen&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=35&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=271&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=02615479&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02615479.2015.1131257

Social Work and Social Media in Aotearoa New Zealand: Educating Social Workers across Shifting Boundaries of Social Work Identity

Author: Stanfield, Deb1; Beddoe, Liz21 Centre for Health and Social Practice, Waikato Institute of Technology, Hamilton, New Zealand; Faculty of Education and Social Work, School of Counselling, Human Services and Social Work, University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand2 Faculty of Education and Social Work, School of Counselling, Human Services and Social Work, University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand

Publication info: Social Work Education ; Abingdon  Vol. 35, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2016): 284-296.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784417730?accountid=14667

Abstract: The uneasy relationship between the social work profession and the media has led to recognition by social work educators of the need to incorporate knowledge of media processes and skills of media engagement into the social work education agenda. In addition, there is a clear link between traditional media and social media in the social work context, and the tensions experienced in the media landscape resulting from the recent move to 'new media' are relevant to social work and its role in advocating publicly for the rights and needs of vulnerable people. This article makes reference to these ideas in the context of a small Aotearoa New Zealand study that seeks information about social workers' professional use of social media in this country. Ideas offered by professional leaders in social work are thematically analysed, and themes discussed in this article relate to the complex personal and professional identities social workers negotiate as social media users. Implications for social work education are offered, including those that relate to professional identity development and the ever-shifting ethical landscape of social media engagement.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+and+Social+Media+in+Aotearoa+New+Zealand%3A+Educating+Social+Workers+across+Shifting+Boundaries+of+Social+Work+Identity&amp;rft.au=Stanfield%2C+Deb%3BBeddoe%2C+Liz&amp;rft.aulast=Stanfield&amp;rft.aufirst=Deb&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=35&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=284&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=02615479&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02615479.2016.1154663

Social Media and HIV/AIDS: Implications for Social Work Education

Author: Chandran, Devyani11 Department of Health and Community Studies, Western Washington University, Bellingham, United States

Publication info: Social Work Education ; Abingdon  Vol. 35, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2016): 333-343.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784417846?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work educators and practitioners continue to grapple with the strengths and challenges that access to social media provides. This paper presents the use of a range of social media platforms such as Twitter, Facebook, and Weibo in HIV/AIDS prevention and education with hard to reach populations in diverse settings. Lessons learned in the field are applied to areas in social work education with a particular emphasis on enhancing privacy and confidentiality through the use of firewalls and privacy settings on social media and content development with an emphasis on valuing cultural capital of social media users, respecting fellow users and recognizing the utility of social media in conducting research and disseminating research. The role of the professional in guiding and monitoring content and bridging the digital divide for those hard to reach populations are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Media+and+HIV%2FAIDS%3A+Implications+for+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.au=Chandran%2C+Devyani&amp;rft.aulast=Chandran&amp;rft.aufirst=Devyani&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=35&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=333&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=02615479&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02615479.2016.1154659

Deploying virtual communities of practice as a digital tool in social work: a rapid review and critique of the literature

Author: Adedoyin, A Christson A11 Department of Social Work, School of Public Health, College of Health Sciences, Samford University, Birmingham, AL, USA

Publication info: Social Work Education ; Abingdon  Vol. 35, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2016): 357-370.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784417877?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper provides a rapid review, and a critique of extant literature on the use of virtual communities of practice (VCoP) as a type of digital tool in enhancing the social work profession. VCoP are ubiquitous and well documented as increasing the deployment of evidence-based practice interventions, and offers a borderless professional interaction for social workers. To this end, a rapid review of extant literature spanning a decade (2005-2015) was conducted using four electronic databases. Only 10 articles satisfied the inclusion-exclusion criteria out of the 67 potential articles produced from the databases searched. Summary of evidence table showed that Ning, Web 2.0, WebCT, email discussion forum, LISTSERV, and government-based web platforms were mostly used as VCoP digital tools by social workers. The 10 studies amplified VCoP utilization experiences of social workers from Israel, the USA, the UK, and India. Moreover, the study revealed that two major domains of social work (educational institutions and social service agencies) mostly used VCoP. Furthermore, the merits and demerits of VCoP, and a critique of the literature are delineated.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Deploying+virtual+communities+of+practice+as+a+digital+tool+in+social+work%3A+a+rapid+review+and+critique+of+the+literature&amp;rft.au=Adedoyin%2C+A+Christson+A&amp;rft.aulast=Adedoyin&amp;rft.aufirst=A+Christson&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=35&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=357&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=02615479&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02615479.2016.1154660

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Deploying+virtual+communities+of+practice+as+a+digital+tool+in+social+work%3A+a+rapid+review+and+critique+of+the+literature&amp;rft.au=Adedoyin%2C+A+Christson+A&amp;rft.aulast=Adedoyin&amp;rft.aufirst=A+Christson&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=35&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=357&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=02615479&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02615479.2016.1154660

International Collaborative Learning Using Social Media to Learn about Social Work Ethics and Social Media

Author: Knowles, Alan James1; Cooner, Tarsem Singh21 Social Work, MacEwan University, Edmonton, Canada2 Center of Interdisciplinary Excellence in Mental Health, University of Birmingham, Birmingham, UK

Publication info: Social Work Education ; Abingdon  Vol. 35, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2016): 260-270.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784417894?accountid=14667

Abstract: The widespread adoption of social media (SM) has created new ethical challenges for social workers in understanding the use of SM and professional practice. This paper describes a project where social work students participated in international collaborative blended learning using closed Facebook groups to explore ethical issues related to professional practice and SM. The learning design incorporated the use of an innovative smart phone app, an online video case scenario, and asynchronous collaborative learning. The results of students' evaluations, lessons learned and recommendations about the learning design are included in the discussion.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=International+Collaborative+Learning+Using+Social+Media+to+Learn+about+Social+Work+Ethics+and+Social+Media&amp;rft.au=Knowles%2C+Alan+James%3BCooner%2C+Tarsem+Singh&amp;rft.aulast=Knowles&amp;rft.aufirst=Alan&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=35&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=260&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=02615479&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02615479.2016.1154662

Using Facebook as a tool for informal peer support: a case example

Author: Gandy-Guedes, Megan E1; Vance, Michelle M2; Bridgewater, Elisabeth A3; Montgomery, Tchernavia4; Taylor, Kris51 Anne and Henry Zarrow School of Social Work, University of Oklahoma, Norman, OK, USA2 School of Social Work, University of Central Florida, Orlando, FL, USA3 Group Health Cooperative, Seattle, Washington, USA4 School of Social Work, University of North Carolina at Charlotte, Charlotte, NC, USA5 Pat's Place Child Advocacy Center, Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

Publication info: Social Work Education ; Abingdon  Vol. 35, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2016): 323-332.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784417902?accountid=14667

Abstract: The social media site (SMS) Facebook can provide social workers with a method to engage in informal peer support. Scholars to date have mainly focused on SMSs such as Facebook as they pertain to clinical interactions with clients, maintaining professionalism especially among social work students, using them for professional or organizational promotion, and using them as an educational tool. Informal peer groups have been found to be an effective tool to combat burnout in high-stress professions such as social work. The use of a SMS such as Facebook for informal peer support could provide additional benefits to social workers beyond what they would experience from offline contact. This article fills a gap in the literature by describing how a group of practicing social workers use a private Facebook group for peer support, informal consultation, emotional support, and personal social connection. Given the continual high rates of job stress and burnout, social workers should consider new and innovative ways to use SMSs such as Facebook to enhance their self-care efforts.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Using+Facebook+as+a+tool+for+informal+peer+support%3A+a+case+example&amp;rft.au=Gandy-Guedes%2C+Megan+E%3BVance%2C+Michelle+M%3BBridgewater%2C+Elisabeth+A%3BMontgomery%2C+Tchernavia%3BTaylor%2C+Kris&amp;rft.aulast=Gandy-Guedes&amp;rft.aufirst=Megan&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=35&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=323&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=02615479&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02615479.2016.1154937

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Using+Facebook+as+a+tool+for+informal+peer+support%3A+a+case+example&amp;rft.au=Gandy-Guedes%2C+Megan+E%3BVance%2C+Michelle+M%3BBridgewater%2C+Elisabeth+A%3BMontgomery%2C+Tchernavia%3BTaylor%2C+Kris&amp;rft.aulast=Gandy-Guedes&amp;rft.aufirst=Megan&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=35&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=323&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=02615479&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02615479.2016.1154937

Exploring Service Provider Perceptions of Treatment Barriers Facing Black, Non-Gay-Identified MSMW

Author: Forenza, Brad1; Benoit, Ellen21 Montclair State University, Center for Child Advocacy and Policy, Montclair, NJ, USA2 National Development and Research Institutes, Inc., New York, New York, USA

Publication info: Journal of Ethnic & Cultural Diversity in Social Work ; Abingdon  Vol. 25, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 114-129.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784674528?accountid=14667

Abstract: Non-gay-identified men who have sex with men and women and who use alcohol and other drugs are a vulnerable population. Little is known about health and medical service provider interaction with these underserved clients. This article presents a thematic analysis of two focus groups undertaken with social and medical service providers regarding the needs of non-gay-identified men who have sex with men and women. Four emergent themes (labeling, constructions of masculinity, HIV/AIDS awareness, and treatment success) illustrate perceived barriers to HIV/AIDS prevention and treatment, as well as treatment success. Implications for policy, practice, and future research are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+Service+Provider+Perceptions+of+Treatment+Barriers+Facing+Black%2C+Non-Gay-Identified+MSMW&amp;rft.au=Forenza%2C+Brad%3BBenoit%2C+Ellen&amp;rft.aulast=Forenza&amp;rft.aufirst=Brad&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=114&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2015.1071300

Sing ... Then Think: Musical Interventions and Nondeliberative Forms of Practice in Social Work Groups

Author: Olcon, Katarzyna1; Beno, Mary Frances H21 University of Texas at Austin, Austin, Texas USA2 Independent Researcher, Lisle, Illinois USA

Publication info: Social Work with Groups ; New York  Vol. 39, Iss. 2-3,  (Apr/Sep 2016): 129-142.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784674565?accountid=14667

Abstract: The positive effects of music have been demonstrated worldwide in many fields including social work, psychology, medicine, and education. Musical interventions including music listening, lyric analysis, and singing have also been found effective in group work. This article, guided by Norma Lang&apos;s nondeliberative theory, aims to provide the "why," "when," and "how" of incorporating music into social work groups. It also provides the reader with a toolbox of musical interventions and the encouragement to utilize these "artful, actional, and analogic" activities in group work.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Sing+...+Then+Think%3A+Musical+Interventions+and+Nondeliberative+Forms+of+Practice+in+Social+Work+Groups&amp;rft.au=Olcon%2C+Katarzyna%3BBeno%2C+Mary+Frances+H&amp;rft.aulast=Olcon&amp;rft.aufirst=Katarzyna&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=129&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2015.1049929

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Sing+...+Then+Think%3A+Musical+Interventions+and+Nondeliberative+Forms+of+Practice+in+Social+Work+Groups&amp;rft.au=Olcon%2C+Katarzyna%3BBeno%2C+Mary+Frances+H&amp;rft.aulast=Olcon&amp;rft.aufirst=Katarzyna&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=129&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2015.1049929

____________________________________________________________

Supports for College-Bound African-Americans Formerly in Foster Care: A Qualitative Study of Their Influences on Enrollment in College

Author: Lane, Tiffany Yvette11 Undergraduate Social Work Department, West Chester University, West Chester, Pennsylvania, USA

Publication info: Journal of Ethnic & Cultural Diversity in Social Work ; Abingdon  Vol. 25, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 153-171.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784674577?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study provides in-depth descriptive data on the key influences and supports that assisted 10 African-Americans who aged out of foster care with enrolling in college and other tasks related to their transition into college. The findings revealed that participants were affected by social and community supports. Social supports were described by the participants as professional social workers, caseworkers, foster care parents, and clergy. Communal supports were described as churches, community-based organizations, and nonprofit organizations. There was an intersection between the social and communal supports. Although the participants successfully enrolled in college, they suggested that they would have benefited from a college preparation program to prepare them for the college environment. This article notes the implications for effective and culturally sensitive social work practice and the study&apos;s limitations, which suggest areas for further research.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Supports+for+College-Bound+African-Americans+Formerly+in+Foster+Care%3A+A+Qualitative+Study+of+Their+Influences+on+Enrollment+in+College&amp;rft.au=Lane%2C+Tiffany+Yvette&amp;rft.aulast=Lane&amp;rft.aufirst=Tiffany&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=153&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2015.1028120

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Supports+for+College-Bound+African-Americans+Formerly+in+Foster+Care%3A+A+Qualitative+Study+of+Their+Influences+on+Enrollment+in+College&amp;rft.au=Lane%2C+Tiffany+Yvette&amp;rft.aulast=Lane&amp;rft.aufirst=Tiffany&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=153&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2015.1028120

Exploring Nondeliberative Practice through Recreational, Art, and Music-Based Activities in Social Work with Groups

Author: Kelly, Brian L1; Doherty, Lauren11 Loyola University Chicago, School of Social Work, Chicago, Illinois USA

Publication info: Social Work with Groups ; New York  Vol. 39, Iss. 2-3,  (Apr/Sep 2016): 221-233.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784674627?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reviews the history of recreational, arts, and music-based activities in social work with groups, providing a nondeliberative practice context. The article begins with an overview of nondeliberative practice, then presents various uses of recreational, art, and music-based activities during the Settlement House and Recreational Movements, in mid-20th-century group work practice and in present practice. The article concludes with a review of current projects in the Chicago land area and highlights their potential to decrease young person on young person violence.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+Nondeliberative+Practice+through+Recreational%2C+Art%2C+and+Music-Based+Activities+in+Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.au=Kelly%2C+Brian+L%3BDoherty%2C+Lauren&amp;rft.aulast=Kelly&amp;rft.aufirst=Brian&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=221&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2015.1057681

Use of Nondeliberative Practice in Groups for Older Adults with Substance Use and Mental Health Disorder: Group in an Art Gallery

Author: White-Campbell, Marilyn1; Campbell, Burgundy2; Sullivan, Nancy E3; Vindel, Horacio41 Specialized Geriatric Services, Canadian Mental Health Association, Guelph, Ontario, Canada2 Fine Arts Department, Ontario College of Art and Design University, Toronto, Ontario, Canada3 School of Social Work, Memorial University of Newfoundland, Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada4 Crisis Outreach Service for Seniors, Community Outreach Programs in Addictions, Toronto, Ontario, Canada

Publication info: Social Work with Groups ; New York  Vol. 39, Iss. 2-3,  (Apr/Sep 2016): 246-259.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784674631?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents an application of Norma Lang&apos;s nondeliberative theory in groupwork with clients of Community Outreach Programs in Addictions (COPA), a Toronto community-based organization that assists adults age 55 and older who struggle with addictions and mental health. The article illustrates how we challenged concepts of group work which are predominantly discussion-based problem solving or premeditated by hosting a group in a major art gallery with clients considered difficult to serve. What was done is juxtaposed with what might have been done with greater knowledge of nondeliberative theory.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Use+of+Nondeliberative+Practice+in+Groups+for+Older+Adults+with+Substance+Use+and+Mental+Health+Disorder%3A+Group+in+an+Art+Gallery&amp;rft.au=White-Campbell%2C+Marilyn%3BCampbell%2C+Burgundy%3BSullivan%2C+Nancy+E%3BVindel%2C+Horacio&amp;rft.aulast=White-Campbell&amp;rft.aufirst=Marilyn&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=246&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2015.1054774

Group Work Camp as Nondeliberative Process

Author: Bergart, Ann M11 University of Chicago and Loyola University, Chicago, Illinois, USA

Publication info: Social Work with Groups ; New York  Vol. 39, Iss. 2-3,  (Apr/Sep 2016): 183-193.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784674650?accountid=14667

Abstract: The article seeks to identify examples of several features of nondeliberative practice within the process of Group Work Camp, an experiential training program. Camp provides an alternative environment for learning, in which novice group workers can effectively deal with their anxiety about facilitating groups. Examples of specific features of nondeliberative process are identified, including "worker of the self" nondeliberative and deliberative process working in tandem, problem solving without awareness of a problem, casting the problem in manageable form, transforming nondeliberative experience into analog, shifting from artful to actional to analogic forms, and worker role.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Group+Work+Camp+as+Nondeliberative+Process&amp;rft.au=Bergart%2C+Ann+M&amp;rft.aulast=Bergart&amp;rft.aufirst=Ann&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=183&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2015.1047730

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Group+Work+Camp+as+Nondeliberative+Process&amp;rft.au=Bergart%2C+Ann+M&amp;rft.aulast=Bergart&amp;rft.aufirst=Ann&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=183&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2015.1047730

____________________________________________________________

How Creative Group Work Helps Adolescents Create Relations with Self and Peers

Author: Vysniauskyte-Rimkiene, Jorune1; Matuleviciute, Daiva21 Vytautas Magnus University, Department of Social Work, Kaunas, Lithuania2 University of Applied Sciences, Kaunas, Lithuania

Publication info: Social Work with Groups ; New York  Vol. 39, Iss. 2-3,  (Apr/Sep 2016): 234-245.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784674774?accountid=14667

Abstract: Practitioners often face questions about how to approach adolescents to join a group where they can develop healthy relationships with themselves and their peers. A growing number of practitioners and researchers value creative-nondeliberative-forms of working with such groups. This article discusses the artful, actional methods the authors use in their work with time-limited small groups of adolescents (age 14-17) who experienced behavioral challenges. These creative methods were used in settings such as secondary schools, counseling centers, and nongovernmental organizations in Lithuania during social skills training groups facilitated by the social workers.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=How+Creative+Group+Work+Helps+Adolescents+Create+Relations+with+Self+and+Peers&amp;rft.au=Vysniauskyte-Rimkiene%2C+Jorune%3BMatuleviciute%2C+Daiva&amp;rft.aulast=Vysniauskyte-Rimkiene&amp;rft.aufirst=Jorune&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=234&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2015.1056074

Nondeliberative Practice from the Field: Illustrations from a Group Worker

Author: Nosko, Anna11 Family Service Toronto, Ontario, Canada

Publication info: Social Work with Groups ; New York  Vol. 39, Iss. 2-3,  (Apr/Sep 2016): 143-154.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784674788?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reviews features of Lang&apos;s nondeliberative practice and provides illustrations from the field of group work that demonstrate these concepts. Nondeliberative practice enables problem solving in ways other than verbal and cognitive: the experience of a group of women who went on their first Outward Bound trip into the wilderness; adolescents who, through acting as their favorite living creature, made connections in nonverbal ways. The "doing" of the activity-be it symbolic, pictorial, performance, game, or other actional mode- is experienced affectively and analogically, and is transferable to other aspects of life.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Nondeliberative+Practice+from+the+Field%3A+Illustrations+from+a+Group+Worker&amp;rft.au=Nosko%2C+Anna&amp;rft.aulast=Nosko&amp;rft.aufirst=Anna&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=143&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2015.1049856

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Nondeliberative+Practice+from+the+Field%3A+Illustrations+from+a+Group+Worker&amp;rft.au=Nosko%2C+Anna&amp;rft.aulast=Nosko&amp;rft.aufirst=Anna&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=143&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2015.1049856

Nondeliberative Forms of Practice in Social Work: Artful, Actional, Analogic

Author: Lang, Norma C, [dagger]11 Professor Emerita, Factor-Inwentash Faculty of Social Work, University of Toronto, Ontario, Canada

Publication info: Social Work with Groups ; New York  Vol. 39, Iss. 2-3,  (Apr/Sep 2016): 97-117.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784674793?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this article is to explicate the features of a model of practice (and its theoretical supports) that characteristically employs processes other than those that are deliberatively thought out and processed verbally. The model, identified as a nondeliberative form of practice, has the capability of extending significantly the range of social work practice options. This article articulates the central features of nondeliberative forms of practice and provides a conceptual way of thinking about this modality for use throughout the profession, and in particular in social work with groups.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Nondeliberative+Forms+of+Practice+in+Social+Work%3A+Artful%2C+Actional%2C+Analogic&amp;rft.au=Lang%2C+Norma+C%2C+%5Bdagger%5D&amp;rft.aulast=Lang&amp;rft.aufirst=Norma&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=97&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2015.1047701

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Nondeliberative+Forms+of+Practice+in+Social+Work%3A+Artful%2C+Actional%2C+Analogic&amp;rft.au=Lang%2C+Norma+C%2C+%5Bdagger%5D&amp;rft.aulast=Lang&amp;rft.aufirst=Norma&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=97&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2015.1047701

A Punch, A Stitch, A Bell: The Power of Nondeliberative Practice in Social Group Work

Author: Wright, Whitney11 San Francisco, California, USA

Publication info: Social Work with Groups ; New York  Vol. 39, Iss. 2-3,  (Apr/Sep 2016): 170-182.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784674795?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article examines the nondeliberative approach in social work with groups through five qualities inherent in the modality. It explores how the practice stands out as unique and valuable within the field: how it taps what other modalities may not by truly meeting the members where they are in space and time. Using examples taken from an array of social group work programs spanning 20 years, it illustrates how the nondeliberative approach takes place in diverse locations and utilizes diverse mediums and modes of communication. Special recognition is given to Norma Lang who articulated the theory about this approach.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=A+Punch%2C+A+Stitch%2C+A+Bell%3A+The+Power+of+Nondeliberative+Practice+in+Social+Group+Work&amp;rft.au=Wright%2C+Whitney&amp;rft.aulast=Wright&amp;rft.aufirst=Whitney&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=170&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2015.1048417

Facilitating Arts-Based Mindfulness Group Activities with Vulnerable Children: An Example of Nondeliberative Social Group Work Practice

Author: Coholic, Diana A1; Oystrick, Vivian1; Posteraro, Jennifer1; Lougheed, Sean11 Laurentian University, Sudbury, Ontario, Canada

Publication info: Social Work with Groups ; New York  Vol. 39, Iss. 2-3,  (Apr/Sep 2016): 155-169.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784674826?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article discusses the process of facilitating arts-based mindfulness group work and activities with vulnerable children age 8 to 12 years who were involved with the child welfare or mental health systems. Specifically, it delineates connections between our group program and Norma Lang&apos;s nondeliberative social group work practice. Importantly, in working with vulnerable children, the authors purposefully fostered the development of mutual aid, creativity, and strengths and recognized that each group had a life of its own.

Norma Lang's Use of Nondeliberative Approaches: Through a Multidimensional Lens of Activity in Social Work Groups

Author: Shapiro, Ben Zion11 Factor-Inwentash Faculty of Social Work, University of Toronto, Toronto, Ontario, Canada

Publication info: Social Work with Groups ; New York  Vol. 39, Iss. 2-3,  (Apr/Sep 2016): 260-273.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784674867?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article is intended to enter into a conversation with the significant work done by Norma Lang on nondeliberative approaches in social work with groups, and, in particular, her use of these approaches in working with people who have limited social skills. The intention is to locate significant strands of her conceptualizing, teaching, and practice within a discussion of the concept "activity"-a concept that social work with groups has uniquely contributed to social work theory and practice. It is proposed that aspects of "activity" can be more fully understood and analyzed using a number of intersecting dimensions: interaction, purpose, meaning, and analog.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Norma+Lang%27s+Use+of+Nondeliberative+Approaches%3A+Through+a+Multidimensional+Lens+of+Activity+in+Social+Work+Groups&amp;rft.au=Shapiro%2C+Ben+Zion&amp;rft.aulast=Shapiro&amp;rft.aufirst=Ben&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=260&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2015.1048419

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Norma+Lang%27s+Use+of+Nondeliberative+Approaches%3A+Through+a+Multidimensional+Lens+of+Activity+in+Social+Work+Groups&amp;rft.au=Shapiro%2C+Ben+Zion&amp;rft.aulast=Shapiro&amp;rft.aufirst=Ben&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=260&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2015.1048419

Sobresalir: The Undocumented Experience

Author: Mendez-Shannon, Consuelo E1; Daugherty Bailey, Jo11 Department of Social Work, Metropolitan State University of Denver, Denver, Colorado, USA

Publication info: Journal of Ethnic & Cultural Diversity in Social Work ; Abingdon  Vol. 25, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 98-113.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1784674967?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this qualitative study was to explore how undocumented Hispanic immigrants interpret and manage living in the United States. Semi-structured interviews were conducted with 16 participants in New York City. Key findings include that they experience significant culture shock, exacerbated by their immigrant status, and paradoxically, they exhibit a resiliency emanating from their sense of purpose and meaning to their suffering. This study provides social service providers with an insight about the trauma and strengths prevalent among the undocumented and how this knowledge can be used to better serve this community.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Sobresalir%3A+The+Undocumented+Experience&amp;rft.au=Mendez-Shannon%2C+Consuelo+E%3BDaugherty+Bailey%2C+Jo&amp;rft.aulast=Mendez-Shannon&amp;rft.aufirst=Consuelo&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=98&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2015.1134375
