____________________________________________________________

Health behaviors and demographic factors of chronic health conditions among elderly veteran men

Author: Tran, Thanh V1; Canfield, Julie1; Wang, Kaipeng11 School of Social Work, Boston College, Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 4,  (Apr 2016): 328-345.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1786264693?accountid=14667

Abstract: As male veterans age, there are unique opportunities for health-related prevention efforts to be introduced throughout the life cycle to ameliorate the effects of chronic health conditions such as cardiovascular disease, asthma, arthritis, and diabetes. This study analyzed data from the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (2012) with a sample of 27,187 male veterans aged 65-84 years and 4,079 male veterans over 85 years of age. The study examined associations between behaviors, demographics, and five chronic health conditions with variables that included marital status, health insurance coverage, alcohol consumption, smoking history, and income levels. These associations varied between the two age groups, suggesting the need for intervention with veterans across their lifespans. Public health social workers could help veterans modify their health behaviors to prevent the occurrence or worsening of chronic health conditions over time and across the aging process.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Health+behaviors+and+demographic+factors+of+chronic+health+conditions+among+elderly+veteran+men&amp;rft.au=Tran%2C+Thanh+V%3BCanfield%2C+Julie%3BWang%2C+Kaipeng&amp;rft.aulast=Tran&amp;rft.aufirst=Thanh&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=328&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2015.1137255

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Health+behaviors+and+demographic+factors+of+chronic+health+conditions+among+elderly+veteran+men&amp;rft.au=Tran%2C+Thanh+V%3BCanfield%2C+Julie%3BWang%2C+Kaipeng&amp;rft.aulast=Tran&amp;rft.aufirst=Thanh&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=328&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2015.1137255

The cleft team social worker

Author: Kaye, Alison, MD1; Lybrand, Sandra, LMSW, LCSW21 Pediatric Plastic and Cleft Surgery, Children's Mercy Hospital, Kansas City, Missouri, USA2 Department of Social Work, Children's Mercy Hospital, Kansas City, Missouri, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 4,  (Apr 2016): 280-295.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1786264746?accountid=14667

Abstract: The birth of a child with significant medical problems poses challenges for most families. Congenital orofacial clefting is a common condition affecting families worldwide. Orofacial clefting requires long-term medical care and can affect multiple body systems. Having a child with a chronic medical condition such as cleft lip or palate creates many psychosocial ramifications for a family. This article describes the importance of medical social work involvement in the coordinated care for children with cleft lip and palate. Specific cases spanning prenatal care through adolescence are used to highlight the variety of complex psychosocial situations encountered in the multidisciplinary cleft team setting.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=The+cleft+team+social+worker&amp;rft.au=Kaye%2C+Alison%2C+MD%3BLybrand%2C+Sandra%2C+LMSW%2C+LCSW&amp;rft.aulast=Kaye&amp;rft.aufirst=Alison&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=280&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1145168

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=The+cleft+team+social+worker&amp;rft.au=Kaye%2C+Alison%2C+MD%3BLybrand%2C+Sandra%2C+LMSW%2C+LCSW&amp;rft.aulast=Kaye&amp;rft.aufirst=Alison&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=280&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1145168

____________________________________________________________

Seriously clowning: Medical clowning interaction with children undergoing invasive examinations in hospitals

Author: Tener, Dafna, PhD1; Ofir, Shoshi, MA2; Lev-Wiesel, Rachel, PhD3; Franco, Nessia L, MD2; On, Avi, MD41 The Paul Baerwald School of Social Work and Social Welfare, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Israel2 The Baruch Padeh Medical Center, Poriya, Israel3 The Emili Sagol Creative Arts Therapies Research Center, University of Haifa, Haifa, Israel4 Pediatric GI Unit, Baruch Padeh Medical Center, The Faculty of Medicine in the Galilee, Bar-Ilan University, Safed, Israel

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 4,  (Apr 2016): 296-313.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1786269774?accountid=14667

Abstract: This qualitative study examined the subjective experience of children undergoing an invasive examination in the hospital when accompanied by a medical clown. In-depth semi-structured interviews were conducted with nine such children and nine of their accompanying parents. The children were patients in two outpatient departments (Pediatric Gastroenterology and a Center for the Sexually Abused) in a hospital in Israel. Interviews were coded thematically using an Atlas.ti software program. Analysis of the interviews indicated that the intervention of the clown positively changed the children&apos;s perceptions of the hospital, of experiencing the examination, and of their life narrative. Medical clowns thus appear to be a central, meaningful, and therapeutic source for children undergoing invasive examinations in hospital, as well as for their parents. Therefore, it may be advisable to incorporate medical clowns as an integral part of medical teams performing invasive procedures and to include the clowns in all stages of the hospital visit.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Seriously+clowning%3A+Medical+clowning+interaction+with+children+undergoing+invasive+examinations+in+hospitals&amp;rft.au=Tener%2C+Dafna%2C+PhD%3BOfir%2C+Shoshi%2C+MA%3BLev-Wiesel%2C+Rachel%2C+PhD%3BFranco%2C+Nessia+L%2C+MD%3BOn%2C+Avi%2C+MD&amp;rft.aulast=Tener&amp;rft.aufirst=Dafna&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=296&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1141826

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Seriously+clowning%3A+Medical+clowning+interaction+with+children+undergoing+invasive+examinations+in+hospitals&amp;rft.au=Tener%2C+Dafna%2C+PhD%3BOfir%2C+Shoshi%2C+MA%3BLev-Wiesel%2C+Rachel%2C+PhD%3BFranco%2C+Nessia+L%2C+MD%3BOn%2C+Avi%2C+MD&amp;rft.aulast=Tener&amp;rft.aufirst=Dafna&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=296&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1141826

____________________________________________________________

A model of integrated health care in a poverty-impacted community in New York City: Importance of early detection and addressing potential barriers to intervention implementation

Author: Acri, Mary C1; Bornheimer, Lindsay A1; O'Brien, Kyle1; Sezer, Sara2; Little, Virna2; Cleek, Andrew F1; McKay, Mary M11 McSilver Institute for Poverty Policy & Research, New York University Medical Center, New York, New York, USA2 The Institute for Family Health, New York, New York, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 4,  (Apr 2016): 314-327.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1786270518?accountid=14667

Abstract: Disruptive behavior disorders (DBDs) are chronic, impairing, and costly behavioral health conditions that are four times more prevalent among children of color living in impoverished communities as compared to the general population. This disparity is largely due to the increased exposure to stressors related to low socioeconomic status including community violence, unstable housing, under supported schools, substance abuse, and limited support systems. However, despite high rates and greater need, there is a considerably lower rate of mental health service utilization among these youth. Accordingly, the current study aims to describe a unique model of integrated health care for ethnically diverse youth living in a New York City borough. With an emphasis on addressing possible barriers to implementation, integrated models for children have the potential to prevent ongoing mental health problems through early detection and intervention.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=A+model+of+integrated+health+care+in+a+poverty-impacted+community+in+New+York+City%3A+Importance+of+early+detection+and+addressing+potential+barriers+to+intervention+implementation&amp;rft.au=Acri%2C+Mary+C%3BBornheimer%2C+Lindsay+A%3BO%27Brien%2C+Kyle%3BSezer%2C+Sara%3BLittle%2C+Virna%3BCleek%2C+Andrew+F%3BMcKay%2C+Mary+M&amp;rft.aulast=Acri&amp;rft.aufirst=Mary&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=314&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2015.1137256

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=A+model+of+integrated+health+care+in+a+poverty-impacted+community+in+New+York+City%3A+Importance+of+early+detection+and+addressing+potential+barriers+to+intervention+implementation&amp;rft.au=Acri%2C+Mary+C%3BBornheimer%2C+Lindsay+A%3BO%27Brien%2C+Kyle%3BSezer%2C+Sara%3BLittle%2C+Virna%3BCleek%2C+Andrew+F%3BMcKay%2C+Mary+M&amp;rft.aulast=Acri&amp;rft.aufirst=Mary&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=314&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2015.1137256

____________________________________________________________

Feasibility and Acceptability of Smartphone Assessment in Older Adults with Cognitive and Emotional Difficulties

Author: Ramsey, Alex T1; Wetherell, Julie Loebach2; Depp, Colin2; Dixon, David1; Lenze, Eric11 Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis, Missouri2 VA San Diego Healthcare System, San Diego, California; University of California, San Diego, California

Publication info: Journal of Technology in Human Services ; New York  Vol. 34, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 209-223.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1787721742?accountid=14667

Abstract: This feasibility study assessed perceived acceptability, adherence rates, and reasons for nonadherence to smartphone-based ecological momentary assessment (EMA). At two sites, participants (n = 103) ages 65 years or older with diagnosed anxiety or depressive disorder and cognitive concerns responded three times daily to smartphone-based EMA questions assessing clinical outcomes for two 10-day periods. Quantitative and qualitative measures followed both 10-day EMA periods. Overall, 76% of participants completed surveys on [greater than or equal to] 10 of the 20 assessment days, and 70% of participants completed at least 30% of the total surveys. Reasons for nonadherence included technical, logistical, physiological, and cognitive issues. Smartphone-based EMA is feasible in older adults with cognitive and emotional difficulties. EMA tools should be responsive to the needs and preferences of participants to ensure adequate acceptability and adherence in this population. Our findings can inform the design, development, and implementation of mobile technologies in older adults in research and clinical contexts.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.atitle=Feasibility+and+Acceptability+of+Smartphone+Assessment+in+Older+Adults+with+Cognitive+and+Emotional+Difficulties&amp;rft.au=Ramsey%2C+Alex+T%3BWetherell%2C+Julie+Loebach%3BDepp%2C+Colin%3BDixon%2C+David%3BLenze%2C+Eric&amp;rft.aulast=Ramsey&amp;rft.aufirst=Alex&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=209&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.issn=15228835&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228835.2016.1170649

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.atitle=Feasibility+and+Acceptability+of+Smartphone+Assessment+in+Older+Adults+with+Cognitive+and+Emotional+Difficulties&amp;rft.au=Ramsey%2C+Alex+T%3BWetherell%2C+Julie+Loebach%3BDepp%2C+Colin%3BDixon%2C+David%3BLenze%2C+Eric&amp;rft.aulast=Ramsey&amp;rft.aufirst=Alex&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=209&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.issn=15228835&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228835.2016.1170649

Subject: Cognition; Acceptability; Adults; Anxiety-Depression; Assessment; Clinical outcomes; Clinical research; Depressive personality disorders; Feasibility; Older people; Elderly; Anxiety; Treatment outcomes; Cognitive development; Environmental factors

Promoting Well-Being Through Relationship Building: The Role of Smartphone Technology in Foster Care

Author: Denby, Ramona W1; Gomez, Efren2; Alford, Keith A31 School of Social Work, University of Nevada Las Vegas, Las Vegas, Nevada2 The Lincy Institute, University of Nevada Las Vegas, Las Vegas, Nevada3 School of Social Work, Falk College of Sport and Human Dynamics, Syracuse University, Syracuse, New York

Publication info: Journal of Technology in Human Services ; New York  Vol. 34, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 183-208.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1787721770?accountid=14667

Abstract: Mindful of the tremendous risk factors that foster youths encounter, a federal demonstration project sought to increase their protective factors and to mitigate their adverse experiences. The ability to form and maintain healthy relationships is a key protective factor as it helps youths navigate life&apos;s challenges, especially those challenges that result from unresolved loss and grief as a result of being in care. The study was guided by a relational competence framework. The youths were issued smartphones, and their social service providers were given a Web-based application designed to increase communication between the foster youths, their providers, and their mentors. Findings reveal several favorable outcomes associated with the use of the smartphones but also several unintended negative consequences. Recommendations for balancing youths&apos;, caregivers&apos;, and providers&apos; needs, positions, and rights are discussed. Likewise, the authors discuss the study&apos;s implications for program development that utilizes smartphone technology to increase youths&apos; ability to experience healthy relationships.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.atitle=Promoting+Well-Being+Through+Relationship+Building%3A+The+Role+of+Smartphone+Technology+in+Foster+Care&amp;rft.au=Denby%2C+Ramona+W%3BGomez%2C+Efren%3BAlford%2C+Keith+A&amp;rft.aulast=Denby&amp;rft.aufirst=Ramona&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=183&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.issn=15228835&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228835.2016.1168761

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.atitle=Promoting+Well-Being+Through+Relationship+Building%3A+The+Role+of+Smartphone+Technology+in+Foster+Care&amp;rft.au=Denby%2C+Ramona+W%3BGomez%2C+Efren%3BAlford%2C+Keith+A&amp;rft.aulast=Denby&amp;rft.aufirst=Ramona&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=183&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.issn=15228835&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228835.2016.1168761

Understanding Client Communities Spatially for Developing Effective Interventions: Application of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) Technology for Program Planning in Health and Human Services Agencies

Author: Mandayam, Gokul1; Joosten, Dawn11 University of Southern California, Los Angeles, California

Publication info: Journal of Technology in Human Services ; New York  Vol. 34, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 171-182.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1787721786?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social workers are better equipped to understand the need to incorporate geographical aspects pertaining to their clients&apos; lives as part of their practice, given the significant influence these factors have on client well-being. Geographic Information Systems (GIS) technology is a useful tool for administrators and planners to make informed decisions regarding human service programs including examining program outcomes and impact as well as streamlining program implementation. This article synthesizes the literature to date on GIS in health and human services with examples of real world applications.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.atitle=Understanding+Client+Communities+Spatially+for+Developing+Effective+Interventions%3A+Application+of+Geographic+Information+Systems+%28GIS%29+Technology+for+Program+Planning+in+Health+and+Human+Services+Agencies&amp;rft.au=Mandayam%2C+Gokul%3BJoosten%2C+Dawn&amp;rft.aulast=Mandayam&amp;rft.aufirst=Gokul&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=171&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.issn=15228835&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228835.2015.1133370

Conceptualizing a Mobile App for Foster Youth Transitioning to Adulthood: A Mixed-Method Approach

Author: Miller, J Jay1; Chih, Ming-Yuan1; Washington, Earl21 College of Social Work, University of Kentucky, Lexington, Kentucky2 Kentucky United Methodist Home for Children and Youth, Lexington, Kentucky

Publication info: Journal of Technology in Human Services ; New York  Vol. 34, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 145-170.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1787721839?accountid=14667

Abstract: Despite the promise of mobile smartphone applications (apps) in addressing challenges faced by foster youth transitioning to adulthood, the literature is devoid of conceptual frameworks for the development of these apps. This article documents the process of using Concept Mapping to delineate a conceptual framework germane to developing an app to assist youth transitioning from foster care to adulthood, and explore differences in development priority areas among participants. Participant data was collected via qualitative brainstorming sessions, and analyzed using multidimensional scaling and hierarchical cluster analysis. This article explicates findings from this study, discusses implications, and identifies apposite areas for future research.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.atitle=Conceptualizing+a+Mobile+App+for+Foster+Youth+Transitioning+to+Adulthood%3A+A+Mixed-Method+Approach&amp;rft.au=Miller%2C+J+Jay%3BChih%2C+Ming-Yuan%3BWashington%2C+Earl&amp;rft.aulast=Miller&amp;rft.aufirst=J&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=145&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.issn=15228835&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228835.2015.1108260

Heads in the Cloud: An Example of Practice-Based Information and Communication Technology in Child Welfare

Author: Tregeagle, Susan11 Program Services, Barnardos Australia, Sydney, Australia; Faculty of Education and Social Work, University of Sydney, Sydney, Australia

Publication info: Journal of Technology in Human Services ; New York  Vol. 34, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 224-239.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1787721876?accountid=14667

Abstract: Changes in information and communications technology (ICT) in human services have accelerated rapidly and have elicited academic concern about the impact on practice, changes in approaches to implementation, and a shift to user-led development. This article describes the development of ICT by a nongovernment child welfare agency over the past two decades. It is guided by a social constructionist view of technology in which technology is shaped by social factors, but in turn shapes the "social" implementation as requiring the integration of two distinct technologies: a standardized framework for practice and the computer. Both technologies had to be carefully aligned to workplace culture, but the interests of workers have not been allowed to dominate those of and children and families. The organization of work has had to change. This article explores the agency&apos;s experience drawing on theories of implementation of ICT in human services.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.atitle=Heads+in+the+Cloud%3A+An+Example+of+Practice-Based+Information+and+Communication+Technology+in+Child+Welfare&amp;rft.au=Tregeagle%2C+Susan&amp;rft.aulast=Tregeagle&amp;rft.aufirst=Susan&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=224&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.issn=15228835&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228835.2016.1177479

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.atitle=Heads+in+the+Cloud%3A+An+Example+of+Practice-Based+Information+and+Communication+Technology+in+Child+Welfare&amp;rft.au=Tregeagle%2C+Susan&amp;rft.aulast=Tregeagle&amp;rft.aufirst=Susan&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=224&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.issn=15228835&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228835.2016.1177479

AMHP Work: Dirty or Prestigious? Dirty Work Designations and the Approved Mental Health Professional

Author: Morriss, Lisa

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2016): 703.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1788497461?accountid=14667

Abstract: The paper explores the notion of 'dirty work' in relation to the newly created role of the Approved Mental Health Professional (AMHP). An AMHP undertakes various duties set out in the 1983 Mental Health Act, as amended by the 2007 Act, in relation to assessments to make applications for compulsory admission to psychiatric hospital. It has been argued that undertaking this social control function is 'dirty work'. However, the findings from a study of social work AMHPs in England suggest that the picture is more complex. Extracts from narrative interviews are analysed using dialogical narrative analysis. Rather than being designated as dirty work, AMHP duty was presented as prestigious and as advanced social work. However, through their storytelling, the social workers clearly delineated the aspects of AMHP work that they did designate as dirty, specifically the lack of beds, the complexities of co-ordination and the emotional labour which is an inherent part of the work. [web URL: http://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/3/703.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=AMHP+Work%3A+Dirty+or+Prestigious%3F+Dirty+Work+Designations+and+the+Approved+Mental+Health+Professional&amp;rft.au=Morriss%2C+Lisa&amp;rft.aulast=Morriss&amp;rft.aufirst=Lisa&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=703&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=AMHP+Work%3A+Dirty+or+Prestigious%3F+Dirty+Work+Designations+and+the+Approved+Mental+Health+Professional&amp;rft.au=Morriss%2C+Lisa&amp;rft.aulast=Morriss&amp;rft.aufirst=Lisa&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=703&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Working with Women with a Learning Disability Experiencing Domestic Abuse: How Social Workers Can Negotiate Competing Definitions of Risk

Author: Dixon, Jeremy; Robb, Megan

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2016): 773.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1788497476?accountid=14667

Abstract: Women with a learning disability who experience domestic abuse receive intervention from both social services and the police. Responses from these services have increasingly become focused on notions of risk. This article uses governmentality theory to examine how risk is understood and managed by both services through a focus on policy and practice. The article examines how policy directs social workers to promote positive risk taking whilst assessing and managing risk for those deemed vulnerable or lacking mental capacity to self-protect. It is argued that, whilst social work decision making around risk has primarily been based on the judgement of individual workers, the police have increasingly adopted assessments utilising calculative measures. In addition, the article explores the extent to which these women are treated as autonomous agents responsible for managing their own risk. It is argued that social workers and the police should adopt a common screening process to highlight groups of women who may be at risk of abuse. In addition, social workers should draw on their interpersonal skills to enable women with a learning disability to recognise and make informed choices about abuse. [web URL: http://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/3/773.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Working+with+Women+with+a+Learning+Disability+Experiencing+Domestic+Abuse%3A+How+Social+Workers+Can+Negotiate+Competing+Definitions+of+Risk&amp;rft.au=Dixon%2C+Jeremy%3BRobb%2C+Megan&amp;rft.aulast=Dixon&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeremy&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=773&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Working+with+Women+with+a+Learning+Disability+Experiencing+Domestic+Abuse%3A+How+Social+Workers+Can+Negotiate+Competing+Definitions+of+Risk&amp;rft.au=Dixon%2C+Jeremy%3BRobb%2C+Megan&amp;rft.aulast=Dixon&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeremy&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=773&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Mental Health Workers' Perception of Role Self-Efficacy and the Organisational Climate Regarding the Ethos of Recovery

Author: MacAteer, Aidan; Manktelow, Roger; Fitzsimons, Lelia

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2016): 737.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1788497606?accountid=14667

Abstract: The recent organisational changes in mental health service delivery with their increasing emphasis on implementing and evaluating recovery-oriented practice have implications for ongoing professional development. This study examined the relationship between work-related self-efficacy, organisational climate in terms of perceived service resilience, and the organisational conditions of role conflict and role ambiguity. A survey of members of community and hospital mental health multidisciplinary teams in a Northern Ireland Health and Social Care integrated Trust was conducted. Sixty-seven of a sample of one hundred and ten mental health staff, including social workers, nurses, occupational therapists and day-care workers, in three service settings including hospital, community and day-care completed a thirty-eight-item questionnaire. The questionnaire contained four scales measuring organisational change, self-efficacy, and role conflict and role ambiguity. Results showed that there were strong negative correlations between organisational climate and role stressors, and a negative correlation of moderate significance between self-efficacy and role ambiguity. The researchers suggest that task-specific, self-efficacy measures could be used routinely with increased reflective practice to promote a reduction in role ambiguity. The continued use of personal and professional recovery-enhancing measures as part of service evaluation is also advocated. [web URL: http://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/3/737.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Mental+Health+Workers%27+Perception+of+Role+Self-Efficacy+and+the+Organisational+Climate+Regarding+the+Ethos+of+Recovery&amp;rft.au=MacAteer%2C+Aidan%3BManktelow%2C+Roger%3BFitzsimons%2C+Lelia&amp;rft.aulast=MacAteer&amp;rft.aufirst=Aidan&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=737&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Mental+Health+Workers%27+Perception+of+Role+Self-Efficacy+and+the+Organisational+Climate+Regarding+the+Ethos+of+Recovery&amp;rft.au=MacAteer%2C+Aidan%3BManktelow%2C+Roger%3BFitzsimons%2C+Lelia&amp;rft.aulast=MacAteer&amp;rft.aufirst=Aidan&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=737&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Power, Choice and Control: How Do Personal Budgets Affect the Experiences of People with Mental Health Problems and Their Relationships with Social Workers and Other Practitioners?

Author: Hamilton, Sarah; Tew, Jerry; Szymczynska, Paulina; Clewett, Naomi; Manthorpe, Jill; Larsen, John; Pinfold, Vanessa

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2016): 719.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1788497629?accountid=14667

Abstract: There has been substantial research on the implementation of personal budgets across adult social care in England, but relatively little exploration of take-up within the field of mental health -- and whether personal budgets are providing an effective mechanism for service users to exercise greater power, choice and control in their lives. Drawing upon in-depth interviews with fifty-two people using mental-health-related social care services and twenty-eight social work and other practitioners, undertaken for a national study in 2010-13, this paper explores experiences from their different perspectives. Interviews were undertaken in three English local authorities which were at different stages of implementing personal budgets in mental health social care. Data were analysed using an Interpretive Framework Approach. The findings provide evidence of how personal budgets may deliver opportunities for people to take more power and control, sometimes collaboratively with practitioners, and also identify some of the barriers and challenges which can militate against such outcomes. A key factor in enabling personal budgets to support empowerment and recovery was reported to be the quality and continuity of the professional relationship -- which raises particular implications for the organisation of mental health social work and the organisational cultures within which this is situated. [web URL: http://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/3/719.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Power%2C+Choice+and+Control%3A+How+Do+Personal+Budgets+Affect+the+Experiences+of+People+with+Mental+Health+Problems+and+Their+Relationships+with+Social+Workers+and+Other+Practitioners%3F&amp;rft.au=Hamilton%2C+Sarah%3BTew%2C+Jerry%3BSzymczynska%2C+Paulina%3BClewett%2C+Naomi%3BManthorpe%2C+Jill%3BLarsen%2C+John%3BPinfold%2C+Vanessa&amp;rft.aulast=Hamilton&amp;rft.aufirst=Sarah&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=719&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Power%2C+Choice+and+Control%3A+How+Do+Personal+Budgets+Affect+the+Experiences+of+People+with+Mental+Health+Problems+and+Their+Relationships+with+Social+Workers+and+Other+Practitioners%3F&amp;rft.au=Hamilton%2C+Sarah%3BTew%2C+Jerry%3BSzymczynska%2C+Paulina%3BClewett%2C+Naomi%3BManthorpe%2C+Jill%3BLarsen%2C+John%3BPinfold%2C+Vanessa&amp;rft.aulast=Hamilton&amp;rft.aufirst=Sarah&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=719&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Work Knowledge Production and Utilisation: An International Comparison

Author: Kreisberg, Nicole; Marsh, Jeanne C

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2016): 599.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1788497658?accountid=14667

Abstract: The social work profession has a long-standing commitment to social innovation and to the production and utilisation of knowledge to improve social work processes, practices and social welfare policy. To extend understanding of knowledge production and utilisation in social work, this study compares the most highly cited US and European social work articles in their contributions to a cumulative body of research and scholarship that is contributing to knowledge development and innovation in the field. One hundred highly cited English-language articles were analysed from a previous study: sixty-nine US articles and thirty-one European articles. To assess the types of knowledge social work readers and writers find most important, the articles were first classified by content. They then were categorised into non-research or research articles, with the research articles further delineated by their potential contribution to practice decision making. The results show the majority of European articles are about the profession of social work itself or theory while US articles report widely on populations, research and intervention effectiveness. The majority of articles in Europe are non-research articles, whereas the majority of articles in the USA are research articles. Among research and non-research articles, 15 per cent of US articles report on intervention effectiveness, while 3 per cent of European articles report on intervention effectiveness. [web URL: http://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/3/599.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+Knowledge+Production+and+Utilisation%3A+An+International+Comparison&amp;rft.au=Kreisberg%2C+Nicole%3BMarsh%2C+Jeanne+C&amp;rft.aulast=Kreisberg&amp;rft.aufirst=Nicole&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=599&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+Knowledge+Production+and+Utilisation%3A+An+International+Comparison&amp;rft.au=Kreisberg%2C+Nicole%3BMarsh%2C+Jeanne+C&amp;rft.aulast=Kreisberg&amp;rft.aufirst=Nicole&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=599&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Dilemmas of Contemporary Social Work: A Case Study of the Social Work Degree in England

Author: Higgins, Martyn; Popple, Keith; Crichton, Nicola

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2016): 619.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1788497730?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Social Work Reform Board's changes were implemented to improve the professional standards and reputation of social work in England. However, the government is already reviewing both social work education and social work practice even as the reforms are implemented. The aim of this paper is to explore whether the dilemmas of social work education and practice are linked to a fundamental debate about the nature and future of contemporary social work. A qualitative case study of a social work degree programme in England was completed after ethical approval was given. Data were collected at two different points in time by means of interviews and focus groups. A total of forty-eight participants contributed to the study. A thematic analysis was adopted. The findings suggested there were a number of conflicts or contradictions within the degree which were reflected in qualified social work practice. The contribution of this study is to the current discussions about qualifying education and social work practice. Its key message is that the contradictions of qualifying education, practice and models of social work reflect the debates about the nature and purpose of contemporary social work. [web URL: http://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/3/619.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Dilemmas+of+Contemporary+Social+Work%3A+A+Case+Study+of+the+Social+Work+Degree+in+England&amp;rft.au=Higgins%2C+Martyn%3BPopple%2C+Keith%3BCrichton%2C+Nicola&amp;rft.aulast=Higgins&amp;rft.aufirst=Martyn&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=619&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Dilemmas+of+Contemporary+Social+Work%3A+A+Case+Study+of+the+Social+Work+Degree+in+England&amp;rft.au=Higgins%2C+Martyn%3BPopple%2C+Keith%3BCrichton%2C+Nicola&amp;rft.aulast=Higgins&amp;rft.aufirst=Martyn&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=619&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Understanding Depression from Different Paradigms: Toward an Eclectic Social Work Approach

Author: Huang, Yu-Te; Fang, Lin

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2016): 756.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1788498048?accountid=14667

Abstract: Depression is a significant mental health issue that many social workers encounter in their practice. There is great deal of theoretical and empirical knowledge concerning depression that stems from different paradigms. In this paper, we argue for the importance of understanding depression from four paradigms, post-positivism, social constructivism, critical theory and Eastern paradigm, and we illuminate how depression would be known and dealt with by these paradigmatic approaches. Given multiple paradigms available in understanding depression, we argue that social workers need to have the ability to appreciate and discern these different paradigms. Such ability can help strengthen social work practice. We further illustrate an eclectic approach that not only allows social workers to recognise the utilities and limitations of different paradigms, but also enables them to be dynamic, effectively addressing a range of issues when working with a service user who has depression. [web URL: http://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/3/756.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Understanding+Depression+from+Different+Paradigms%3A+Toward+an+Eclectic+Social+Work+Approach&amp;rft.au=Huang%2C+Yu-Te%3BFang%2C+Lin&amp;rft.aulast=Huang&amp;rft.aufirst=Yu-Te&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=756&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Understanding+Depression+from+Different+Paradigms%3A+Toward+an+Eclectic+Social+Work+Approach&amp;rft.au=Huang%2C+Yu-Te%3BFang%2C+Lin&amp;rft.aulast=Huang&amp;rft.aufirst=Yu-Te&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=756&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Retracing the Historical Social Care Context of Autism: A Narrative Overview

Author: D'Astous, Valerie; Manthorpe, Jill; Lowton, Karen; Glaser, Karen

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2016): 789.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1788498601?accountid=14667

Abstract: Autism is a lifelong neurodevelopmental disorder requiring various levels of social support across the life course. Early cohorts of children first diagnosed as having autism are now middle-aged or older. Needs for support and services, meaningful and accurate information, and acceptance are substantial among both families supporting a person with autism and people with autism themselves. Social awareness and services for people with autism have changed over time; however, there is a paucity of reviews of the social context and services available since autism's 'discovery'. This narrative overview explores historically the social care services available to adults with autism and their families, in the context of changes in societal understanding and awareness of autism over time in England. Such an approach may contribute to understandings of older people with autism who have had a label of autism for many decades or who may have acquired this in later life. Retracing the historical social context and care services for autism contextualises the life course experiences and interactions with social workers of today's adults with autism and their families. This review may assist social workers supporting adults with autism and their families to have a better understanding of service trajectories and why contact with professionals may be or has been varied and inconsistent. The key themes from this narrative review suggest the interconnections between scientific development, social awareness and service provision for individuals with autism and their families and changes in social care over time. [web URL: http://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/3/789.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Retracing+the+Historical+Social+Care+Context+of+Autism%3A+A+Narrative+Overview&amp;rft.au=D%27Astous%2C+Valerie%3BManthorpe%2C+Jill%3BLowton%2C+Karen%3BGlaser%2C+Karen&amp;rft.aulast=D%27Astous&amp;rft.aufirst=Valerie&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=789&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Retracing+the+Historical+Social+Care+Context+of+Autism%3A+A+Narrative+Overview&amp;rft.au=D%27Astous%2C+Valerie%3BManthorpe%2C+Jill%3BLowton%2C+Karen%3BGlaser%2C+Karen&amp;rft.aulast=D%27Astous&amp;rft.aufirst=Valerie&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=789&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Thinking about Thinking after Munro: The Contribution of Cognitive Interviewing to Child-Care Social Work Supervision and Decision-Making Practices

Author: Turney, Danielle; Ruch, Gillian

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 46, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2016): 669.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1788500415?accountid=14667

Abstract: There has been a recurrent recognition in inquiry reports following high-profile deaths of children known to welfare services of shortcomings in social workers' analytical and assessment skills. There is an urgent need to explore what might help supervisors and practitioners 'think about their thinking'. This paper draws on cognitive interviewing (CI) and examines its applicability/transferability to the professional domain of child-care social work supervision. Focusing on how practitioners make sense of their practice, this approach homes in on cognitive understandings but, in so doing, heightens practitioners' awareness of the emotional and affective dimensions of practice and of their thinking. The integration of cognitive and affective ways of knowing resonates with psycho-socially informed ideas about the interrelationship between thinking and feeling and the importance of emotional containment for effective thinking. This paper suggests that combining the psychological underpinnings of CI with psycho-socially informed concepts, such as containment, creates a more robust and holistic theoretical framework for supporting the application of CI in practice. The paper proposes that the adoption of a cognitive and affective approach to supervisory practice has considerable potential for enhancing practitioners' critical thinking skills and decision-making capabilities, to the benefit of the children and families with whom they work. [web URL: http://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/3/669.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Thinking+about+Thinking+after+Munro%3A+The+Contribution+of+Cognitive+Interviewing+to+Child-Care+Social+Work+Supervision+and+Decision-Making+Practices&amp;rft.au=Turney%2C+Danielle%3BRuch%2C+Gillian&amp;rft.aulast=Turney&amp;rft.aufirst=Danielle&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=669&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Thinking+about+Thinking+after+Munro%3A+The+Contribution+of+Cognitive+Interviewing+to+Child-Care+Social+Work+Supervision+and+Decision-Making+Practices&amp;rft.au=Turney%2C+Danielle%3BRuch%2C+Gillian&amp;rft.aulast=Turney&amp;rft.aufirst=Danielle&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=669&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Reclaiming and Reimagining Macro Social Work Education: A Collective Biography

Author: Netting, F Ellen; O'Connor, Mary Katherine; Cole, Portia L; Hopkins, Karen; Jones, Jenny L; Kim, Youngmi; Leisey, Monica; Mulroy, Elizabeth A; Rotabi, Karen Smith; Thomas, M Lori; Weil, Marie O; Wike, Traci L

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 157-169.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1789449859?accountid=14667

Abstract: The authors focus on a collective biography of 12 women social work educators, all either tenured or in tenure lines, from five different universities at the time of the study. The participants represent several aspects of macro practice including administration, planning, community practice, and policy. Beginning with reflections about coming into macro practice, we highlight memories about first teaching experiences and examine cultural shifts discovered in our academic journeys. We feature students who inspired us and perceptions of challenges in curricular development affecting the preparation of students. This article includes comments that emphasize the themes and focus of our collective reflections. Finally, we place what we learned in the context of a report from the Association for Community Organization and Social Administration calling for the visibility of and advocacy for macro social work education.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Reclaiming+and+Reimagining+Macro+Social+Work+Education%3A+A+Collective+Biography&amp;rft.au=Netting%2C+F+Ellen%3BO%27Connor%2C+Mary+Katherine%3BCole%2C+Portia+L%3BHopkins%2C+Karen%3BJones%2C+Jenny+L%3BKim%2C+Youngmi%3BLeisey%2C+Monica%3BMulroy%2C+Elizabeth+A%3BRotabi%2C+Karen+Smith%3BThomas%2C+M+Lori%3BWeil%2C+Marie+O%3BWike%2C+Traci+L&amp;rft.aulast=Netting&amp;rft.aufirst=F&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=157&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1151271

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Reclaiming+and+Reimagining+Macro+Social+Work+Education%3A+A+Collective+Biography&amp;rft.au=Netting%2C+F+Ellen%3BO%27Connor%2C+Mary+Katherine%3BCole%2C+Portia+L%3BHopkins%2C+Karen%3BJones%2C+Jenny+L%3BKim%2C+Youngmi%3BLeisey%2C+Monica%3BMulroy%2C+Elizabeth+A%3BRotabi%2C+Karen+Smith%3BThomas%2C+M+Lori%3BWeil%2C+Marie+O%3BWike%2C+Traci+L&amp;rft.aulast=Netting&amp;rft.aufirst=F&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=157&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1151271

Social Workers' Conflict of Loyalty in the Context of Social Activism: The Case of the 2011 Social Protests in Israel

Author: Makaros, Ayelet1; Grodofsky, Merav Moshe21 Luis and Gabi Weisfeld School of Social Work, Bar-Ilan University, Ramat-Gan, Israel2 School of Social Work, Sapir College, D.N. Hof Ashkelon, Israel

Publication info: Journal of Community Practice ; Abingdon  Vol. 24, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 147-165.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1789957942?accountid=14667

Abstract: This qualitative study examined the experiences of social workers who participated in the 2011 Israeli social protests. Data were collected through 1 focus group interview. The sample included 11 social workers employed in 11 social welfare departments throughout the country. Findings highlight the complexities and dilemmas experienced by social workers who protested against the system that employs them. Research findings contribute to the discourse regarding the conflict of loyalty experienced by public social workers engaged in social activism that targets the system that employs them.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Workers%27+Conflict+of+Loyalty+in+the+Context+of+Social+Activism%3A+The+Case+of+the+2011+Social+Protests+in+Israel&amp;rft.au=Makaros%2C+Ayelet%3BGrodofsky%2C+Merav+Moshe&amp;rft.aulast=Makaros&amp;rft.aufirst=Ayelet&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=147&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2016.1164784

&quot;What the Social Worker has done for Public Health&quot;: Homer Folk&apos;s 1917 Speech on the Interdisciplinary Efforts of Public Health Social Workers during the Progressive Era

Author: Hitchcock, Laurel Iverson11 Department of Social Work, University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, AL, USA

Publication info: Journal of Community Practice ; Abingdon  Vol. 24, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 215-221.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1789958002?accountid=14667

Abstract: This From the Archives selection shows how social workers in the Progressive Era were actively engaged in public health practice, frequently working with other disciplines to improve the health of clients and communities.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=%26amp%3Bquot%3BWhat+the+Social+Worker+has+done+for+Public+Health%26amp%3Bquot%3B%3A+Homer+Folk%26amp%3Bapos%3Bs+1917+Speech+on+the+Interdisciplinary+Efforts+of+Public+Health+Social+Workers+during+the+Progressive+Era&amp;rft.au=Hitchcock%2C+Laurel+Iverson&amp;rft.aulast=Hitchcock&amp;rft.aufirst=Laurel&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=215&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2016.1165592

Opportunities for Community Organizing in the Realm of Economic Justice and Low Wage Worker Struggles

Author: Simmons, Louise11 School of Social Work, University of Connecticut, West Hartford, CT, USA

Publication info: Journal of Community Practice ; Abingdon  Vol. 24, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 166-181.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1789958024?accountid=14667

Abstract: The new upsurge in labor organizing among low-wage workers provides community organizing with opportunities to engage in economic justice struggles. Low-wage workers are organizing in many sectors of the workforce that are difficult to organize. Their issues are part of the larger discourse concerning inequality in the United States. New forms of community organizing are developing in some areas that embrace economic justice issues. However, many of the national networks have yet to become involved in issues of community members in the capacities as workers. Macro social work needs to revisit its origins and forge a new tradition that incorporates the problems that inspired Jane Addams and her contemporaries, the issues of workers and immigrants.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Opportunities+for+Community+Organizing+in+the+Realm+of+Economic+Justice+and+Low+Wage+Worker+Struggles&amp;rft.au=Simmons%2C+Louise&amp;rft.aulast=Simmons&amp;rft.aufirst=Louise&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=166&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2016.1165779

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Opportunities+for+Community+Organizing+in+the+Realm+of+Economic+Justice+and+Low+Wage+Worker+Struggles&amp;rft.au=Simmons%2C+Louise&amp;rft.aulast=Simmons&amp;rft.aufirst=Louise&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=166&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2016.1165779

Reducing Prejudice Within Community-Based Organizations

Author: Nnawulezi, Nkiru1; Ryan, Ann Marie2; O'Connor, Rachel C21 Department of Psychology, University of Maryland, Baltimore County, Baltimore, MD, USA2 Psychology Department, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI, USA

Publication info: Journal of Community Practice ; Abingdon  Vol. 24, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 182-204.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1789958031?accountid=14667

Abstract: Efforts to help community-based organizations (CBOs) develop interventions that reduce prejudice within the workplace and during service provision can be informed by social psychological prejudice reduction techniques, which tend to be successful in controlled laboratory settings but have limitations that inhibit utility in applied settings. Alternatively, the use of diversity training to reduce prejudice has increased within the for-profit sector, but is rarely applied to CBOs. This article discusses the overlap between the basic and applied literatures, and how community practitioners can use the information gained from both to support CBOs who encounter challenges with diversity.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Reducing+Prejudice+Within+Community-Based+Organizations&amp;rft.au=Nnawulezi%2C+Nkiru%3BRyan%2C+Ann+Marie%3BO%27Connor%2C+Rachel+C&amp;rft.aulast=Nnawulezi&amp;rft.aufirst=Nkiru&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=182&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2016.1157541

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Reducing+Prejudice+Within+Community-Based+Organizations&amp;rft.au=Nnawulezi%2C+Nkiru%3BRyan%2C+Ann+Marie%3BO%27Connor%2C+Rachel+C&amp;rft.aulast=Nnawulezi&amp;rft.aufirst=Nkiru&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=182&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2016.1157541

____________________________________________________________

Insights on Professional Identification and Licensure from Community Practice Social Workers

Author: Lightfoot, Elizabeth1; Nienow, Mary1; Moua, Kao Nou L1; Colburn, Gregg1; Petri, Alissa11 School of Social Work, University of Minnesota, Saint Paul, MN, USA

Publication info: Journal of Community Practice ; Abingdon  Vol. 24, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 123-146.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1789958056?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes a qualitative study designed to explore both how community practice social workers identify professionally and to examine their view towards professional regulation. Thirty-five MSW-level social workers in a large metropolitan region who self-identified as community practice social worker participated in in-depth interviews. The respondents shared their views regarding professional identification as social workers and the impact of professional identity on their work as community practitioners. Approximately half of the respondents indicated that they only sometimes or never identify as a social worker. The respondents were generally critical of the licensing burden placed upon them as community practice social workers.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Insights+on+Professional+Identification+and+Licensure+from+Community+Practice+Social+Workers&amp;rft.au=Lightfoot%2C+Elizabeth%3BNienow%2C+Mary%3BMoua%2C+Kao+Nou+L%3BColburn%2C+Gregg%3BPetri%2C+Alissa&amp;rft.aulast=Lightfoot&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=123&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2016.1165328

Food Landscapes: Cooking, Community Service and Art-Making with Teens

Author: Agnelli, Kate1; Cramer, Elizabeth P1; Buffington, Melanie L2; Norris, Jessica2; Meeken, Luke21 School of Social Work, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, VA, USA2 Department of Art Education, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, VA, USA

Publication info: Journal of Community Practice ; Abingdon  Vol. 24, Iss. 2,  (Apr/Jun 2016): 205-214.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1789958103?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this article, we describe Food Landscapes, an interdisciplinary program involving youth who live in an urban community identified as a food desert. Food Landscapes combined socially engaged art-making, cooking, community engagement, and community service to open dialogue with youth about food justice and equity, the meaning of community, and the formation of meaningful relationships between youth and community members who have disabilities. We describe the program and discuss the theory and model bases for the program and lessons learned during program implementation.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Food+Landscapes%3A+Cooking%2C+Community+Service+and+Art-Making+with+Teens&amp;rft.au=Agnelli%2C+Kate%3BCramer%2C+Elizabeth+P%3BBuffington%2C+Melanie+L%3BNorris%2C+Jessica%3BMeeken%2C+Luke&amp;rft.aulast=Agnelli&amp;rft.aufirst=Kate&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=205&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2016.1168757

Where Are the Beds? Housing Locations for Transition Age Youth Exiting Public Systems

Author: Tam, Christina C; Freisthler, Bridget; Curry, Susanna R; Abrams, Laura S

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 97, Iss. 2,  (2016): 111.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1792708391?accountid=14667

Abstract: Transition age youth (TAY) from the child welfare and juvenile justice systems experience high rates of homelessness, but little is known about the neighborhoods to which they return after they exit these systems. This exploratory study investigates whether housing options are located in areas where TAY exit public systems and if the characteristics of areas surrounding these facilities support their transition to adulthood. Results show that housing is not related to areas where TAY exit public systems. Further, supportive housing and shelter density is related to low-income areas. Implications for practice and policy on housing locations for TAY are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Where+Are+the+Beds%3F+Housing+Locations+for+Transition+Age+Youth+Exiting+Public+Systems&amp;rft.au=Tam%2C+Christina+C%3BFreisthler%2C+Bridget%3BCurry%2C+Susanna+R%3BAbrams%2C+Laura+S&amp;rft.aulast=Tam&amp;rft.aufirst=Christina&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=111&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Match Between Engagement Beliefs of Child Welfare Professionals and Consumer Expectations

Author: Huebner, Ruth A; Durbin, Lisa A; Cordell, Christopher; James, Teresa

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 97, Iss. 2,  (2016): 102.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1792708499?accountid=14667

Abstract: Engaging families, youth, and partners in working relationships with child welfare (CW) professionals is an essential interpersonal process and an important outcome influenced by beliefs and expectations of both parties. This study describes the match between beliefs and attitudes of CW professionals in one state agency (n = 989; 51% response rate) and the expectations of families, youth, and partners found in previous research. The Engagement Beliefs and Attitudes Scale was administered and tested with 19 items having adequate factor loadings, evidence of reliability, and support in previous research. Measuring subjective beliefs proved challenging; lessons learned with implications for future research and practice are explored.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=The+Match+Between+Engagement+Beliefs+of+Child+Welfare+Professionals+and+Consumer+Expectations&amp;rft.au=Huebner%2C+Ruth+A%3BDurbin%2C+Lisa+A%3BCordell%2C+Christopher%3BJames%2C+Teresa&amp;rft.aulast=Huebner&amp;rft.aufirst=Ruth&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=102&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Gender and Sexual Minority Youth in Nonmetropolitan Communities: Individual- and Community-Level Needs for Support

Author: Paceley, Megan S

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 97, Iss. 2,  (2016): 77.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1792708542?accountid=14667

Abstract: Gender and sexual minority (GSM) youth are at risk of mental and physical health problems due to experiences of stigmatization and marginalization. GSM youth in nonmetropolitan communities may be at increased risk, yet have less access to other GSM people and resources. Given GSM youth&apos;s risks, the lack of research in nonmetropolitan areas, and the need for interventions to meet the needs of GSM youth, this study aimed to establish an understanding of what nonmetropolitan GSM youth perceive as their needs for support within their small communities. Using grounded theory, qualitative interviews were conducted with 34 youth. Findings revealed 4 categories of needs: reduction in isolation, social acceptance and visibility, emotional support and safety, and GSM identity development.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Gender+and+Sexual+Minority+Youth+in+Nonmetropolitan+Communities%3A+Individual-+and+Community-Level+Needs+for+Support&amp;rft.au=Paceley%2C+Megan+S&amp;rft.aulast=Paceley&amp;rft.aufirst=Megan&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=77&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Gender+and+Sexual+Minority+Youth+in+Nonmetropolitan+Communities%3A+Individual-+and+Community-Level+Needs+for+Support&amp;rft.au=Paceley%2C+Megan+S&amp;rft.aulast=Paceley&amp;rft.aufirst=Megan&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=77&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Living On the Edge: Access to Liquid Assets as a Determinant of Unmarried Urban Mothers&apos; Life Satisfaction

Author: Crocker, Tianca; Padilla, Yolanda C

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 97, Iss. 2,  (2016): 132.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1792708797?accountid=14667

Abstract: According to recent estimates, more than 70% of female-headed households lack access to liquid assets such as emergency cash or credit in times of need. Liquid assets support a household&apos;s ability to manage unpredictable changes in income and expenses. Aside from the economic benefits, however, to what extent does having access to resources affect subjective well-being? This study explored the effects of access to liquid assets on unmarried mothers&apos; life satisfaction using data from the Fragile Families and Child Wellbeing Study. Controlling for socioeconomic status, health, and financial situation, unmarried mothers with even limited access to liquid assets (compared to no access) had 61% higher odds of being satisfied with life; mothers with greater access had 182% higher odds. This study provides evidence for safety net programs that aim to improve access to liquid assets in this group.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Living+On+the+Edge%3A+Access+to+Liquid+Assets+as+a+Determinant+of+Unmarried+Urban+Mothers%26amp%3Bapos%3B+Life+Satisfaction&amp;rft.au=Crocker%2C+Tianca%3BPadilla%2C+Yolanda+C&amp;rft.aulast=Crocker&amp;rft.aufirst=Tianca&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=132&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Living+On+the+Edge%3A+Access+to+Liquid+Assets+as+a+Determinant+of+Unmarried+Urban+Mothers%26amp%3Bapos%3B+Life+Satisfaction&amp;rft.au=Crocker%2C+Tianca%3BPadilla%2C+Yolanda+C&amp;rft.aulast=Crocker&amp;rft.aufirst=Tianca&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=132&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Research at Work: Understanding Regression Tables in Research Studies

Author: Kondrat, David C; Jaggers, Jeremiah W

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 97, Iss. 2,  (2016): 142.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1792708840?accountid=14667

Abstract: Understanding and interpreting regression tables is not the exclusive purview of academics. Social workers and allied professionals in micro and macro practice, regardless of whether they are undergraduate or graduate trained, can use the information provided in a research article to make informed decisions about practice and assessment. Regression tables are interpretable once the reader has a basic understanding of regression terms, tables, and criteria for causal inferences. While not an exhaustive discussion of multiple regression, this overview functions as a heuristic understanding for how to interpret multiple regression tables and statistics, and provides a framework for drawing causal inferences.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Research+at+Work%3A+Understanding+Regression+Tables+in+Research+Studies&amp;rft.au=Kondrat%2C+David+C%3BJaggers%2C+Jeremiah+W&amp;rft.aulast=Kondrat&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=142&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/
