____________________________________________________________

Lost in Limbo: An Exploratory Study of Homeless Mothers&apos; Experiences and Needs at Emergency Assistance Hotels

Author: Thomas, Kristie A; So, Marvin

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 97, Iss. 2,  (2016): 120.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1792708862?accountid=14667

Abstract: Increases in family homelessness have led several states to use hotels and motels as shelters. Except for investigations into "welfare hotels" of the 1980s, research on this practice is largely nonexistent. This study explored the experience of living in an emergency assistance hotel through in-depth interviews with 10 homeless mothers, triangulated with proximity analyses of the walking distance and public transit time between emergency assistance hotels in Massachusetts (n = 49) and 6 basic need types. Four themes emerged from interviews: living in limbo, profound isolation, role conflict, and immense difficulty meeting basic needs -- which proximity analyses further illustrated. Findings suggest the need for systems to consider homeless families&apos; mobility barriers and assess the built environment around hotels used to shelter families.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Lost+in+Limbo%3A+An+Exploratory+Study+of+Homeless+Mothers%26amp%3Bapos%3B+Experiences+and+Needs+at+Emergency+Assistance+Hotels&amp;rft.au=Thomas%2C+Kristie+A%3BSo%2C+Marvin&amp;rft.aulast=Thomas&amp;rft.aufirst=Kristie&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=120&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Leadership Development: A Pathway to Transforming the Public Child Welfare System

Author: Gentles-Gibbs, Natallie

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 97, Iss. 2,  (2016): 95.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1792708895?accountid=14667

Abstract: Calls for systemic reform within public child welfare have been consistent, yet the system has struggled to respond adequately. This article discusses the issue of system reform by examining perspectives of caseworkers and supervisors on organizational readiness for change. It presents data from semistructured qualitative interviews with 29 public child welfare employees. The findings indicate that organizational leadership is the core determining condition for employees&apos; perceptions of readiness for change. The article discusses practice and policy recommendations for child welfare leadership in order to effect organizational transformation and, ultimately, meaningful and long-term change for the families served by the system.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Leadership+Development%3A+A+Pathway+to+Transforming+the+Public+Child+Welfare+System&amp;rft.au=Gentles-Gibbs%2C+Natallie&amp;rft.aulast=Gentles-Gibbs&amp;rft.aufirst=Natallie&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=97&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=95&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Factor Structure and Validity of the K6 Scale for Adults With Suicidal Ideation

Author: Ko, Jungyai; Harrington, Donna

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 7, Iss. 1,  (Spring 2016): 43.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837349?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examines the factor structure and utility of the K6 psychological distress scale for adults with suicidal ideation. The sample, drawn from the 2011 National Survey on Drug Use and Health, consists of 2,098 adults age 18 years or older who reported suicidal ideation. The results from the CFA indicate the single-factor model, the 2-factor model, and the second-order 2-factor model all fit the data well, with all items loading significantly, as expected. However, the results from the SEM analyses suggest that only the single-factor model has concurrent validity for suicide plan and attempt. Chi-square analysis suggests the K6 cutoff point for serious psychological distress is associated with increased probability of suicidal behaviors. The K6 can be used as a single-factor measure of psychological distress among adults with suicidal ideation in clinical studies.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Factor+Structure+and+Validity+of+the+K6+Scale+for+Adults+With+Suicidal+Ideation&amp;rft.au=Ko%2C+Jungyai%3BHarrington%2C+Donna&amp;rft.aulast=Ko&amp;rft.aufirst=Jungyai&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=43&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Delaying Youth Substance-Use Initiation: A Cluster Randomized Controlled Trial of Complementary Youth and Parenting Interventions

Author: Williams, Lela Rankin; Ayers, Stephanie; Baldwin, Adrienne; Marsiglia, Flavio F

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 7, Iss. 1,  (Spring 2016): 177.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837607?accountid=14667

Abstract: The parenting intervention Familias: Preparando la Nueva Generacion(FPNG), was developed using community-based participatory research in primarily immigrant Latino communities. FPNG was designed to complement the efficacious classroom-based substance-use prevention program keepin&apos; it REAL (kiR). This study tests whether using FPNG in combination with kiR delays the initiation of alcohol and cigarette use over an 18-month period among a sample of predominantly Mexican-heritage 7th grade youth (N = 358, M age = 12 years) beyond the effects of the classroom intervention alone and control conditions. In a completed cluster-randomized controlled trial, 9 schools were evenly randomized into 3 conditions: Parent and youth (n = 118 youth); youth-only (n = 136 youth), or control (n = 139 youth). Logistic regression models using the maximum likelihood estimator assessed whether kiR (10 weeks) concurrently delivered withFPNG (8 weeks) delays substance use among 7th grade adolescents. They found no significant effects by condition immediately following the intervention.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Delaying+Youth+Substance-Use+Initiation%3A+A+Cluster+Randomized+Controlled+Trial+of+Complementary+Youth+and+Parenting+Interventions&amp;rft.au=Williams%2C+Lela+Rankin%3BAyers%2C+Stephanie%3BBaldwin%2C+Adrienne%3BMarsiglia%2C+Flavio+F&amp;rft.aulast=Williams&amp;rft.aufirst=Lela&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=177&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Predicting Adult Criminality Among Louisiana&apos;s Urban Youth: Poverty, Academic Risk, and Delinquency

Author: Jaggers, Jeremiah W; Robison, Samuel B; Rhodes, Judith L F; Guan, Xian; Church, Wesley T, II

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 7, Iss. 1,  (Spring 2016): 89.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837805?accountid=14667

Abstract: School truancy, school failure, and dropout are highly correlated with delinquency and criminality. There are also racial inequalities regarding the relationship between education and crime. Using administrative data from the Louisiana Department of Education, the Louisiana Office of Juvenile Justice, and the Louisiana Department of Public Safety and Corrections (LADOC), hierarchical, mixed-effects logistic regression models (N = 507,613) explored whether youth later encountered the LADOC and were incarcerated, and whether they committed a violent crime leading to their contact. Despite its intent, punishment-oriented approaches such as suspension, expulsion, and the juvenile justice system seem to encourage further deviant behavior among youth. Reform is necessary to decrease adult criminality for those engaging in risky behavior during adolescence. Additional considerations must be made for youth from disadvantaged backgrounds.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Predicting+Adult+Criminality+Among+Louisiana%26amp%3Bapos%3Bs+Urban+Youth%3A+Poverty%2C+Academic+Risk%2C+and+Delinquency&amp;rft.au=Jaggers%2C+Jeremiah+W%3BRobison%2C+Samuel+B%3BRhodes%2C+Judith+L+F%3BGuan%2C+Xian%3BChurch%2C+Wesley+T%2C+II&amp;rft.aulast=Jaggers&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeremiah&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=89&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Minor and Adult Domestic Sex Trafficking Risk Factors in Ohio

Author: Chohaney, Michael L

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 7, Iss. 1,  (Spring 2016): 117.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837826?accountid=14667

Abstract: Sex trafficking is a pressing issue in Ohio-a major node in national sex trafficking networks; however, no quantitative analysis of risk factors specific to Ohio victims has been conducted. Using a survey conducted by the Ohio Human Trafficking Commission representing Ohio urban, street-based sex workers (N = 328), this study uses a life-course theory framework to identify and measure the effect of direct risk factors on domestic minor and adult sex-trafficking outcomes using multivariate logistic regressions. Variables of specific interest include peer influence, experiences during transience, prior minor victimization, and a lack of support while attempting to escape. This analysis produces a better understanding of risk factors facing Ohio&apos;s sex trafficking victims and provides broader insights about the determinants of domestic sex trafficking. In addition, these results have been used in a report to an Ohio Senate Caucus promoting a federal bill regarding missing children.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Minor+and+Adult+Domestic+Sex+Trafficking+Risk+Factors+in+Ohio&amp;rft.au=Chohaney%2C+Michael+L&amp;rft.aulast=Chohaney&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=117&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Correlates of Homeless Youths&apos; Stability-Seeking Behaviors Online and In Person

Author: Curry, Susanna R; Rhoades, Harmony; Rice, Eric

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 7, Iss. 1,  (Spring 2016): 143.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837841?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examines correlates of service seeking and use of the Internet for stability-seeking purposes such as employment, housing, and health needs among homeless youth. The purpose was to (a) analyze previously unexplored youth characteristics and behaviors such as substance use and self-reported reasons for homelessness; (b) understand the relationship between youth characteristics and behaviors and use of the Internet for stability-seeking purposes; and (c) compare Internet resource-seeking between those who used in-person services and those who did not use in-person services in each domain. Individuals who use hard drugs are 2 times more likely (OR = 1.82, p < .05) to use health services than those who do not use hard drugs. Youth who indicate they are homeless because of mental illness are 5 times more likely (OR = 5.13, p < .001) to look online for health services than homeless youth who do not give mental illness as a reason for homelessness.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Correlates+of+Homeless+Youths%26amp%3Bapos%3B+Stability-Seeking+Behaviors+Online+and+In+Person&amp;rft.au=Curry%2C+Susanna+R%3BRhoades%2C+Harmony%3BRice%2C+Eric&amp;rft.aulast=Curry&amp;rft.aufirst=Susanna&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=143&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Field Instructors Extending EBP Learning in Dyads (FIELD): Results of a Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial

Author: Tennille, Julie; Solomon, Phyllis; Brusilovskiy, Eugene; Mandell, David

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 7, Iss. 1,  (Spring 2016): 1.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837878?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objective: The act of moving, tailoring, and sustaining evidence-based practices (EBP) into real world settings has proven formidable. Schools of social work are responsible for preparing students to deliver EBP interventions while trying to engender the practice of routinely using evidence for decision making. Given the difficulty of accomplishing these objectives and cognizant that field education is the heart of the experiential component of graduate social work curricula, we developed FIELD as an educational intervention for dyads of field instructors and their students. FIELD is a multiphase didactic and experiential intervention driven by the interests of field instructors. This article presents findings from a pilot randomized controlled trial that examined the effectiveness of FIELD using motivational interviewing as the focal EBP. Methods: A convenience sample of 40 dyads (composed of a field instructor and a field student) was randomly assigned to experimental (n = 38) or control conditions (n = 42). Data collected at baseline and 1- and 3-month post intervention included 2 measures to examine attitudes toward both the EBP process of decision making as well as toward the use of designated EBPs. Results: Both groups were equal at baseline. At the 2 follow-up time points, experimental dyads had significantly higher scores on the attitude measures. Conclusion: FIELD holds promise as an EBP implementation strategy that capitalizes on the important role of field instruction in social work education by bridging classroom and field curricula while imparting competencies to both future and current generations of social workers. ﻿

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Field+Instructors+Extending+EBP+Learning+in+Dyads+%28FIELD%29%3A+Results+of+a+Pilot+Randomized+Controlled+Trial&amp;rft.au=Tennille%2C+Julie%3BSolomon%2C+Phyllis%3BBrusilovskiy%2C+Eugene%3BMandell%2C+David&amp;rft.aulast=Tennille&amp;rft.aufirst=Julie&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Field+Instructors+Extending+EBP+Learning+in+Dyads+%28FIELD%29%3A+Results+of+a+Pilot+Randomized+Controlled+Trial&amp;rft.au=Tennille%2C+Julie%3BSolomon%2C+Phyllis%3BBrusilovskiy%2C+Eugene%3BMandell%2C+David&amp;rft.aulast=Tennille&amp;rft.aufirst=Julie&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Location, Location, Location: Perceptions of Safety and Security Among Formerly Homeless Persons Transitioned to Permanent Supportive Housing

Author: Hsu, Hsun-Ta; Simon, James David; Henwood, Benjamin F; Wenzel, Suzanne L; Couture, Julie

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 7, Iss. 1,  (Spring 2016): 65.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837896?accountid=14667

Abstract: Low perceived safety and security might have adverse health consequences, especially for chronically homeless individuals who are at high risk of victimization on the street. However, it is unclear how formerly homeless individuals&apos; perceptions of safety and security reflect the objective neighborhood environment in which the PSH is located. This article presents a study of the perceived safety and security of formerly homeless individuals transitioned to PSH in and around Skid Row. This mixed-method study examines the perceptions of safety and security of 24 PSH residents living in the Skid Row area of Los Angeles. Participants housed within Skid Row also reported social isolation and exposure to situations reminiscent of past traumatic events. These findings correspond with objective neighborhood environmental differences in which more trash, malodors, and homeless people were observed on the blocks located near the center of Skid Row.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Location%2C+Location%2C+Location%3A+Perceptions+of+Safety+and+Security+Among+Formerly+Homeless+Persons+Transitioned+to+Permanent+Supportive+Housing&amp;rft.au=Hsu%2C+Hsun-Ta%3BSimon%2C+James+David%3BHenwood%2C+Benjamin+F%3BWenzel%2C+Suzanne+L%3BCouture%2C+Julie&amp;rft.aulast=Hsu&amp;rft.aufirst=Hsun-Ta&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=65&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Location%2C+Location%2C+Location%3A+Perceptions+of+Safety+and+Security+Among+Formerly+Homeless+Persons+Transitioned+to+Permanent+Supportive+Housing&amp;rft.au=Hsu%2C+Hsun-Ta%3BSimon%2C+James+David%3BHenwood%2C+Benjamin+F%3BWenzel%2C+Suzanne+L%3BCouture%2C+Julie&amp;rft.aulast=Hsu&amp;rft.aufirst=Hsun-Ta&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=65&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Procrastination among Students: The Role of Gender, Perfectionism and Self-Esteem

Author: Wazid, Syeda Waspeea; Shahnawaz, Md Ghazi; Gupta, Dolly

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 77, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2016): 191.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1848081542?accountid=14667

Abstract: The study explored the role of gender, perfectionism and self-esteem on procrastination in the academic setting. Data was collected from 100 young adult college students (50 males and 50 females) studying in colleges and universities of Delhi. Gender emerged as a significant predictor of procrastination and males were found to be higher on procrastination and perfectionism than females. Self-esteem was found to be significantly influence procrastination in the negative direction. The adaptive perfectionism factors correlated positively with procrastination on a significant level. However the maladaptive perfectionism factors did not show any significant correlation with procrastination. The findings were in accord with temporal motivation theory and social status theory.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Procrastination+among+Students%3A+The+Role+of+Gender%2C+Perfectionism+and+Self-Esteem&amp;rft.au=Wazid%2C+Syeda+Waspeea%3BShahnawaz%2C+Md+Ghazi%3BGupta%2C+Dolly&amp;rft.aulast=Wazid&amp;rft.aufirst=Syeda&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=77&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=191&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Socio-Economic Disability: A Roadblock to Inclusive Education in India

Author: Richards, Julie; Lotlikar, Medha; Lotlikar, Pallavi

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 77, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2016): 161.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1848081656?accountid=14667

Abstract: The social and economic conditions in India determine children's future and the opportunities available to them. With education being one of the most important solutions in the governments Poverty Alleviation Programme (20th five year plan), it is imperative that impoverished Indians have equitable access to education. It is essential to extend beyond the label of learning difficulties to also more aptly identify any co-occurring socioeconomic disability that may hinder the implementation of the Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Act 2009 (RTE) and further provide more appropriate and effective strategies for addressing learning challenges. Socioeconomic disability results from the interaction of poverty and its consequent gender inequity and environmental risk factors, social devaluation, weakened sense of coherence, caste, and mother tongue. This article presents the Socioeconomic Disability Model, a Framework of the Ecology of Policy Development, as well as implications for practice and policy.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Socio-Economic+Disability%3A+A+Roadblock+to+Inclusive+Education+in+India&amp;rft.au=Richards%2C+Julie%3BLotlikar%2C+Medha%3BLotlikar%2C+Pallavi&amp;rft.aulast=Richards&amp;rft.aufirst=Julie&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=77&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=161&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Quest for the Chimerical 'Typical' Village

Author: Mathrani, Vinalini

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 77, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2016): 237.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1848081705?accountid=14667

Abstract: The main aim of this study was to first unveil and then understand a range of rural women's responses and associated agency in situations of ill-health. Key emphasis was placed on the word `range'. The underlying assumption was that it is likely that women from different castes, class and age groups and women with differing marital statuses would manifest different responses. This highly nuanced landscape of responses and associated agency could ideally be captured through a single village study. Studying multiple villages could potentially yield a superficial understanding. In addition to these, there existed another very practical variable that had to be included. A non-profit research organisation called the `Belaku Trust' was in the process of conducting a 'Quality of Care' study in 73 villages of Kanakapura Taluka. He was engaged in providing inputs to the qualitative component of this research study.

Human Development Approach: A Framework for Development Practice in India

Author: Mutatkar, Rohit

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 77, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2016): 119.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1848081790?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article seeks to provide a brief overview of the human development approach and its implications for development practice in India. The article argues that the human development approach provides an integrated framework for development practice in India, including social work, to address the challenges of mass poverty, deprivations and socioeconomic disparities in Indian society.

Sustainable Agricultural Methods in Empowering Rural Women Farmers of Karnataka

Author: Dhawan, Ankita

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 77, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2016): 179.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1848081832?accountid=14667

Abstract: The contribution of rural women towards agricultural production in India has often been overlooked. Patriarchcal socio-political systems have expanded inequalities in the distribution of wages and entitlement of land rights. In the context of landless agriculturalists and livelihood opportunities, this paper examines the role of women farmers in the rural communities of Chitradurga and Ramnagar districts of Kamataka. The paper further offers a critical analysis of the implementation of sustainable agricultural practices for agro-based industries in Karnataka.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Sustainable+Agricultural+Methods+in+Empowering+Rural+Women+Farmers+of+Karnataka&amp;rft.au=Dhawan%2C+Ankita&amp;rft.aulast=Dhawan&amp;rft.aufirst=Ankita&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=77&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=179&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Counselling and Psychological Wellbeing of People Living with HIV in Kerala

Author: Sebastian, K Biju; Reddy, K Jayashankar; Kothapally, Esther Glory C

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 77, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2016): 211.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1848081870?accountid=14667

Abstract: There is a dearth in the documentation of the benefits of HIV-counselling in India. This article deals with how HIV-counselling facilitates the psychological wellbeing of Persons Living with HIV (PLHIV) in Kerala, India. About 269 PLHIV participated in the study. Meaning in Life Questionnaire, Illness Perception Questionnaire and Psychological Wellbeing Scale were used. It was noticed that counselling did not impact the scores on subscales such as Timeline, Emotional Representation and Consequences, while the scores on Self-Acceptance and Autonomy did not differ even with counselling. Findings call for a reconsideration of the way HIV-counselling is provided.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Counselling+and+Psychological+Wellbeing+of+People+Living+with+HIV+in+Kerala&amp;rft.au=Sebastian%2C+K+Biju%3BReddy%2C+K+Jayashankar%3BKothapally%2C+Esther+Glory+C&amp;rft.aulast=Sebastian&amp;rft.aufirst=K&amp;rft.date=2016-04-01&amp;rft.volume=77&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=211&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Predictors of behavioural problems in foster children: the key role of impulsivity

Author: Salas, Maria D; Fuentes, Maria J; Bernedo, Isabel M; Garcia-Martin, Miguel A

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 2,  (May 2016): 146-155.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1780486839?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although several variables have been reported to be associated with behavioural problems in foster children, few studies have sought to establish more precisely the extent to which these variables may explain problematic behaviour. The main aim of this study is to determine the extent to which certain variables may predict behavioural problems shown by foster children. Participants included 104 foster children and their respective foster families. Multiple linear regression analysis revealed that the following variables predict behavioural problems in foster children: impulsivity/attention deficit in the child, level of burden in the foster carers, rigid or authoritarian parental discipline, and criticism/rejection by the foster parents. The model explained 46% of the variance in behaviour problems, with the greatest predictive power (29%) corresponding to the variable 'impulsivity/attention deficit'. The results show that impulsivity/attention deficit is the most powerful predictor of behavioural problems in foster children. This is consistent with the findings of various studies that have reported an association between a lack of inhibitory control and problematic behaviour.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Predictors+of+behavioural+problems+in+foster+children%3A+the+key+role+of+impulsivity&amp;rft.au=Salas%2C+Maria+D%3BFuentes%2C+Maria+J%3BBernedo%2C+Isabel+M%3BGarcia-Martin%2C+Miguel+A&amp;rft.aulast=Salas&amp;rft.aufirst=Maria&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=146&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12124

____________________________________________________________

Children's accounts of moving to a foster home

Author: Goodyer, Annabel

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 2,  (May 2016): 188-197.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1780486904?accountid=14667

Abstract: Little is known about how children themselves understand their moves to and between foster homes. The data presented in this paper come from a study that sought children's views on becoming and being a foster child. A key finding of that study was how children's accounts of being fostered illustrated a high level of anxiety and concern about their moving to live with a foster family. This paper firstly explores the key issues about looked-after children's moves. It then describes the research study undertaken, before exploring the data generated from children's accounts of their moves to a new foster home. Lastly, there is a discussion of the implications for social work practice in this area.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Children%27s+accounts+of+moving+to+a+foster+home&amp;rft.au=Goodyer%2C+Annabel&amp;rft.aulast=Goodyer&amp;rft.aufirst=Annabel&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=188&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12128

____________________________________________________________

Suicidal ideation and self-harm among youths in Norway: associations with verbal, physical and sexual abuse

Author: Mossige, Svein1; Huang, Lihong2; Straiton, Malanie3; Roen, Katrina11 Department of Psychology, University of Oslo, Oslo, Norway2 NOVA-Norwegian Social Research, Oslo and Akershus University College of Applied Sciences, Oslo, Norway3 Norwegian Institute of Public Health, Oslo, Norway

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 2,  (May 2016): 166-175.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1780746616?accountid=14667

Abstract: Using data from a national survey (n=6979) of young people in their last year in Norwegian secondary schools in 2007 (aged 18-19), this paper explores the relationship between sexual abuse and experiences of violence among young people in Norway and their reporting of suicidal ideation and self-harm. This investigation includes three types of abuse experienced by young people: non-physical, physical and sexual. We investigate suicidal ideation and two types of self-harming behaviour: non-suicidal self-injury and suicidal self-injury. The analyses that are reported involve descriptive analysis, chi-square and t-tests, and logistic regression. The hypothesis that was confirmed by the analysis was that being subject to sexual abuse or other violence was associated with increased risk of self-harm. The hypothesis that was partially supported by the analysis was that violence experienced during childhood would have more effect on suicidal ideation and self-harm than violence experienced at a later age. Contrary to our expectations, it was found that peer bullying has a stronger effect on young people&apos;s suicidal ideation and self-harming behaviours than sexual abuse or physical violence. The implications of these findings for practitioners working with children and youth involve raising awareness about the long-term effects of verbal, physical, sexual and witnessed abuse.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Suicidal+ideation+and+self-harm+among+youths+in+Norway%3A+associations+with+verbal%2C+physical+and+sexual+abuse&amp;rft.au=Mossige%2C+Svein%3BHuang%2C+Lihong%3BStraiton%2C+Malanie%3BRoen%2C+Katrina&amp;rft.aulast=Mossige&amp;rft.aufirst=Svein&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=166&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12126

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Suicidal+ideation+and+self-harm+among+youths+in+Norway%3A+associations+with+verbal%2C+physical+and+sexual+abuse&amp;rft.au=Mossige%2C+Svein%3BHuang%2C+Lihong%3BStraiton%2C+Malanie%3BRoen%2C+Katrina&amp;rft.aulast=Mossige&amp;rft.aufirst=Svein&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=166&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12126

Post-adoption reunion sibling relationships: factors facilitating and hindering the development of sensitive relationships following reunion in adulthood

Author: O'Neill, Denise1; McAuley, Colette1; Loughran, Hilda21 School of Applied Social Science, University College Dublin, Dublin, Republic of Ireland2 School of Social and International Studies, University of Bradford, Bradford, UK

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 2,  (May 2016): 218-227.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1780746618?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper explores findings from an exploratory study on sibling relationships following adoption reunion in adulthood. The qualitative data was gathered through in-depth interviews with 33 adopted adults who were reunited with their birth sibling(s) through an adoption agency in the Republic of Ireland. The findings throw light upon the development of the emotional, often complex, relationships which may emerge when siblings meet for the first time in adult life. Factors influential in facilitating or hindering these post-reunion relationships are discussed. The important insights are then considered in the context of the wider international literature on adoption, search and reunion.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Post-adoption+reunion+sibling+relationships%3A+factors+facilitating+and+hindering+the+development+of+sensitive+relationships+following+reunion+in+adulthood&amp;rft.au=O%27Neill%2C+Denise%3BMcAuley%2C+Colette%3BLoughran%2C+Hilda&amp;rft.aulast=O%27Neill&amp;rft.aufirst=Denise&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=9781267016409&amp;rft.btitle=Absence+makes+the+heart+grow+fonder%2C+behaviors+adaptive+and+perceptions+idealized%3A+The+effects+of+geographic+separation+and+interpersonal+media+on+intimacy+process&amp;rft.title=Absence+makes+the+heart+grow+fonder%2C+behaviors+adaptive+and+perceptions+idealized%3A+The+effects+of+geographic+separation+and+interpersonal+media+on+intimacy+process&amp;rft.issn=9781267016409&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Being there for my grandchild - grandparents' responses to their grandchildren's exposure to domestic violence

Author: Sandberg, Linn11 ISV Department of Social and Welfare Studies - Unit of Social Work, Linköping University, Norrköping, Sweden

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 2,  (May 2016): 136-145.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1780746625?accountid=14667

Abstract: Grandparents whose grandchildren are exposed to domestic violence are faced with some unique challenges in their grandparenting, which have thus far been little discussed in research. This paper discusses the narratives of 10 Swedish grandparents whose grandchildren have been exposed to violence towards their mother. The aim was to explore grandparents&apos; narrations of their responses in the face of violence, and their understanding of the role they play in their grandchildren&apos;s social networks. Two significant responses are discussed: &apos;being there&apos; and &apos;acknowledging the independence and self-determination of the adult children&apos;. Grandparents experienced these responses as contradictory and felt powerless when it came to their possibilities to protect their grandchildren. The paper suggests that grandparents could be a resource for domestic violence services, and social work practice needs to assess the roles of grandparents of children exposed to domestic violence. Social workers should consider the challenges these grandparents are facing and what support they may need in order to support their grandchildren.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Being+there+for+my+grandchild+-+grandparents%27+responses+to+their+grandchildren%27s+exposure+to+domestic+violence&amp;rft.au=Sandberg%2C+Linn&amp;rft.aulast=Sandberg&amp;rft.aufirst=Linn&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=136&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12123

How professionals talk about complex cases: a critical discourse analysis

Author: Hood, Rick11 School of Social Work, Kingston University, Kingston upon Thames, UK

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 2,  (May 2016): 125-135.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1780746632?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper reports on a qualitative study of child protection in the UK. The research involved children&apos;s practitioners from a range of agencies, including social care, education, health and youth offending, who were asked about working together on complex child protection cases. The aim was to explore how participants talked about complexity in these cases, in order to deconstruct influential perspectives on interprofessional working. Interview transcripts were analysed using critical discourse analysis, a qualitative method that examines patterns of language use in relation to social structures of power and control. The findings identified three overall perspectives: clinical, expert system and relation-centred approaches, which practitioners combined in various ways. These perspectives have a bearing on how the &apos;team around the child&apos; is conceptualized in discourse about child protection. The paper links these findings to the assumptions of predictability and control currently embedded in policy and practice guidance, and explores their implications for social workers and other children&apos;s practitioners.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=How+professionals+talk+about+complex+cases%3A+a+critical+discourse+analysis&amp;rft.au=Hood%2C+Rick&amp;rft.aulast=Hood&amp;rft.aufirst=Rick&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=125&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12122

____________________________________________________________

Achieving high quality and long-lasting matches in youth mentoring programmes: a case study of 4Results mentoring

Author: Higley, Elizabeth1; Walker, Sarah C2; Bishop, Asia S2; Fritz, Cindy11 Columbia River Mental Health Services, Vancouver, Washington, USA2 Division of Public Behavioral Health and Justice Policy, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Science, University of Washington, Seattle, Washington, USA

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 2,  (May 2016): 240-248.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1780746680?accountid=14667

Abstract: Mentoring programmes show significant promise for enhancing the well-being of youth with complex needs. Research indicates that high quality mentoring, although difficult to achieve, positively impacts youth development across behavioural, social, emotional and academic domains. The difficulty of sustaining long-term matches between mentors and youth, however, remains an important concern for the field of mentoring, as foreshortened matches can be harmful to youth. The 4Results mentoring programme has been identified as a Promising Practice through the Washington State Inventory of child-serving behavioural and mental health programmes and has developed a unique infrastructure to support critical programme values such as match longevity. In 7 years, the programme has successfully retained 98% of mentors for at least 1 year with an average match length of 3.7 years. The following article describes the programme&apos;s guiding philosophy and approach to recruiting and training mentors in the context of existing best practices research.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Achieving+high+quality+and+long-lasting+matches+in+youth+mentoring+programmes%3A+a+case+study+of+4Results+mentoring&amp;rft.au=Higley%2C+Elizabeth%3BWalker%2C+Sarah+C%3BBishop%2C+Asia+S%3BFritz%2C+Cindy&amp;rft.aulast=Higley&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=240&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12141

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Achieving+high+quality+and+long-lasting+matches+in+youth+mentoring+programmes%3A+a+case+study+of+4Results+mentoring&amp;rft.au=Higley%2C+Elizabeth%3BWalker%2C+Sarah+C%3BBishop%2C+Asia+S%3BFritz%2C+Cindy&amp;rft.aulast=Higley&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=240&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12141

____________________________________________________________

Why parents matter: exploring the impact of a hegemonic concern with the timetable for the child

Author: Holt, Kim1; Kelly, Nancy21 University of Northumbria, Newcastle upon Tyne, UK2 Division of Psychology, University of Bradford, West Yorkshire, UK

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 2,  (May 2016): 156-165.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1780746715?accountid=14667

Abstract: In a climate of austerity, timescales and targets, this paper probes whether parents matter sufficiently within the current child protection system in England. Evidence suggests that achieving partnership working in the context of child protection has become increasingly illusive, particularly when parents are notified that the local authority is considering compulsory intervention to remove their children under the Children Act 1989. Recent changes to legislation, policy and practice ushered in with the aim of achieving earlier decisions within the time frame for the child are laudable, but there are consequences for both children and their parents. The aspirations of the Public Law Outline (2008) are well rehearsed, but the changes being introduced with the recent reform of the family justice system, alongside particular constructions of parenting, may be failing to recognize the potential of many parents, if offered appropriate support, to care safely for their children.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Why+parents+matter%3A+exploring+the+impact+of+a+hegemonic+concern+with+the+timetable+for+the+child&amp;rft.au=Holt%2C+Kim%3BKelly%2C+Nancy&amp;rft.aulast=Holt&amp;rft.aufirst=Kim&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=156&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12125

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Why+parents+matter%3A+exploring+the+impact+of+a+hegemonic+concern+with+the+timetable+for+the+child&amp;rft.au=Holt%2C+Kim%3BKelly%2C+Nancy&amp;rft.aulast=Holt&amp;rft.aufirst=Kim&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=156&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12125

A Qualitative Study of Smoking Behaviors among Newly Released Justice-Involved Men and Women in New York City

Author: Valera, Pamela; Bachman, Lauren; Rucker, A Justin

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 41, Iss. 2,  (May 2016): 121.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1785220322?accountid=14667

Abstract: Long-term effects of cigarette smoking result in an estimated 443,000 deaths each year, including approximately 49,400 deaths due to exposure to secondhand smoke. Tobacco is a major risk factor for a variety of chronic health problems, including certain cancers and heart disease. In this article, authors present qualitative findings derived from individual interviews with men and women who were incarcerated in New York state and New York City. Participants were 60 racially and ethnically diverse men and women ages 21 through 60 (M = 46.42, SD = 6.88). Of the participants interviewed, 91.7 percent released from a smoke-free correctional facility resumed cigarette smoking and 8.3 percent remained abstinent. Daily consumption ranged from smoking four cigarettes to 60 cigarettes. The four themes that emerged from the study were (1) lifetime exposure to cigarette smoking influences smoking behavior; (2) cigarettes help relieve stress and are pleasurable; (3) there is a relationship between access, availability, and relapse; and (4) smoking cessation strategies are available. Negative influences from participants&apos; families and peers, stressful housing situations, and mandated programs emerged from this study as key challenges to abstaining from smoking cigarettes. Involving family members and partners in smoking cessation interventions could influence newly released justice-involved men and women not to resume cigarette smoking and possibly maintain long-term abstinence. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/41/2/121.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=A+Qualitative+Study+of+Smoking+Behaviors+among+Newly+Released+Justice-Involved+Men+and+Women+in+New+York+City&amp;rft.au=Valera%2C+Pamela%3BBachman%2C+Lauren%3BRucker%2C+A+Justin&amp;rft.aulast=Valera&amp;rft.aufirst=Pamela&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=121&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=A+Qualitative+Study+of+Smoking+Behaviors+among+Newly+Released+Justice-Involved+Men+and+Women+in+New+York+City&amp;rft.au=Valera%2C+Pamela%3BBachman%2C+Lauren%3BRucker%2C+A+Justin&amp;rft.aulast=Valera&amp;rft.aufirst=Pamela&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=121&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Challenges Faced by Social Workers as Members of Interprofessional Collaborative Health Care Teams

Author: Ambrose-Miller, Wayne; Ashcroft, Rachelle

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 41, Iss. 2,  (May 2016): 101.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1785220367?accountid=14667

Abstract: Interprofessional collaboration is increasingly being seen as an important factor in the work of social workers. A focus group was conducted with Canadian social work educators, practitioners, and students to identify barriers and facilitators to collaboration from the perspective of social work. Participants identified six themes that can act as barriers and facilitators to collaboration: culture, self-identity, role clarification, decision making, communication, and power dynamics. These findings carry important implications for interprofessional collaboration with social workers in health practice. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/41/2/101.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Challenges+Faced+by+Social+Workers+as+Members+of+Interprofessional+Collaborative+Health+Care+Teams&amp;rft.au=Ambrose-Miller%2C+Wayne%3BAshcroft%2C+Rachelle&amp;rft.aulast=Ambrose-Miller&amp;rft.aufirst=Wayne&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=101&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Childhood, Adolescent, and Teenage Obesity: Recommendations for Community Initiatives in Central Harlem

Author: Maidenberg, Michelle P

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 41, Iss. 2,  (May 2016): 85.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1785220487?accountid=14667

Abstract: Because of poverty, the high prevalence of obesity, and the lack of adequate supports, Central Harlem&apos;s children, adolescents, and teenagers are at risk for major physiological, psychological, and social issues. This article discusses the public health concerns related to this population, especially the prevalence of obesity. This article identifies the prevalence of illness and obesity in the inner city and stipulates the causes and consequences of obesity among children, adolescents, and teenagers. In addition, it reports on the appropriate community intervention, using a coalition and a community collaborative organization that serve as models to build support for Central Harlem. A proposal is offered for reducing obesity among youths in the community. The intervention outlines a logic model that identifies a multisystemic approach at the micro and macro level for community intervention and policy initiatives to advocate for fundamental change. Further research recommendations are described to reduce the prevalence of childhood, adolescent, and teenage obesity in urban communities. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/41/2/85.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Childhood%2C+Adolescent%2C+and+Teenage+Obesity%3A+Recommendations+for+Community+Initiatives+in+Central+Harlem&amp;rft.au=Maidenberg%2C+Michelle+P&amp;rft.aulast=Maidenberg&amp;rft.aufirst=Michelle&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=85&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Exploring Motivations, Awareness of Side Effects, and Attitudes among Potential Egg Donors

Author: Gezinski, Lindsay B; Karandikar, Sharvari; Carter, James; White, Melinda

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 41, Iss. 2,  (May 2016): 75.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1785220519?accountid=14667

Abstract: This research study surveyed prospective egg donors at orientation to (a) understand women&apos;s motivations to donate eggs, (b) assess awareness and knowledge of egg donation prior to entry into the egg donation program, and (c) explore attitudes toward egg donation. Ninety-two women completed the questionnaire at one fertility clinic located in the Midwest between August 2011 and August 2012. Descriptive and inferential statistics as well as textual analysis were used to analyze the data. Three themes emerged regarding participant motivations: (1) altruistic, (2) financial, and (3) desire to pass on genetic material. The majority of participants were unconcerned with potential physical and psychological side effects; however, differences emerged based on motherhood status and educational level. Although potential donors felt recipients should receive some information about the donor, they tended to value privacy regarding information giving to resultant offspring. This research study has implications for social work practice, policy, and future research. It is crucial that women receive adequate procedural and side effect information prior to engaging in egg donation. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/41/2/75.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+Motivations%2C+Awareness+of+Side+Effects%2C+and+Attitudes+among+Potential+Egg+Donors&amp;rft.au=Gezinski%2C+Lindsay+B%3BKarandikar%2C+Sharvari%3BCarter%2C+James%3BWhite%2C+Melinda&amp;rft.aulast=Gezinski&amp;rft.aufirst=Lindsay&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=75&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+Motivations%2C+Awareness+of+Side+Effects%2C+and+Attitudes+among+Potential+Egg+Donors&amp;rft.au=Gezinski%2C+Lindsay+B%3BKarandikar%2C+Sharvari%3BCarter%2C+James%3BWhite%2C+Melinda&amp;rft.aulast=Gezinski&amp;rft.aufirst=Lindsay&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=75&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Care Transition Experiences of Older Veterans and Their Caregivers

Author: Ford, Bryan Keith; Ingersoll-Dayton, Berit; Burgio, Kathryn

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 41, Iss. 2,  (May 2016): 129.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1785220560?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study&apos;s main objective was to examine care transition experiences of older veterans and their caregivers. Fifty patients age 65 years and older, discharged from a Veterans Affairs Medical Center hospital, completed the Care Transitions Measure-15... survey three to four weeks postdischarge. Seven patients and six caregivers participated in semistructured interviews. Overall, the quality of care transitions was rated as good; however, some items were indicated as problematic for veterans. Themes that emerged included agreeableness, frustration with complex information, caregiver education, and the timing and methods of information delivery. These findings have implications for all clinical staff working with veterans, and particularly for social workers facilitating care transitions for veterans and their caregivers. (ProQuest: ... denotes formulae/symbols omitted.) [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/41/2/129.abstract]

A Population Health Approach to Clinical Social Work with Complex Patients in Primary Care

Author: Rose, Stephen M; Hatzenbuehler, Stephanie; Gilbert, Erika; Bouchard, Mark P; McGill, Debra

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 41, Iss. 2,  (May 2016): 93.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1785220755?accountid=14667

Abstract: Chronic diseases disproportionately occur among people from disadvantaged backgrounds. These backgrounds correlate with poor health in adulthood. Capacity for patients&apos; to collaborate in their care tends to be lower than among other patients, leading to inefficient uses in medical services and higher risk of adverse events. In the course of this study, social workers engaged patients with increased inpatient and emergency department (ED) use and barriers to self-management, and evaluated them for lifetime exposure to material disadvantage and violence. Intervention focused on creating a primary care team that improved patients&apos; self-efficacy, increased locus of control, and improved capacity for engagement. Results include a 49 percent decrease in admissions and a 5 percent decrease in ED utilization with significant cost savings. Authors recommend further study to analyze social, clinical, and financial risk in a larger sample, which may yield information about a health care provider&apos;s most at-risk patients for early targeted intervention. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/41/2/93.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=A+Population+Health+Approach+to+Clinical+Social+Work+with+Complex+Patients+in+Primary+Care&amp;rft.au=Rose%2C+Stephen+M%3BHatzenbuehler%2C+Stephanie%3BGilbert%2C+Erika%3BBouchard%2C+Mark+P%3BMcGill%2C+Debra&amp;rft.aulast=Rose&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=93&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=A+Population+Health+Approach+to+Clinical+Social+Work+with+Complex+Patients+in+Primary+Care&amp;rft.au=Rose%2C+Stephen+M%3BHatzenbuehler%2C+Stephanie%3BGilbert%2C+Erika%3BBouchard%2C+Mark+P%3BMcGill%2C+Debra&amp;rft.aulast=Rose&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=93&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Distal Stressors and Depression among Homeless Men

Author: Coohey, Carol; Easton, Scott D

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 41, Iss. 2,  (May 2016): 111.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1785220869?accountid=14667

Abstract: Depression is a common problem among homeless men that may interfere with functional tasks, such as securing stable housing, obtaining employment, and accessing health services. Previous research on depression among homeless men has largely focused on current psychosocial resources, substance abuse, and past victimization. Guided by Ensel and Lin&apos;s life course stress process model, the authors examined whether distal stressors, including victimization and exposure to parent problems in childhood, contributed to men&apos;s depression above and beyond current (or proximal) stressors, such as substance abuse and health problems, and social resources. The sample consisted of 309 homeless men who had entered a federally funded emergency shelter. Using the Burns Depression Checklist, the authors found that one out of three men met the threshold for moderate to severe depression during the past week. The logistic regression showed that past exposure to parent problems was related to depression after accounting for current stressors and social resources (number of close adult relationships and whether their emotional support needs were met). Past victimization was not related to depression. To address men&apos;s depression, workers should concurrently provide services that meet men&apos;s basic needs (for example, housing) and address their relationship needs, including their need for emotional support. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/41/2/111.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Distal+Stressors+and+Depression+among+Homeless+Men&amp;rft.au=Coohey%2C+Carol%3BEaston%2C+Scott+D&amp;rft.aulast=Coohey&amp;rft.aufirst=Carol&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=111&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Distal+Stressors+and+Depression+among+Homeless+Men&amp;rft.au=Coohey%2C+Carol%3BEaston%2C+Scott+D&amp;rft.aulast=Coohey&amp;rft.aufirst=Carol&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=111&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Formerly Incarcerated Women Speak Out

Author: López-Garza, Marta11 Gender & Women's Studies Department and Chicana/o Studies Department, California State University at Northridge, Northridge, California, USA

Publication info: Journal of Progressive Human Services ; Binghamton  Vol. 27, Iss. 2,  (May/Aug 2016): 69-94.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1787041655?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents the stories of formerly incarcerated women as they transition from prison back to their communities. The purpose of the article, based on feminist and visual ethnographic research methods, is to learn from the women themselves about the entities that support their efforts to rebuild their lives and stay out of prison as well as the barriers that impede such efforts. A major focus of this article is the women who mobilized on behalf the civil and human rights for all formerly incarcerated people and thus become their own advocates for change in policies and societal attitudes toward those with criminal records.

____________________________________________________________

Can Health Care Reform End Stigma Toward Mental Illness?

Author: Weiss, Eugenia L1; Gross, Gregory D2; Moncrief, Don11 School of Social Work, University of Southern California, Irvine, California, USA2 Department of Social Work, The College of Saint Rose, Albany, New York, USA

Publication info: Journal of Progressive Human Services ; Binghamton  Vol. 27, Iss. 2,  (May/Aug 2016): 95-110.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1787041799?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article addresses the destigmatization of mental health through health care reform by incorporating antistigma efforts-a destaining of mental illness-through prevention and early intervention in community-based programs that would be mandated and funded through the auspices of Patient Protection and the Affordable Care Act (ACA). Mental health care policies under the ACA and the Mental Health Parity Act are briefly described, following a definition of mental health stigma and its impacts. Recommendations for statutory mandates in stigma reduction at the community and federal levels and guidelines for mental health/behavioral health providers form the article&apos;s conclusion.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Progressive+Human+Services&amp;rft.atitle=Can+Health+Care+Reform+End+Stigma+Toward+Mental+Illness%3F&amp;rft.au=Weiss%2C+Eugenia+L%3BGross%2C+Gregory+D%3BMoncrief%2C+Don&amp;rft.aulast=Weiss&amp;rft.aufirst=Eugenia&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=27&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=95&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Progressive+Human+Services&amp;rft.issn=10428232&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10428232.2016.1155249

Executive Leadership and Social Innovation in Direct-Service Nonprofits: Shaping the Organizational Culture to Create Social Change

Author: Shier, Micheal L1; Handy, Femida21 Factor-Inwentash Faculty of Social Work, University of Toronto, Toronto, Ontario, Canada2 School of Social Policy and Practice, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA

Publication info: Journal of Progressive Human Services ; Binghamton  Vol. 27, Iss. 2,  (May/Aug 2016): 111-130.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1787041829?accountid=14667

Abstract: Direct-service nonprofits have taken on increasing responsibility in creating social change (operationalized through the concept of social innovation) within local communities. Qualitative interviews were conducted with executive directors to determine the factors within the intra-organizational environment that support an orientation toward social innovation. Findings show that aspects related to staff engagement and development and direction by the executive leadership team are particularly important. The findings provide a conceptual model of the varying intra-organizational dynamics that support the development of a social innovation-oriented organizational culture. This research offers a focus for social work education programs to equip practitioners with the skills needed in contemporary practice.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Progressive+Human+Services&amp;rft.atitle=Executive+Leadership+and+Social+Innovation+in+Direct-Service+Nonprofits%3A+Shaping+the+Organizational+Culture+to+Create+Social+Change&amp;rft.au=Shier%2C+Micheal+L%3BHandy%2C+Femida&amp;rft.aulast=Shier&amp;rft.aufirst=Micheal&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=27&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=111&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Progressive+Human+Services&amp;rft.issn=10428232&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10428232.2016.1155429

Development and validation of a diabetes self-management instrument for older African-Americans

Author: McCaskill, Gina M, PhD1; Bolland, Kathleen A, PhD2; Burgio, Kathryn L, PhD1; Leeper, James, PhD31 Birmingham/Atlanta Geriatric Research, Education, and Clinical Center (GRECC), Department of Veterans Affairs, Birmingham, Alabama, USA; Comprehensive Center for Healthy Aging, School of Medicine, The University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama, USA2 School of Social Work, The University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, Alabama, USA3 Department of Community and Rural Medicine, The University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, Alabama, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 5,  (May/Jun 2016): 381-394.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1788496132?accountid=14667

Abstract: The objective of this study was to develop and validate a new diabetes self-management instrument for older African-Americans 65 years of age and older. The Self-Care Utility Geriatric African-American Rating (SUGAAR) was developed using the American Diabetes Association&apos;s standards for the management of type 2 diabetes in older adults and cognitive interviews with older African-Americans. The instrument underwent extensive review by a panel of experts, two rounds of cognitive interviews, and a pilot test before it was administered in an interview format to 125 community-dwelling older African-Americans. The instrument demonstrated content validity and significant, but modest, convergent validity with items from an established diabetes self-management instrument. Social workers and health care professionals can use the SUGARR to assess diabetes self-management and to identify areas for education and support for older African-Americans with type 2 diabetes.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Development+and+validation+of+a+diabetes+self-management+instrument+for+older+African-Americans&amp;rft.au=McCaskill%2C+Gina+M%2C+PhD%3BBolland%2C+Kathleen+A%2C+PhD%3BBurgio%2C+Kathryn+L%2C+PhD%3BLeeper%2C+James%2C+PhD&amp;rft.aulast=McCaskill&amp;rft.aufirst=Gina&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=381&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2015.1129012

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Development+and+validation+of+a+diabetes+self-management+instrument+for+older+African-Americans&amp;rft.au=McCaskill%2C+Gina+M%2C+PhD%3BBolland%2C+Kathleen+A%2C+PhD%3BBurgio%2C+Kathryn+L%2C+PhD%3BLeeper%2C+James%2C+PhD&amp;rft.aulast=McCaskill&amp;rft.aufirst=Gina&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=381&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2015.1129012

The Ambulatory Integration of the Medical and Social (AIMS) model: A retrospective evaluation

Author: Rowe, Jeannine M1; Rizzo, Victoria M2; Shier Kricke, Gayle3; Krajci, Kate4; Rodriguez-Morales, Grisel4; Newman, Michelle4; Golden, Robyn41 Department of Social Work, College of Letters and Science, University of Wisconsin-Whitewater, Whitewater, Wisconsin, USA2 Department of Social Work, College of Community & Public Affairs, Binghamton University, Binghamton, New York, USA3 Center for Healthcare Studies, Northwestern University, Chicago, Illinois, USA4 Department of Health and Aging, Rush University Medical Center, Chicago, Illinois, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 5,  (May/Jun 2016): 347-361.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1788496299?accountid=14667

Abstract: An exploratory, retrospective evaluation of Ambulatory Integration of the Medical and Social (AIMS), a care coordination model designed to integrate medical and non-medical needs of patients and delivered exclusively by social workers was conducted to examine mean utilization of costly health care services for older adult patients. Results reveal mean utilization of 30-day hospital readmissions, emergency department (ED) visits, and hospital admissions are significantly lower for the study sample compared to the larger patient population. Comparisons with national population statistics reveal significantly lower mean utilization of 30-day admissions and ED visits for the study sample. The findings offer preliminary support regarding the value of AIMS.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=The+Ambulatory+Integration+of+the+Medical+and+Social+%28AIMS%29+model%3A+A+retrospective+evaluation&amp;rft.au=Rowe%2C+Jeannine+M%3BRizzo%2C+Victoria+M%3BShier+Kricke%2C+Gayle%3BKrajci%2C+Kate%3BRodriguez-Morales%2C+Grisel%3BNewman%2C+Michelle%3BGolden%2C+Robyn&amp;rft.aulast=Rowe&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeannine&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=347&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1164269

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=The+Ambulatory+Integration+of+the+Medical+and+Social+%28AIMS%29+model%3A+A+retrospective+evaluation&amp;rft.au=Rowe%2C+Jeannine+M%3BRizzo%2C+Victoria+M%3BShier+Kricke%2C+Gayle%3BKrajci%2C+Kate%3BRodriguez-Morales%2C+Grisel%3BNewman%2C+Michelle%3BGolden%2C+Robyn&amp;rft.aulast=Rowe&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeannine&amp;rft.date=2016-05-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=347&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1164269
