The Meaning of "Place" to Older Adults

Author: Sokolec, Jeanne11 School of Social Work, Loyola University Chicago, Chicago, IL, USA

Publication info: Clinical Social Work Journal ; New York  Vol. 44, Iss. 2,  (Jun 2016): 160-169.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1788992493?accountid=14667

Abstract: Issue Title: Special Issue: Clinical Considerations In Older Adulthood Social workers are well-equipped to work with older adults and their families. The life course perspective provides a framework for seeing older adulthood as a stage of life in the continuum of life as well as a stage with its own characteristics and tasks. All the roles within social work practice can be adapted to this population. In addition, social workers working with older adults and their families must be cognizant of the specific issues that are associated with aging and older adulthood. The issue of loss on many levels is a frequent topic. One area of loss that is not frequently addressed is the loss associated with where one lives. The word place can have several meanings. One meaning has to do with where one lives. The second meaning of loss is about one&apos;s status and role--place-in-society. For older adults both meanings become important issues as they and their families navigate the decisions that have to be made. While residence is based on the level of independence and competence of the older adult, the issue of place-as-status is a constant frustration for older adults. Issues of leaving one&apos;s place and losing status in the eyes of others evoke a myriad of feelings depending on the particular older adult. But given that as one ages there are naturally some physical and mental acuity losses, every older adult is subject to feelings of sadness, depression, hopelessness, and even anger. These feelings are natural responses to loss. Among the roles of social workers working with older adults is one of helping a mourning process move to a healthy acceptance of one&apos;s aging and planning rather than devolving into major depression.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=The+Meaning+of+%22Place%22+to+Older+Adults&amp;rft.au=Sokolec%2C+Jeanne&amp;rft.aulast=Sokolec&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeanne&amp;rft.date=2016-06-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=160&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=00911674&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10615-015-0545-2

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=The+Meaning+of+%22Place%22+to+Older+Adults&amp;rft.au=Sokolec%2C+Jeanne&amp;rft.aulast=Sokolec&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeanne&amp;rft.date=2016-06-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=160&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Clinical+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=00911674&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10615-015-0545-2

Working with Communities to Develop Resilience in End of Life and Bereavement Care: Hospices, Schools and Health Promoting Palliative Care

Author: Paul, Sally11 The University of Strathclyde, School of Social Work and Social Policy, Lord Hope Building, 141 St James Road, Glasgow, , UK

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Practice ; Abingdon  Vol. 30, Iss. 2,  (Jun 2016): 187-201.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1807912074?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper discusses research undertaken to explore and develop practice between a hospice and two primary schools. Action research was used to increase understanding about current practice in, and with, schools and to explore, implement and evaluate models of practice. Seven practice innovations were identified that are in various stages of being piloted. These innovations can be understood as health promoting palliative care activities, due to the process through which they were designed and their focus on developing the capacity of communities to respond to death, dying and bereavement. They demonstrate the diverse role that hospices, can play in developing how communities experience death, dying and bereavement and propose that a broader lens is employed to understand and facilitate end of life and bereavement services.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Working+with+Communities+to+Develop+Resilience+in+End+of+Life+and+Bereavement+Care%3A+Hospices%2C+Schools+and+Health+Promoting+Palliative+Care&amp;rft.au=Paul%2C+Sally&amp;rft.aulast=Paul&amp;rft.aufirst=Sally&amp;rft.date=2016-06-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=187&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650533.2016.1168383

Integrating Early Multi-disciplinary Advance Care Planning into Core Social Work Practice: Social Workers' Bread and Butter

Author: Chaddock, Rebecca11 Eden Valley Hospice and Jigsaw, Carlisle, UK

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Practice ; Abingdon  Vol. 30, Iss. 2,  (Jun 2016): 129-138.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1807912090?accountid=14667

Abstract: Many people remain unaware of their rights under the Mental Capacity Act, 2005 to make plans in advance and often approach the end of their lives without being asked about their thoughts and preferences by family or professionals. The author argues that in order for all citizens to attain their preferences at end of life, it is imperative that there is cross professional, organisational and operational agreement, paperwork and a shared understanding of Advanced Care Planning (ACP) that advocates early intervention. Skilled communication is the bedrock of social work, and difficult conversations are a routine part of daily practice. Integrating ACP into general social work practice offers a congruent approach to introducing ACP at an early stage. Drawing on the author&apos;s experience of implementing a county wide ACP project in Cumbria, this paper will advocate a standardised approach across health and social care with social work as a key tenet.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Integrating+Early+Multi-disciplinary+Advance+Care+Planning+into+Core+Social+Work+Practice%3A+Social+Workers%27+Bread+and+Butter&amp;rft.au=Chaddock%2C+Rebecca&amp;rft.aulast=Chaddock&amp;rft.aufirst=Rebecca&amp;rft.date=2016-06-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=129&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650533.2016.1168382

'Living to tell the tale' - Narratives of Surviving Cancer and the Social Work Response

Author: Taplin, Sue11 Department of Psychology, Sociology and Social Work, University Campus Suffolk, Ipswich, UK

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Practice ; Abingdon  Vol. 30, Iss. 2,  (Jun 2016): 155-168.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1807912091?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article draws on themes derived from research conducted as part of my doctoral study with eighteen individuals who were living with cancer, in which they were invited to explore the ways in which they experienced the world around them, how it had affected their sense of self and their relationships with others and whether and in what ways it had given them a different perspective on the present and the future. This research developed from my practice as a Social Worker in Palliative Care, during which time I became fascinated by the different reactions and responses which individual people displayed to a diagnosis of life-threatening illness, and how these changed during the trajectory of the illness, and specifically, in people living with a diagnosis of cancer, which did not always result in death. Drawing on interviews with cancer &apos;survivors&apos;, the concepts of biographical disruption, liminality and survivorship are explored as a means of understanding the reality of living with cancer. Finally there is a discussion of the implications of the research for contemporary social work practice.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=%27Living+to+tell+the+tale%27+-+Narratives+of+Surviving+Cancer+and+the+Social+Work+Response&amp;rft.au=Taplin%2C+Sue&amp;rft.aulast=Taplin&amp;rft.aufirst=Sue&amp;rft.date=2016-06-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=155&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650533.2016.1168380

Psychosocial perspectives on end of life care

Author: Scanlan, Katharine11 Tavistock and Portman NHS Trust, London, UK

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Practice ; Abingdon  Vol. 30, Iss. 2,  (Jun 2016): 139-154.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1807912098?accountid=14667

Abstract: Personal and professional experience has made the author aware of the way in which emotional responses to vulnerability, life threatening illness, death and dying can significantly influence the course and outcome of medical and social interventions, as well as the provision and quality of care provided. In recent years psychoanalytic studies have enabled a deeper understanding of the unconscious primitive anxieties and associated defences that are part of being human, and to think about the implications for health and social care workers as society strives to meet the needs of an increasingly ageing population. Aspects of psychoanalytic theory, including contemporary applications, have been useful in reflecting on what it means to provide care for those at the end of life. The author will discuss the value of applying psychoanalytic understanding and faculties to this developing area of health and social care. Early findings from a doctoral research project, "Bringing Death Home", will be referred to. The conclusion will reflect on personal knowledge and lived experience of palliative care social work to consider the significant contribution that relationship-based social work practice can make to the ongoing implementation of the end of life care strategy and the wider integrated care agenda.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Psychosocial+perspectives+on+end+of+life+care&amp;rft.au=Scanlan%2C+Katharine&amp;rft.aulast=Scanlan&amp;rft.aufirst=Katharine&amp;rft.date=2016-06-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=139&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650533.2016.1168381

____________________________________________________________

Schwartz rounds® - promoting compassionate care and healthy organisations

Author: Cullen, Anne11 Princess Alice Hospice, Esher, UK

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Practice ; Abingdon  Vol. 30, Iss. 2,  (Jun 2016): 219-228.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1807912112?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reviews evidence about the factors that can make it difficult for healthcare staff to provide compassionate care for individuals and their families. These relate to the intrinsic strain of caring for people who are suffering both physically and existentially, and the pressure of working conditions including high workloads, lack of support and continuing change. It presents Schwartz Rounds as an intervention that responds directly to these factors and has been found to be of significant benefit in hospitals, hospices and other health care settings in the USA and UK. It describes how this intervention is based on techniques that are integral to the practice of many social workers and draws attention to the fact that palliative care social workers have played a significant role in establishing the rounds in end of life services. It suggests that Schwartz Rounds could be helpfully introduced in other areas of activity where social workers and others are employed to provide care and protection for vulnerable people, including children and young people, where similar pressures and limitations have been identified.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Schwartz+rounds%C2%AE+-+promoting+compassionate+care+and+healthy+organisations&amp;rft.au=Cullen%2C+Anne&amp;rft.aulast=Cullen&amp;rft.aufirst=Anne&amp;rft.date=2016-06-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=219&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650533.2016.1168386

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Schwartz+rounds%C2%AE+-+promoting+compassionate+care+and+healthy+organisations&amp;rft.au=Cullen%2C+Anne&amp;rft.aulast=Cullen&amp;rft.aufirst=Anne&amp;rft.date=2016-06-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=219&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650533.2016.1168386

Subject: Hospitals; Youth; Vulnerability; Children; Hospices; Protection; Health care; Young children; Sympathy; Compassionate care; Vulnerable people; Caring; Young people; Interventions; Palliative care; End of life decisions; Social workers; Working conditions; Workloads; Suffering; Work environment; Health care services

Location: United Kingdom--UK

Classification: 6120: social work practice

Identifier / keyword: compassionate care palliative care social work end of life

Title: Schwartz rounds® - promoting compassionate care and healthy organisations

Publication title: Journal of Social Work Practice; Abingdon

Volume: 30

Guardians of Chastity and Morality: A Century of Silence in Social Work

Author: O'Neill, Elizabeth

Publication info: Journal of Sociology and Social Welfare ; Kalamazoo  Vol. 43, Iss. 2,  (Jun 2016): 1.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1868553646?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reflecting the social norms of the late 1800s and early 1900s, much of social work practice aimed to promote moral sexual behavior and penalize deviance. Even following the widespread adoption of psychoanalytic theory in the United States, social work persisted in having a poorly defined role with regard to issues of sexuality. In the 21st century, the profession continues to largely limit its involvement in matters of sexuality to those practice situations where deviance and public health concerns predominate. Limited topical exposure in peer-reviewed publications and the lack of broad-based human sexuality education for social workers perpetuate the invisibility of sexuality in the social work profession.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Sociology+and+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Guardians+of+Chastity+and+Morality%3A+A+Century+of+Silence+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=O%27Neill%2C+Elizabeth&amp;rft.aulast=O%27Neill&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2016-06-01&amp;rft.volume=43&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Sociology+and+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=01915096&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Sociology+and+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Guardians+of+Chastity+and+Morality%3A+A+Century+of+Silence+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=O%27Neill%2C+Elizabeth&amp;rft.aulast=O%27Neill&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2016-06-01&amp;rft.volume=43&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Sociology+and+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=01915096&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Construction of a Class with a Sense of Entitlement: A Case Study on Political Rhetoric as Symbolic Violence in Denmark

Author: Lueg, Klarissa; Jakobsen, Andreas

Publication info: Journal of Sociology and Social Welfare ; Kalamazoo  Vol. 43, Iss. 2,  (Jun 2016): 1.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1868553700?accountid=14667

Abstract: Taking a Bourdieusian perspective, this paper illustrates how one politically staged TV broadcast on a receiver of benefit payment has triggered political scapegoating in Denmark. The case has challenged the prevailing welfare state discourse and fostered the construction of a low class with a "sense of entitlement" by the media. We show that the media adopted the notion of a "sense of entitlement" originally used by politicians. Welfare state critical phrases and proverbs experienced a revival. We claim that this one-sided rhetoric abstracts from political responsibility and that power, agenda-building and rhetoric act as symbolic violence.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Sociology+and+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=The+Construction+of+a+Class+with+a+Sense+of+Entitlement%3A+A+Case+Study+on+Political+Rhetoric+as+Symbolic+Violence+in+Denmark&amp;rft.au=Lueg%2C+Klarissa%3BJakobsen%2C+Andreas&amp;rft.aulast=Lueg&amp;rft.aufirst=Klarissa&amp;rft.date=2016-06-01&amp;rft.volume=43&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Sociology+and+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=01915096&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Sociology+and+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=The+Construction+of+a+Class+with+a+Sense+of+Entitlement%3A+A+Case+Study+on+Political+Rhetoric+as+Symbolic+Violence+in+Denmark&amp;rft.au=Lueg%2C+Klarissa%3BJakobsen%2C+Andreas&amp;rft.aulast=Lueg&amp;rft.aufirst=Klarissa&amp;rft.date=2016-06-01&amp;rft.volume=43&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Sociology+and+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=01915096&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Support and Crime: A State-Level Analysis of Social Support Policies

Author: Brown, Jessica

Publication info: Journal of Sociology and Social Welfare ; Kalamazoo  Vol. 43, Iss. 2,  (Jun 2016): 1.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1868553833?accountid=14667

Abstract: There is a growing theoretical and empirical tradition that examines the relationship between social support and crime. While academic research supports the idea that social support inhibits crime, public discourse and the popular media often assert that support, especially instrumental support to the poor, can increase crime. This article adds to the growing literature by including multiple forms of social support in an investigation of the relationship between social support and property crime and violent crime over a ten year period. Results indicate that while some forms of support have the expected negative relationship with crime, others displayed a significant positive relationship, and others had no significant relationship. Implications for these findings are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Sociology+and+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Support+and+Crime%3A+A+State-Level+Analysis+of+Social+Support+Policies&amp;rft.au=Brown%2C+Jessica&amp;rft.aulast=Brown&amp;rft.aufirst=Jessica&amp;rft.date=2016-06-01&amp;rft.volume=43&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Sociology+and+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=01915096&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Assessing Access to Social Services in Emerging Systems: A Conceptual Approach

Author: Anderson, Steven G; Liu, Meirong; Gao, Xiang

Publication info: Journal of Sociology and Social Welfare ; Kalamazoo  Vol. 43, Iss. 2,  (Jun 2016): 1.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1868553836?accountid=14667

Abstract: There has been considerable concern about systemic factors that serve as access barriers for vulnerable groups in need of services, but conceptual and empirical work related to such issues have been limited. This article presents a new conceptual approach for considering and assessing access, which we call the "Funnel Framework". The framework is explicated abstractly, and is illustrated with use of the U.S. child care subsidy system. We argue that the framework can usefully guide the analysis of access to any social benefit system, and can be helpful to administrators and program developers as they design and implement benefit systems.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Sociology+and+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Assessing+Access+to+Social+Services+in+Emerging+Systems%3A+A+Conceptual+Approach&amp;rft.au=Anderson%2C+Steven+G%3BLiu%2C+Meirong%3BGao%2C+Xiang&amp;rft.aulast=Anderson&amp;rft.aufirst=Steven&amp;rft.date=2016-06-01&amp;rft.volume=43&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Sociology+and+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=01915096&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Grand Challenges: Social Justice and the Need for Evidence-Based Sex Offender Registry Reform

Author: Levenson, Jill S; Grady, Melissa; Leibowitz, George

Publication info: Journal of Sociology and Social Welfare ; Kalamazoo  Vol. 43, Iss. 2,  (Jun 2016): 1.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1868553957?accountid=14667

Abstract: Sex offender registries, though popular, bring with them enormous fiscal costs and unintended consequences for offenders and communities. Consistent with the Grand Challenges, social workers can play a role in advocating for sex offender management policies that are better informed by evidence and thus a better use of resources. Registry reform would also moderate the stigma resulting from the sex offender label, and reduce barriers to offender reintegration. First, a brief history of registration laws and the research around their effectiveness will be provided, followed by a rationale for needed improvements in sex offender management policy. Finally, evidence-based recommendations for reform will be offered. Such changes can result in improved public safety outcomes and social justice in our communities.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Sociology+and+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Grand+Challenges%3A+Social+Justice+and+the+Need+for+Evidence-Based+Sex+Offender+Registry+Reform&amp;rft.au=Levenson%2C+Jill+S%3BGrady%2C+Melissa%3BLeibowitz%2C+George&amp;rft.aulast=Levenson&amp;rft.aufirst=Jill&amp;rft.date=2016-06-01&amp;rft.volume=43&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Sociology+and+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=01915096&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Fear and Misinformation as Predictors of Support for Sex Offender Management Policies

Author: Kernsmith, Poco; Comartin, Erin; Kernsmith, Roger

Publication info: Journal of Sociology and Social Welfare ; Kalamazoo  Vol. 43, Iss. 2,  (Jun 2016): 1.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1868554230?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study investigated the public's agreement with sex offender management policies. Respondents (N = 703) were randomly sampled from the state of Michigan, using a CATI system. Two pathanalysis models were used to test if personal characteristics, level of fear of sex offenders, and misinformation regarding this population were predictive of agreement with: (a) sex offender registration and community notification policies; and (b) more severe sanctions (life in prison and chemical castration). The findings suggest that greater fear of sex offenders and acceptance of misinformation were predictive of more support of sex offender management policies. Research has found that these policies are costly and ineffective in promoting community safety. Effective and efficient policy development occurs when policy is based on evidence. Community and legislative education may promote thoughtful policy development that holds offenders accountable and promotes successful reintegration.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Sociology+and+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Fear+and+Misinformation+as+Predictors+of+Support+for+Sex+Offender+Management+Policies&amp;rft.au=Kernsmith%2C+Poco%3BComartin%2C+Erin%3BKernsmith%2C+Roger&amp;rft.aulast=Kernsmith&amp;rft.aufirst=Poco&amp;rft.date=2016-06-01&amp;rft.volume=43&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Sociology+and+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=01915096&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Correlates of Social Work Students' Abortion Knowledge and Attitudes: Implications for Education and Research

Author: Begun, Stephanie1; Bird, Melissa2; Ramseyer Winter, Virginia3; Massey Combs, Katie1; McKay, Kimberly41 Graduate School of Social Work, University of Denver Denver, Colorado, USA2 School of Social Work, University of Southern California Los Angeles, California, USA3 School of Social Work, University of Missouri Columbia, Missouri, USA4 School of Social Work, Temple University Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 4,  (Jul 2016): 276-287.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1787041659?accountid=14667

Abstract: Researchers have established that individuals&apos; abortion knowledge is positively associated with their support of abortion rights. However, social workers&apos; personal beliefs regarding abortion are under-researched, even though social workers are often employed in health promotion and education roles in which the topic of abortion is encountered. The current study examines the results of a nationwide survey of social work students (N = 504) and explores the relationship between social work students&apos; abortion knowledge and abortion attitudes. Less abortion knowledge was significantly associated with antichoice attitude endorsement. Implications for social work research, training, and education are subsequently discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Correlates+of+Social+Work+Students%27+Abortion+Knowledge+and+Attitudes%3A+Implications+for+Education+and+Research&amp;rft.au=Begun%2C+Stephanie%3BBird%2C+Melissa%3BRamseyer+Winter%2C+Virginia%3BMassey+Combs%2C+Katie%3BMcKay%2C+Kimberly&amp;rft.aulast=Begun&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephanie&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=276&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1137510

Health and Social Security Needs of Rickshaw Pullers in Ranchi

Author: Kumar, Anant1; Thomas, Joe2; Wadhwa, Sonal S3; Mishra, Aprajita3; Dasgupta, Smita31 Xavier Institute of Social Service, Ranchi, India2 Partners in Population and Development, Dhaka, Bangladesh3 Maitri India, Delhi and Ranchi, India

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 4,  (Jul 2016): 246-254.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1787041678?accountid=14667

Abstract: A significant number of "marginalized" population groups are denied their health rights, healthcare access, benefits of government health programs, and other health-related social security benefits. These population groups, particularly the rickshaw pullers of India, are vulnerable because of their poor social and economic status, migration history, lack of permanent settlements, lack of social capital, and so on. These reasons, coupled with other social-political reasons, lead to no or limited access to health services and poor health conditions. This study intends to explore and understand the context and health seeking behavior of rickshaw pullers in Ranchi, the capital city of Jharkhand state in India, with special reference to wider social determinants of health such as, access, affordability, and delivery of health services. The data was collected from 1,000 rickshaw pullers from 40 "rickshaw garages" in Ranchi. The findings of the study show that rickshaw pullers can&apos;t afford to "attach" much importance to their health due to various reasons and suffer from a variety of occupational and other illnesses. The health conditions of the rickshaw pullers are affected by poverty, negligence, illiteracy, lack of awareness and unavailability of affordable, quality health services. These are only a symptom of the larger structural issues affecting health. The study suggests that rickshaw pullers, being a marginalized and excluded population group, require special health and social security programs that include safe, affordable, and accessible services along with a special focus on health education, behavior change, and promotion of appropriate health-seeking behavior.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Health+and+Social+Security+Needs+of+Rickshaw+Pullers+in+Ranchi&amp;rft.au=Kumar%2C+Anant%3BThomas%2C+Joe%3BWadhwa%2C+Sonal+S%3BMishra%2C+Aprajita%3BDasgupta%2C+Smita&amp;rft.aulast=Kumar&amp;rft.aufirst=Anant&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=246&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1125323

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Health+and+Social+Security+Needs+of+Rickshaw+Pullers+in+Ranchi&amp;rft.au=Kumar%2C+Anant%3BThomas%2C+Joe%3BWadhwa%2C+Sonal+S%3BMishra%2C+Aprajita%3BDasgupta%2C+Smita&amp;rft.aulast=Kumar&amp;rft.aufirst=Anant&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=246&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1125323

Armed Conflict in the Federally Administered Tribal Areas of Pakistan and the Role of NGOs in Restoring Health Services

Author: Khan, Muhammad Ammad1; Xiaoying, Jian1; Kanwal, Nazish21 Department of Development Studies, China Agricultural University, Beijing, China2 Department of Agricultural Economics and Management, China Agricultural University, Beijing, China

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 4,  (Jul 2016): 215-230.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1787041688?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Federally Administered Tribal Areas (FATA) of Pakistan have been a hotbed of terrorists&apos; violence since 9/11. The unremitted armed conflict in the region and limited role of the government in delivering fundamental health services has left the people at the disposal of nongovernmental organizations (NGOs). This research aims at empirically substantiating the successful strategies adopted by the NGOs to run their projects under threats and to know the perceptions of the community toward NGOs and their services. Triangulation methodology was adopted in collecting data. Based on results, the research found that health care is a highly demanded service in the study area, and the government does not have the capacity nor the resources to ensure decent health coverage for all the people of the region. NGOs indeed have a crucial role not only in building the capacity of the government and the community but also in restoring and providing health services in the region, but still many efforts are required to overcome the challenges they are facing. By implication, the research places forward some recommendations.

The Frequent Fliers of New Mexico: Hospital Readmissions among the Homeless Population

Author: Dirmyer, Victoria F11 Health Systems Epidemiology Program, New Mexico Department of Health, Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 4,  (Jul 2016): 288-298.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1787041737?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is estimated that there are 1.7 million homeless individuals in the United States; 36% are families with children under the age of 18. Due to lack of resources, individuals who are homeless frequent emergency departments for immediate health care needs. The aim of this study was to examine a homeless population over a 3-year time period who were admitted to an Albuquerque area hospital at any time during the time period. A comparison of demographic characteristics as well as hospitalization characteristics between two populations was analyzed: individuals who were homeless and had a 30-day readmission compared to those that did not have a 30-day readmission. There were 850 unique homeless patients that were admitted to an Albuquerque area hospital during the 3-year time period. The mean age was 43.8 years with the majority of the population being male. The 3-year average 30-day readmission rate was 30.1%. Multivariate regression analysis indicated that homeless patients older than 19 years, individuals with more than 1 admission during the time period, and individuals who left against medical advice had increased odds of a 30-day readmission. Individuals who were homeless who were admitted for respiratory conditions or cardiovascular disease had decreased odds of a 30-day readmission compared to patients admitted for neuropsychiatric conditions. In New Mexico, patients who were homeless experienced a high 30-day readmission rate. These results suggest a need for further research into the healthcare needs of this population and how to improve discharge protocols to prevent future readmissions.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=The+Frequent+Fliers+of+New+Mexico%3A+Hospital+Readmissions+among+the+Homeless+Population&amp;rft.au=Dirmyer%2C+Victoria+F&amp;rft.aulast=Dirmyer&amp;rft.aufirst=Victoria&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=288&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1101036

Correlates of Self-Rated Health and Self-Rated Mental Health in Older Chinese Americans

Author: Jang, Yuri1; Huang, Ya-Ching2; Yoon, Hyunwoo1; Lin, Shumin31 School of Social Work, The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, Texas, USA2 School of Nursing, The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, Texas, USA3 Language Teaching and Research Center and Graduate Institute of Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages, National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 4,  (Jul 2016): 309-315.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1787041795?accountid=14667

Abstract: The present study examined the factors associated with self-rated health (SRH) and self-rated mental health (SRMH) in a sample of 108 older Chinese Americans (MeanAge = 70.6, SD = 7.70). SRH and SRMH were highly associated with each other. In the multiple regression models, chronic conditions and functional disability emerged as significant predictors of poor SRH and SRMH. However, the significance of depressive symptoms was only obtained in the model of SRMH. The findings reflect the body-mind connection among older Chinese Americans and provide implications for integrative health promotion efforts.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Correlates+of+Self-Rated+Health+and+Self-Rated+Mental+Health+in+Older+Chinese+Americans&amp;rft.au=Jang%2C+Yuri%3BHuang%2C+Ya-Ching%3BYoon%2C+Hyunwoo%3BLin%2C+Shumin&amp;rft.aulast=Jang&amp;rft.aufirst=Yuri&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=309&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1137515

A Multilevel Ecological Model of HIV Risk for People Who Are Homeless or Unstably Housed and Who Use Drugs in the Urban United States

Author: Bowen, Elizabeth A11 School of Social Work, University at Buffalo, State University of New York, Buffalo, New York, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 4,  (Jul 2016): 264-275.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1787041816?accountid=14667

Abstract: Elevated HIV prevalence has been observed among urban U.S. individuals who use drugs and who lack stable housing. This article synthesizes extant research on this population and situates it in a multilevel, ecologically based model of HIV risk. Based on a multidisciplinary review of the literature, the model applies social-ecological theory on human development to identify factors shaping the HIV risk context for individuals who use drugs and who are unstably housed at global, societal, neighborhood, household, and individual levels of influence. At the global level, the model includes neoliberal ideologies contributing to the social inequalities that frame the HIV epidemic. U.S. housing and drug policy, including urban renewal, HOPE VI, and the War on Drugs, is the focus of the societal level. At the neighborhood level, mechanisms of the built environment and psychosocial mechanisms are explored for their salience to HIV risk. Research on the association between housing instability and HIV risk is reviewed at the household level. At the last level, relevant individual differences in biology, psychology, and cognition are discussed. Modeling risk at multiple levels of the environment underscores the need to expand the focus of research, treatment, and prevention interventions for HIV/AIDS and addictions beyond individuals and their risk behaviors to address facets of structural violence and incorporate the broader social, political, and economic contexts of risk and health.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=A+Multilevel+Ecological+Model+of+HIV+Risk+for+People+Who+Are+Homeless+or+Unstably+Housed+and+Who+Use+Drugs+in+the+Urban+United+States&amp;rft.au=Bowen%2C+Elizabeth+A&amp;rft.aulast=Bowen&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=264&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1137511

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=A+Multilevel+Ecological+Model+of+HIV+Risk+for+People+Who+Are+Homeless+or+Unstably+Housed+and+Who+Use+Drugs+in+the+Urban+United+States&amp;rft.au=Bowen%2C+Elizabeth+A&amp;rft.aulast=Bowen&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=264&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1137511

Subject: Housing; Biology; Ideologies; War; Prevention; Health; Homelessness; Neoliberalism; Risk; Individual differences; Drug abuse; Social policy; Cognitive development; Urban areas; Housing policy; Environmental factors; Built environment; Acquired immune deficiency syndrome; Urban renewal; Urban policy; Public policy

Location: United States--US

Classification: 6124: health care promotion/education

Identifier / keyword: Ecological model HIV/AIDS homeless structural violence War on Drugs

Title: A Multilevel Ecological Model of HIV Risk for People Who Are Homeless or Unstably Housed and Who Use Drugs in the Urban United States

Publication title: Social Work in Public Health; Abingdon

Volume: 31

Issue: 4

Pages: 264-275

Publication year: 2016

Publication date: Jul 2016

Publisher: Taylor & Francis Ltd.

Place of publication: Abingdon

Country of publication: United Kingdom

Publication subject: Public Health And Safety, Social Services And Welfare

ISSN: 1937-1918

Source type: Scholarly Journals

Language of publication: English

Identifying Barriers and Facilitators to Breast Health Services among Women with Disabilities

Author: Welch Saleeby, Patricia1; Hunter-Jones, Josalin21 School of Social Work, Southern Illinois University Carbondale, Carbondale, Illinois, USA2 Grace Crum Rollins School of Public Health, Emory University, Atlanta, Georgia, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 4,  (Jul 2016): 255-263.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1787042507?accountid=14667

Abstract: Women with disabilities experience significant disparities in accessing breast health services. Many studies have focused on barriers, but few have explored facilitators to improving breast health services. This study used a participatory-research approach involving women with physical, mobility, sensory, and developmental disabilities to explore facilitators and barriers affecting the access and quality of breast health services. Findings confirmed commonly cited barriers including attitudinal, environmental, financial, and structural issues but also identified multiple facilitators such as enhancing accessibility of breast health facilities and equipment, improving information sources, and increasing training of health professionals. Findings from this study can be used in improving breast health services among women with disabilities by targeting not only the removal of barriers but also the increase in proven facilitators.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Identifying+Barriers+and+Facilitators+to+Breast+Health+Services+among+Women+with+Disabilities&amp;rft.au=Welch+Saleeby%2C+Patricia%3BHunter-Jones%2C+Josalin&amp;rft.aulast=Welch+Saleeby&amp;rft.aufirst=Patricia&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=255&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1137509

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Identifying+Barriers+and+Facilitators+to+Breast+Health+Services+among+Women+with+Disabilities&amp;rft.au=Welch+Saleeby%2C+Patricia%3BHunter-Jones%2C+Josalin&amp;rft.aulast=Welch+Saleeby&amp;rft.aufirst=Patricia&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=255&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1137509

Voices of the Homeless: An Emic Approach to the Experiences of Health Disparities Faced by People Who Are Homeless

Author: Hsieh, Elaine11 Department of Communication, University of Oklahoma, Norman, Oklahoma, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 4,  (Jul 2016): 328-340.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1787042529?accountid=14667

Abstract: People who are homeless are particularly vulnerable to health disparities. Rather than using population statistics to highlight the prevalence or severity of the suffering of people who are homeless, 28 undergraduate students each conducted an in-depth interview with an individual who relied on a local homeless shelter to cope with everyday life. The interview explored the participants&apos; health concerns and strategies for health management. Due to equipment failure and incomplete recording, only 16 interviews are included in this study. The author adopted thematic analysis while focused on preserving the richness of the interactions between the participants who are homeless and the undergraduate students. The author&apos;s goal is to provide emic, intimate insights about the struggles and challenges faced by the people who are homeless. The author concluded the study by situating the findings in the larger literature of health disparities experienced by people who are homeless.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Voices+of+the+Homeless%3A+An+Emic+Approach+to+the+Experiences+of+Health+Disparities+Faced+by+People+Who+Are+Homeless&amp;rft.au=Hsieh%2C+Elaine&amp;rft.aulast=Hsieh&amp;rft.aufirst=Elaine&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=328&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1137512

Teaching and incorporating practice models in a human behavior in the social environment (HBSE) course

Author: Tsagaris, George S1; Welch-Brewer, Chiquitia L21 School of Social Work, College of Liberal Arts & Social Sciences, Cleveland State University, Cleveland, Ohio, USA2 Department of Sociology and Social Work, North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University, Greensboro, North Carolina, USA

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment ; Abingdon  Vol. 26, Iss. 5,  (Jul 2016): 470-487.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1788495349?accountid=14667

Abstract: Human behavior and the social environment (HBSE) instructors do not systematically or routinely teach and incorporate practice models in their course. In this article, social work educators describe an approach to teaching and incorporating practice models in a HBSE course using a five-step adapted, modified version of Mosey's extrapolation method for teaching master level social work students to evaluate and apply practice models. The authors use the Balanced and Restorative Justice (BARJ) model as an illustration to help social work students develop critically reflective approaches to evaluating and applying practice models. The techniques and guidelines outlined in this article could be applied to other practice models and used by social work educators and students interested in other fields of practice.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Teaching+and+incorporating+practice+models+in+a+human+behavior+in+the+social+environment+%28HBSE%29+course&amp;rft.au=Tsagaris%2C+George+S%3BWelch-Brewer%2C+Chiquitia+L&amp;rft.aulast=Tsagaris&amp;rft.aufirst=George&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=470&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2015.1087923

Intimate partner violence: An application of attachment theory

Author: J Park, Christine11 National Catholic School of Social Service, The Catholic University of America, Washington, DC, USA; Family Services Department, Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Arlington, Arlington, Virginia, USA

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment ; Abingdon  Vol. 26, Iss. 5,  (Jul 2016): 488-497.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1788495354?accountid=14667

Abstract: Attachment theory has gained increased prominence over the past several decades in the fields of psychiatry, psychology, and social work. Attachment theory, however, has not been systematically applied to intimate partner violence (IPV), a phenomenon that disproportionately affects women in poverty. This article provides an overview of IPV as a social problem, reviews existing literature related to the application of attachment theory to IPV, discusses the theory's strengths and limitations in understanding and resolving IPV, and considers areas for future knowledge development.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Intimate+partner+violence%3A+An+application+of+attachment+theory&amp;rft.au=J+Park%2C+Christine&amp;rft.aulast=J+Park&amp;rft.aufirst=Christine&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=488&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2015.1087924

Renaissance beauty = Today's ugly: What appearance factors determine attractiveness judgments?

Author: Osborn, Don R11 Departments of Psychology, Sociology, and Criminal Justice Studies, Bellarmine University, Louisville, Kentucky, USA

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment ; Abingdon  Vol. 26, Iss. 5,  (Jul 2016): 437-446.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1788497456?accountid=14667

Abstract: By comparing photos of portraits of the faces of Renaissance courtesans to photos of attractive contemporary women's faces this study estimates the importance of sociocultural factors in the personal perception of faces. Physical attractiveness is an important causal factor in choosing a sex partner, so the difference between averaged attractiveness judgments, a focus of attractiveness research, and individual attractiveness judgment, most relevant to choosing a sex partner, is important. Except for modesty and faithfulness, 13 normally attractive contemporary models were rated much more positively by college student participants (N = 189) than were eight celebrated Renaissance courtesans, both in attractiveness (contemporary stimuli 63%; Renaissance courtesans 31%) and in personality traits. All of the Renaissance courtesan trait ratings showed more variability than the contemporary stimuli. This study supports the view that once a relatively low baseline level of biological attractiveness is surpassed, latent and explicit sociocultural factors, culturally relative gender role appearance expectations, culturally relative aesthetic judgment factors, individual differences, and interpersonal dynamics are major determining factors of judgments of pretty and/or beautiful showing large subcultural and cultural individual differences. Pretty and beautiful may be discrete concepts, with beautiful strongly culturally determined. These data suggest that sociocultural and subcultural factors are important determiners of attractiveness.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Renaissance+beauty+%3D+Today%27s+ugly%3A+What+appearance+factors+determine+attractiveness+judgments%3F&amp;rft.au=Osborn%2C+Don+R&amp;rft.aulast=Osborn&amp;rft.aufirst=Don&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=437&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2015.1083508

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Renaissance+beauty+%3D+Today%27s+ugly%3A+What+appearance+factors+determine+attractiveness+judgments%3F&amp;rft.au=Osborn%2C+Don+R&amp;rft.aulast=Osborn&amp;rft.aufirst=Don&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=437&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2015.1083508

Parenting challenges and parents' intimate relationships

Author: Khajehei, Marjan11 Research Department, Karitane, Carramar, New South Wales, Australia; and School of Women's and Children's Health, University of New South Wales, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment ; Abingdon  Vol. 26, Iss. 5,  (Jul 2016): 447-451.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1788497520?accountid=14667

Abstract: Parenthood is a rewarding as well as a potentially stressful event for many couples as it brings many changes to their lives. Having young children at home can result in decreased relationship satisfaction and a low-quality sexual relationship. Same-sex couples may, however, report different parenting experiences, and their parenthood may not significantly affect their level of relationship satisfaction. The quality of marital relationship is an important determinant of the parenting stress and the quality of the parent-child relationship. Mothers and fathers who report dissatisfaction with their marriage and relationship experience more parenting difficulties and stress than those who are satisfied with their relationships. Although research into transition to parenthood is very significant, the association between parenting challenges and parents' intimate relationships remains an understudied topic. Research needs not only to highlight the importance of parents and family well-being and its direct impacts on the child's well-being, but also to emphasize the bidirectional association between parent-child interactions and couples' intimate relationship satisfaction.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Parenting+challenges+and+parents%27+intimate+relationships&amp;rft.au=Khajehei%2C+Marjan&amp;rft.aulast=Khajehei&amp;rft.aufirst=Marjan&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=447&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2015.1083509

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Parenting+challenges+and+parents%27+intimate+relationships&amp;rft.au=Khajehei%2C+Marjan&amp;rft.aulast=Khajehei&amp;rft.aufirst=Marjan&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=447&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2015.1083509

____________________________________________________________

An approach of the moral disengagement through the moral content judgment

Author: Proios, Miltiadis11 Department of Physical Education and Sport Science, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, Greece

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment ; Abingdon  Vol. 26, Iss. 5,  (Jul 2016): 461-469.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1788497561?accountid=14667

Abstract: The goal of the present study was the best understanding of the development of mechanisms of moral disengagement. Participants were 281 athletes (males, n = 133, and females, n = 148) all involved in competitive sport (teams and individuals). Their ages ranged from 13 to 23 years (M = 15.01, SD = 2.29), while their experience ranged from 1 to15 years (M = 5.42, SD = 3.13). The participants filled out two questionnaires: the Moral Disengagement in Sport Scale (MDSS) and the Moral Content Judgment in Sport Questionnaire (MCJSQ). Results revealed significant differences in gender and a negative correlation between the three mechanisms of moral disengagement (advantageous comparison, non-responsibility, and attribution of blame) with age. Findings also revealed that the mechanisms of moral disengagement relationship with elements of moral content judgment was positive with egoistic utilitarianism/consequences and negative with fairness.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=An+approach+of+the+moral+disengagement+through+the+moral+content+judgment&amp;rft.au=Proios%2C+Miltiadis&amp;rft.aulast=Proios&amp;rft.aufirst=Miltiadis&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=461&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2015.1087922

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=An+approach+of+the+moral+disengagement+through+the+moral+content+judgment&amp;rft.au=Proios%2C+Miltiadis&amp;rft.aulast=Proios&amp;rft.aufirst=Miltiadis&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=461&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2015.1087922

Solution-focused financial therapy with couples

Author: Smith, Thomas E1; Shelton, Victoria M2; Richards, Kristin V31 College of Social Work, Florida State University, Tallahassee, Florida, USA2 Boys Town North Florida, Tallahassee, Florida, USA3 Department of Social Work, Mississippi Valley State University, Itta Bena, Mississippi, USA

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment ; Abingdon  Vol. 26, Iss. 5,  (Jul 2016): 452-460.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1788497719?accountid=14667

Abstract: Conflicts over finances are a key reason why marital relationships dissolve. Financial literacy interventions provide a strategy to ameliorate this conflict. Because financial literacy interventions have a mixed history of success, a new model of financial counseling is presented. The model described in this article has three components: transtheoretical indicators of readiness for change, solution-focused therapeutic techniques in negotiating the stages of change, and a five step model of financial therapy. Implications for refining the practice model are given.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Solution-focused+financial+therapy+with+couples&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Thomas+E%3BShelton%2C+Victoria+M%3BRichards%2C+Kristin+V&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Thomas&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=452&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2015.1087921

Author Guidelines for Manuscripts Reporting on Qualitative Research

Author: Wu, Shiyou; Wyant, Diane C; Fraser, Mark W

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research, suppl. SPECIAL ISSUE ON THE ETIOLOGY AND TREATMENT OF SEVERE .. ; Chicago  Vol. 7, Iss. 2,  (Summer 2016): 405.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837346?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes author guidelines for developing qualitative manuscripts for peer-reviewed journals. The article explains the process used in the development of qualitative guidelines for JSSWR. The Journal sought to develop a set of guidelines, not as a prescribed checklist, but as benchmarks or, perhaps, touchstones to ensure that readers have sufficient information to fully understand qualitative research procedures. Qualitative research is diverse and guidelines -- no matter how expertly crafted -- will apply differentially. The guidelines presented here aim to offer authors practical advice toward increasing the clarity of reporting.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Author+Guidelines+for+Manuscripts+Reporting+on+Qualitative+Research&amp;rft.au=Wu%2C+Shiyou%3BWyant%2C+Diane+C%3BFraser%2C+Mark+W&amp;rft.aulast=Wu&amp;rft.aufirst=Shiyou&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=405&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Feasibility Study of Increasing Social Support to Enhance a Healthy Lifestyle Intervention for Individuals with Serious Mental Illness

Author: Aschbrenner, Kelly A; Mueser, Kim T; Naslund, John A; Gorin, Amy A; Kinney, Allison; Daniels, Lucas; Bartels, Stephen J

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research, suppl. SPECIAL ISSUE ON THE ETIOLOGY AND TREATMENT OF SEVERE .. ; Chicago  Vol. 7, Iss. 2,  (Summer 2016): 289.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837365?accountid=14667

Abstract: Healthy lifestyle interventions addressing obesity in people with serious mental illness (SMI) lead to modest weight losses that tend not to be sustained over time. The purpose of this study was to assess the feasibility of increasing support from family and friends to enhance a healthy lifestyle intervention (In SHAPE) adapted for individuals with SMI. A sample of 7 dyads (14 total participants) participated in this small-scale open-feasibility trial of social support strategies to enhance health promotion. Feasibility was assessed by program participation and by examining participants&apos; satisfaction and exploring suggestions for improving the model post-intervention. Participants reported high satisfaction and perceived benefits from the program. This formative research showed that the study design is feasible and that the intervention can facilitate social support for health behavior change in people with SMI. Further research is needed to evaluate the effectiveness of this intervention.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Feasibility+Study+of+Increasing+Social+Support+to+Enhance+a+Healthy+Lifestyle+Intervention+for+Individuals+with+Serious+Mental+Illness&amp;rft.au=Aschbrenner%2C+Kelly+A%3BMueser%2C+Kim+T%3BNaslund%2C+John+A%3BGorin%2C+Amy+A%3BKinney%2C+Allison%3BDaniels%2C+Lucas%3BBartels%2C+Stephen+J&amp;rft.aulast=Aschbrenner&amp;rft.aufirst=Kelly&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=289&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Feasibility+Study+of+Increasing+Social+Support+to+Enhance+a+Healthy+Lifestyle+Intervention+for+Individuals+with+Serious+Mental+Illness&amp;rft.au=Aschbrenner%2C+Kelly+A%3BMueser%2C+Kim+T%3BNaslund%2C+John+A%3BGorin%2C+Amy+A%3BKinney%2C+Allison%3BDaniels%2C+Lucas%3BBartels%2C+Stephen+J&amp;rft.aulast=Aschbrenner&amp;rft.aufirst=Kelly&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=289&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Support-Centered Versus Symptom-Centered Models in Predicting Functional Outcomes for Individuals with Schizophrenia

Author: Pahwa, Rohini; Smith, Melissa Edmondson; McCullagh, Charlotte A; Hoe, Maanse; Brekke, John S

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research, suppl. SPECIAL ISSUE ON THE ETIOLOGY AND TREATMENT OF SEVERE .. ; Chicago  Vol. 7, Iss. 2,  (Summer 2016): 247.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837597?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study tests 2 competing models to explore the influence of symptomatology and social support on functioning for individuals with schizophrenia. The symptom-centered model hypothesizes that social support has an indirect association with functioning through symptoms. These models were examined using 166 individuals with schizophrenia receiving community-based services. For social functioning, the social support-centered model is an adequate fit to the data (x2 = 0.316, df = 2, p = .854; CFI = 1.000, NFI = .990, AIC = 24.316, RMSEA = .000); however, the symptom-centered model is a poor fit to the data (x2 = 15.597, df = 3, p = .001; CFI = .772, NFI = .718, AIC = 37.597, RMSEA = .160). Overall, the findings suggest that models for understanding functioning and interventions in schizophrenia need to be differentially focused, depending on the targeted outcome. Implications for social work practice and policy are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Support-Centered+Versus+Symptom-Centered+Models+in+Predicting+Functional+Outcomes+for+Individuals+with+Schizophrenia&amp;rft.au=Pahwa%2C+Rohini%3BSmith%2C+Melissa+Edmondson%3BMcCullagh%2C+Charlotte+A%3BHoe%2C+Maanse%3BBrekke%2C+John+S&amp;rft.aulast=Pahwa&amp;rft.aufirst=Rohini&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=247&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Support-Centered+Versus+Symptom-Centered+Models+in+Predicting+Functional+Outcomes+for+Individuals+with+Schizophrenia&amp;rft.au=Pahwa%2C+Rohini%3BSmith%2C+Melissa+Edmondson%3BMcCullagh%2C+Charlotte+A%3BHoe%2C+Maanse%3BBrekke%2C+John+S&amp;rft.aulast=Pahwa&amp;rft.aufirst=Rohini&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=247&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Race: America&apos;s Grand Challenge

Author: Davis, Larry E

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research, suppl. SPECIAL ISSUE ON THE ETIOLOGY AND TREATMENT OF SEVERE .. ; Chicago  Vol. 7, Iss. 2,  (Summer 2016): 395.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837761?accountid=14667

Abstract: This invited article is based on the 2016 Presidential Plenary Lecture presented by Dr. Larry E. Davis at the 20th Annual Conference of the Society for Social Work and Research in Washington, DC. The annual Presidential Plenary Lecture highlights distinguished scholars and leaders whose work has impacted public policy, research methods, or social work practice.

Suicide Attempt Status and Quality of Life Disparity Among Individuals with Schizophrenia: A Longitudinal Analysis

Author: Fulginiti, Anthony; Brekke, John S

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research, suppl. SPECIAL ISSUE ON THE ETIOLOGY AND TREATMENT OF SEVERE .. ; Chicago  Vol. 7, Iss. 2,  (Summer 2016): 269.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837845?accountid=14667

Abstract: Survivors of a suicide attempt are at greater risk for future suicide than those who have no history of such attempts (ie, non-attempters), particularly in the context of schizophrenia. This study examined 2 types of QoL differences between attempt survivors and non-attempters over a 3-year period: (a) differences in levels of QoL (ie, chronic disparity), and (b) differences in QoL change (i.e., change disparity). In a sample of 166 adults with schizophrenia entering community-based psychosocial rehabilitation, 2-level hierarchical linear models were used to compare attempt survivors and non-attempters on objective and subjective QoL domains over 7 waves. Finding chronic and change disparities between attempt survivors and non-attempters suggests that QoL disparity could reflect a distinct clinical profile for attempt survivors over time, that service delivery efforts should account for attempt status to address enduring and emerging QoL gaps, and that suicide attempt status deserves more attention in schizophrenia research.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Suicide+Attempt+Status+and+Quality+of+Life+Disparity+Among+Individuals+with+Schizophrenia%3A+A+Longitudinal+Analysis&amp;rft.au=Fulginiti%2C+Anthony%3BBrekke%2C+John+S&amp;rft.aulast=Fulginiti&amp;rft.aufirst=Anthony&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=269&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Living a Meaningful Life With Serious Mental Illness: Defining and Understanding Personal Medicine

Author: Radohl, Tamara

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research, suppl. SPECIAL ISSUE ON THE ETIOLOGY AND TREATMENT OF SEVERE .. ; Chicago  Vol. 7, Iss. 2,  (Summer 2016): 345.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837939?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objective: Shared decision making (SDM) is an approach adapted from the health care field for use in mental health treatment because SDM promotes collaborative decision making of providers and consumers regarding treatment options and goals. Personal medicine, defined as “self-initiated, non-pharmaceutical self-care activities that serve to decrease symptoms, avoid undesirable outcomes such as hospitalization, and improve mood, thoughts, behaviors, and overall sense of well-being” (Deegan, 2005, p. 31), has been incorporated into SDM when applied in mental health settings. This exploratory, qualitative study investigates how mental health consumers define and use personal medicine. Method: A sample of 14 consumers with severe and persistent mental illness were selected from a local community mental health agency using purposeful sampling. Participants used Common Ground, a software program that formalizes SDM and uses the concept of personal medicine. Participants were interviewed using a naturalistic inquiry approach and a semi-structured interview protocol of open-ended questions. Interviews were transcribed and coded, and findings were corroborated with consultant panels. Comprehensive member checks ensured trustworthiness. Results: Personal medicine might be a larger concept than can be explained by any single modality. Several factors contribute to the use of personal medicine, including the individualization of personal medicine by consumers, how consumers define the concept of personal medicine, and the purposes and benefits of personal medicine. Conclusions: Participants report personal medicine to have benefit, value, and purpose that impact recovery. These findings support current literature and practical implications that might inform the ways in which professionals use personal medicine.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Living+a+Meaningful+Life+With+Serious+Mental+Illness%3A+Defining+and+Understanding+Personal+Medicine&amp;rft.au=Radohl%2C+Tamara&amp;rft.aulast=Radohl&amp;rft.aufirst=Tamara&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=345&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Living+a+Meaningful+Life+With+Serious+Mental+Illness%3A+Defining+and+Understanding+Personal+Medicine&amp;rft.au=Radohl%2C+Tamara&amp;rft.aulast=Radohl&amp;rft.aufirst=Tamara&amp;rft.date=2016-07-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=345&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/
