Preventive Health Services Utilization Among Korean Americans

Author: Kim, Kyeongmo1; Casado, Banghwa Lee21 School of Social Work, University of Maryland, Baltimore, Maryland, USA2 School of Social Work, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, Colorado, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 5,  (Aug/Sep 2016): 431-438.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1800756152?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examined the use of preventive health services among Korean American adults. Data were drawn from a cross-sectional survey of 212 Korean Americans in the Chicago, Illinois, metropolitan area. Guided by the Andersen&apos;s behavioral model, the authors examined whether predisposing (age, gender, marital status, household size, education), enabling (income, health insurance, English proficiency, citizenship, social network), and need (health status) factors are predictive of Korean Americans&apos; preventive health services utilization. A binomial logistic regression showed that younger age, male, noncitizen, low income, no insurance, a larger family network, and better perceived health were associated with decreased odds of using preventive health services.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Preventive+Health+Services+Utilization+Among+Korean+Americans&amp;rft.au=Kim%2C+Kyeongmo%3BCasado%2C+Banghwa+Lee&amp;rft.aulast=Kim&amp;rft.aufirst=Kyeongmo&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=431&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1137508

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Preventive+Health+Services+Utilization+Among+Korean+Americans&amp;rft.au=Kim%2C+Kyeongmo%3BCasado%2C+Banghwa+Lee&amp;rft.aulast=Kim&amp;rft.aufirst=Kyeongmo&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=431&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1137508

The Significance of Harm Reduction as a Social and Health Care Intervention for Injecting Drug Users: An Exploratory Study of a Needle Exchange Program in Fresno, California

Author: Clarke, Kris1; Harris, Debra1; Zweifler, John A2; Lasher, Marc2; Mortimer, Roger B2; Hughes, Susan21 Department of Social Work, California State University, Fresno, California, USA2 Department of Family & Community Medicine, University of California, San Francisco, Fresno Medical Education Program, Fresno, California, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 5,  (Aug/Sep 2016): 398-407.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1800756167?accountid=14667

Abstract: Infectious disease remains a significant social and health concern in the United States. Preventing more people from contracting HIV/AIDS or Hepatitis C (HCV), requires a complex understanding of the interconnection between the biomedical and social dimensions of infectious disease. Opiate addiction in the US has skyrocketed in recent years. Preventing more cases of HIV/AIDS and HCV will require dealing with the social determinants of health. Needle exchange programs (NEPs) are based on a harm reduction approach that seeks to minimize the risk of infection and damage to the user and community. This article presents an exploratory small-scale quantitative study of the injection drug using habits of a group of injection drug users (IDUs) at a needle exchange program in Fresno, California. Respondents reported significant decreases in high risk IDU behaviors, including sharing of needles and to a lesser extent re-using of needles. They also reported frequent use of clean paraphernalia. Greater collaboration between social and health outreach professionals at NEPs could provide important frontline assistance to people excluded from mainstream office-based services and enhance efforts to reduce HIV/AIDS or HCV infection.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=The+Significance+of+Harm+Reduction+as+a+Social+and+Health+Care+Intervention+for+Injecting+Drug+Users%3A+An+Exploratory+Study+of+a+Needle+Exchange+Program+in+Fresno%2C+California&amp;rft.au=Clarke%2C+Kris%3BHarris%2C+Debra%3BZweifler%2C+John+A%3BLasher%2C+Marc%3BMortimer%2C+Roger+B%3BHughes%2C+Susan&amp;rft.aulast=Clarke&amp;rft.aufirst=Kris&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=398&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1137522

Public Health Services for Foreign Workers in Malaysia

Author: Noh, Normah Awang1; Wahab, Haris Abd2; Bakar Ah, Siti Hajar Abu2; Islam, M Rezaul31 Faculty of Applied Social Sciences, University of Sultan Zainal Abidin, Kuala Terengganu, Malaysia2 Department of Social Administration & Justice, Faculty of Arts & Social Sciences, University of Malaya, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia3 Department of Social Administration & Justice, Faculty of Arts & Social Sciences, University of Malaya, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; Institute of Social Welfare & Research, University of Dhaka, Dhaka, Bangladesh

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 5,  (Aug/Sep 2016): 419-430.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1800756180?accountid=14667

Abstract: The objective of this study was to know the status of the foreign workers&apos; access to public health services in Malaysia based on their utilization pattern. The utilization pattern covered a number of areas, such as frequency of using health services, status of using health services, choice and types of health institutions, and cost of health treatment. The study was conducted on six government hospitals in the Klang Valley area in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Data were collected from 600 foreign patients working in the country, using an interview method with a structured questionnaire. The results showed that the foreign workers&apos; access to public health services was very low. The findings would be an important guideline to formulate an effective health service policy for the foreign workers in Malaysia.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Public+Health+Services+for+Foreign+Workers+in+Malaysia&amp;rft.au=Noh%2C+Normah+Awang%3BWahab%2C+Haris+Abd%3BBakar+Ah%2C+Siti+Hajar+Abu%3BIslam%2C+M+Rezaul&amp;rft.aulast=Noh&amp;rft.aufirst=Normah&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=419&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1125321

Parental Book Reading and Social-Emotional Outcomes for Head Start Children in Foster Care

Author: Lee, Kyunghee1; Lee, Jung-Sook21 School of Social Work, Michigan State University, East Lansing, Michigan, USA2 School of Social Work, University of New South Wales, Sydney, Australia

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 5,  (Aug/Sep 2016): 408-418.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1800756185?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examines the associations between parental book reading and social-emotional outcomes for Head Start children in foster care. Despite no main Head Start impact on parental book reading, subgroup effects were found. Foster parents in Head Start provided more book reading for children with disabilities but less for children with low preacademic scores. Head Start enhanced social-emotional outcomes for children in foster care. The positive impacts of Head Start on children&apos;s social-emotional outcomes were greater when parents read books frequently. Head Start should include more foster families and provided parenting skills to enhance social-emotional outcomes for children in foster care.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Parental+Book+Reading+and+Social-Emotional+Outcomes+for+Head+Start+Children+in+Foster+Care&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Kyunghee%3BLee%2C+Jung-Sook&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Kyunghee&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=408&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1137523

Gender and Women Development Initiatives in Bangladesh: A Study of Rural Mother Center

Author: Karim, K M Rabiul1; Emmelin, Maria2; Lindberg, Line3; Wamala, Sarah41 Department of Public Health Sciences, Karolinska Institute, Stockholm, Sweden; Department of Social Work, University of Rajshahi, Bangladesh2 Division of Social Medicine and Global Health, Department of Clinical Sciences, Lund University, Lund, Sweden3 Department of Public Health Sciences, Karolinska Institute, Stockholm, Sweden4 Department of Public Health Sciences, Karolinska Institute, Stockholm, Sweden; Health Systems & Leadership Development, Center for Health Care Innovation, Stockholm, Sweden; Swedish National Institute of Public Health, Östersund, Sweden

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 5,  (Aug/Sep 2016): 369-386.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1800756220?accountid=14667

Abstract: Women-focused development initiatives have become a controversial issue connected with women&apos;s health and welfare. Previous studies indicated that development initiatives might increase women&apos;s workload, family conflict, and marital violence. This study explored the gendered characteristics of a development initiative Rural Mother Center in Bangladesh. Data incorporated policy document and interviews of social workers working with the mother centers in two northwest subdistricts. The qualitative content analysis of data emerged a general theme of expanding women&apos;s responsibility while maintaining male privilege explaining gendered design and practice of the development initiative. The theme was supported by two gendered categories related to the design: (a) essentializing women&apos;s participation; (b) maintaining traditional gender, and four categories related to the practice; (c) inadequate gender knowledge and skills; (d) reinforcing traditional gender; (e) using women for improving office performance; and (f) upholding male privilege. The study suggests that though women-focused development initiatives need to be embraced with gender-redistributive policies, the social workers should be trained for attaining gender-transformative motivation and competencies.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Gender+and+Women+Development+Initiatives+in+Bangladesh%3A+A+Study+of+Rural+Mother+Center&amp;rft.au=Karim%2C+K+M+Rabiul%3BEmmelin%2C+Maria%3BLindberg%2C+Line%3BWamala%2C+Sarah&amp;rft.aulast=Karim&amp;rft.aufirst=K+M&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=369&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1137517

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Gender+and+Women+Development+Initiatives+in+Bangladesh%3A+A+Study+of+Rural+Mother+Center&amp;rft.au=Karim%2C+K+M+Rabiul%3BEmmelin%2C+Maria%3BLindberg%2C+Line%3BWamala%2C+Sarah&amp;rft.aulast=Karim&amp;rft.aufirst=K+M&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=369&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1137517

Truancy: It's Not About Skipping School

Author: Mallett, Christopher A11 Cleveland State University, Cleveland, OH, USA

Publication info: Child & Adolescent Social Work Journal : C & A ; New York  Vol. 33, Iss. 4,  (Aug 2016): 337-347.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1801840230?accountid=14667

Abstract: Truancy and related school attendance issues are serious problems nationwide, and are often the result of a punitive school-based paradigm that harms more students than the protocols help. While some school districts and juvenile courts have shifted toward a rehabilitative paradigm and approach truancy with preventive efforts, unfortunately, this is not the norm. This manuscript summarizes and reviews: (1) the prevalence of the problems within schools and juvenile courts; (2) truancy and delinquency&apos;s inter-related risk and protective factors for children and adolescents and the disproportionate impact on some students; and (3) the evidence of what schools and related stakeholders can do to improve student truancy/attendance problem outcomes. The analysis concludes with case examples from two states (Colorado and Ohio) that have taken dichotomous approaches to addressing truancy, and what child and adolescent social workers should do to fix the problems.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.atitle=Truancy%3A+It%27s+Not+About+Skipping+School&amp;rft.au=Mallett%2C+Christopher+A&amp;rft.aulast=Mallett&amp;rft.aufirst=Christopher&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=337&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.issn=07380151&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10560-015-0433-1

Resilience and Deviant Behavior Among Institutionalized Adolescents: The Relationship with Significant Adults

Author: Mota, Catarina Pinheiro1; Costa, Mónica2; Matos, Paula Mena31 Department of Education and Psychology, University of Trás-os-Montes and Alto Douro (UTAD), Vila Real, Portugal; Center for Psychology, University of Porto, Porto, Portugal2 Faculty of Psychology and Education, University of Porto, Porto, Portugal3 Center for Psychology, University of Porto, Porto, Portugal; Faculty of Psychology and Education, University of Porto, Porto, Portugal

Publication info: Child & Adolescent Social Work Journal : C & A ; New York  Vol. 33, Iss. 4,  (Aug 2016): 313-325.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1801840242?accountid=14667

Abstract: The transition to institutional care often implies the separation from a dysfunctional environment, marked by neglect, abandonment and lack of emotional responsiveness, which makes youth more vulnerable to the development of deviant behavior. The quality of the relationship established with significant figures within the institution as well as with teachers is suggested as a protective factor for the development of resilience and the detachment from deviant behaviour. The present study aims to test the predictive effect of the quality of relationship to institutional caregivers and teachers on the development of resilience and deviant behaviour in institutionalized adolescents. We also intend to test the mediating effect of resilience in the previous association. The sample was composed by 202 institutionalized adolescents, 12-18 aged (M = 14.96, SD = 1.80), and from both genders. Data were collected using self-report questionnaires. The results demonstrated that the quality of relationship with significant figures was positively associated with resilience and may play an important role in preventing deviant behaviour. There was also a total mediation effect of resilience on the association between quality of relationship with significant figures and development of deviant behaviour. The results suggest that the affective reorganization of institutionalized adolescents can be promoted by the establishment of safe havens, which reflect feelings of belonging and acceptance, facilitating a more adaptive experience.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.atitle=Resilience+and+Deviant+Behavior+Among+Institutionalized+Adolescents%3A+The+Relationship+with+Significant+Adults&amp;rft.au=Mota%2C+Catarina+Pinheiro%3BCosta%2C+M%C3%B3nica%3BMatos%2C+Paula+Mena&amp;rft.aulast=Mota&amp;rft.aufirst=Catarina&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=313&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.issn=07380151&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10560-015-0429-x

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.atitle=Resilience+and+Deviant+Behavior+Among+Institutionalized+Adolescents%3A+The+Relationship+with+Significant+Adults&amp;rft.au=Mota%2C+Catarina+Pinheiro%3BCosta%2C+M%C3%B3nica%3BMatos%2C+Paula+Mena&amp;rft.aulast=Mota&amp;rft.aufirst=Catarina&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=313&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.issn=07380151&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10560-015-0429-x

Subject: Caregivers; Teachers; Prediction; Youth; Vulnerability; Adolescents; Disengagement; Resilience; Residential care; Responsiveness; Dysfunctional; Deviant behaviour; Reorganization; Abandonment; Mediation; Belongingness; Institutionalized; Social development; Carers; Selfreport; Questionnaires; Emotional responsiveness; Deviant behavior; Quality of health care

Classification: 6143: child & family welfare

Identifier / keyword: Institutionalization Resilience Deviant behaviour Significant figures

Title: Resilience and Deviant Behavior Among Institutionalized Adolescents: The Relationship with Significant Adults

Publication title: Child & Adolescent Social Work Journal : C & A; New York

Volume: 33

Issue: 4

Transition from Foster Care to Independent Living: Ecological Predictors Associated with Outcomes

Author: Scannapieco, Maria1; Smith, Marcella1; Blakeney-strong, Amy11 School of Social Work, University of Texas at Arlington, Arlington, TX, USA

Publication info: Child & Adolescent Social Work Journal : C & A ; New York  Vol. 33, Iss. 4,  (Aug 2016): 293-302.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1801840264?accountid=14667

Abstract: Nationally, the outcomes for youth aging out of foster care are dismal. Most children leaving foster care do not have the financial, medical, or social support tools necessary to bridge this transition successfully, placing a significant burden on youth leaving care (Courtney, Piliavin, Grogan, & Nesmith in Child Welfare 80:685-717, 2001 ; Kools & Kennedy in Pediatric Nursing 29(1):39-45, 2003 ; Simms, Dubowitz, & Szilagyi in Pediatrics 106:909-918, 2000 ). Given the poor outcomes for youth aging out of foster care, and the small body of literature on what works to improve outcomes, the purpose of this study was twofold. First to examine youth characteristics associated with better outcomes, and secondly to explore what program characteristics were correlated with outcomes. A causal comparative research design was used, employing pre-existing data. Records were collected from an agency in a large urban/suburban area in the State of Texas. Data was collected from both the Transition Resource Action Center (TRAC) and Children's Protective Services databases. To determine outcomes, both TRAC's Self-Sufficiency Matrix and case records were used. TRAC's Self-Sufficiency Matrix has five domains: Education, Employment, Employability, Financial Literacy, and Shelter. t tests were used to examine differences in outcomes between youth who received TRAC services before and after leaving care. t tests were also used to examine changes in overall Self-Sufficiency Matrix scores. Furthermore, linear and stepwise regressions were conducted to determine which variables were predictive of scores on the Self-Sufficiency Matrix. The results of this study indicate that TRAC is having a positive influence on the youth receiving services. Youth show significant improvement across four of the five identified domains and maintained on the fifth domain, employment. Implications for research practice and policy are presented.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.atitle=Transition+from+Foster+Care+to+Independent+Living%3A+Ecological+Predictors+Associated+with+Outcomes&amp;rft.au=Scannapieco%2C+Maria%3BSmith%2C+Marcella%3BBlakeney-strong%2C+Amy&amp;rft.aulast=Scannapieco&amp;rft.aufirst=Maria&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=293&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.issn=07380151&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10560-015-0426-0

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.atitle=Transition+from+Foster+Care+to+Independent+Living%3A+Ecological+Predictors+Associated+with+Outcomes&amp;rft.au=Scannapieco%2C+Maria%3BSmith%2C+Marcella%3BBlakeney-strong%2C+Amy&amp;rft.aulast=Scannapieco&amp;rft.aufirst=Maria&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=293&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.issn=07380151&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10560-015-0426-0

The Role of Behavioral Theory in Model Development Research with Single Parent Families

Author: Briggs, Harold Eugene1; Cox, Wendell2; Sharkey, Caroline N3; Corley, Nicole1; Briggs, Adam Christopher4; Black, Michelle11 University of Georgia, School of Social Work, Athens, GA, USA2 Washington, DC, USA3 Advantage Behavioral Health Systems, Inc., Athens, GA, USA4 HB Associates, Portland, Oregon, USA

Publication info: Child & Adolescent Social Work Journal : C & A ; New York  Vol. 33, Iss. 4,  (Aug 2016): 349-363.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1801840270?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this paper, the authors critically examine the plight of single parent families with young children. Next, they lay out in detail the contributions of the behavioral perspective to practice model development research with single-parent families of children under the age of 12. The authors discuss implications for future theory driven practice model development research with cultural specific single parent families. They believe that future model development research efforts with culturally diverse single parent families will aid in advancing the state of cultural competence research in social work while assisting single parents relieve suffering and enhance child and family well-being.

Theoretical Explanations for Bullying in School: How Ecological Processes Propagate Perpetration and Victimization

Author: Evans, Caroline B; R1; Smokowski, Paul R21 School of Social Work, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC, USA2 School of Social Welfare, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, USA

Publication info: Child & Adolescent Social Work Journal : C & A ; New York  Vol. 33, Iss. 4,  (Aug 2016): 365-375.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1801840297?accountid=14667

Abstract: Bullying is a complex social dynamic that can best be understood by using various theoretical frameworks. The current article uses social capital theory, dominance theory, the theory of humiliation, and organizational culture theory to better understand the motivations behind bullying behavior, bullying&apos;s negative effects on victims, and how school culture and climate play a role in the prevalence of bullying. Specifically, the acquisition and maintenance of social capital and the desire for dominance are prime motivating factors for the initiation and continuation of bullying perpetration. The lack of social capital experienced by victims serves to maintain victims in their current role and prevents them from gaining social status. Further, the domination used by bullies to subjugate victims results in intense humiliation that has lasting negative effects on victims, such as anger and depression. The overall culture and climate of the school setting impacts the prevalence and severity of bullying behavior, highlighting the need for whole school bullying interventions. Implications for social work practice are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.atitle=Theoretical+Explanations+for+Bullying+in+School%3A+How+Ecological+Processes+Propagate+Perpetration+and+Victimization&amp;rft.au=Evans%2C+Caroline+B%3B+R%3BSmokowski%2C+Paul+R&amp;rft.aulast=Evans&amp;rft.aufirst=Caroline+B%3B&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=365&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.issn=07380151&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10560-015-0432-2

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.atitle=Theoretical+Explanations+for+Bullying+in+School%3A+How+Ecological+Processes+Propagate+Perpetration+and+Victimization&amp;rft.au=Evans%2C+Caroline+B%3B+R%3BSmokowski%2C+Paul+R&amp;rft.aulast=Evans&amp;rft.aufirst=Caroline+B%3B&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=365&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.issn=07380151&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10560-015-0432-2

A Trauma-Informed Model for Empowerment Programs Targeting Vulnerable Youth

Author: Bulanda, Jeffrey1; Byro Johnson, Trisha21 Northeastern Illinois University, Chicago, IL, USA2 School District 54, Schaumburg, IL, USA

Publication info: Child & Adolescent Social Work Journal : C & A ; New York  Vol. 33, Iss. 4,  (Aug 2016): 303-312.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1801840308?accountid=14667

Abstract: Youth-led program development, organizing, research, and health promotion have been identified as an important practices for community practitioners. Since such practices target vulnerable youth, it is critical that such empowerment programs are trauma-informed. This paper addresses trauma, its potential impacts, and cultural differences in understanding trauma as well as the assumptions of empowerment and youth-led programming. The relationship between health and empowerment is described as well as how youth empowerment programs can specifically target symptoms of powerlessness, low self-esteem and interpersonal difficulties, commonly experienced by youth living in socially toxic environments. Implications for program development, research, and policy are considered.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.atitle=A+Trauma-Informed+Model+for+Empowerment+Programs+Targeting+Vulnerable+Youth&amp;rft.au=Bulanda%2C+Jeffrey%3BByro+Johnson%2C+Trisha&amp;rft.aulast=Bulanda&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeffrey&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=303&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal+%3A+C+%26+A&amp;rft.issn=07380151&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10560-015-0427-z

Advance care planning in South Korea: Social work perspective

Author: Kwon, Sung Ae1; Kolomer, Stacey21 School of Social Work, University of Georgia, Athens, Georgia, USA2 School of Social Work, University of North Carolina - Wilmington, Wilmington, North Carolina, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 7,  (Aug 2016): 545-558.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1805276619?accountid=14667

Abstract: As ethical issues arise concerning the continuation of futile medical treatment for dying patients in Korean society, advance directive planning initiatives have been put into place to guide practice. This article describes the awareness and attitudes of social workers in Korea regarding advance care planning and related factors. A total of 246 gerontological/geriatric social workers completed a mailed or in-person survey regarding awareness and attitudes toward advance care planning. Seventy-three percent (n = 180) of the participants reported no knowledge of advance directives. Social workers who emphasized self-determination as a professional value, professed a preference for hospice care, and who were comfortable discussing death were more likely to have a positive attitudes toward advance care planning. This study reinforces the need for the infusion of advance care planning and end-of-life training in social work education in Korea.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Advance+care+planning+in+South+Korea%3A+Social+work+perspective&amp;rft.au=Kwon%2C+Sung+Ae%3BKolomer%2C+Stacey&amp;rft.aulast=Kwon&amp;rft.aufirst=Sung&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=545&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1186132

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Advance+care+planning+in+South+Korea%3A+Social+work+perspective&amp;rft.au=Kwon%2C+Sung+Ae%3BKolomer%2C+Stacey&amp;rft.aulast=Kwon&amp;rft.aufirst=Sung&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=545&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1186132

____________________________________________________________

Job satisfaction and turnover intent among hospital social workers in the United States

Author: Pugh, Greg L, MSW, PhD11 School of Social Work, Portland State University, Portland, Oregon, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 7,  (Aug 2016): 485-502.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1805276620?accountid=14667

Abstract: Feelings of job satisfaction and turnover intentions among social workers affect work quality for both social workers and the people for whom they provide services. Existing literature on job satisfaction among hospital social workers is limited, and is overly focused on issues of compensation. There is job satisfaction research with hospital nurses available for comparison. Other informative social work research on job satisfaction and turnover exists in mental health and generally, across settings. Research on turnover intent in social work is primarily from child welfare settings and may not generalize. The literature notes gaps and contradictions about predictors of job satisfaction and turnover intent. Using a large national dataset of hospital social workers, this research clarifies and fills gaps regarding hospital social workers, and explores how Herzberg&apos;s theory of work can clarify the difference between sources of job dissatisfaction and job satisfaction. Findings include hospital social workers reporting high job satisfaction and that demographics do not contribute to the predictive models. The findings do support centralized social work departments and variety in the job functions of hospital social workers, and are consistent with the theoretical framework.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Job+satisfaction+and+turnover+intent+among+hospital+social+workers+in+the+United+States&amp;rft.au=Pugh%2C+Greg+L%2C+MSW%2C+PhD&amp;rft.aulast=Pugh&amp;rft.aufirst=Greg&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=485&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1186133

The experiences of emergency department use by street-involved youth: Perspectives of health care and community service providers

Author: Nicholas, David B, PhD, RSW1; Newton, Amanda S, PhD2; Kilmer, Christopher, BSW, RSW1; Calhoun, Avery, PhD, RSW1; deJong-Berg, Margaret A, PhD, RSW1; Dong, Kathryn, MD, MSc, FRCPC3; Hamilton, Faye, MSW, RSW4; McLaughlin, Anne Marie, PhD, RSW1; Shankar, Janki, PhD, RSW1; Smyth, Peter, MSW, RSW51 Faculty of Social Work, University of Calgary, Central and Northern Alberta Region, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada2 Department of Pediatrics, Faculty of Medicine & Dentistry, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada3 Department of Emergency Medicine, Faculty of Medicine & Dentistry, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada4 School of Social Work, MacEwan University, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada5 Alberta Human Services, Government of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 7,  (Aug 2016): 531-544.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1805276713?accountid=14667

Abstract: Street-involved (SI) youth represent a significant proportion of urban homeless populations. While previous research has identified SI youth as substantial users of emergency department (ED) services and has examined their experiences of ED care, little is known about the experiences and perceptions of the service providers who assist these youth with health care related issues. Using grounded theory, individual interviews and focus groups were conducted with 20 community agency staff serving SI youth, 17 health service providers, two hospital administrators, and two hospital security personnel regarding their experiences in providing or facilitating ED care for SI youth. Results identify differences in expectations between SI youth and hospital staff, along with service issues and gaps, including relational barriers and resource constraints. Implications for practice and policy development are offered.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=The+experiences+of+emergency+department+use+by+street-involved+youth%3A+Perspectives+of+health+care+and+community+service+providers&amp;rft.au=Nicholas%2C+David+B%2C+PhD%2C+RSW%3BNewton%2C+Amanda+S%2C+PhD%3BKilmer%2C+Christopher%2C+BSW%2C+RSW%3BCalhoun%2C+Avery%2C+PhD%2C+RSW%3BdeJong-Berg%2C+Margaret+A%2C+PhD%2C+RSW%3BDong%2C+Kathryn%2C+MD%2C+MSc%2C+FRCPC%3BHamilton%2C+Faye%2C+MSW%2C+RSW%3BMcLaughlin%2C+Anne+Marie%2C+PhD%2C+RSW%3BShankar%2C+Janki%2C+PhD%2C+RSW%3BSmyth%2C+Peter%2C+MSW%2C+RSW&amp;rft.aulast=Nicholas&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=531&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1183553

Associations of multiplicity of comorbid health conditions, serious mental illness, and health care costs

Author: Lee, Sungkyu, PhD1; Black, Denise, LCSW2; Held, Mary, PhD, LCSW21 School of Social Welfare, Soongsil University, Seoul, South Korea2 College of Social Work, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, Tennessee, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 7,  (Aug 2016): 518-530.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1805276716?accountid=14667

Abstract: Using a nationally representative U.S. sample, this study analyzed the effects of serious mental illness (SMI) and comorbid medical conditions on the cost of health care. The results of path model indicated that SMI and comorbid health conditions each increased total health care costs. Additionally, individuals with SMI were likely to have more comorbid medical conditions, which in turn, increased total health care costs. Findings raise awareness of an increased risk of medical conditions among individuals with SMI and the concern of high expenditures associated with comorbid SMI and medical conditions.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Associations+of+multiplicity+of+comorbid+health+conditions%2C+serious+mental+illness%2C+and+health+care+costs&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Sungkyu%2C+PhD%3BBlack%2C+Denise%2C+LCSW%3BHeld%2C+Mary%2C+PhD%2C+LCSW&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Sungkyu&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=518&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1183551

The experience of gender dysphoria for pre-pubescent children and their families: a review of the literature

Author: Gregor, Claire; Davidson, Sarah; Hingley-Jones, Helen

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 3,  (Aug 2016): 339-346.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1805448590?accountid=14667

Abstract: In recent years, the experience of gender dysphoria has gained public prominence through an explosion of sensationalized interest in the popular media. However, childhood gender dysphoria remains poorly understood and both parents and children often find themselves having to educate professionals around them. This not only creates a sense of disconnect between family and professionals, but also means that social workers can often be unaware of the myriad of competing perspectives that seek to explain gender variance. This review of the literature seeks to provide interested social workers with an overview of gender dysphoria, current research in the field and theoretical paradigms, with a view to promoting understanding and better practice with families in this little understood field.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+experience+of+gender+dysphoria+for+pre-pubescent+children+and+their+families%3A+a+review+of+the+literature&amp;rft.au=Gregor%2C+Claire%3BDavidson%2C+Sarah%3BHingley-Jones%2C+Helen&amp;rft.aulast=Gregor&amp;rft.aufirst=Claire&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=339&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12150

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+experience+of+gender+dysphoria+for+pre-pubescent+children+and+their+families%3A+a+review+of+the+literature&amp;rft.au=Gregor%2C+Claire%3BDavidson%2C+Sarah%3BHingley-Jones%2C+Helen&amp;rft.aulast=Gregor&amp;rft.aufirst=Claire&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=339&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12150

____________________________________________________________

Child welfare inequalities: new evidence, further questions

Author: Bywaters, Paul; Brady, Geraldine; Sparks, Tim; Bos, Elizabeth

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 3,  (Aug 2016): 369-380.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1805448622?accountid=14667

Abstract: Research internationally has identified large differences in rates of child safeguarding interventions, recently characterized as child welfare inequalities, markers of social inequalities in childhood with parallels to inequalities in health and education. This paper reports a Nuffield Foundation-funded study to examine the role of deprivation in explaining differences in key children's services interventions between and within local authorities (LAs). The study involved an analysis of descriptive data on over 10% of children on child protection plans or in out-of-home care in 14 English LAs at 31 March 2012. The data demonstrate very large inequalities in rates of child welfare interventions within and between LAs, systematically related to levels of deprivation. There is evidence of a gradient in child welfare inequalities across the whole of society. There also appears to be an equivalent of the inverse care law for health: For any given level of deprivation in local neighbourhoods, LAs with lower overall levels of deprivation were intervening more often. The findings raise fundamental questions for research, policy and practice including whether the allocation of children's service resources sufficiently recognize the impact of deprivation on demand and how we judge whether a safeguarding system is effective at the population level.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Child+welfare+inequalities%3A+new+evidence%2C+further+questions&amp;rft.au=Bywaters%2C+Paul%3BBrady%2C+Geraldine%3BSparks%2C+Tim%3BBos%2C+Elizabeth&amp;rft.aulast=Bywaters&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=369&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12154

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Child+welfare+inequalities%3A+new+evidence%2C+further+questions&amp;rft.au=Bywaters%2C+Paul%3BBrady%2C+Geraldine%3BSparks%2C+Tim%3BBos%2C+Elizabeth&amp;rft.aulast=Bywaters&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=369&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12154

Matching children and substitute homes: some theoretical and empirical notions

Author: Poso, Tarja; Laakso, Riitta

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 3,  (Aug 2016): 307-316.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1805448750?accountid=14667

Abstract: Matching describes the process of selecting the substitute home for a child who needs to be placed away from the care of his/her birth parents. However, very little theorizing is done about matching and there is also a lack of systematic investigation into models of practice currently in use. Most importantly, very little is known about front-line matching practices in different socio-historical child welfare contexts. This paper aims to explore the concept of matching by addressing it theoretically and empirically as a decision-making practice in social work. Based on the analysis of phone interviews (49) and focus group interviews (five groups with 18 child welfare practitioners) in Finland, we claim that matching includes a high degree of navigation: decision-making balances between professional discretion, legal norms and principles, subjective views of the children and their parents as well as the economic and bureaucratic conditions of the service provision administration in the municipality. Navigation is shadowed by uncertainty and compromises. The analysis suggests that the notion of matching needs further analysis as it plays an important role in child welfare decision-making. The interplay between front-line practice and the socio-historical context needs to be further addressed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Matching+children+and+substitute+homes%3A+some+theoretical+and+empirical+notions&amp;rft.au=Poso%2C+Tarja%3BLaakso%2C+Riitta&amp;rft.aulast=Poso&amp;rft.aufirst=Tarja&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=307&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12144

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Matching+children+and+substitute+homes%3A+some+theoretical+and+empirical+notions&amp;rft.au=Poso%2C+Tarja%3BLaakso%2C+Riitta&amp;rft.aulast=Poso&amp;rft.aufirst=Tarja&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=307&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12144

____________________________________________________________

Collaborating with families in differential responses: practitioners' views

Author: Healy, Karen; Harrison, Gai; Venables, Jemma; Bosly, Fiona

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 3,  (Aug 2016): 328-338.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1805449422?accountid=14667

Abstract: Child protection authorities in many countries are concerned with reducing the rates of investigations and with diverting at-risk families from the child protection service system. In several countries, differential responses have been introduced into child protection law providing service providers with some choice between investigative or family support pathways, depending upon the level of risk posed in the circumstance. In this paper, we report on a study into a form of differential response known as Intervention with Parents' Agreement introduced in Queensland, Australia, in 2005. A unique feature of this differential response is that it occurs after an initial child protection investigation, although it does provide child protection services with options for providing supportive interventions to at-risk families to prevent the further escalation of concerns. In this paper, we analyse practitioners' perceptions of factors that inhibit and promote implementation of the Intervention with Parents' Agreement. Drawing upon interviews with 25 practitioners, we identify factors that become important for securing participation after an initial investigation has occurred. We discuss the implications for the development of differential responses in child protection service systems.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Collaborating+with+families+in+differential+responses%3A+practitioners%27+views&amp;rft.au=Healy%2C+Karen%3BHarrison%2C+Gai%3BVenables%2C+Jemma%3BBosly%2C+Fiona&amp;rft.aulast=Healy&amp;rft.aufirst=Karen&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=328&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12149

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Collaborating+with+families+in+differential+responses%3A+practitioners%27+views&amp;rft.au=Healy%2C+Karen%3BHarrison%2C+Gai%3BVenables%2C+Jemma%3BBosly%2C+Fiona&amp;rft.aulast=Healy&amp;rft.aufirst=Karen&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=328&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12149

Outcomes of the ON FIRE peer support programme for children and adolescents in families with mental health problems

Author: Foster, Kim1; McPhee, Ingrid1; Fethney, Judith1; McCloughen, Andrea11 Sydney Nursing School, The University of Sydney, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 3,  (Aug 2016): 295-306.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1805463637?accountid=14667

Abstract: Children in families with mental health problems may encounter multiple risks to their well-being. General aims of peer support programmes for these children include fostering resilience and effective coping strategies, and enhancing self-esteem and social skills. This study aimed to evaluate outcomes from a pilot multi-site implementation of the ON FIRE peer support programme. The purpose of ON FIRE is to cultivate hope, resilience and well-being in children and adolescents aged 8-17 years living in families affected by sibling or parental mental health problems. We employed a pre-post test (baseline and 4 months) evaluation using a suite of outcome measures. The Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ), Children&apos;s Hope Scale, Kids Connections Scale and Positive and Negative Affect Scale for Children (PANAS-C) were completed for 64 child/adolescent participants. At baseline, participants had significantly greater difficulties compared with Australian norms. At 4 months, there were significant differences in children&apos;s hope and in connections outside the family. There were no significant differences in the SDQ or the PANAS-C.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Outcomes+of+the+ON+FIRE+peer+support+programme+for+children+and+adolescents+in+families+with+mental+health+problems&amp;rft.au=Foster%2C+Kim%3BMcPhee%2C+Ingrid%3BFethney%2C+Judith%3BMcCloughen%2C+Andrea&amp;rft.aulast=Foster&amp;rft.aufirst=Kim&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=295&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12143

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Outcomes+of+the+ON+FIRE+peer+support+programme+for+children+and+adolescents+in+families+with+mental+health+problems&amp;rft.au=Foster%2C+Kim%3BMcPhee%2C+Ingrid%3BFethney%2C+Judith%3BMcCloughen%2C+Andrea&amp;rft.aulast=Foster&amp;rft.aufirst=Kim&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=295&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12143

Are foster children's schools of origin always best? School quality in birth vs. foster parent neighbourhoods

Author: Fries, Lauren1; Klein, Sacha1; Ballantyne, Molly21 School of Social Work, Michigan State University, East Lansing, USA2 Eaton Regional Service Academy, Charlotte, MI, USA

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 3,  (Aug 2016): 317-327.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1805465163?accountid=14667

Abstract: Research has documented that foster children have high rates of school mobility, and it is widely believed that this contributes to their poor educational outcomes. Recent US policies address this by attempting to minimize schools transfers for foster children; however, these policies have largely ignored the issue of school quality. The current study uses descriptive statistics and mixed factor analysis of variance to assess (i) the quality of schools attended by elementary-aged US foster children living in a large, urban school district (n = 683); (ii) their rates of school mobility; and (iii) differences between the quality of schools located in their birth parent vs. foster placement neighbourhoods. Results indicate that these foster children were attending poor performing schools and had high rates of school transfers. For the sample as a whole and specifically for African-Americans and Hispanics, schools located in placement neighbourhoods were higher performing than schools in birth parent neighbourhoods. For white children, however, birth parent schools outperformed placement schools. These findings highlight the importance of considering school quality, not just continuity, when making educational decisions for children in out-of-home care.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Are+foster+children%27s+schools+of+origin+always+best%3F+School+quality+in+birth+vs.+foster+parent+neighbourhoods&amp;rft.au=Fries%2C+Lauren%3BKlein%2C+Sacha%3BBallantyne%2C+Molly&amp;rft.aulast=Fries&amp;rft.aufirst=Lauren&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=317&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12145

Parenting interventions in shelter settings: a qualitative systematic review of the literature

Author: Haskett, Mary E1; Loehman, Jessica1; Burkhart, Kimberly21 North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC, USA2 Nationwide Children's Hospital, Columbus, OH, USA

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 3,  (Aug 2016): 272-282.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1805465196?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aim of this literature review was to critique the state of the research on the effects of implementing parenting programmes in shelters for homeless families. A comprehensive search of multiple databases yielded 12 studies for inclusion. The methodological sophistication of the studies varied, with most investigations based on very small samples and one-group pre-post designs. Results indicated that parents generally viewed the interventions as enjoyable and informative, and attendance was good. Incentives were often used to encourage attendance. Evidence was limited in terms of effectiveness of the interventions, but the few studies of evidence-based parenting programmes showed changes in parenting and child functioning. Suggestions are provided for future investigations in this important yet challenging field of study.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Parenting+interventions+in+shelter+settings%3A+a+qualitative+systematic+review+of+the+literature&amp;rft.au=Haskett%2C+Mary+E%3BLoehman%2C+Jessica%3BBurkhart%2C+Kimberly&amp;rft.aulast=Haskett&amp;rft.aufirst=Mary&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=272&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12147

Assessing parenting capacity in child protection: towards a knowledge-based model

Author: Houston, Stan11 School of Sociology, Social Policy and Social Work, Queen's University Belfast, Belfast, UK

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 3,  (Aug 2016): 347-357.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1805467274?accountid=14667

Abstract: The assessment of parenting capacity continues to engender public concern in cases of suspected harm to children. This paper outlines a model for approaching this task based on the application of three key domains of knowledge in social work relating to facts, theory and practice wisdom. The McMaster Model of Family Assessment is identified out of this process and reworked to give it a sharper focus on parenting roles and responsibilities. Seven formative dimensions of parenting are then elicited and combined with an analytical process of identifying strengths, concerns, prospects for growth and impact on child outcomes. The resulting assessment framework, it is argued, adds rigour to professional judgements about parenting capacity and enhances formulations on risk in child protection.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Assessing+parenting+capacity+in+child+protection%3A+towards+a+knowledge-based+model&amp;rft.au=Houston%2C+Stan&amp;rft.aulast=Houston&amp;rft.aufirst=Stan&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=347&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12151

Formal and Informal Neighborhood Social Organization: Which Promotes Better Resident Health?

Author: Gilster, Megan E; Meier, Cristian L

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 41, Iss. 3,  (Aug 2016): 182.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1810087674?accountid=14667

Abstract: Neighborhood social organization captures how neighborhood residents differently organize to exert social control and enact their vision of their community. Whereas structural aspects of neighborhoods have been found to predict the health of neighborhood residents, we know less about whether neighborhood social characteristics, like social organization, matter for resident health. In their study, authors tested whether two types of social organization -- formal and informal -- were more predictive of resident self-rated health in a diverse sample of Chicago residents. They used multilevel models with survey weights, ordered dependent variables, and multiple imputation. They found that one measure of formal social organization, organizational participation, was significantly associated with self-rated health even when controlling for other types of social organization and individual participation. The article concludes with a discussion of the implications for macro social work practice to address social determinants of health and improve community health. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/41/3/182.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Formal+and+Informal+Neighborhood+Social+Organization%3A+Which+Promotes+Better+Resident+Health%3F&amp;rft.au=Gilster%2C+Megan+E%3BMeier%2C+Cristian+L&amp;rft.aulast=Gilster&amp;rft.aufirst=Megan&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=182&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Formal+and+Informal+Neighborhood+Social+Organization%3A+Which+Promotes+Better+Resident+Health%3F&amp;rft.au=Gilster%2C+Megan+E%3BMeier%2C+Cristian+L&amp;rft.aulast=Gilster&amp;rft.aufirst=Megan&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=182&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

The Subjective Experiences of Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder of Chinese Families in Hong Kong: Co-Construction of Meanings in Multiple Family Groups

Author: Wan, Erica S F; Ma, Joyce L C; Lai, Kelly Y C; Lo, Julia W K

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 41, Iss. 3,  (Aug 2016): 164.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1810087688?accountid=14667

Abstract: The subjective experiences of Chinese children in Hong Kong with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) are underexplored. This article reports the results of a qualitative study that aims to understand the subjective experiences of children with ADHD in Hong Kong, taken from among a clinical sample of Chinese families with children struggling with ADHD who have participated in cross-disciplinary research of multiple family groups (MFG). The participating children revealed the subjective experiences of their struggle with the disorder in response to their parents&apos; concern at a "press conference," one of the MFG activities, which underscored the importance of developing a new social work model to meet the multiple psychosocial service needs of these families. The article concludes with the discussion of the implications for the new model. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/41/3/164.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Subjective+Experiences+of+Attention-Deficit%2FHyperactivity+Disorder+of+Chinese+Families+in+Hong+Kong%3A+Co-Construction+of+Meanings+in+Multiple+Family+Groups&amp;rft.au=Wan%2C+Erica+S+F%3BMa%2C+Joyce+L+C%3BLai%2C+Kelly+Y+C%3BLo%2C+Julia+W+K&amp;rft.aulast=Wan&amp;rft.aufirst=Erica+S&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=164&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Meaning Reconstruction among Women following Stillbirth: A Loss Fraught with Ambiguity and Doubt

Author: Golan, Aiya; Leichtentritt, Ronit Dina

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 41, Iss. 3,  (Aug 2016): 147.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1810087699?accountid=14667

Abstract: Stillbirth (SB), death of a fetus in late stages of pregnancy or during birth, usually leads to extended and intense grief among women. However, their grief is often disenfranchised and they are denied the social right to mourn their loss. Constructivist theories recently assuming a central place in bereavement studies inform this article, which aims to identify the meaning that women who experience SB ascribe to their loss in general and to the lost figure. This tack may offer the opportunity to examine the consequences of the discrepancy between personal and environmental constructions of this loss on its personal construction and to learn about the essence of the loss. Within the domain of qualitative research, the current article draws on phenomenology and the research method that has emerged from this approach. Specifically, the article focuses on in-depth interviews with 10 women who experienced SB. Its findings suggest that for these women, the lost figure and the loss in general engender ambiguity both internally -- that is, within the psyche of women themselves -- and externally, within the women&apos;s social environment. Thus, ambiguity, uncertainty, and doubt infused women&apos;s experience of SB. Implications for theory and practice are discussed. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/41/3/147.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Meaning+Reconstruction+among+Women+following+Stillbirth%3A+A+Loss+Fraught+with+Ambiguity+and+Doubt&amp;rft.au=Golan%2C+Aiya%3BLeichtentritt%2C+Ronit+Dina&amp;rft.aulast=Golan&amp;rft.aufirst=Aiya&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=147&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Impact of Racial and Socioeconomic Disparities on Binge Eating and Self-Efficacy among Adults in a Behavioral Weight Loss Trial

Author: Goode, Rachel; Ye, Lei; Zheng, Yaguang; Ma, Qianheng; Sereika, Susan M; Burke, Lora E

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 41, Iss. 3,  (Aug 2016): E60.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1810087776?accountid=14667

Abstract: The prevalence of obesity is a significant problem among racial and ethnic minorities and those of low socioeconomic status (SES). Psychosocial barriers, such as binge eating and low self-efficacy, are known to hinder the adoption of a more healthful diet. There is limited research identifying racial and SES differences in binge eating and self-efficacy. Further investigations of these constructs may allow researchers to improve the effectiveness of weight management interventions and increase social worker involvement. In this article, the authors examine the socioeconomic and racial differences in binge eating and eating self-efficacy in a sample of individuals seeking weight loss treatment (N = 151). They explore associations between various sociodemographic variables and the Binge Eating Scale and Weight Efficacy Lifestyle Questionnaire (WEL). At baseline, nonwhite participants or those with fewer years of education exhibited more confidence resisting ating when food was available. Moreover, nonwhite participants reported more self-confidence eating under social pressure and had higher total WEL scores than white participants. However, at six months, nonwhite participants&apos; WEL scores decreased. White participants increased their total WEL scores and obtained a higher percent weight change by the end of the intervention. Additional investigations on the dynamics affecting the development of self-efficacy are warranted. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/41/3/e60.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Impact+of+Racial+and+Socioeconomic+Disparities+on+Binge+Eating+and+Self-Efficacy+among+Adults+in+a+Behavioral+Weight+Loss+Trial&amp;rft.au=Goode%2C+Rachel%3BYe%2C+Lei%3BZheng%2C+Yaguang%3BMa%2C+Qianheng%3BSereika%2C+Susan+M%3BBurke%2C+Lora+E&amp;rft.aulast=Goode&amp;rft.aufirst=Rachel&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=E60&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Impact+of+Racial+and+Socioeconomic+Disparities+on+Binge+Eating+and+Self-Efficacy+among+Adults+in+a+Behavioral+Weight+Loss+Trial&amp;rft.au=Goode%2C+Rachel%3BYe%2C+Lei%3BZheng%2C+Yaguang%3BMa%2C+Qianheng%3BSereika%2C+Susan+M%3BBurke%2C+Lora+E&amp;rft.aulast=Goode&amp;rft.aufirst=Rachel&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=E60&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Assessing the level of risk of families supported by Child and Family Protection Services: Practitioners and mothers as informants

Author: Álvarez-Dardet, Susana Menéndez1; García, M Victoria Hidalgo1; Lara, Bárbara Lorence1; Padilla, Javier Pérez11 University of Huelva, Spain; University of Seville, Spain; University of Huelva, Spain; University of Huelva, Spain

Publication info: Journal of Social Work ; London  Vol. 16, Iss. 5,  (Sep 2016): 595-609.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1809134941?accountid=14667

Abstract: Summary The evaluation of the specific level of family risk is a central topic to better understand the diversity of families assisted by Child and Family Protection Services, and also to design and address effective social interventions. Professionals of these services tend to have a great amount of knowledge and experience that has been rarely taken into account in research about at-risk families. In this study the level of family risk, according to data reported both by practitioners and mothers receiving family preservation intervention, is analyzed in a sample of 106 mothers assisted by state Child and Family Protection Services in Huelva, Spain. Findings A frequent profile of poor and multi-assisted families was found, but there was also an important level of heterogeneity in the level of risk, suggesting that these families are not a homogeneous group. The global valuation of family risk informed by professionals was significantly related to data reported by mothers using a standardized tool of family risk factors. Analyses presented also show significant relations with both the family socio-demographic profile and data of the case history involving protection services: higher levels of family risk were mainly associated with higher levels of economic, educational, and labor precariousness, and with more complex and complicated case indicators. Applications Implications of these results concerning both the importance of incorporating systematic evaluations of family risk by means standardized tools to practice and considering practitioners as a relevant source of information in family research are discussed.

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Assessing+the+level+of+risk+of+families+supported+by+Child+and+Family+Protection+Services%3A+Practitioners+and+mothers+as+informants&amp;rft.au=%C3%81lvarez-Dardet%2C+Susana+Men%C3%A9ndez%3BGarc%C3%ADa%2C+M+Victoria+Hidalgo%3BLara%2C+B%C3%A1rbara+Lorence%3BPadilla%2C+Javier+P%C3%A9rez&amp;rft.aulast=%C3%81lvarez-Dardet&amp;rft.aufirst=Susana&amp;rft.date=2016-09-01&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=595&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017315583174

Relocation, portability and social care practice: A scoping review

Author: White, Caroline1; Marsland, Dave1; Manthorpe, Jill11 Centre for Applied Research and Evaluation (CARE), University of Hull, England; Centre for Applied Research and Evaluation (CARE), University of Hull, England; Social Care Workforce Research Unit (SCWRU), King's College London, England

Publication info: Journal of Social Work ; London  Vol. 16, Iss. 5,  (Sep 2016): 521-540.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1809134942?accountid=14667

Abstract: Summary The portability of publicly-funded adult social care across local authority boundaries received recent policy attention in England and was addressed in the Care Act 2014. This article presents the findings of a scoping review conducted between July-September 2012 that searched selected journals and online databases for relevant material. The aim of the review was to identify what is known about the experiences of adults entitled to publicly-funded social care who move between local authorities, and the support provided by social workers to those planning to relocate. The review focused specifically on disabled adults and carers, eligible for and in receipt of social care support, who relocate for work or education in England. Findings The review identified little direct research covering experiences of moving between local authorities. However, six specific barriers, challenges and facilitators to relocation were identified; these included the portability of social care support, variations in policy and practice between local authorities, and housing availability. The review concludes that the process of relocation may be complex, challenging, and uncertain, although individuals may experience benefits and positive outcomes. Applications The review outlines areas for good social work practice in supporting people using social care services to relocate. These include: ensuring the provision of information; close working between local authorities and social workers; the development of interim plans to address potential delays in setting up support; proactive and rapid monitoring and reassessment following a move to address potentially changed support needs arising from changed housing circumstances.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Relocation%2C+portability+and+social+care+practice%3A+A+scoping+review&amp;rft.au=White%2C+Caroline%3BMarsland%2C+Dave%3BManthorpe%2C+Jill&amp;rft.aulast=White&amp;rft.aufirst=Caroline&amp;rft.date=2016-09-01&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=521&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017315581532
