Case Manager Perspectives on the Role of Treatment in Supportive Housing for People with Severe Mental Illness

Author: Stanhope, Victoria; Choy-Brown, Mimi; Tiderington, Emmy; Henwood, Benjamin F; Padgett, Deborah K

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 7, Iss. 3,  (Fall 2016): 507.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1819298228?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objective: Growing recognition exists of housing as a social determinant of health, and thus, health care reform initiatives are expanding the reach of health care beyond traditional settings. One result of this expansion is increased Medicaid funds for supportive-housing programs for people with severe mental illnesses. This qualitative study explores the ways in which case managers working in a supportive housing program approach treatment and how their approach is influenced by both program requirements and their beliefs about mental illness. Method: The study is part of a longitudinal qualitative study on recovery for people with severe mental illnesses living in supportive housing. Multiple interviews (n = 55) with 24 case managers from a residential-continuum supportive-housing program were conducted over 18 months. To provide an in-depth view of case manager perspectives, the study uses thematic analysis with multiple coders. Results: Overall, case managers understand supportive housing as being a treatment program but predominantly characterize treatment as medication management. The following themes emerged: believing medication to be the key to success in the program, persuading residents to take medication, and questioning the utility of the program for residents who were not medication adherent. Conclusions: Case managers understand supportive housing to be a treatment program; however, given the external constraints and their own beliefs about mental illness, case managers often equate treatment with taking medication. Study findings demonstrate the need to train case managers about mental health recovery and integrated health care. The findings also have implications for policies that tie housing to services.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Case+Manager+Perspectives+on+the+Role+of+Treatment+in+Supportive+Housing+for+People+with+Severe+Mental+Illness&amp;rft.au=Stanhope%2C+Victoria%3BChoy-Brown%2C+Mimi%3BTiderington%2C+Emmy%3BHenwood%2C+Benjamin+F%3BPadgett%2C+Deborah+K&amp;rft.aulast=Stanhope&amp;rft.aufirst=Victoria&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=507&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Case+Manager+Perspectives+on+the+Role+of+Treatment+in+Supportive+Housing+for+People+with+Severe+Mental+Illness&amp;rft.au=Stanhope%2C+Victoria%3BChoy-Brown%2C+Mimi%3BTiderington%2C+Emmy%3BHenwood%2C+Benjamin+F%3BPadgett%2C+Deborah+K&amp;rft.aulast=Stanhope&amp;rft.aufirst=Victoria&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=507&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Workers' Orientation Toward the Evidence-Based Practice Process

Author: van der Zwet, Renske J M; Kolmer, Deirdre M Beneken genaamd; Schalk, René

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 26, Iss. 6,  (Oct 2016): 712-722.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1819497889?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objectives: This study assesses social workers' orientation toward the evidence-based practice (EBP) process and explores which specific variables (e.g. age) are associated. Methods: Data were collected from 341 Dutch social workers through an online survey which included a Dutch translation of the EBP Process Assessment Scale (EBPPAS), along with 13 background/demographic questions. Results: The overall level of orientation toward the EBP process is relatively low. Although respondents are slightly familiar with it and have slightly positive attitudes about it, their intentions to engage in it and their actual engagement are relatively low. Respondents who followed a course on the EBP process as a student are more oriented toward it than those who did not. Social workers under 29 are more familiar with the EBP process than those over 29. Conclusions: We recommend educators to take a more active role in teaching the EBP process to students and social workers.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Workers%27+Orientation+Toward+the+Evidence-Based+Practice+Process%3A+A+Dutch+Survey&amp;rft.au=van+der+Zwet%2C+Renske+J+M%3BKolmer%2C+Deirdre+M+Beneken+genaamd%3BSchalk%2C+Ren%C3%A9&amp;rft.aulast=van+der+Zwet&amp;rft.aufirst=Renske+J&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=712&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514540340

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Workers%27+Orientation+Toward+the+Evidence-Based+Practice+Process%3A+A+Dutch+Survey&amp;rft.au=van+der+Zwet%2C+Renske+J+M%3BKolmer%2C+Deirdre+M+Beneken+genaamd%3BSchalk%2C+Ren%C3%A9&amp;rft.aulast=van+der+Zwet&amp;rft.aufirst=Renske+J&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=712&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514540340

Evaluation of a family camp intervention for children with a heart transplant and their families

Author: Nicholas, David B1; Dodd, Bernadette2; Urschel, Simon3; Young, Amber1; West, Lori J31 Faculty of Social Work, University of Calgary, Central and Northern Alberta Region, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada2 Pediatric Cardiac Transplant Unit, Stollery Children's Hospital, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada3 Faculty of Medicine and Dentistry, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 9,  (Oct 2016): 752-765.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1825970841?accountid=14667

Abstract: Given the arduous course of heart transplantation and follow-up care, recipients and their families face complex challenges and stressors warranting supportive interventions. This study explored the impact of a family camp as an intervention of education and social support for pediatric transplant recipients and their families. A total of 49 individuals participated in this evaluation, including eight children and nine youth with heart transplants, five siblings, 19 parents, and 13 health care providers. Participants ranked and described the 3-day family camp experience. Analysis of pre/post intervention measures on knowledge, social support, and coping revealed statistically significant improvements in knowledge, social support, self-esteem, and psychological stability. Satisfaction surveys revealed the camp to be an important resource for education, family fun, and peer support among transplant recipients, their families, and the health care team. Implications and recommendations are offered for clinical and community practice.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Evaluation+of+a+family+camp+intervention+for+children+with+a+heart+transplant+and+their+families&amp;rft.au=Nicholas%2C+David+B%3BDodd%2C+Bernadette%3BUrschel%2C+Simon%3BYoung%2C+Amber%3BWest%2C+Lori+J&amp;rft.aulast=Nicholas&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=9&amp;rft.spage=752&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1218402

Current realities and future vision: Developing an interprofessional, integrated health care workforce

Author: Dubus, Nicole, PhD, MSW, LCSW1; Howard, Heather, PhD, MSW21 Department of Social Work, San Jose State University, San Jose, California, USA2 Department of Social Work, Wheelock College, Boston, Massachusetts, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 9,  (Oct 2016): 766-778.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1825970855?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article shares findings from an interprofessional symposium that took place in Boston in the spring of 2015. Educators and practitioners from various disciplines shared challenges, successes, and ideas on best interprofessional collaboration (IPC) and curricula development. The findings include the importance of patient-and-family-centered care, which includes the patient and his/her family in the decision-making process; increased education regarding IPC in universities and major hospitals; and educational opportunities within health care systems.

A pilot feasibility study of virtual patient simulation to enhance social work students' brief mental health assessment skills

Author: Washburn, Micki, PhD1; Bordnick, Patrick, PhD, MPH2; Rizzo, Albert "Skip", PhD31 Virtual Reality Clinical Research Lab, Center for Health Equity and Evaluation Research, Graduate College of Social Work, University of Houston, Houston, Texas, USA2 School of Social Work, Tulane University, New Orleans, Louisiana, USA3 Institute for Creative Technologies, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Keck School of Medicine, University of Southern California, Playa Vista, California, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 9,  (Oct 2016): 675-693.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1825970859?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study presents preliminary feasibility and acceptability data on the use of virtual patient (VP) simulations to develop brief assessment skills within an interdisciplinary care setting. Results support the acceptability of technology-enhanced simulations and offer preliminary evidence for an association between engagement in VP practice simulations and improvements in diagnostic accuracy and clinical interviewing skills. Recommendations and next steps for research on technology-enhanced simulations within social work are discussed.

____________________________________________________________

Opportunities for social work under the Affordable Care Act: A call for action

Author: Lynch, Sean, PhD1; Greeno, Catherine, PhD2; Teich, Judith, PhD1; Delany, Peter, PhD31 Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, Rockville, Maryland, USA2 School of Social Work, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA3 Office of National Drug Control Policy, Washington, District of Columbia, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 9,  (Oct 2016): 651-674.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1825970871?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Affordable Care Act (ACA) has profoundly restructured American health care. Numerous social work authors have commented on the importance of the ACA's reforms to social work practice, education, and research. This article summarizes the literature, adds relevant information, and makes recommendations for future actions. The policy, opinion, and peer-reviewed literatures were systematically reviewed. Sixty-three publications appeared between 2010 and 2015 are included. Five themes emerged, as follows: 1) the crucial provisions of the ACA, 2) the natural affinity of social work and the ACA reforms, 3) curricular adaptations needed to address changing workforce needs, 4) areas for continued social work advocacy, and 5) opportunities for high-impact social work research. This article provides a comprehensive introduction to the ACA, its reforms, and opportunities for social work to assume a high visibility leadership role in implementing the reforms, with particular emphasis on needed curricular changes and opportunities for research.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Opportunities+for+social+work+under+the+Affordable+Care+Act%3A+A+call+for+action&amp;rft.au=Lynch%2C+Sean%2C+PhD%3BGreeno%2C+Catherine%2C+PhD%3BTeich%2C+Judith%2C+PhD%3BDelany%2C+Peter%2C+PhD&amp;rft.aulast=Lynch&amp;rft.aufirst=Sean&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=9&amp;rft.spage=651&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1221871

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Opportunities+for+social+work+under+the+Affordable+Care+Act%3A+A+call+for+action&amp;rft.au=Lynch%2C+Sean%2C+PhD%3BGreeno%2C+Catherine%2C+PhD%3BTeich%2C+Judith%2C+PhD%3BDelany%2C+Peter%2C+PhD&amp;rft.aulast=Lynch&amp;rft.aufirst=Sean&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=9&amp;rft.spage=651&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1221871

The association between unemployment status and physical health among veterans and civilians in the United States

Author: Tran, Thanh V1; Canfield, Julie1; Chan, Keith21 School of Social Work, Boston College, Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts, USA2 SUNY School of Social Welfare, University at Albany, Albany, New York, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 9,  (Oct 2016): 720-731.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1825970876?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study analyzed data from the 2012 Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System to examine the association between unemployment status and physical health among a sample of 170,924 civilians and 12,129 veterans (aged 18-50 years). Multivariate regression analysis was used to test the interaction effect between employment status and veteran/civilian status on physical health. Veterans who were unemployed long term (longer than 27 weeks) reported a significantly greater number of days with poor physical health than civilians who experienced long-term unemployment. Timely prevention and intervention efforts to integrate veterans into the workforce could lead to substantially improved physical health outcomes. Public health policies and programs that are funded to assist veterans in securing and maintaining gainful employment can have lasting implications for their overall improved health and physical well-being.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=The+association+between+unemployment+status+and+physical+health+among+veterans+and+civilians+in+the+United+States&amp;rft.au=Tran%2C+Thanh+V%3BCanfield%2C+Julie%3BChan%2C+Keith&amp;rft.aulast=Tran&amp;rft.aufirst=Thanh&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=9&amp;rft.spage=720&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1191582

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=The+association+between+unemployment+status+and+physical+health+among+veterans+and+civilians+in+the+United+States&amp;rft.au=Tran%2C+Thanh+V%3BCanfield%2C+Julie%3BChan%2C+Keith&amp;rft.aulast=Tran&amp;rft.aufirst=Thanh&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=9&amp;rft.spage=720&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1191582

____________________________________________________________

Increasing self-knowledge: Utilizing tele-coaching for patients with congestive heart failure

Author: Rosen, Daniel, PhD, MSW1; Berrios-Thomas, Saskia1; Engel, Rafael J, PhD, MSW11 School of Social Work, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 9,  (Oct 2016): 711-719.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1825970928?accountid=14667

Abstract: The objective was to assess self-care knowledge changes with dually eligible Medicare and Medicaid patients diagnosed with congestive heart failure (CHF), who received a telecoaching protocol integrating symptom monitoring with face-to-face video chat with a social worker. We recruited 45 patients with CHF from a regional managed care organization. Sessions via a Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act-compliant tablet-based platform focused on educational information designed to improve patient self-care. Social workers administered the 13-item Member Confidence Measure (MCM) at baseline and at a 30-day follow-up period. Scores were recorded to measure differences in patients' understanding of CHF and related symptoms, their knowledge of the disease, and the behaviors necessary to prevent their symptoms from getting worse. Over the 30-day period, scores significantly (p < .01) increased on the total scale score and specific confidence measure subscales (symptom recognition, medication adherence, medical attention, healthy choices, and safety). Gender, race, and age were unrelated to these improvements. In addition, effect sizes for the sub-scales ranged from .54 to 1.08; the effect size of the intervention as expressed by the total scale score was 1.12. Overall, patients increased knowledge over a 30-day period. Tele-coaching by social workers holds promise as a feasible model for health education for high-risk populations.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Increasing+self-knowledge%3A+Utilizing+tele-coaching+for+patients+with+congestive+heart+failure&amp;rft.au=Rosen%2C+Daniel%2C+PhD%2C+MSW%3BBerrios-Thomas%2C+Saskia%3BEngel%2C+Rafael+J%2C+PhD%2C+MSW&amp;rft.aulast=Rosen&amp;rft.aufirst=Daniel&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=9&amp;rft.spage=711&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1191581

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Increasing+self-knowledge%3A+Utilizing+tele-coaching+for+patients+with+congestive+heart+failure&amp;rft.au=Rosen%2C+Daniel%2C+PhD%2C+MSW%3BBerrios-Thomas%2C+Saskia%3BEngel%2C+Rafael+J%2C+PhD%2C+MSW&amp;rft.aulast=Rosen&amp;rft.aufirst=Daniel&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=9&amp;rft.spage=711&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1191581

____________________________________________________________

Racial/ethnic variation in health care satisfaction: The role of acculturation

Author: Han, Woojae, PhD1; Lee, Sungkyu, PhD21 Department of Social Work, Binghamton University, Binghamton, New York, USA2 School of Social Welfare, Soongsil University, Seoul, South Korea

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 9,  (Oct 2016): 694-710.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1825970929?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examined the role of acculturation and racial/ethnic variation in health care satisfaction among four different racial/ethnic groups. The study sample consisted of 41,560 adults from the 2011 California Health Interview Survey. Health care satisfaction was measured via two questions regarding doctors' listening and explanations. Guided by Andersen's behavioral model of health care use, multivariate logistic regressions were conducted. Hispanic and Asian respondents showed the lowest levels of satisfaction with their doctors' listening and explanations, respectively. Acculturation was found to be a significant predictor of health care satisfaction. Health care professionals should develop ways of expanding culturally competent health care professionals, who are aware of racial/ethnic variation in health care satisfaction.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Racial%2Fethnic+variation+in+health+care+satisfaction%3A+The+role+of+acculturation&amp;rft.au=Han%2C+Woojae%2C+PhD%3BLee%2C+Sungkyu%2C+PhD&amp;rft.aulast=Han&amp;rft.aufirst=Woojae&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=9&amp;rft.spage=694&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1191580

Enhancing women's health: A call for social work research

Author: Bird, Melissa, MSW1; Wright, Rachel L, PhD, MSW2; Frost, Caren J, PhD, MPH31 School of Social Work, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, California, USA2 Department of Social Work, Appalachian State University, Boone, North Carolina, USA3 College of Social Work, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, Utah, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care ; New York  Vol. 55, Iss. 9,  (Oct 2016): 732-751.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827469632?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents a critical synthesis of the social work empirical literature on women's health. In light of recent policy changes that directly affect women's health and social work, the authors conducted a literature review of recent publications (2010-2015) regarding social work and women's health nationally. Despite frequent accounts cited in the literature, there has been no comprehensive review of issues involving women's health and social work in the United States. The purpose of this review is to examine the current social work literature addressing women's health at the national (U.S.) level. This research presents a summary description of the status of the social work literature dealing with women's health, specifically 51 articles published between 2010 and 2015. Our search highlights the need for social work research to fill gaps and more fully address the needs of women across the lifespan.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Enhancing+women%27s+health%3A+A+call+for+social+work+research&amp;rft.au=Bird%2C+Melissa%2C+MSW%3BWright%2C+Rachel+L%2C+PhD%2C+MSW%3BFrost%2C+Caren+J%2C+PhD%2C+MPH&amp;rft.aulast=Bird&amp;rft.aufirst=Melissa&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=9&amp;rft.spage=732&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2016.1205706

Environmental Justice Is a Social Justice Issue: Incorporating Environmental Justice Into Social Work Practice Curricula

Author: Beltrán, Ramona; Hacker, Alice; Begun, Stephanie

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. 4,  (Oct/Dec 2016): 493-502.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827936313?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social justice education for social work practice is concerned with addressing issues of power and oppression as they impact intersections of identity, experience, and the social environment. However, little focus is directed toward the physical and natural environment despite overwhelming evidence that traditionally marginalized groups bear the burden of environmental problems. In this article, we discuss environmental disaster impacts on marginalized communities, presence of environmental justice in social work literature, and opportunities for integrating environmental justice into social work's mandated disciplinary competencies. We conclude with an example of a module implemented in a foundation Social Justice for Social Work Practice course using place-based education principles as an illustration of concrete strategies for incorporating environmental justice into social justice curricula.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Environmental+Justice+Is+a+Social+Justice+Issue%3A+Incorporating+Environmental+Justice+Into+Social+Work+Practice+Curricula&amp;rft.au=Beltr%C3%A1n%2C+Ramona%3BHacker%2C+Alice%3BBegun%2C+Stephanie&amp;rft.aulast=Beltr%C3%A1n&amp;rft.aufirst=Ramona&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=493&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1215277

Technology in Social Work Education: A Systematic Review

Author: Wretman, Christopher J; Macy, Rebecca J

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. 4,  (Oct/Dec 2016): 409-421.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827936546?accountid=14667

Abstract: Given the growing prevalence of technology-based instruction, social work faculty need a clear understanding of the strengths and limitations of these methods. We systematically examined the evidence for technology-based instruction in social work education. Using comprehensive and rigorous methods, 38 articles were included in the review. Of these, 23 employed Web-based strategies, 12 employed interactive television-based strategies, and three combined both methods. Among the studies, there was a wide range of samples, content areas, measures, and data analyses. Results found that 84.2% of the studies reported that technology-based pedagogical methods produced academic outcomes equivalent or superior to traditional methods. Despite limitations, this body of evidence supports the continued use of technology in social work education as an alternative to classroom education. Future directions include the need for higher quality research and further investigations of specific issues relating to content, student subpopulations, and measures.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Technology+in+Social+Work+Education%3A+A+Systematic+Review&amp;rft.au=Wretman%2C+Christopher+J%3BMacy%2C+Rebecca+J&amp;rft.aulast=Wretman&amp;rft.aufirst=Christopher&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=409&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1198293

Promoting Resilience Through Social Work Practice with Groups: Implications for the Practice and Field Curricula

Author: Gitterman, Alex; Knight, Carolyn

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. 4,  (Oct/Dec 2016): 448-461.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827936551?accountid=14667

Abstract: The realities of contemporary social work practice often push social workers toward a deficit-focused orientation. The article begins with an overview of the major tenets of resiliency and adversarial growth theories and related research findings. We suggest that the group modality epitomizes the application of resiliency theory and adversarial growth to social work practice. A primary focus of this article is on articulating and illustrating the unique contribution group work makes for promoting client resilience. The article provides a theoretical and empirical framework that students, practitioners, and educators alike can use to identify, understand, and capitalize on client strengths through group work. Implications for social work education, specifically the practice and field curricula, are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Promoting+Resilience+Through+Social+Work+Practice+with+Groups%3A+Implications+for+the+Practice+and+Field+Curricula&amp;rft.au=Gitterman%2C+Alex%3BKnight%2C+Carolyn&amp;rft.aulast=Gitterman&amp;rft.aufirst=Alex&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=448&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1198295

Promoting Election-Related Policy Practice Among Social Work Students

Author: Pritzker, Suzanne; Burwell, Christianna

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. 4,  (Oct/Dec 2016): 434-447.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827936575?accountid=14667

Abstract: Political involvement is an integral component of the social work profession, yet there is no explicit reference to social work participation in election-related activities in either the National Association of Social Workers Code of Ethics or the Council on Social Work Education Educational Policy and Accreditation Standards. Social work education may offer an opportune time to shape crucial patterns of future electoral participation among social workers. This study examines BSW, MSW, and PhD student electoral involvement during the 2012 presidential election and ways social work program administrators across the country encouraged students to acquire skills and experience in election-related policy practice during the election season. Findings indicate that the extent of opportunities offered to students varied widely across programs as well as across types of electoral activities.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Promoting+Election-Related+Policy+Practice+Among+Social+Work+Students&amp;rft.au=Pritzker%2C+Suzanne%3BBurwell%2C+Christianna&amp;rft.aulast=Pritzker&amp;rft.aufirst=Suzanne&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=434&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1198294

Can Clinical Skills Be Taught Online? Comparing Skill Development Between Online and F2F Students Using a Blinded Review

Author: Wilke, Dina J; King, Erin; Ashmore, Margaret; Stanley, Craig

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. 4,  (Oct/Dec 2016): 484-492.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827936607?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study compared the development of clinical assessment and intervention skills between students enrolled in a face-to-face (F2F) or an asynchronous online clinical social work class. All students from three semesters of F2F (n = 74) and online (n = 78) sections of an MSW clinical class taught by the same instructor were included. Two assignments were used to compare students: an assessment and treatment plan of a fictional case and a digital role-play. A doctoral student who was blinded to the course delivery mechanism graded the role-play. After controlling for baseline differences in age, there were no differences between online and F2F students in skill demonstration. It appears clinical skills can be taught as effectively online as in F2F situations based on blinded review of role-plays.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Can+Clinical+Skills+Be+Taught+Online%3F+Comparing+Skill+Development+Between+Online+and+F2F+Students+Using+a+Blinded+Review&amp;rft.au=Wilke%2C+Dina+J%3BKing%2C+Erin%3BAshmore%2C+Margaret%3BStanley%2C+Craig&amp;rft.aulast=Wilke&amp;rft.aufirst=Dina&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=484&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1215276

Teaching Note-Using TED Talks in the Social Work Classroom: Encouraging Student Engagement and Discourse

Author: Loya, Melody Aye; Klemm, Terri

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. 4,  (Oct/Dec 2016): 518-523.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827936779?accountid=14667

Abstract: Focusing on TED Talks (online videos) as a resource for social work educators, this teaching note shares our ideas regarding the use of the online videos as an avenue for reaching students and encouraging discussions in the social work classroom. The article first explores the TED platform and then discusses using TED as a teaching tool. Finally, we share our perspectives and student voices on selected videos that can be useful in social work education, including references to specific Council on Social Work Education competencies and practice behaviors. The videos bring world-renowned speakers into the classroom, providing social work educators with rich teaching opportunities limited only by their imagination.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Teaching+Note-Using+TED+Talks+in+the+Social+Work+Classroom%3A+Encouraging+Student+Engagement+and+Discourse&amp;rft.au=Loya%2C+Melody+Aye%3BKlemm%2C+Terri&amp;rft.aulast=Loya&amp;rft.aufirst=Melody&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=518&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1198291

Field Education in the Present Moment: Evaluating a 14-Week Pedagogical Model to Increase Mindfulness Practice

Author: Lee, Jacquelyn J; Himmelheber, Sarah A

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. 4,  (Oct/Dec 2016): 473-483.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827936800?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work practitioners increasingly use mindfulness techniques, and research into the impact of this practice is being explored by multiple related disciplines, such as psychology and education. Cultivating the potential benefits of mindfulness at multiple practice levels necessitates curricular integration of mindfulness training. This article reports on the evaluation of a 14-week mindfulness-based pedagogical model implemented in two sections of social work field seminars. Using a pretest and posttest survey design that included an existing five-dimension mindfulness scale, students exhibited significant change in three facets of mindfulness: observing, nonjudgment of inner experience, and nonreactivity to inner experience. Implications for social work education and directions for future research are explored.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Field+Education+in+the+Present+Moment%3A+Evaluating+a+14-Week+Pedagogical+Model+to+Increase+Mindfulness+Practice&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Jacquelyn+J%3BHimmelheber%2C+Sarah+A&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Jacquelyn&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=473&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1215274

Conceptualising the politics of social protection expansion in low income countries: The intersection of transnational ideas and domestic politics

Author: Lavers, Tom; Hickey, Sam

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 25, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2016): 388-398.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1828050627?accountid=14667

Abstract: The growing literature on social protection in low income developing countries has tended to focus on definitional debates, policy design and impact evaluations, with relatively little consideration of the ways in which politics shape policy. This article argues that politics needs to be at the centre of efforts to understand social protection and outlines a new conceptual framework for investigating this, with a particular focus on explaining the variation in progress made by low income countries in adopting and implementing social protection. We propose that an adapted 'political settlements' framework that incorporates insights from the literatures on welfare state development - notably 'power constellations' theory, discursive institutionalism and global policy networks - can help frame political commitment to social protection as flowing from the interaction of domestic political economy and transnational ideas. Importantly, this approach situates social protection within a broader political and policy context, and highlights the influence of underlying power relations at multiple levels.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Conceptualising+the+politics+of+social+protection+expansion+in+low+income+countries%3A+The+intersection+of+transnational+ideas+and+domestic+politics&amp;rft.au=Lavers%2C+Tom%3BHickey%2C+Sam&amp;rft.aulast=Lavers&amp;rft.aufirst=Tom&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=388&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12210

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Conceptualising+the+politics+of+social+protection+expansion+in+low+income+countries%3A+The+intersection+of+transnational+ideas+and+domestic+politics&amp;rft.au=Lavers%2C+Tom%3BHickey%2C+Sam&amp;rft.aulast=Lavers&amp;rft.aufirst=Tom&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=388&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12210

Women's participation in self-help groups as a pathway to women's empowerment: A case of Nepal

Author: Atteraya, Madhu Sudhan; Gnawali, Shreejana; Palley, Elizabeth

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 25, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2016): 321-330.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1828050679?accountid=14667

Abstract: Non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and the government of Nepal have made some effort to reduce poverty in Nepal by creating women's affiliation groups, some of which are micro-credit organizations. Using capabilities as defined by Amartya Sen (Development as freedom, Oxford University Press, New Delhi, 2000), which includes employment opportunities, women's ownership in productive resources such as land and/or homes, educational opportunities, and women's participation in decision-making in the family, this study evaluated the extent to which women's ethnic group or caste affiliation affected a woman's likelihood of being empowered by participation in these groups. We analyzed a sample of 8,973 women which was taken from the 2011 Nepal Demographic and Health Survey. Previous research has demonstrated that participation in gender-based groups is correlated with higher economic status. This study adds to the literature on women's affiliation groups by investigating the impact of structural factors, such as caste and ethnicity, on women's self-help group participation (women's groups and credit groups).

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Women%27s+participation+in+self-help+groups+as+a+pathway+to+women%27s+empowerment%3A+A+case+of+Nepal&amp;rft.au=Atteraya%2C+Madhu+Sudhan%3BGnawali%2C+Shreejana%3BPalley%2C+Elizabeth&amp;rft.aulast=Atteraya&amp;rft.aufirst=Madhu&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=321&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12212

____________________________________________________________

Intimate partner violence and use of contraceptives in Bangladesh: Results from a national sample

Author: Murshid, Nadine S; Ely, Gretchen E

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 25, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2016): 331-338.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1828050952?accountid=14667

Abstract: The effect of intimate partner violence (IPV) on women's lives includes negative reproductive health outcomes by way of compromised control over their bodies. This effect is contextual, which leads to contradictory implications for practitioners involved in sexual and reproductive health. The current article adds to the literature by providing an examination of the association between partner violence and contraceptive use in a nationally representative sample of married women in Bangladesh, where some 24% of national samples of women report IPV. The study is a secondary data analysis of the Bangladesh Demographic and Health Survey 2007 with a sample of 4,467 women aged 15-49 years. Significant main effects were observed for partner violence: The probability of using contraceptives was 9% higher for women who reported partner violence compared with women who did not. Additionally, women were more likely to use contraceptives when they had children under the age of five and were employed. Policy and practice implications for social work are discussed. Key Practitioner Message: * To understand how intimate partner violence may increase the odds of contraceptive use as a way of "help seeking"; * To understand the implications of contraceptive use in a Muslim majority population; * To provide policy suggestions for bundling services for intimate partner violence with reproductive health services.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Intimate+partner+violence+and+use+of+contraceptives+in+Bangladesh%3A+Results+from+a+national+sample&amp;rft.au=Murshid%2C+Nadine+S%3BEly%2C+Gretchen+E&amp;rft.aulast=Murshid&amp;rft.aufirst=Nadine&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=331&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12204

____________________________________________________________

The impact of education and occupation on domestic violence in Saudi Arabia

Author: Shiraz, Mohammed S

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 25, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2016): 339-346.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1828050956?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examined the role of education and occupation in connection with domestic violence in Saudi Arabia based on a survey administered to 917 women who had varying years of education and various types of occupations. Results show that education and occupation play a positive role in the life of Saudi women by reducing the level of domestic violence to which they are exposed. Education was found to lower the rate of domestic violence by around 7%. A significant difference in the level of domestic violence was found as well between employed and unemployed women. In Saudi Arabia, having an education and/or earning an income seems to give women more power and higher social status, which in turn appears to lower the level of domestic violence they experience compared with women who do not work, have few years of education or are not currently enrolled in education.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=The+impact+of+education+and+occupation+on+domestic+violence+in+Saudi+Arabia&amp;rft.au=Shiraz%2C+Mohammed+S&amp;rft.aulast=Shiraz&amp;rft.aufirst=Mohammed&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=339&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12214

Predicting unemployment: Occupational aspiration-achievement discrepancy as a risk factor in Norwegian young adults

Author: Gjerustad, Cay11 Norwegian Social Research (NOVA), Oslo and Akershus University college of Applied Sciences, Oslo, Norway

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 25, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2016): 361-372.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1828157824?accountid=14667

Abstract: Research on risk of unemployment has focused primarily on the importance of individual assets, such as level of education achieved and personal characteristics. This study investigated whether a discrepancy between current occupational position and occupational aspirations predicts unemployment. Achieving occupational aspirations may be highly important for young people in Western societies. The analyses were conducted using longitudinal survey data linked to register data on 1,681 Norwegian young adults. The results showed that being in an occupation with lower status than the occupation to which one aspires significantly predicts the risk of later unemployment. The findings accord with research suggesting that a mismatch between employees' subjective expectations and their actual job situation has negative consequences. For example, failure to acquire a job that matches one's expectations may lead to unemployment either through proactive behaviour, such as quitting a current job to find a new one, or through giving up, such as withdrawing from work.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Predicting+unemployment%3A+Occupational+aspiration-achievement+discrepancy+as+a+risk+factor+in+Norwegian+young+adults&amp;rft.au=Gjerustad%2C+Cay&amp;rft.aulast=Gjerustad&amp;rft.aufirst=Cay&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=361&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12211

Institutions and structures as barriers? A comparison of native-born and immigrant unemployment durations across 12 European countries

Author: Diop-Christensen, Anna1; Pavlopoulos, Dimitris21 Metropolitan University College, Denmark; Aalborg University, Denmark2 Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, The Netherlands

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 25, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2016): 347-360.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1828157832?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study investigated the effect of institutions on the unemployment duration gap between non-EU immigrants and native-born in 12 European countries. Going further than the existing literature, our study encompassed unemployment duration, distinguishing between exits to inactivity, primary and secondary employment. Additionally, we have provided a stronger micro-foundation to the comparative literature by introducing institutional measures for unemployment-related benefits at the individual level rather than merely using aggregate proxies. Our analysis found no disincentive effects of benefits for immigrants. Furthermore, the employment prospects of immigrants were better when the demand for low-skilled labour was high, and immigration policy was labour market-oriented. In contrast, employment protection legislation did not affect the unemployment duration of immigrants.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Institutions+and+structures+as+barriers%3F+A+comparison+of+native-born+and+immigrant+unemployment+durations+across+12+European+countries&amp;rft.au=Diop-Christensen%2C+Anna%3BPavlopoulos%2C+Dimitris&amp;rft.aulast=Diop-Christensen&amp;rft.aufirst=Anna&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=347&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12206

The breadth and depth of multidimensional child poverty in China

Author: Wu, Yichao1; Qi, Di21 Department of Economics, School of Economics and Management, Southeast University, Nanjing, China2 Department of Sociology, School of Public Administration, Hohai University, Nanjing, China

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 25, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2016): 373-387.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1828157970?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study analysed the multidimensional child poverty status in China between 1989 and 2009, using the China Health and Nutrition survey data. Based on the Alkire-Foster method for measuring poverty, a multidimensional poverty index was calculated and further decomposed into seven deprivation dimensions: nutrition, water, sanitation, health, education, shelter and information. The study has four main findings: (1) The multidimensional child poverty rate in China declined gradually where the sanitation facility was most severely deprived; (2) The poverty gap between rich and poor provinces remained over the years; (3) The urban-rural disparity was reduced in all seven dimensions; (4) The poorest of the poor climbed out of ultra-poverty and became the moderately poor or even the non-poor.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=The+breadth+and+depth+of+multidimensional+child+poverty+in+China&amp;rft.au=Wu%2C+Yichao%3BQi%2C+Di&amp;rft.aulast=Wu&amp;rft.aufirst=Yichao&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=373&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12209

____________________________________________________________

Theory and social work: A conceptual review of the literature

Author: Hicks, Stephen11 School of Health Sciences, University of Manchester, UK

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 25, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2016): 399-414.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1828157982?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents a conceptual review of the literature concerning social work and theory. Based on analysis of 93 research studies, drawn from literature in English published between 1968 and 2016, the review considers the many ways that theory is conceptualised in the literature, and asks meta-theoretical questions about how and why different conceptualisations arise. The article examines definitional questions and ambiguities concerning the use of theory, extant research on the use of theory by social workers in practice, hostility expressed regarding theory in social work, the theory/practice divide and perspectives that emphasise theory's utility or functionality. The article points at some methodological and ethical limitations concerning current research, and summarises dominant, as well as less prominent, versions of what counts as theory within the social work discipline, before finally suggesting that further meta-theoretical research is needed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Theory+and+social+work%3A+A+conceptual+review+of+the+literature&amp;rft.au=Hicks%2C+Stephen&amp;rft.aulast=Hicks&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=399&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12215

Evaluation of a Standardized Method of Quality Assurance in Mental Health Records

Author: Bradshaw, Kelsey M; Donohue, Bradley; Fayeghi, Jasmine; Lee, Tiffany; Wilks, Chelsey R; Ross, Brendon

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 26, Iss. 6,  (Oct 2016): 686-692.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1830154773?accountid=14667

Abstract: The widespread adoption of research-supported treatments by mental health providers has facilitated empirical development of quality assurance (QA) methods. Research in this area has focused on QA systems aimed at assuring the integrity of research-supported treatment implementation, while examination of QA systems to assure appropriate documentation of the implementation has received extant attention. Therefore, the purpose of this study was to pilot the initial development of a standardized QA system to assist mental health providers in effectively maintaining records of their implementation of a research-supported treatment. After a baseline of record-keeping errors was established, a QA program was implemented. Results indicated that QA audits were reliably conducted, frequency of errors decreased significantly upon the implementation of QA, and the QA program was determined to be feasible. A significant negative linear relationship was found between frequency of QA audits and frequency of errors. Study implications for research-supported treatments are discussed in light of these results.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Evaluation+of+a+Standardized+Method+of+Quality+Assurance+in+Mental+Health+Records%3A+A+Pilot+Study&amp;rft.au=Bradshaw%2C+Kelsey+M%3BDonohue%2C+Bradley%3BFayeghi%2C+Jasmine%3BLee%2C+Tiffany%3BWilks%2C+Chelsey+R%3BRoss%2C+Brendon&amp;rft.aulast=Bradshaw&amp;rft.aufirst=Kelsey&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=686&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514563146

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Evaluation+of+a+Standardized+Method+of+Quality+Assurance+in+Mental+Health+Records%3A+A+Pilot+Study&amp;rft.au=Bradshaw%2C+Kelsey+M%3BDonohue%2C+Bradley%3BFayeghi%2C+Jasmine%3BLee%2C+Tiffany%3BWilks%2C+Chelsey+R%3BRoss%2C+Brendon&amp;rft.aulast=Bradshaw&amp;rft.aufirst=Kelsey&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=686&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514563146

____________________________________________________________

Social Media Policy in Social Work Education: A Review and Recommendations

Author: Karpman, Hannah E; Drisko, James

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. 4,  (Oct/Dec 2016): 398-408.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1830471950?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although social media use has grown dramatically, program policies have not kept pace. Some programs now state that student social media activities have led to professional conduct reviews and may violate ethical standards. This article reviews current social media policies and conceptualizes their key elements. A review of current social media policies is reported, pointing to the need for further policy development. Six domains of a social media policy are identified: understanding social media, ethical and legal obligations, implications of one's personal and professional online presence, institutional obligations to the program and agency, productivity implications, and possible consequences for violations of the policy. A model social media policy is detailed, and unresolved issues are identified.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Media+Policy+in+Social+Work+Education%3A+A+Review+and+Recommendations&amp;rft.au=Karpman%2C+Hannah+E%3BDrisko%2C+James&amp;rft.aulast=Karpman&amp;rft.aufirst=Hannah&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=398&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1202164

Promoting Cognitive Development Through Field Education

Author: Simmons, Chris; Fisher, Amy K

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 52, Iss. 4,  (Oct/Dec 2016): 462-472.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1830478526?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reports results from a study examining the effects of field education on cognitive development. BSW students enrolled in either a semester-long practicum/field seminar or prepracticum courses completed pretest and posttest measures of cognitive complexity to assess cognitive development. Results indicated that field practicum students made significantly higher gains in cognitive complexity than prepracticum students even when controlling for age and ethnicity. The research suggests that field education, that is, working with actual clients under the supervision of more senior members of the profession, and participating in a field seminar course with other social work students have important implications for enhancing cognitive development.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Promoting+Cognitive+Development+Through+Field+Education&amp;rft.au=Simmons%2C+Chris%3BFisher%2C+Amy+K&amp;rft.aulast=Simmons&amp;rft.aufirst=Chris&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=462&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2016.1198290

Putting Racism on the Table: The Implementation and Evaluation of a Novel Racial Equity and Cultural Competency Training/Consultation Model in New York City

Author: De Jesús, Anthony1; Hogan, Jane2; Martinez, Robert3; Adams, Joan4; Hawkins Lacy, Tula51 Department of Social Work and Latino Community Practice, University of Saint Joseph, West Hartford, Connecticut, USA2 Department of Psychology and Social Work, Mercy College, Dobbs Ferry, New York, USA3 The NYC Administration for Children's Services, Child Welfare Programs-Family Permanency Team Conferencing, Bronx, New York, USA4 Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services Anti-Racism and Multicultural Consultation and Training Service; Independent Trainer and Consultant, New York, New York, USA5 Tula Hawkins Lacy Consulting, New York, New York, USA

Publication info: Journal of Ethnic & Cultural Diversity in Social Work ; Abingdon  Vol. 25, Iss. 4,  (Oct/Dec 2016): 300-319.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1839206068?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents the findings of a mixed-methods study of a racial equity and cultural competency training and case consultation model for child welfare practitioners. Findings suggest that the model enhanced participants' capacity for effective practice with diverse populations. A pretest/posttest instrument and evaluation revealed statistically significant increases of participants' awareness, knowledge, and skills related to culturally diverse populations. In addition, qualitative interview participants described the model as being highly influential and provided evidence of the development of the key skills for culturally effective practice.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Putting+Racism+on+the+Table%3A+The+Implementation+and+Evaluation+of+a+Novel+Racial+Equity+and+Cultural+Competency+Training%2FConsultation+Model+in+New+York+City&amp;rft.au=De+Jes%C3%BAs%2C+Anthony%3BHogan%2C+Jane%3BMartinez%2C+Robert%3BAdams%2C+Joan%3BHawkins+Lacy%2C+Tula&amp;rft.aulast=De+Jes%C3%BAs&amp;rft.aufirst=Anthony&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=300&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2016.1206497

The U Visa for Immigrant Victims of Violent Crime: What Social Workers Need to Know

Author: Warren, Sherry11 School of Social Welfare, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, USA

Publication info: Journal of Ethnic & Cultural Diversity in Social Work ; Abingdon  Vol. 25, Iss. 4,  (Oct/Dec 2016): 320-324.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1839206582?accountid=14667

Abstract: Immigrant victims of violent crime can obtain citizenship in the United States through the U Visa provision of the Violence Against Women Act of 2000. Social workers must engage with community agencies and law enforcement to increase awareness of the U Visa, streamline the process, and convince legislators to undertake revisions that address current gaps and increase community safety.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+U+Visa+for+Immigrant+Victims+of+Violent+Crime%3A+What+Social+Workers+Need+to+Know&amp;rft.au=Warren%2C+Sherry&amp;rft.aulast=Warren&amp;rft.aufirst=Sherry&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=320&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2016.1187102

From Cultural Competence to Cultural Consciousness: Transitioning to a Critical Approach to Working Across Differences in Social Work

Author: Azzopardi, Corry1; McNeill, Ted21 The Hospital for Sick Children, Division of Pediatric Medicine, Department of Social Work, Toronto, Ontario, Canada2 University of Toronto, Factor-Inwentash Faculty of Social Work, Toronto, Ontario, Canada

Publication info: Journal of Ethnic & Cultural Diversity in Social Work ; Abingdon  Vol. 25, Iss. 4,  (Oct/Dec 2016): 282-299.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1839206997?accountid=14667

Abstract: Driven by increasing cultural diversity and growing inequities in health and social outcomes, cross-cultural competence has become a fundamental dimension of effective and ethical social work practice. It has assumed a prominent discourse in social work education, scholarship, professional practice, codes of ethics, and organizational policy; however, how one defines, acquires, applies, and evaluates cultural competencies continue to be issues of debate. Grounded in a postmodern epistemic frame, an integrated model of critical cultural consciousness for working across differences in social work is proposed and implications for micro, mezzo, and macro levels of practice are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=From+Cultural+Competence+to+Cultural+Consciousness%3A+Transitioning+to+a+Critical+Approach+to+Working+Across+Differences+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Azzopardi%2C+Corry%3BMcNeill%2C+Ted&amp;rft.aulast=Azzopardi&amp;rft.aufirst=Corry&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=282&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2016.1206494

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=From+Cultural+Competence+to+Cultural+Consciousness%3A+Transitioning+to+a+Critical+Approach+to+Working+Across+Differences+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Azzopardi%2C+Corry%3BMcNeill%2C+Ted&amp;rft.aulast=Azzopardi&amp;rft.aufirst=Corry&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=282&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2016.1206494

Developing a Culturally Appropriate Assessment Tool: Reflections on Process Considerations

Author: Weaver, Hilary N11 School of Social Work, University at Buffalo, Buffalo, New York, USA

Publication info: Journal of Ethnic & Cultural Diversity in Social Work ; Abingdon  Vol. 25, Iss. 4,  (Oct/Dec 2016): 270-281.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1839207313?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes the process of modifying an assessment tool in order to make it culturally appropriate for South Asian Tamil refugees and asylum seekers. This was envisioned as an important step in giving practitioners who work with Tamils a useful tool and advancing the knowledge base on cultural competence to make it more inclusive of instrument development. This article provides a detailed description of how the instrument was developed, thus addressing a significant deficiency in the literature.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Developing+a+Culturally+Appropriate+Assessment+Tool%3A+Reflections+on+Process+Considerations&amp;rft.au=Weaver%2C+Hilary+N&amp;rft.aulast=Weaver&amp;rft.aufirst=Hilary&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=270&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15313204.2016.1206495

Financial Knowledge and Behaviors of Chinese Migrant Workers: An International Perspective on a Financially Vulnerable Population

Author: Chen, Zibei1; Lemieux, Catherine M11 School of Social Work, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA

Publication info: Journal of Community Practice ; Abingdon  Vol. 24, Iss. 4,  (Oct/Dec 2016): 462-486.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1841204815?accountid=14667

Abstract: Making informed financial decisions is crucial to the wellbeing of Chinese migrant workers. Using interview survey data (N = 329), this study examined financial knowledge and behaviors of migrant workers in China. Results showed that participants demonstrated low levels of financial knowledge (51.4%) and beneficial financial behaviors (51.0%). Multivariate results indicated that a modest proportion of the variance in financial behaviors was explained by financial knowledge, attitudes, and socio-demographic characteristics (e.g., marital status and income). Findings underscore the importance of disseminating culturally-relevant educational interventions to financially at-risk, low-paid migrant workers in China.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Financial+Knowledge+and+Behaviors+of+Chinese+Migrant+Workers%3A+An+International+Perspective+on+a+Financially+Vulnerable+Population&amp;rft.au=Chen%2C+Zibei%3BLemieux%2C+Catherine+M&amp;rft.aulast=Chen&amp;rft.aufirst=Zibei&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=462&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2016.1233475

Toward Culturally Sensitive Financial Education Interventions with Latinos

Author: Barros Lane, Liza1; Pritzker, Suzanne11 Graduate College of Social Work, University of Houston, Houston, TX

Publication info: Journal of Community Practice ; Abingdon  Vol. 24, Iss. 4,  (Oct/Dec 2016): 410-427.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1841205096?accountid=14667

Abstract: To expand the financial capability of Latinos, culturally sensitive interventions are needed. A literature search was conducted to examine how financial education interventions have been used to improve financial outcomes for Latinos. Just 7 peer-reviewed intervention studies were identified, suggesting a substantial gap in knowledge in this area. Although conclusions about the effectiveness of financial education interventions with Latinos are limited, each study finds positive changes in financial attitudes or behaviors. Using Resnicow's (1999) cultural sensitivity framework, surface and deep structure methods of tailoring financial education were identified. Implications for designing and testing culturally sensitive financial education interventions are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Toward+Culturally+Sensitive+Financial+Education+Interventions+with+Latinos&amp;rft.au=Barros+Lane%2C+Liza%3BPritzker%2C+Suzanne&amp;rft.aulast=Barros+Lane&amp;rft.aufirst=Liza&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=410&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2016.1233476

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Toward+Culturally+Sensitive+Financial+Education+Interventions+with+Latinos&amp;rft.au=Barros+Lane%2C+Liza%3BPritzker%2C+Suzanne&amp;rft.aulast=Barros+Lane&amp;rft.aufirst=Liza&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=410&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2016.1233476

From Being Unbanked to Becoming Unbanked or Unbankable: Community Experts Describe Financial Practices of Latinos in East Los Angeles

Author: Padua, Larissa A1; Doran, Joanna K11 School of Social Work, California State University, Los Angeles, CA

Publication info: Journal of Community Practice ; Abingdon  Vol. 24, Iss. 4,  (Oct/Dec 2016): 428-444.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1841209371?accountid=14667

Abstract: Appropriate use of formal financial institutions facilitates saving and asset building. Yet 20% of the US Latino population is unbanked. In this cross-sectional qualitative study, 34 community experts were interviewed regarding financial practices in the predominantly low-income Latino and immigrant community of East Los Angeles. Thematic analysis of these in-depth, semistructured interviews suggests that immigration status fuels fears regarding banking and ultimately the persistence of unbanked status; limited financial education prompts community members to move from being unbanked to being unbankable. Techniques employed to reverse this cycle appear helpful, but ultimately overwhelmed by the magnitude of community mistrust and misinformation.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=From+Being+Unbanked+to+Becoming+Unbanked+or+Unbankable%3A+Community+Experts+Describe+Financial+Practices+of+Latinos+in+East+Los+Angeles&amp;rft.au=Padua%2C+Larissa+A%3BDoran%2C+Joanna+K&amp;rft.aulast=Padua&amp;rft.aufirst=Larissa&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=428&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2016.1233477
