Social Media and Child Welfare: Policy, Training, and the Risks and Benefits From the Administrator's Perspective

Author: Stott, Tonia C; MacEachron, Ann; Gustavsson, Nora

Publication info: Advances in Social Work ; Indianapolis  Vol. 17, Iss. 2,  (Fall 2016): 221.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1865209815?accountid=14667

Abstract: The field of public child welfare faces special challenges as it interweaves the use of social media into practice. Social media can assist agencies in meeting demands of practice such as communication, preservation of important family connections, identification of kin, and service coordination with caretakers and community partners. It also presents risks with respect to privacy, confidentiality, and safety. To look at the role of social media in child welfare practice, we began by examining the literature on social media use and how agencies are responding to the risks and benefits of this technology. We then report the findings from an exploratory national survey of training administrators (n=14) that suggests states vary in both policy development and training with respect to social media in child welfare work. We further report on state training administrators' views of the perceived risks vs. benefits of the use of social media in various case management tasks and in enhancing the well-being of youth in out-of-home care. Agencies would reduce their liability risks and at the same time benefit their staff and clients by developing policies that offer guidelines to protect agency and staff privacy and safety, as well as client privacy and safety. Agencies may also promote the well-being of youth in out-of-home care by providing adequate information to staff and care-givers regarding the safe use of social media to create and maintain appropriate connections.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Advances+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Media+and+Child+Welfare%3A+Policy%2C+Training%2C+and+the+Risks+and+Benefits+From+the+Administrator%27s+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Stott%2C+Tonia+C%3BMacEachron%2C+Ann%3BGustavsson%2C+Nora&amp;rft.aulast=Stott&amp;rft.aufirst=Tonia&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=221&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Advances+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15278565&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Advances+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Media+and+Child+Welfare%3A+Policy%2C+Training%2C+and+the+Risks+and+Benefits+From+the+Administrator%27s+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Stott%2C+Tonia+C%3BMacEachron%2C+Ann%3BGustavsson%2C+Nora&amp;rft.aulast=Stott&amp;rft.aufirst=Tonia&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=221&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Advances+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15278565&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Graduating MSW Students' Recommended Interventions for Teen Dating Violence: A Descriptive Analysis

Author: Heidi Adams Rueda; Hawley, Alicia; Black, Beverly M; Ombayo, Bernadette

Publication info: Advances in Social Work ; Indianapolis  Vol. 17, Iss. 2,  (Fall 2016): 203.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1865209858?accountid=14667

Abstract: Teen dating violence (TDV) is a widespread issue that social workers are likely to encounter in their practice with youth, yet little research exists concerning their preparedness to do so. This study assessed the proposed interventions of graduating MSW students (n=73) from two accredited universities in response to two scenarios of TDV. Each scenario reflected various forms of relational violence. Nearly one-third of students' proposed interventions focused on the need to deliver some form of education, healthy relationships being the most prevalent theme. Other interventions included teaching about appropriate boundaries, issues of control and anger, self-esteem-building, and communication skills. The second most common set of responses pertained to individual assessment, and the third to individual and couple's counseling. Few comments identified specific TDV interventions, such as safety planning or evidence-based prevention programs. Students' recommendations for education and counseling rather than safety planning or multi-level interventions indicate that social work programs need to provide specific content in MSW curricula related to TDV and evidence-based interventions.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Advances+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Graduating+MSW+Students%27+Recommended+Interventions+for+Teen+Dating+Violence%3A+A+Descriptive+Analysis&amp;rft.au=Heidi+Adams+Rueda%3BHawley%2C+Alicia%3BBlack%2C+Beverly+M%3BOmbayo%2C+Bernadette&amp;rft.aulast=Heidi+Adams+Rueda&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=203&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Advances+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15278565&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Towards Recognition and Analysis of the Field of Family Studies

Author: Hartman, Deborah1; Crofts, Penny21 Family Action Centre, Faculty of Health and Medicine, University of Newcastle, Newcastle, NSW, Australia2 Penny Crofts Consulting

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 77, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2016): 407.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1919588109?accountid=14667

Abstract: This Bourdieusian field analysis of Family Studies in Australia as a social field in which the criteria for recognition of a discipline and establishment of a discipline in a university context operate as field structures is shaping what is possible within the field. Many applied social science disciplines are very subject to the power of the state and are hierarchically organised. Knowing the strategic actions of players in the field can operate to stabilise or bring about change in a discipline by disrupting this hierarchical organisation. The authors conclude that the establishment of the academic discipline of Family Studies at the University of Newcastle was a strategic move in the Australian context, which was possible because of the collaborative relationships within the Global Consortium for International Family Studies. This move shifted the power relations and brought about a unique contribution to the study of families in Australia, which has great potential to strengthen the autonomy of the field in Australia and globally.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Towards+Recognition+and+Analysis+of+the+Field+of+Family+Studies&amp;rft.au=Hartman%2C+Deborah%3BCrofts%2C+Penny&amp;rft.aulast=Hartman&amp;rft.aufirst=Deborah&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=77&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=407&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Author: Prasad, B Devi1; Juvva, Srilatha2; Nayar, Mahima3; Nagchoudhuri, Madhura11 Centre for Equity and Justice for Children and Families, School of Social Work (SSW)2 Centre for Disability Studies and Action, SSW, TISS, Mumbai3 International Family Studies Programme, TISS, Mumbai

Media, Technology and Family: Exploring the Dynamics of Interactions

Author: Nair, Tara11 Gujarat Institute of Development Research, Ahmedabad

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 77, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2016): 387.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1919588152?accountid=14667

Abstract: Indian media system has undergone profound transformation since the 1990s as private television and digital media entered the country riding on the wave of economic reform and restructuring. The country has witnessed the hegemonic rise of the mid- die class, progressive retreat of the state from the provisioning of basic services and increasing relative poverty gap, increased cross border flows of goods and services, including from culture industries as also the emergence of cities as critical arenas of articulation of neoliberalism and the attendant modernism. However, there has not been much appreciation of the ways in which these changes in the environment have Influenced an important and foundational unit of social organisation - family. This Is partly due to the fact that understanding of family is hugely contested in the country, as there is wide diversity of family systems - complex phenomena of kinship behaviour and values and norms - across regions, castes, classes, communities and individual life cycles. Such analytical challenge notwithstanding, this paper attempts to critically review the existing scholarship on the pathways of influence that link family and the cultural institution of media in the light of the significant technological revolution in the sphere of communications as also shifts in the political economy of policy making In India. The paper specifically focusses on television and digital media.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Media%2C+Technology+and+Family%3A+Exploring+the+Dynamics+of+Interactions&amp;rft.au=Nair%2C+Tara&amp;rft.aulast=Nair&amp;rft.aufirst=Tara&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=77&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=387&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Media%2C+Technology+and+Family%3A+Exploring+the+Dynamics+of+Interactions&amp;rft.au=Nair%2C+Tara&amp;rft.aulast=Nair&amp;rft.aufirst=Tara&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=77&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=387&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Teaching and Practice of Family Social Work: Insights from Nepal School of Social Work

Author: Nikku, Bala Raju1; Kadambari, Pradipta21 Founding Chairperson of the Nepal School of Social Work2 Kadambari Memorial College of Science and Management

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 77, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2016): 479.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1919588227?accountid=14667

Abstract: A decade long history of internal conflict from 1996 to 2006 in Nepal was followed by a ten-year transition period towards establishing peace. Political transitions led to the out migration of thousands of men and women in search of work, thus altering family structure and the social fabric of Nepal. The mega earthquakes of 2015, which resulted in more than 10,000 deaths and severely damaged the cultural heritage and essential infrastructures such as homes, schools and hospitals, Impacted the well-being of thousands of families. This paper looks at the role played by the Nepal School of Social Work In addressing the decade long societal conflicts and the aftermath of the earthquake that shook the social, political, cultural and economic fabric of families in Nepal. The paper highlights the constructive role played by professional social workers with families in post conflict and disaster prone Nepal.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Teaching+and+Practice+of+Family+Social+Work%3A+Insights+from+Nepal+School+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Nikku%2C+Bala+Raju%3BKadambari%2C+Pradipta&amp;rft.aulast=Nikku&amp;rft.aufirst=Bala&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=77&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=479&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Teaching+and+Practice+of+Family+Social+Work%3A+Insights+from+Nepal+School+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Nikku%2C+Bala+Raju%3BKadambari%2C+Pradipta&amp;rft.aulast=Nikku&amp;rft.aufirst=Bala&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=77&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=479&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Enhancing Family Agency through Family-Centered Practices

Author: Bischoff, Richard J1; Springer, Paul R2; Baker, Gina31 Department Chair of Child, Youth and Family Studies at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln2 Department of Child, Youth and Family Studies at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln3 Boone County C.A.R.E. Team Member

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 77, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2016): 425.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1919588318?accountid=14667

Abstract: The use of approaches that are family-centered increase impact of programmes and practices on families, individuals, communities and societies. Through this article, the authors describe what family-centered practices are and how they enhance impact. The characteristics of family-centered approaches (that is, family as the unit of attention, emphasise family strengths, facilitate family agency, encourage collaborative family-professional worker relationships, and programmes and practices that are flexible enough to meet individual family needs) are described and illustrated through an example of an initiative in the United States to address mental health disparities in rural communities.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Enhancing+Family+Agency+through+Family-Centered+Practices&amp;rft.au=Bischoff%2C+Richard+J%3BSpringer%2C+Paul+R%3BBaker%2C+Gina&amp;rft.aulast=Bischoff&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=77&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=425&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Making Sense: Familial Journeys towards Acceptance of Gay and Lesbian Family Members in India

Author: Ranade, Ketki1; Shah, Chavanika2; Chatierjee, Sangeeta31 Center for Health and Mental Health, Tata Institute of Social Sciences (TISS)2 TISS3 School of Social Work, Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 77, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2016): 437.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1919588519?accountid=14667

Abstract: Initial responses of family members to `coming out' or finding out' the same-sex sexual orientation of their children include disappointment, disapproval, shock, rejection, hostility and even violence. Several factors structural, interpersonal and personal-play a role in the journeys that families undertake in `making sense' of same-sex sexuality of a family member. The current study employs a qualitative exploratory method to document these familial processes and their complexities along with factors that Influence these journeys. Twenty-two family members (parents and siblings) in the city of Mumbai (erstwhile Bombay), India having a gay/lesbian, child/sibling, were interviewed for the present study. Most of the existing research in India is focused on the gay or lesbian persons themselves and familial responses have received attention only through the experiences of the gay or lesbian person. The current study would thus start a dialogue on an area hitherto unexplored.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Making+Sense%3A+Familial+Journeys+towards+Acceptance+of+Gay+and+Lesbian+Family+Members+in+India&amp;rft.au=Ranade%2C+Ketki%3BShah%2C+Chavanika%3BChatierjee%2C+Sangeeta&amp;rft.aulast=Ranade&amp;rft.aufirst=Ketki&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=77&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=437&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Making+Sense%3A+Familial+Journeys+towards+Acceptance+of+Gay+and+Lesbian+Family+Members+in+India&amp;rft.au=Ranade%2C+Ketki%3BShah%2C+Chavanika%3BChatierjee%2C+Sangeeta&amp;rft.aulast=Ranade&amp;rft.aufirst=Ketki&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=77&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=437&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Subject: Families & family life; Lesbianism; Sexual preferences; Research responses; Acceptance; Siblings; Hostility; Homosexuality; Children; Sexuality; Gays & lesbians; Parents; Family

Title: Making Sense: Familial Journeys towards Acceptance of Gay and Lesbian Family Members in India

Women, Family and the Everyday Struggle in a Contested Space: A Case of Kashmir

Author: Faheem, Fahrukh11 Centre for Community Organisation and Development Practice, School of Social Work, Tata Institute of Social Sciences, Mumbai

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 77, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2016): 491.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1919588695?accountid=14667

Abstract: The uprising in Jammu and Kashmir in the early 1990s against the Indian rule, subsequent militarisation, and the clampdowns on protesting population followed by long curfews and violence, affected the everyday life in Kashmir. The presence of enhanced Indian armed forces and the vulnerability of male members to detention and disappearance have stretched the traditional roles played out by Kashmiri women. Consequently, these roles have impacted social relations and familial obligations. In this paper, I argue that in contested spaces, violence often has repercussions on family organisation and such influences become a part of the larger patterns of change witnessed In the socio-political order. As political contestations Increase, the conventional lines of difference between the domestic realm of the family and the public domain of politics vanishes. My attempt is to capture the tensions between the domestic realm of the family and the public realm of politics and how political contestations enter the domestic domain of the family and produce new contexts for social relations. This paper is based on my field experience of working with the victims of state violence including the families of the victims of enforced disappearances associated with the Association of Parents of Disappeared Persons (APDP) in Kashmir.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Women%2C+Family+and+the+Everyday+Struggle+in+a+Contested+Space%3A+A+Case+of+Kashmir&amp;rft.au=Faheem%2C+Fahrukh&amp;rft.aulast=Faheem&amp;rft.aufirst=Fahrukh&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=77&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=491&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Women%2C+Family+and+the+Everyday+Struggle+in+a+Contested+Space%3A+A+Case+of+Kashmir&amp;rft.au=Faheem%2C+Fahrukh&amp;rft.aulast=Faheem&amp;rft.aufirst=Fahrukh&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=77&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=491&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Families They Choose: Examining the Hijra Family and Relations

Author: Aasaavari, Asmita1; Mohapatra, Sushreeta2; Sharma, Aarushie31 Lokniti-Centre for the Study of Developing Societies (CSDS), Delhi2 freelance writer3 M.Phil in Sociology from Department of Sociology, Delhi School of Economics, University of Delhi

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 77, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2016): 459.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1919588714?accountid=14667

Abstract: Challenging the dominant definitions of hetero-normative families, the present paper throws light on families epitomised by hijras, who, often as a result of rejection by their natal families, come to form their own kinship networks and so far have not been covered in the existing body of scholarship on alternative family arrangements. Based on ethnographic data and narratives collected from hijra deras of Delhi, this paper seeks to discuss the nuances of families outside of a 'monolithic understanding' of family. The broad argument of the paper revolves around the role played by families of choice in the building of the hijra identity and also deepening and enriching the existing discourse on families in India.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Families+They+Choose%3A+Examining+the+Hijra+Family+and+Relations&amp;rft.au=Aasaavari%2C+Asmita%3BMohapatra%2C+Sushreeta%3BSharma%2C+Aarushie&amp;rft.aulast=Aasaavari&amp;rft.aufirst=Asmita&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=77&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=459&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Families+They+Choose%3A+Examining+the+Hijra+Family+and+Relations&amp;rft.au=Aasaavari%2C+Asmita%3BMohapatra%2C+Sushreeta%3BSharma%2C+Aarushie&amp;rft.aulast=Aasaavari&amp;rft.aufirst=Asmita&amp;rft.date=2016-10-01&amp;rft.volume=77&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=459&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

High-Impact Social Work Scholars

Author: Hodge, David R; Kremer, Kristen P; Vaughn, Michael G

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 26, Iss. 7,  (Nov 2016): 751-761.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1824036752?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objective: The purpose of this study was to identify and describe the bibliometric contributions of high-impact social work faculty. Methods: Toward this end, we used a sample comprising fellows ( N = 143) affiliated with the Society for Social Work and Research (SSWR) and the American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare (AASWSW). To quantify impact, we relied primarily upon the h-index (a measure of lifetime scholarly impact) and the m-index (which adjusts for career length). Results: Analyses revealed the mean h-index value for SSWR fellows ( M = 26.44, SD = 14.72) was substantially lower than the mean for AASWSW fellows ( M = 32.52, SD = 15.96), but minimal differences existed in m-index values. H- and m-index values for the 40 highest impact scholars ranged, respectively, from 33 to 93 and 1.13 to 3.33. Conclusions: The results indicate the social work profession includes many researchers who are making an exceptional scientific impact.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=High-Impact+Social+Work+Scholars%3A+A+Bibliometric+Examination+of+SSWR+and+AASWSW+Fellows&amp;rft.au=Hodge%2C+David+R%3BKremer%2C+Kristen+P%3BVaughn%2C+Michael+G&amp;rft.aulast=Hodge&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=751&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731516645929

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=High-Impact+Social+Work+Scholars%3A+A+Bibliometric+Examination+of+SSWR+and+AASWSW+Fellows&amp;rft.au=Hodge%2C+David+R%3BKremer%2C+Kristen+P%3BVaughn%2C+Michael+G&amp;rft.aulast=Hodge&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=751&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731516645929

"Thank You, Sorry, Love" (TSL) Therapy With North Korean Refugee Women

Author: Kim, Hee Jin; Kim, Jae Yop; Kim, Dong Goo

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 26, Iss. 7,  (Nov 2016): 816-824.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1824036767?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objectives: This study was designed to evaluate the effectiveness of The "Thank You, Sorry, Love" (TSL) family therapy program in potentially improving the marital relationships and health of North Korean refugee women. Methods: The participants included 12 married North Korean female refugees in their 20s to 40s. Using a blinded assignment, six received the TSL family therapy program and six did not receive any treatment. Pretests (just before the program), posttests (just after termination of the program), and follow-up tests (1 month after termination of the program) were conducted. Results: The program participants experienced a statistically significant decrease in marital violence and an increase in their total antioxidant activity levels. Conclusions: TSL family therapy has the potential to contribute to improving the lives of traumatized North Korean refugee women. Larger scale replication studies involving random assignment would be a useful next step in evaluating the TSL program.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=%22Thank+You%2C+Sorry%2C+Love%22+%28TSL%29+Therapy+With+North+Korean+Refugee+Women%3A+A+Pilot+Study&amp;rft.au=Kim%2C+Hee+Jin%3BKim%2C+Jae+Yop%3BKim%2C+Dong+Goo&amp;rft.aulast=Kim&amp;rft.aufirst=Hee&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=816&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731515570137

Measures of Consumer Satisfaction in Social Welfare and Behavioral Health

Author: Fraser, Mark W; Wu, Shiyou

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 26, Iss. 7,  (Nov 2016): 762-776.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1824036779?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reviews the origins, conceptual bases, psychometric properties, and limitations of consumer satisfaction measures in social welfare and behavioral health. Based on a systematic review of research reports published between 2003 and 2013, we identify 58 consumer satisfaction measures. On average, these measures have acceptable reliability (mean Cronbach's α = .85). However, the research on the concurrent and predictive validity of consumer satisfaction is inconclusive. We identify the following three core aspects of consumer satisfaction: (a) satisfaction with alternative elements of service, (b) promotion or recommendation of a program based on a recent service experience, and (c) subjective appraisal of change or problem resolution related to participation in a service. Attrition bias, reactivity, and confounding of ratings with the image of service providers complicate and condition the interpretation of consumer satisfaction as an outcome measure.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Measures+of+Consumer+Satisfaction+in+Social+Welfare+and+Behavioral+Health%3A+A+Systematic+Review&amp;rft.au=Fraser%2C+Mark+W%3BWu%2C+Shiyou&amp;rft.aulast=Fraser&amp;rft.aufirst=Mark&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=762&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514564990

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Measures+of+Consumer+Satisfaction+in+Social+Welfare+and+Behavioral+Health%3A+A+Systematic+Review&amp;rft.au=Fraser%2C+Mark+W%3BWu%2C+Shiyou&amp;rft.aulast=Fraser&amp;rft.aufirst=Mark&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=762&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514564990

Attrition in Psychotherapy

Author: Roseborough, David John; McLeod, Jeffrey T; Wright, Florence I

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 26, Iss. 7,  (Nov 2016): 803-815.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1824036785?accountid=14667

Abstract: Purpose: Attrition is a common problem in psychotherapy and can be defined as clients ending treatment before achieving an optimal response. Method: This longitudinal, archival study utilized data for 3,728 clients, using the Outcome Questionnaire 45.2. A Cox regression proportional hazards (hazard ratios) model was used in order to better understand who is likely to attrit when considering (1) demographics, (2) diagnostic categories, and (3) process variables (e.g., recent symptom change). Results: A pattern emerged, with younger clients and those reporting less education and lower incomes being more likely to end. Clients who demonstrated a recent status change were more likely to remain in treatment. Discussion: Consistent with the large-scale STAR*D study, clients with more social and economic challenges demonstrated more risk. Adults diagnosed with a substance or obsessive compulsive disorder-related disorder showed the most elevated risk. Engagement strategies are discussed, with the goal of better supporting recovery.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Attrition+in+Psychotherapy%3A+A+Survival+Analysis&amp;rft.au=Roseborough%2C+David+John%3BMcLeod%2C+Jeffrey+T%3BWright%2C+Florence+I&amp;rft.aulast=Roseborough&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=803&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731515569073

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Attrition+in+Psychotherapy%3A+A+Survival+Analysis&amp;rft.au=Roseborough%2C+David+John%3BMcLeod%2C+Jeffrey+T%3BWright%2C+Florence+I&amp;rft.aulast=Roseborough&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=803&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731515569073

____________________________________________________________

Social Work Science and Knowledge Utilization

Author: Marsh, Jeanne C; Reed, Martena

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 26, Iss. 7,  (Nov 2016): 742-750.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1824036860?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objective: This article advances understanding of social work science by examining the content and methods of highly utilized or cited journal articles in social work. Methods: A data base of the 100 most frequently cited articles from 79 social work journals was coded and categorized into three primary domains: content, research versus nonresearch, and, for research articles only, method used. Results: Findings show that knowledge utilization occurs on a conceptual level (related to professional developments, theory, and service needs of specific populations) as well as an instrumental level (such as related to intervention effectiveness). Fifty-one percent of highly cited articles were empirical and, of these, 33% relied on descriptive methods, 45% on explanatory methods, and 22% on control methods used primarily to study intervention effectiveness. Conclusion: Operationalizing the utilization of scientific knowledge in terms of the demand for specific journal articles reveals the content and methodological domains that characterize extant social work science. Six strategies in research, practice, and education are proposed to advance the further development of social work science.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+Science+and+Knowledge+Utilization&amp;rft.au=Marsh%2C+Jeanne+C%3BReed%2C+Martena&amp;rft.aulast=Marsh&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeanne&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=742&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731515604733

Head Start Impact on Social-Emotional Outcomes for Children With Disabilities

Author: Lee, Kyunghee; Calkins, Andrea; Shin, Tae Seob

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 26, Iss. 7,  (Nov 2016): 790-802.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1824036890?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objective: Using the Head Start Impact Study data, this study examines Head Start's impacts on social-emotional outcomes for children with disabilities. Method: Among 4,442 children, 570 children were reported to have disabilities. Ordinary least squares regression was used to determine whether the number of disabilities, having an individualized education plan (IEP), and receiving Supplemental Security Income (SSI) affect social-emotional outcomes for children with disabilities and whether Head Start's impact differs depending on these factors. Results: Children with multiple disabilities, an IEP, and SSI had lower social-emotional scores. Head Start impact was found for the following subgroups: children with no disabilities, children who never received an IEP, children living in a higher income household, and Black children. Conclusions: Head Start should identify potential disabilities early and support the provision of adequate services to increase social-emotional outcomes for children with disabilities.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Head+Start+Impact+on+Social-Emotional+Outcomes+for+Children+With+Disabilities&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Kyunghee%3BCalkins%2C+Andrea%3BShin%2C+Tae+Seob&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Kyunghee&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=790&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514568024

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Head+Start+Impact+on+Social-Emotional+Outcomes+for+Children+With+Disabilities&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Kyunghee%3BCalkins%2C+Andrea%3BShin%2C+Tae+Seob&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Kyunghee&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=790&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514568024

Feasibility of Virtual Reality Environments for Adolescent Social Anxiety Disorder

Author: Parrish, Danielle E; Oxhandler, Holly K; Duron, Jacuelynn F; Swank, Paul; Bordnick, Patrick

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 26, Iss. 7,  (Nov 2016): 825-835.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1824036967?accountid=14667

Abstract: Purpose: This study assessed the feasibility of virtual reality (VR) exposure as an assessment and treatment modality for youth with social anxiety disorder (SAD). Methods: Forty-one adolescents, 20 of which were identified as having SAD, were recruited from a community sample. Youth with and without SAD were exposed to two social virtual environments--party and public speaking--and two neutral virtual environments. Results: All youth reported significantly higher ratings on the Subjective Units of Distress Scale (SUDS) during the party and public speaking scenarios compared to the two neutral environments, while youth with SAD reported significantly higher SUDS in the public speaking and party environments than those without SAD. Youth also demonstrated acceptable levels of presence and immersion in the VR environments. Discussion: VR exposure treatment appears to be feasible for youth with SAD, highlighting the need for further research on its development.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Feasibility+of+Virtual+Reality+Environments+for+Adolescent+Social+Anxiety+Disorder&amp;rft.au=Parrish%2C+Danielle+E%3BOxhandler%2C+Holly+K%3BDuron%2C+Jacuelynn+F%3BSwank%2C+Paul%3BBordnick%2C+Patrick&amp;rft.aulast=Parrish&amp;rft.aufirst=Danielle&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=825&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514568897

Medical Surveillance and Child Maltreatment Incidence Reporting among NICU Graduates

Author: Owora, Arthur1; Chaffin, Mark2; Nandyal, Raja2; Risch, Elizabeth2; Bonner, Barbara2; Carabin, Hélène31 Department of Pediatrics, University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, USA; College of Public Health, University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, USA2 Department of Pediatrics, University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, USA3 College of Public Health, University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 7,  (Nov/Dec 2016): 607-616.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827659913?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objective of this study is to identify background infant and maternal characteristics that predict child maltreatment (CM) incidence reporting among Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) graduates by health care providers versus community sentinels with the goal of identifying ways to improve CM risk surveillance. Demographic, medical data including diagnoses and caregiving needs at discharge for infants treated in a NICU during 2005 to 2008 were obtained from the neonatology databases. CM outcome data was obtained from child welfare databases. Latent class analysis procedures were used to identify observable infant and maternal characteristics that define unobserved groups (latent classes) that predict NICU graduates CM incidence reporting among health care providers versus community sentinels. Medical surveillance (reports made by health care providers) accounted for only 37% of the CM reports made to child welfare. Infant health was more predictive of medical surveillance than maternal characteristics suggesting that health providers may assess risk differently than community sentinels. Based on a simple, two latent class model, the latent class with high infant health indicator membership probabilities was a better predictor of health care provider related reports than the class with lower membership probabilities (odds ratio = 2.72; 95% confidence interval [1.76, 4.20]). Health care providers may be keyed more to an infant's medical frailty than to caregiver (maternal) contextual characteristics and thus may miss an opportunity to identify and intervene to prevent CM among children with medical problems. Findings raise the question of whether increased attention to contextual factors can aid or increase early identification of infants at risk of child maltreatment in NICU settings.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Medical+Surveillance+and+Child+Maltreatment+Incidence+Reporting+among+NICU+Graduates&amp;rft.au=Owora%2C+Arthur%3BChaffin%2C+Mark%3BNandyal%2C+Raja%3BRisch%2C+Elizabeth%3BBonner%2C+Barbara%3BCarabin%2C+H%C3%A9l%C3%A8ne&amp;rft.aulast=Owora&amp;rft.aufirst=Arthur&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=607&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2016.1160348

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Medical+Surveillance+and+Child+Maltreatment+Incidence+Reporting+among+NICU+Graduates&amp;rft.au=Owora%2C+Arthur%3BChaffin%2C+Mark%3BNandyal%2C+Raja%3BRisch%2C+Elizabeth%3BBonner%2C+Barbara%3BCarabin%2C+H%C3%A9l%C3%A8ne&amp;rft.aulast=Owora&amp;rft.aufirst=Arthur&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=607&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2016.1160348

The Challenges Encountered by Immigrant-Serving Agencies in Addressing the Health of Temporary Foreign Workers

Author: Salami, Bukola1; Kirova, Anna2; Hegadoren, Kathleen1; Meherali, Salima1; Chiu, Yvonne3; Nsaliwa, Christina41 Faculty of Nursing, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada2 Faculty of Education, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada3 Multicultural Health Brokers Co-op, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada4 Edmonton Immigrant Services Association, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 7,  (Nov/Dec 2016): 599-606.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827659949?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study sought to examine the challenges encountered by immigrant-serving agencies in meeting the health needs of temporary foreign workers and their families in one Canadian province. The authors interviewed 11 representatives of immigrant-serving agencies and two policy makers. Some of the challenges that agencies face in delivering programs and services for temporary foreign workers and their families include the time required to build trust with this population, temporary foreign workers' reluctance to use services due to fear that it will affect their immigration status, and the emotional labor associated with working with temporary foreign workers.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=The+Challenges+Encountered+by+Immigrant-Serving+Agencies+in+Addressing+the+Health+of+Temporary+Foreign+Workers&amp;rft.au=Salami%2C+Bukola%3BKirova%2C+Anna%3BHegadoren%2C+Kathleen%3BMeherali%2C+Salima%3BChiu%2C+Yvonne%3BNsaliwa%2C+Christina&amp;rft.aulast=Salami&amp;rft.aufirst=Bukola&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=599&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2016.1160347

The Role of Diabetes in Predicting Employment Status for Individuals with Bipolar Disorder

Author: O'Neill, Elizabeth A11 School of Social Welfare, University of Kansas, Lawrence, Kansas, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 7,  (Nov/Dec 2016): 646-655.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827659954?accountid=14667

Abstract: Diabetes is a growing public health concern for the general population, but individuals with bipolar disorder (BPD) are at increased risk. There is a dearth of research investigating how diabetes affects outcomes for those with BPD. Using data from the 2012 National Health Interview Survey, this study investigates the relationship between diabetes and employment for individuals with BPD (N = 748). Logistic regression results indicated among individuals with BPD, the odds of being unemployed were approximately 3.5 times higher for those with diabetes compared to those without diabetes. Relevant policy considerations and implications for professionals are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=The+Role+of+Diabetes+in+Predicting+Employment+Status+for+Individuals+with+Bipolar+Disorder&amp;rft.au=O%27Neill%2C+Elizabeth+A&amp;rft.aulast=O%27Neill&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=646&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2016.1160351

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=The+Role+of+Diabetes+in+Predicting+Employment+Status+for+Individuals+with+Bipolar+Disorder&amp;rft.au=O%27Neill%2C+Elizabeth+A&amp;rft.aulast=O%27Neill&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=646&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2016.1160351

Immigrant Health in Toronto, Canada: Addressing Food Insecurity as a Social Determinant of Tuberculosis

Author: Burgess, Danielle11 Faculty of Social Work, University of Toronto, Toronto, Ontario, Canada

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 7,  (Nov/Dec 2016): 617-625.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827659966?accountid=14667

Abstract: In Canada, tuberculosis is 20 times more likely to be experienced by new immigrants than by Canadian citizens. Food insecurity, which has implications for developing tuberculosis, is linked to poverty and immigration status and has costly implications for individuals and public health. This article explores the history of the Ontario government's failure to adequately address poverty and food insecurity and the role of social work in addressing these issues. Recommendations for addressing food insecurity at a policy level include increasing the rate and goals of the Ontario Works program. Implications for new immigrants, tuberculosis and public health are explored.

Prevalence of Violence: Male and Female Seasonal Agricultural Workers' Approach to Violence in Turkey

Author: Simsek, Zeynep1; Kara, Burcu1; Ersin, Fatma2; Ökten, Sevket3; Yildirimkaya, Gökhan41 Faculty of Medicine, Public Health Department, Yenisehir Campus, Harran University, Sanliurfa, Turkey2 Department of Community Health Nursing, Harran Universty School of Nursing, Sanliurfa, Turkey3 Department of Sociology, Osmanbey Campus, Harran University Science Faculty, Sanliurfa, Turkey4 United Nations Population Fund, Ankara, Turkey

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 7,  (Nov/Dec 2016): 626-637.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827659969?accountid=14667

Abstract: The objective of this study is to determine the male and female seasonal agricultural workers' perception of violence, prevalence of violence, frequency of victimization, and their related factors. Quantitative and qualitative data were used, and 89.5% of women were exposed to violence that included the restriction of their human rights. The sample consisted of 1,211 women and 1,064 men. Their marital status, duration of work, and attention to their health affected the violence exposure. Arabic people who were unmarried, had a poor educational background, and poor health perception approved of the physical violence.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Prevalence+of+Violence%3A+Male+and+Female+Seasonal+Agricultural+Workers%27+Approach+to+Violence+in+Turkey&amp;rft.au=Simsek%2C+Zeynep%3BKara%2C+Burcu%3BErsin%2C+Fatma%3B%C3%96kten%2C+Sevket%3BYildirimkaya%2C+G%C3%B6khan&amp;rft.aulast=Simsek&amp;rft.aufirst=Zeynep&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=626&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1137520

The Role of Social Work for Foreign Residents in an Epidemic: The MERS Crisis in the Republic of Korea

Author: Park, Hong-Jae1; Lee, Bong Joo21 School of Counselling, Human Services and Social Work, Faculty of Education and Social Work, The University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand2 Department of Social Welfare, Seoul National University, Seoul, Republic of Korea

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 7,  (Nov/Dec 2016): 656-664.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827659982?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article explores the experiences of foreign residents during the period of the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) outbreak in (South) Korea and discusses from a social work perspective the implications of their experiences and their needs. Data were obtained from interviews with 22 foreigners who either live and work or study in Korea. The data were then interpreted using a thematic analysis approach in a multilingual research context. The findings from the study show that foreign residents experienced a wide range of social and psychoemotional difficulties during the MERS health threat. Implications for social work practice in an epidemic emergency are presented.

A Comparison of Opioid and Nonopioid Substance Users in Residential Treatment for Co-Occurring Substance Use and Mental Disorders

Author: Bride, Brian E1; Macmaster, Samuel A2; Morse, Siobhan A3; Watson, Cayce M4; Choi, Sam5; Seiters, John31 School of Social Work, Georgia State University, Atlanta, Georgia, USA2 Department of Family and Community Medicine, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, Texas, USA3 Foundations Recovery Network, Brentwood, Tennessee, USA4 Department of Social Work and Sociology, Lipscomb University, Nashville, Tennessee, USA5 College of Social Work, University of Tennessee, Nashville, Tennessee, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 7,  (Nov/Dec 2016): 678-687.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827659983?accountid=14667

Abstract: The past decade has seen a marked increase in the illicit use of opioids, as well as a doubling of the percentage of individuals seeking treatment for opioid use disorders. However, little is known about the differences between opioid users and nonopioid users in residential treatment. Further, no studies have been published that compare opioid users and nonopioid users in treatment for co-occurring substance use and mental disorders. To address this gap, this study examined differences between opioid and nonopioid substance users in residential treatment for co-occurring disorders. Data was drawn from 1,972 individuals treated between 2009 and 2011 at one of three private residential treatment centers that provide integrated treatment for co-occurring substance use and mental disorders. Data was collected at program intake, and 1- and 6-month postdischarge using the Addiction Severity Index and the University of Rhode Island Change Assessment. To examine within-group changes in substance use, addiction severity, and mental health across time, linear mixed-model analyses were conducted with facility, year, age, gender, and race included as covariates. The authors found more similarities than differences between the two groups on baseline characteristics, treatment motivation, length of stay, and outcomes on measures of substance use, addiction severity, and mental health. The results demonstrate that though opioid users entered treatment with higher levels of substance use-related impairment, they were just as successful in treatment outcomes as their non-opioid-using peers.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=A+Comparison+of+Opioid+and+Nonopioid+Substance+Users+in+Residential+Treatment+for+Co-Occurring+Substance+Use+and+Mental+Disorders&amp;rft.au=Bride%2C+Brian+E%3BMacmaster%2C+Samuel+A%3BMorse%2C+Siobhan+A%3BWatson%2C+Cayce+M%3BChoi%2C+Sam%3BSeiters%2C+John&amp;rft.aulast=Bride&amp;rft.aufirst=Brian&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=678&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2016.1188738

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=A+Comparison+of+Opioid+and+Nonopioid+Substance+Users+in+Residential+Treatment+for+Co-Occurring+Substance+Use+and+Mental+Disorders&amp;rft.au=Bride%2C+Brian+E%3BMacmaster%2C+Samuel+A%3BMorse%2C+Siobhan+A%3BWatson%2C+Cayce+M%3BChoi%2C+Sam%3BSeiters%2C+John&amp;rft.aulast=Bride&amp;rft.aufirst=Brian&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=678&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2016.1188738

Hospital Social Work and Spirituality: Views of Medical Social Workers

Author: Pandya, Samta P11 Tata Institute of Social Sciences, Mumbai, India

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 7,  (Nov/Dec 2016): 700-710.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827659984?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article is based on a study of 1,389 medical social workers in 108 hospitals across 12 countries, on their views on spirituality and spiritually sensitive interventions in hospital settings. Results of the logistic regression analyses and structural equation models showed that medical social workers from European countries, United States of America, Canada, and Australia, those had undergone spiritual training, and those who had higher self-reported spiritual experiences scale scores were more likely to have the view that spirituality in hospital settings is for facilitating integral healing and wellness of patients and were more likely to prefer spiritual packages of New Age movements as the form of spiritual program, understand spiritual assessment as assessing the patients' spiritual starting point, to then build on further interventions and were likely to attest the understanding of spiritual techniques as mindfulness techniques. Finally they were also likely to understand the spiritual goals of intervention in a holistic way, that is, as that of integral healing, growth of consciousness and promoting overall well-being of patients vis-à-vis only coping and coming to terms with health adversities. Results of the structural equation models also showed covariances between religion, spirituality training, and scores on the self-reported spiritual experiences scale, having thus a set of compounding effects on social workers' views on spiritual interventions in hospitals. The implications of the results for health care social work practice and curriculum are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Hospital+Social+Work+and+Spirituality%3A+Views+of+Medical+Social+Workers&amp;rft.au=Pandya%2C+Samta+P&amp;rft.aulast=Pandya&amp;rft.aufirst=Samta&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=700&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2016.1188740

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Hospital+Social+Work+and+Spirituality%3A+Views+of+Medical+Social+Workers&amp;rft.au=Pandya%2C+Samta+P&amp;rft.aulast=Pandya&amp;rft.aufirst=Samta&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=700&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2016.1188740

____________________________________________________________

"Not Homeless Yet. I'm Kind of Couch Surfing": Finding Identities for People at a Homeless Shelter

Author: Terui, Sachiko1; Hsieh, Elaine11 Department of Communication, University of Oklahoma, Norman, Oklahoma, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 7,  (Nov/Dec 2016): 688-699.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827659998?accountid=14667

Abstract: The meanings of homelessness are fluid and socially constructed, providing resources and limitations for individuals to negotiate their identities and relationships in everyday life. In this study, we examine the strategies and corresponding resources utilized by people who are homeless to cope with the labeling of a homeless identity and to redefine their identities. We used constant comparative analysis to examine in-depth interviews with 16 participants (male = 11, female = 5) who access a local homeless shelter in the southwest United States for resources. We identified three strategies that homeless people adopt to cope with the labeling of homeless identity: (a) differentiating oneself from others who are homeless, (b) prioritizing certain aspects of life, and (c) embracing the status of homelessness. Although these strategies have been identified in previous literature, the authors extend this line of research by identifying the common resources people who are homeless utilize when adopting these strategies, which entail important implications for theory development and practical implications.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=%22Not+Homeless+Yet.+I%27m+Kind+of+Couch+Surfing%22%3A+Finding+Identities+for+People+at+a+Homeless+Shelter&amp;rft.au=Terui%2C+Sachiko%3BHsieh%2C+Elaine&amp;rft.aulast=Terui&amp;rft.aufirst=Sachiko&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=688&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2016.1188739

Negotiation, Mediation and Communication between Cultures: End-of-Life Care for South Asian Immigrants in Canada from the Perspective of Family Caregivers

Author: Weerasinghe, Swarna1; Maddalena, Victor21 Community Health and Epidemiology, Dalhousie University, Centre for Clinical Research, Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada2 Faculty of Medicine, Division of Community Health and Humanities, Memorial University of Newfoundland, St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 7,  (Nov/Dec 2016): 665-677.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827660003?accountid=14667

Abstract: In the present study, we explored family caregivers' experiences in providing end-of-life care for terminally ill South Asian immigrants. We employed qualitative methods and. in-depth interviews were conducted with seven family caregivers living in Nova Scotia, Canada. Interview data were validated, coded and organized for themes. Three major themes identified in the data illustrated (a) how South Asian caregivers experienced clashes between biomedical and ethno-cultural realms of care that led to cultural insensitivity, (b) how family members acted as mediators, and (c) how communication issues that challenged cultural sensitivity were handled. Findings provide directions for culturally sensitive end-of-life care planning.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Negotiation%2C+Mediation+and+Communication+between+Cultures%3A+End-of-Life+Care+for+South+Asian+Immigrants+in+Canada+from+the+Perspective+of+Family+Caregivers&amp;rft.au=Weerasinghe%2C+Swarna%3BMaddalena%2C+Victor&amp;rft.aulast=Weerasinghe&amp;rft.aufirst=Swarna&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=665&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2015.1137521

Analysis of Community Participation Levels of Individuals Who Are Physically Disabled and Working in Industrial Environments

Author: Tonak, Hasan Atacan1; Kitis, Ali2; Zencir, Mehmet31 Istanbul Aydin University, Vocational School of Health Services, Sefaköy-Küçükçekmece, Istanbul, Turkey2 School of Physical Therapy and Rehabilitation, Pamukkale University, Denizli, Turkey3 Faculty of Medicine, Department of Public Health, Pamukkale University, Denizli, Turkey

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health ; Abingdon  Vol. 31, Iss. 7,  (Nov/Dec 2016): 638-645.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1827660009?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this study was to determine quality of life, leisure time satisfaction, activity performance, and community participation and analyze the relationship between these determinants and community participation in both physically disabled individuals working in industrial environments and nonworking individuals who are physically disabled. Sociodemographic data was registered into a sociodemographic form. World Health Organization Disability Assessment Schedule 2.0 was used to assess community participation. Activity performance was evaluated with Canadian Occupational Performance Measure. Leisure Satisfaction Scale was used to determine leisure time satisfaction. Short Form-36 was used for evaluating quality of life. When the participants were compared in terms of working status, a significant difference according to their WHO-DAS-II total scores were found (p  0.05). This study shows that community participation was affected by working status, disability level, activity performance, leisure time satisfaction and quality of life. In this regard, occupational therapy and physiotherapy approaches were found necessary for developing community participation. We conclude that this study's results can be used as a guide for community participation in disabled people in community based rehabilitation politics.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Analysis+of+Community+Participation+Levels+of+Individuals+Who+Are+Physically+Disabled+and+Working+in+Industrial+Environments&amp;rft.au=Tonak%2C+Hasan+Atacan%3BKitis%2C+Ali%3BZencir%2C+Mehmet&amp;rft.aulast=Tonak&amp;rft.aufirst=Hasan&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=638&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2016.1160336

Sexual Harassment in Social Work Field Placements

Author: Moylan, Carrie A1; Wood, Leila21 Department of Social Work, College of Community and Public Affairs, Binghamton University, Binghamton, NY, USA2 University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX, USA

Publication info: Affilia ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 31, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2016): 405-417.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1828420883?accountid=14667

Abstract: Addressing sexual harassment in educational environments is integral for Title IX compliance; however, there are few estimates of prevalence of the phenomenon in social work's signature pedagogy, field education. A survey of 515 bachelor of social work and master of social work students revealed that 55% of participants had experienced at least one incident of sexual harassment on the Sexual Experiences Questionnaire. Those participants who were younger, Latina/Hispanic, or in a committed relationship were more likely to report harassment. The most common perpetrators were other staff at the field placement and clients. Implications for social work education and practice are addressed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Sexual+Harassment+in+Social+Work+Field+Placements&amp;rft.au=Moylan%2C+Carrie+A%3BWood%2C+Leila&amp;rft.aulast=Moylan&amp;rft.aufirst=Carrie&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=405&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109916644643

Faith-Based Mental Health Interventions With African Americans

Author: Hays, Krystal; Aranda, Maria P

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 26, Iss. 7,  (Nov 2016): 777-789.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1830154768?accountid=14667

Abstract: Faith-based interventions have emerged culturally sensitive way to address mental health issues among African Americans. This systematic review explores the scope and efficacy of faith-based mental health intervention outcomes among African Americans. Extracted data included the study population, setting, study design, intervention, adaptations, outcome measures, data analysis, and results. Methodological quality and sociocultural adaptations were also examined. The literature search identified 627 articles from 9 targeted databases. Five studies met inclusion criteria for this review. All five studies reported improvement in mental health outcomes and most studies sought to increase knowledge of mental health issues. Intervention settings, outcomes of interest, age groups, and attention to sociocultural modifications varied greatly. This review highlights a gap in the literature regarding African Americans and faith-based interventions. We discuss the potential for collaboration between social work professionals and clergy and the need to make faith-based interventions more accessible.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Faith-Based+Mental+Health+Interventions+With+African+Americans%3A+A+Review&amp;rft.au=Hays%2C+Krystal%3BAranda%2C+Maria+P&amp;rft.aulast=Hays&amp;rft.aufirst=Krystal&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=777&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731515569356

Discourses about children's mental health and developmental disorders in North American women's magazines 1990-2012

Author: Clarke, Juanne; Mosleh, Donya; Janketic, Natasa

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2016): 391-400.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1831628319?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper describes and analyses the portrayal of children's mental health and developmental issues (CMHI) in articles located in a random sample of a selection of available high-circulating English language North American 'women's magazines' indexed in the Reader's Guide to Periodical Literature from 1990 to 2012. It is based upon a qualitative discourse analysis. CMHI are portrayed as materially, biologically real, prevalent and growing in incidence, and severity. They are also portrayed as located in the 'non-normal', 'non-nice', 'disliked' and 'non-successful' individual child. Neither the facticity nor the biomedicalization of CMHI is questioned. The psy-scientists and practitioners cited as experts for the 'disorders' offer contradictory and confusing information and advice. The possible theoretical and pragmatic explanations and consequences of this portrayal are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Discourses+about+children%27s+mental+health+and+developmental+disorders+in+North+American+women%27s+magazines+1990-2012&amp;rft.au=Clarke%2C+Juanne%3BMosleh%2C+Donya%3BJanketic%2C+Natasa&amp;rft.aulast=Clarke&amp;rft.aufirst=Juanne&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=391&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12155

Life satisfaction in the transition from care to adulthood: the contribution of readiness to leave care and social support

Author: Dinisman, Tamar

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2016): 401-411.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1831628331?accountid=14667

Abstract: This research explores whether readiness to leave care mediates the association between social support - from peers, staff and biological parents - on the verge of leaving care and life satisfaction a year after among young people ageing out of care in Israel. The results represent two waves of a longitudinal study. Two hundred seventy-two adolescents from residential settings in Israel completed a self-administered questionnaire shortly before they left care, and one year later, 234 of them were interviewed to assess their life satisfaction. Readiness to leave care was found to mediate the relationship between most social support measurements and life satisfaction. At the same time, the findings also suggest that this mediating effect varies for different types of support and has a lesser amount of influence for profound emotional support than other types of support. These findings highlight the need to include both the preparation to leave care and the reinforcement of emotional support available to young people who aged out of care, before and throughout the transition from care to adulthood.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Life+satisfaction+in+the+transition+from+care+to+adulthood%3A+the+contribution+of+readiness+to+leave+care+and+social+support&amp;rft.au=Dinisman%2C+Tamar&amp;rft.aulast=Dinisman&amp;rft.aufirst=Tamar&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=401&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12156

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Life+satisfaction+in+the+transition+from+care+to+adulthood%3A+the+contribution+of+readiness+to+leave+care+and+social+support&amp;rft.au=Dinisman%2C+Tamar&amp;rft.aulast=Dinisman&amp;rft.aufirst=Tamar&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=401&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12156

Contact visits between foster children and their birth family: the views of foster children, foster parents and social workers

Author: Salas Martinez, María D; Fuentes, María J; Bernedo, Isabel M; Garcia-Martin, Miguel A

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 21, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2016): 473-483.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1831628358?accountid=14667

Abstract: It has been argued that contact visits between foster children and birth parents can help maintain attachment bonds and support the child's development. However, some research suggests that such visits can be detrimental. This study analyses the characteristics of contact visits and examines children's perceptions of the emotional relationship they have with foster carers and their biological parents. Participants were 104 non-kinship foster children and their respective foster carers and social workers. Fifty-six of these foster children had contact visits with their birth parents. Foster children rated the quality of their relationship with foster carers and birth parents using the Affect Scale. Foster children, foster carers and social workers all completed the Evaluation of Contact Visits Questionnaire. Results showed that (i) a high proportion of children had no contact visits; (ii) the contact agreement was often not fulfilled; (iii) many visits were rated as poor quality; (iv) foster carers' evaluation of visits was more negative than that of both foster children and social workers; and (v) children who experienced poor-quality visits and perceived less warmth and more criticism/rejection from their parents. These results highlight the need to improve contact visits by developing intervention strategies targeted at all those involved.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Contact+visits+between+foster+children+and+their+birth+family%3A+the+views+of+foster+children%2C+foster+parents+and+social+workers&amp;rft.au=Salas+Martinez%2C+Mar%C3%ADa+D%3BFuentes%2C+Mar%C3%ADa+J%3BBernedo%2C+Isabel+M%3BGarcia-Martin%2C+Miguel+A&amp;rft.aulast=Salas+Martinez&amp;rft.aufirst=Mar%C3%ADa&amp;rft.date=2016-11-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=473&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12163
